======== 361 : Sebastian2017a

@title:    Temporal correlation detection using computational phase-change memory
@keywords: Folder - Computers - Hardware
@author:   Sebastian, Abu and Tuma, Tomas and Papandreou, Nikolaos and {Le Gallo}, Manuel and Kull, Lukas and Parnell, Thomas and Eleftheriou, Evangelos
@doi:      10.1038/s41467-017-01481-9
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1706.00511 http://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-017-01481-9
@abstract:
 For decades, conventional computers based on the von Neumann architecture have performed computation by repeatedly transferring data between their processing and their memory units, which are physically separated. As computation becomes increasingly data-centric and as the scalability limits in terms of performance and power are being reached, alternative computing paradigms are searched for in which computation and storage are collocated. A fascinating new approach is that of computational memory where the physics of nanoscale memory devices are used to perform certain computational tasks within the memory unit in a non-von Neumann manner. Here we present a large-scale experimental demonstration using one million phase-change memory devices organized to perform a high-level computational primitive by exploiting the crystallization dynamics. Also presented is an application of such a computational memory to process real-world data-sets. The results show that this co-existence of computation and storage at the nanometer scale could be the enabler for new, ultra-dense, low power, and massively parallel computing systems.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Computer Science
- **Subcategory:** Hardware, Computing Systems
- **Specific Domain:** Non-Von Neumann Architectures, Computational Memory, Phase-Change Memory (PCM), Neuromorphic Computing
- **Research Type:** Experimental Demonstration of a New Computing Paradigm

**10 Keywords:**

1. Temporal correlation detection using computational phase-change memory
2. Large-scale experimental demonstration with one million PCM devices
3. High-level computational primitive for data processing and storage
4. Crystallization dynamics in PCM devices for computation
5. Collocated computation and storage at the nanometer scale
6. Ultra-dense, low power, and massively parallel computing systems
7. Non-von Neumann computing architecture using PCM devices
8. Neuromorphic computing paradigm with PCM-based neural networks
9. Real-world data-set processing using PCM-based computational memory
10. Scalability and performance benefits of PCM-based computational memory.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on demonstrating a new computing paradigm based on phase-change memory (PCM) that combines computation and storage at the nanometer scale, enabling ultra-dense, low power, and massively parallel computing systems.

======== 362 : Tian2016

@title:    Lattice engineering through nanoparticle–DNA frameworks
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Engeneering - DNA{\_}origami,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Stochastic Nanomachines - D
@author:   Tian, Ye and Zhang, Yugang and Wang, Tong and Xin, Huolin L. and Li, Huilin and Gang, Oleg
@doi:      10.1038/nmat4571
@url:      http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nmat4571
@abstract:
 Advances in self-assembly over the past decade have demonstrated that nano- and microscale particles can be organized into a large diversity of ordered three-dimensional (3D) lattices. However, the ability to generate different desired lattice types from the same set of particles remains challenging. Here, we show that nanoparticles can be assembled into crystalline and open 3D frameworks by connecting them through designed DNA-based polyhedral frames. The geometrical shapes of the frames, combined with the DNA-assisted binding properties of their vertices, facilitate the well-defined topological connections between particles in accordance with frame geometry. With this strategy, different crystallographic lattices using the same particles can be assembled by introduction of the corresponding DNA polyhedral frames. This approach should facilitate the rational assembly of nanoscale lattices through the design of the unit cell.

======== 365 : Hoyta

@title:    Dr. Rob Hoyt
@author:   Hoyt, Rob
======== 366 : Liljeroth2007

@title:    Current-Induced Hydrogen Tautomerization and Conductance Switching of Naphthalocyanine Molecules
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Electronics - SPM control,Folder - Molecular Engeneering - Molecular switche,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021
@author:   Liljeroth, Peter and Repp, Jascha and Meyer, Gerhard
@doi:      10.1126/science.1144366
@url:      https://www.sciencemag.org/lookup/doi/10.1126/science.1144366 https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.1144366 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17761878
@abstract:
 The bistability in the position of the two hydrogen atoms in the inner cavity of single free-base naphthalocyanine molecules constitutes a two-level system that was manipulated and probed by low-temperature scanning tunneling microscopy. When adsorbed on an ultrathin insulating film, the molecules can be switched in a controlled fashion between the two states by excitation induced by the inelastic tunneling current. The tautomerization reaction can be probed by resonant tunneling through the molecule and is expressed as considerable changes in the conductivity of the molecule. We also demonstrated a coupling of the switching process so that the charge injection in one molecule induced tautomerization in an adjacent molecule.

======== 369 : Goedecker2004

@title:    Minima hopping: An efficient search method for the global minimum of the potential energy surface of complex molecular systems
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - GlobalOptimizatio
@author:   Goedecker, Stefan
@doi:      10.1063/1.1724816
@url:      http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/jcp/120/21/10.1063/1.1724816 http://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.1724816
@abstract:
 A method is presented that can find the global minimum of very complex condensed matter systems. It is based on the simple principle of exploring the configurational space as fast as possible and of avoiding revisiting known parts of this space. Even though it is not a genetic algorithm, it is not based on thermodynamics. The efficiency of the method depends strongly on the type of moves that are used to hop into new local minima. Moves that find low-barrier escape-paths out of the present minimum generally lead into low energy minima.

**Classification:**

8. Simple and fast method for exploring PES of complex systems
9. Applications in condensed matter physics and chemistry
10. Comparison with other global optimization methods, such as genetic algorithms.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on developing an efficient search method called minima hopping for finding the global minimum of the potential energy surface (PES) of complex molecular systems.

======== 372 : Baier2012

@title:    Toward quantitative Kelvin probe force microscopy of nanoscale potential distributions
@keywords: Folder - SPM - KPFM
@author:   Baier, Robert and Leendertz, Caspar and Lux-Steiner, Martha Ch. and Sadewasser, Sascha
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.85.165436
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.85.165436
@abstract:
 Kelvin probe force spectroscopy (KPFS) and ﬁnite-element method (FEM) simulations were employed to investigate the averaging effect of the work function signals of nanoscale potential distributions in Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM). A KPFS routine is presented that enables meaningful experimental results even for electronically inhomogeneous KPFM tips. By use of this routine a strong distance dependence of the averaging effect is revealed. A combination of KPFS experiments and FEM simulations is applied to quantify the averaging effect, which simpliﬁes comparison among different experiments and to theory. No inﬂuence of surface topography on the averaging effect was observed.

======== 375 : Bouchaud2000

@title:    Theory of financial risks: from statistical physics to risk management
@keywords: Economy,Folder - Humanities - Economy
@author:   Bouchaud, JP and Potters, Marc;
@url:      http://www.lavoisier.fr/livre/notice.asp?ouvrage=1439970
======== 376 : Jaculbia2020

@title:    Single-molecule resonance Raman effect in a plasmonic nanocavity
@author:   Jaculbia, Rafael B. and Imada, Hiroshi and Miwa, Kuniyuki and Iwasa, Takeshi and Takenaka, Masato and Yang, Bo and Kazuma, Emiko and Hayazawa, Norihiko and Taketsugu, Tetsuya and Kim, Yousoo
@doi:      10.1038/s41565-019-0614-8
@url:      http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/s41565-019-0614-8 http://www.nature.com/articles/s41565-019-0614-8
@abstract:
 Tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (TERS) is a versatile tool for chemical analysis at the nanoscale. In earlier TERS experiments, Raman modes with components parallel to the tip were studied based on the strong electric field enhancement along the tip. Perpendicular modes were usually neglected. Here, we investigate an isolated copper naphthalocyanine molecule adsorbed on a triple-layer NaCl on Ag(111) using scanning tunnelling microscope TERS imaging. For flat-lying molecules on NaCl, the Raman images present different patterns depending on the symmetry of the vibrational mode. Our results reveal that components of the electric field perpendicular to the tip should be considered aside from the parallel components. Moreover, under resonance excitation conditions, the perpendicular components can play a substantial role in the enhancement. This single-molecule study in a well-defined environment provides insights into the Raman process at the plasmonic nanocavity, which may be useful in the nanoscale metrology of various molecular systems.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics or Chemistry

======== 377 : Ensing2006

@title:    Metadynamics as a tool for exploring free energy landscapes of chemical reactions.
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods - Global{\_}Opt{\_}and{\_}Sad,Folder - Numerics - Optimalization - GlobalOptimiz,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - GlobalOptimizatio,metadynamics
@author:   Ensing, Bernd and {De Vivo}, Marco and Liu, Zhiwei and Moore, Preston and Klein, Michael L
@doi:      10.1021/ar040198i
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16489726
@abstract:
 The metadynamics or hills method is a relatively new molecular dynamics technique aimed to enhance the sampling of separated regions in phase space and map out the underlying free energy landscape as a function of a small number of order parameters or collective variables. The high efficiency allows for the application of metadynamics in combination with first principles dynamics methods, in particular with Car-Parrinello molecular dynamics, to study processes in which changes in the electronic structure play a dominant role, such as chemical reactions. The option to choose several independent collective variables is important to tackle complex and concerted transformations that lack an obvious a priori choice for a single reaction coordinate. In this Account, we discuss the role of metadynamics in the search of transition states, local minima, reaction paths, free energy profiles, and reaction coordinates among a growing list of alternative methods.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry or Physics
- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry, Materials Science
- **Specific Domain:** Metadynamics Method, Free Energy Landscapes, Chemical Reactions, Phase Space Sampling
- **Research Type:** Review Article with a Focus on Discussing the Role of Metadynamics in Exploring Free Energy Landscapes

**10 Keywords:**

1. Metadynamics as a tool for exploring free energy landscapes of chemical reactions
2. Molecular dynamics technique for enhancing phase space sampling
3. Mapping out free energy landscape using collective variables or order parameters
4. Application of metadynamics with first principles dynamics methods, such as Car-Parrinello molecular dynamics
5. Studying chemical reactions where changes in electronic structure play a dominant role
6. Choosing multiple independent collective variables to tackle complex transformations
7. Search for transition states, local minima, reaction paths, and free energy profiles using metadynamics
8. Comparison with alternative methods for exploring free energy landscapes
9. Importance of metadynamics in understanding chemical reactions and catalytic processes
10. Future directions and applications of the metadynamics method.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on discussing the role of metadynamics as a tool for exploring free energy landscapes of chemical reactions and its applications in understanding complex transformations and chemical reactions.

======== 378 : LasHeras2016

@title:    Genetic Algorithms for Digital Quantum Simulations
@keywords: Folder - Computers - QuantumComputing
@author:   {Las Heras}, U. and Alvarez-Rodriguez, U. and Solano, E. and Sanz, M.
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevLett.116.230504
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1512.00674 http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.116.230504
@abstract:
 We propose genetic algorithms, which are robust optimization techniques inspired by natural selection, to enhance the versatility of digital quantum simulations. In this sense, we show that genetic algorithms can be employed to increase the fidelity and optimize the resource requirements of digital quantum simulation protocols, while adapting naturally to the experimental constraints. Furthermore, this method allows us to reduce not only digital errors, but also experimental errors in quantum gates. Indeed, by adding ancillary qubits, we design a modular gate made out of imperfect gates, whose fidelity is larger than the fidelity of any of the constituent gates. Finally, we prove that the proposed modular gates are resilient against different gate errors.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Computer Science or Physics
- **Subcategory:** Quantum Computing
- **Specific Domain:** Digital Quantum Simulations, Genetic Algorithms, Quantum Error Correction, Quantum Gates
- **Research Type:** Methodological Development with a Focus on Enhancing the Versatility of Digital Quantum Simulations

**10 Keywords:**

1. Genetic algorithms for digital quantum simulations

3. Increasing fidelity and optimizing resource requirements of digital quantum simulation protocols
4. Adapting to experimental constraints using genetic algorithms
5. Reducing digital errors and experimental errors in quantum gates
6. Designing modular gates made out of imperfect gates with improved fidelity
7. Using ancillary qubits to enhance gate fidelity
8. Proving resilience against different gate errors for proposed modular gates
9. Enhancing the versatility of digital quantum simulations using genetic algorithms
10. Applications of genetic algorithms in quantum computing and quantum information processing.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on developing and applying genetic algorithms to enhance the versatility of digital quantum simulations by increasing fidelity, optimizing resource requirements, and reducing errors.

======== 379 : Ogawara2011a

@title:    Detecting frequent patterns in video using partly locality sensitive hashing
@author:   Ogawara, Koichi and Tanabe, Yasufumi and Kurazume, Ryo and Hasegawa, Tsutomu
@doi:      10.1007/978-3-642-22822-3_29
======== 380 : Tomita2003a

@title:    High-temperature superconductor bulk magnets that can trap magnetic fields of over 17 tesla at 29 K.
@keywords: Folder - Superconductors - HTS{\_}magnets,HTS,magnet,superconductors
@author:   Tomita, Masaru and Murakami, Masato
@doi:      10.1038/nature01350
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12556888
@abstract:
 Large-grain high-temperature superconductors of the form RE-Ba-Cu-O (where RE is a rare-earth element) can trap magnetic fields of several tesla at low temperatures, and so can be used for permanent magnet applications. The magnitude of the trapped field is proportional to the critical current density and the volume of the superconductor. Various potential engineering applications for such magnets have emerged, and some have already been commercialized. However, the range of applications is limited by poor mechanical stability and low thermal conductivity of the bulk superconductors; RE-Ba-Cu-O magnets have been found to fracture during high-field activation, owing to magnetic pressure. Here we present a post-fabrication treatment that improves the mechanical properties as well as thermal conductivity of a bulk Y-Ba-Cu-O magnet, thereby increasing its field-trapping capacity. First, resin impregnation and wrapping the materials in carbon fibre improves the mechanical properties. Second, a small hole drilled into the centre of the magnet allows impregnation of Bi-Pb-Sn-Cd alloy into the superconductor and inclusion of an aluminium wire support, which results in a significant enhancement of thermal stability and internal mechanical strength. As a result, 17.24 T could be trapped, without fracturing, in a bulk Y-Ba-Cu-O sample of 2.65 cm diameter at 29 K.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Materials Science or Physics
- **Subcategory:** Superconductivity, Magnetism
- **Specific Domain:** High-Temperature Superconductors (HTS), Bulk Magnets, Magnetic Field Trapping, Mechanical Properties of Superconductors
- **Research Type:** Experimental Study with a Focus on Improving the Performance of HTS Bulk Magnets

**10 Keywords:**

1. High-temperature superconductor bulk magnets that can trap magnetic fields over 17 tesla at 29 K
2. Large-grain RE-Ba-Cu-O (RE = rare-earth element) high-temperature superconductors
3. Magnetic field trapping capacity proportional to critical current density and volume of superconductor
4. Post-fabrication treatment to improve mechanical properties and thermal conductivity of HTS bulk magnets
5. Resin impregnation and carbon fibre wrapping for improved mechanical stability
6. Drilling a hole into the centre of the magnet for enhanced thermal stability and internal strength
7. Impregnating Bi-Pb-Sn-Cd alloy and aluminium wire support to improve mechanical properties
8. Trapping 17.24 T magnetic field in a bulk Y-Ba-Cu-O sample at 29 K without fracturing
9. Improving the performance of HTS bulk magnets for various applications, including permanent magnets
10. Enhancing thermal conductivity and internal mechanical strength of HTS bulk magnets.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on developing and improving the performance of high-temperature superconductor bulk magnets that can trap strong magnetic fields by enhancing their mechanical properties and thermal stability.

======== 384 : Dey2021

@title:    DNA origami
@author:   Dey, Swarup and Fan, Chunhai and Gothelf, Kurt V. and Li, Jiang and Lin, Chenxiang and Liu, Longfei and Liu, Na and Nijenhuis, Minke A. D. and Sacc{\`{a}}, Barbara and Simmel, Friedrich C. and Yan, Hao and Zhan, Pengfei
@doi:      10.1038/s43586-020-00009-8
@url:      https://www.nature.com/articles/s43586-020-00009-8
@abstract:
 Biological materials are self-assembled with near-atomic precision in living cells, whereas synthetic 3D structures generally lack such precision and controllability. Recently, DNA nanotechnology, especially DNA origami technology, has been useful in the bottom-up fabrication of well-defined nanostructures ranging from tens of nanometres to sub-micrometres. In this Primer, we summarize the methodologies of DNA origami technology, including origami design, synthesis, functionalization and characterization. We highlight applications of origami structures in nanofabrication, nanophotonics and nanoelectronics, catalysis, computation, molecular machines, bioimaging, drug delivery and biophysics. We identify challenges for the field, including size limits, stability issues and the scale of production, and discuss their possible solutions. We further provide an outlook on next-generation DNA origami techniques that will allow in vivo synthesis and multiscale manufacturing.

======== 386 : Shulaker2013a

@title:    Carbon nanotube computer
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Electronics,Folder - carbon graphene
@author:   Shulaker, Max M. and Hills, Gage and Patil, Nishant and Wei, Hai and Chen, Hong-Yu and Wong, H.-S. Philip and Mitra, Subhasish
@doi:      10.1038/nature12502
@url:      http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nature12502
======== 387 : Grill2007a

@title:    Nano-architectures by covalent assembly of molecular building blocks
@keywords: Chemistry,Chemistry: methods,Crystallization,Crystallization: methods,Folder - Molecular Engeneering - Molecular network,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021,Gold,Gold: chemistry,Macromolecular Substances,Macromolecular Substances: chemistry,Materials Testing,Molecular Conformation,Nanostructures,Nanostructures: chemistry,Nanostructures: ultrastructure,Nanotechnology,Nanotechnology: methods,Particle Size,Porphyrins,Porphyrins: chemistry,Surface Properties
@author:   Grill, Leonhard and Dyer, Matthew and Lafferentz, Leif and Persson, Mats and Peters, Maike V and Hecht, Stefan
@doi:      10.1038/nnano.2007.346
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18654406 http://www.nature.com/articles/nnano.2007.346
@abstract:
 The construction of electronic devices from single molecular building blocks, which possess certain functions such as switching or rectifying and are connected by atomic-scale wires on a supporting surface, is an essential goal of molecular electronics. A key challenge is the controlled assembly of molecules into desired architectures by strong, that is, covalent, intermolecular connections, enabling efficient electron transport between the molecules and providing high stability. However, no molecular networks on surfaces 'locked' by covalent interactions have been reported so far. Here, we show that such covalently bound molecular nanostructures can be formed on a gold surface upon thermal activation of porphyrin building blocks and their subsequent chemical reaction at predefined connection points. We demonstrate that the topology of these nanostructures can be precisely engineered by controlling the chemical structure of the building blocks. Our results represent a versatile route for future bottom-up construction of sophisticated electronic circuits and devices, based on individual functionalized molecules.

@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM - TLS{\_}H2,Folder - HR-SPM - inelastic

@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.61.16921
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.61.16921
======== 389 : Dasog2013

@title:    Chemical insight into the origin of red and blue photoluminescence arising from freestanding silicon nanocrystals.
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs,commonly re-,dots,ductor nanoparticles,ferred to as quantum,he wide-ranging impact of,is well-,nitrogen,photoluminescence,semicon-,silicon nanocrystals,surface functionalization
@author:   Dasog, Mita and Yang, Zhenyu and Regli, Sarah and Atkins, Tonya M and Faramus, Angelique and Singh, Mani P and Muthuswamy, Elayaraja and Kauzlarich, Susan M and Tilley, Richard D and Veinot, Jonathan G C
@doi:      10.1021/nn4000644
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23394574
@abstract:
 Silicon nanocrystals (Si NCs) are attractive functional materials. They are compatible with standard electronics and communications platforms and are biocompatible. Numerous methods have been developed to realize size-controlled Si NC synthesis. While these procedures produce Si NCs that appear identical, their optical responses can differ dramatically. Si NCs prepared using high-temperature methods routinely exhibit photoluminescence agreeing with the effective mass approximation (EMA), while those prepared via solution methods exhibit blue emission that is somewhat independent of particle size. Despite many proposals, a definitive explanation for this difference has been elusive for no less than a decade. This apparent dichotomy brings into question our understanding of Si NC properties and potentially limits the scope of their application. The present contribution takes a substantial step forward toward identifying the origin of the blue emission that is not expected based upon EMA predictions. It describes a detailed comparison of Si NCs obtained from three of the most widely cited procedures as well as the conversion of red-emitting Si NCs to blue emitters upon exposure to nitrogen-containing reagents. Analysis of the evidence is consistent with the hypothesis that the presence of trace nitrogen and oxygen even at the parts per million level in Si NCs gives rise to the blue emission.

**Classification:**

- **Research Type:** Experimental Study with a Focus on Investigating the Origin of Blue and Red Photoluminescence in Si NCs

**10 Keywords:**

1. Chemical insight into the origin of red and blue photoluminescence in freestanding silicon nanocrystals

3. Size-controlled synthesis methods for Si NCs using high-temperature and solution-based procedures
4. Photoluminescence responses of Si NCs prepared via different methods, including blue emission independent of particle size
5. Definitive explanation for the difference in optical responses between high-temperature and solution-prepared Si NCs
6. Role of nitrogen and oxygen impurities in Si NCs on the origin of blue photoluminescence
7. Conversion of red-emitting Si NCs to blue emitters upon exposure to nitrogen-containing reagents
8. Analysis of evidence supporting the hypothesis that trace levels of nitrogen and oxygen cause blue emission in Si NCs
9. Implications for our understanding of Si NC properties and potential limitations on their applications
10. Future directions for research in Si NC synthesis, surface functionalization, and optical properties.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on investigating the origin of blue and red photoluminescence in silicon nanocrystals using various synthesis methods, with a particular emphasis on understanding the role of impurities and nitrogen-containing reagents.

======== 393 : Schuler2013

@title:    Adsorption geometry determination of single molecules by atomic force microscopy
@keywords: Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - Berlin{\_}MSMJ{\_}2013
@author:   Schuler, Bruno and Liu, Wei and Tkatchenko, Alexandre and Moll, Nikolaj and Meyer, Gerhard and Mistry, Anish and Fox, David and Gross, Leo
======== 394 : Simova2013

@title:    Convergence of the Interaction Energies in Noncovalent Complexes in the Coupled-Cluster Methods Up to Full Configuration Interaction
@author:   {\v{S}}imov{\'{a}}, Lucia and Řez{\'{a}}{\v{c}}, Jan and Hobza, Pavel
@doi:      10.1021/ct4002762
@url:      https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/ct4002762
@abstract:
 The CCSD(T) method stands out among various coupled-cluster (CC) approximations as the "golden standard" in computational chemistry and is widely and successfully used in the realm of covalent and noncovalent interactions. The CCSD(T) method provides reliable interaction energies, but their surprising accuracy is believed to arise partially from an error compensation. The convergence of the CC expansion has been investigated up to fully iterative pentuple excitations (CCSDTQP); for the smallest eight electron complexes, the full CI calculations have also been performed. We conclude that the convergence of interaction energy at noncovalent accuracy (0.01 kcal/mol) for the complexes studied is reached already at CCSDTQ or CCSDT(Q) levels. When even higher accuracy (spectroscopic accuracy of 1 cm-1, or 3 cal/mol) is required, then the noniterative CCSDTQ(P) method could be used. {\textcopyright} 2013 American Chemical Society.

**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Research Type:** Theoretical Study with a Focus on Investigating the Convergence of Interaction Energies in Coupled-Cluster Methods

1. Convergence analysis of coupled-cluster methods for noncovalent complexes

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on investigating the convergence of interaction energies in coupled-cluster methods using various approximations, with an emphasis on noncovalent complexes and accuracy criteria.

@author:   Iacona, F. and Pacifici, D. and Irrera, a. and Miritello, M. and Franzò, G. and Priolo, F. and Sanfilippo, D. and {Di Stefano}, G. and Fallica, P. G.
@doi:      10.1063/1.1516235
@url:      http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/apl/81/17/10.1063/1.1516235
======== 398 : Jeon2013

@title:    Facile, scalable synthesis of edge-halogenated graphene nanoplatelets as efficient metal-free eletrocatalysts for oxygen reduction reaction.
@keywords: Folder - carbon graphene - Catalyst
@author:   Jeon, In-Yup and Choi, Hyun-Jung and Choi, Min and Seo, Jeong-Min and Jung, Sun-Min and Kim, Min-Jung and Zhang, Sheng and Zhang, Lipeng and Xia, Zhenhai and Dai, Liming and Park, Noejung and Baek, Jong-Beom
@doi:      10.1038/srep01810
@url:      http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=3672906{\&}tool=pmcentrez{\&}rendertype=abstract
@abstract:
 A series of edge-selectively halogenated (X = Cl, Br, I) graphene nanoplatelets (XGnPs = ClGnP, BrGnP, IGnP) were prepared simply by ball-milling graphite in the presence of Cl2, Br2 and I2, respectively. High BET surface areas of 471, 579 and 662 m(2)/g were observed for ClGnP, BrGnP and IGnP, respectively, indicating a significant extent of delamination during the ball-milling and subsequent workup processes. The newly-developed XGnPs can be well dispersed in various solvents, and hence are solution processable. Furthermore, XGnPs showed remarkable electrocatalytic activities toward oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) with a high selectivity, good tolerance to methanol crossover/CO poisoning effects, and excellent long-term cycle stability. First-principle density-functional calculations revealed that halogenated graphene edges could provide decent adsorption sites for oxygen molecules, in a good agreement with the experimental observations.

- **Specific Domain:** Graphene-based nanomaterials, Edge-halogenation, Electrochemistry
- **Research Type:** Experimental Study with a Focus on Developing Efficient Metal-Free Electrocatalysts for Oxygen Reduction Reaction

**10 Keywords:**

======== 399 : Hase2016

@title:    Machine learning exciton dynamics
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods - Global{\_}Opt{\_}and{\_}Sad
@author:   H{\"{a}}se, Florian and Valleau, St{\'{e}}phanie and Pyzer-Knapp, Edward and Aspuru-Guzik, Al{\'{a}}n
@doi:      10.1039/C5SC04786B
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1511.07883{\%}5Cnhttp://xlink.rsc.org/?DOI=C5SC04786B{\%}5Cnhttp://xlink.rsc.org/?DOI=C5SC04786B
@abstract:
 Obtaining the exciton dynamics of large photosynthetic complexes by using mixed quantum mechanics/molecular mechanics (QM/MM) is computationally demanding. We propose a machine learning technique, multi-layer perceptrons, as a tool to reduce the time required to compute excited state energies. With this approach we predict time-dependent density functional theory (TDDFT) excited state energies of bacteriochlorophylls in the Fenna-Matthews-Olson (FMO) complex. Additionally we compute spectral densities and exciton populations from the predictions. Different methods to determine multi-layer perceptron training sets are introduced, leading to several initial data selections. In addition, we compute spectral densities and exciton populations. Once multi-layer perceptrons are trained, predicting excited state energies was found to be significantly faster than the corresponding QM/MM calculations. We showed that multi-layer perceptrons can successfully reproduce the energies of QM/MM calculations to a high degree of accuracy with prediction errors contained within 0.01 eV (0.5{\%}). Spectral densities and exciton dynamics are also in agreement with the TDDFT results. The acceleration and accurate prediction of dynamics strongly encourage the combination of machine learning techniques with ab-initio methods.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry or Physics
- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry, Quantum Mechanics
- **Specific Domain:** Exciton Dynamics, Machine Learning, Multi-Layer Perceptrons (MLPs), Time-Dependent Density Functional Theory (TDDFT)
- **Research Type:** Theoretical Study with a Focus on Developing Machine Learning Techniques for Predicting Exciton Dynamics

**10 Keywords:**

1. Machine learning exciton dynamics using multi-layer perceptrons
2. Application of MLPs to predict excited state energies in photosynthetic complexes
3. Reduction of computational time required for QM/MM calculations using machine learning
4. Prediction of spectral densities and exciton populations from TDDFT results
5. Comparison of machine learning predictions with ab-initio methods (QM/MM)
6. Development of a new method to determine MLP training sets for photochemical applications
7. Accurate reproduction of excited state energies with prediction errors < 0.01 eV (0.5%)
8. Agreement between machine learning predictions and TDDFT results for spectral densities and exciton dynamics
9. Combination of machine learning techniques with ab-initio methods for predicting dynamics in complex systems
10. Potential applications of machine learning in photosynthetic research, materials science, and chemical physics.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on developing machine learning techniques to predict exciton dynamics in photosynthetic complexes using multi-layer perceptrons, with a focus on reducing computational time and improving accuracy.

======== 400 : Handley2014

@title:    Next generation interatomic potentials for condensed systems
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods - Neural{\_}Networks
@author:   Handley, Christopher Michael and Behler, J{\"{o}}rg
@doi:      10.1140/epjb/e2014-50070-0
@url:      http://link.springer.com/10.1140/epjb/e2014-50070-0
@abstract:
 The computer simulation of condensed systems is a challenging task. While electronic structure methods like density-functional theory (DFT) usually provide a good compromise between accuracy and eﬃciency, they are computationally very demanding and thus applicable only to systems containing up to a few hundred atoms. Unfortunately, many interesting problems require simulations to be performed on much larger systems involving thousands of atoms or more. Consequently, more eﬃcient methods are urgently needed, and a lot of eﬀort has been spent on the development of a large variety of potentials enabling simulations with signiﬁcantly extended time and length scales. Most commonly, these potentials are based on physically motivated functional forms and thus perform very well for the applications they have been designed for. On the other hand, they are often highly system-speciﬁc and thus cannot easily be transferred from one system to another. Moreover, their numerical accuracy is restricted by the intrinsic limitations of the imposed functional forms. In recent years, several novel types of potentials have emerged, which are not based on physical considerations. Instead, they aim to reproduce a set of reference electronic structure data as accurately as possible by using very general and ﬂexible functional forms. In this review we will survey a number of these methods. While they diﬀer in the choice of the employed mathematical functions, they all have in common that they provide high-quality potential-energy surfaces, while the eﬃciency is comparable to conventional empirical potentials. It has been demonstrated that in many cases these potentials now oﬀer a very interesting new approach to study complex systems with hitherto unreached accuracy.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics or Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Computational Physics/Chemistry, Materials Science
- **Specific Domain:** Interatomic Potentials, Condensed Systems, Neural Networks, Machine Learning
- **Research Type:** Review Article with a Focus on Surveying Next-Generation Methods for Modeling Complex Systems

**10 Keywords:**

1. Next-generation interatomic potentials for condensed systems
2. Development of novel methods for modeling complex systems
3. Use of neural networks and machine learning in computational physics/chemistry
4. Survey of recent advances in interatomic potential development
5. Comparison of conventional empirical potentials with new, more accurate methods
6. High-quality potential-energy surfaces achieved through flexible functional forms
7. Improved efficiency and accuracy for simulating complex systems
8. Potential applications in materials science, condensed matter physics, and chemistry
9. Development of transferable interatomic potentials for different systems
10. Opportunities and challenges in using machine learning to improve interatomic potential development.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on surveying recent advances in developing next-generation interatomic potentials for modeling complex condensed systems using neural networks and machine learning.

======== 401 : Wu2012a

@title:    Semiempirical Quantum Chemical Calculations Accelerated on a Hybrid Multicore CPU–GPU Computing Platform
@author:   Wu, Xin and Koslowski, Axel and Thiel, Walter
@doi:      10.1021/ct3001798
@url:      https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/ct3001798
@abstract:
 In this work, we demonstrate that semiempirical quantum chemical calculations can be accelerated significantly by leveraging the graphics processing unit (GPU) as a coprocessor on a hybrid multicore CPU-GPU computing platform. Semiempirical calculations using the MNDO, AM1, PM3, OM1, OM2, and OM3 model Hamiltonians were systematically profiled for three types of test systems (fullerenes, water clusters, and solvated crambin) to identify the most time-consuming sections of the code. The corresponding routines were ported to the GPU and optimized employing both existing library functions and a GPU kernel that carries out a sequence of noniterative Jacobi transformations during pseudodiagonalization. The overall computation times for single-point energy calculations and geometry optimizations of large molecules were reduced by one order of magnitude for all methods, as compared to runs on a single CPU core. {\textcopyright} 2012 American Chemical Society.

======== 403 : Raynal2014

@title:    Supramolecular catalysis. Part 2: artificial enzyme mimics
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Engeneering - artificial{\_}enzyme
@author:   Raynal, Matthieu and Ballester, Pablo and Vidal-Ferran, Anton and van Leeuwen, Piet W N M
@doi:      10.1039/C3CS60037H
@url:      http://dx.doi.org/10.1039/C3CS60037H http://xlink.rsc.org/?DOI=C3CS60037H
@abstract:
 The design of artificial catalysts able to compete with the catalytic proficiency of enzymes is an intense subject of research. Non-covalent interactions are thought to be involved in several properties of enzymatic catalysis, notably (i) the confinement of the substrates and the active site within a catalytic pocket, (ii) the creation of a hydrophobic pocket in water, (iii) self-replication properties and (iv) allosteric properties. The origins of the enhanced rates and high catalytic selectivities associated with these properties are still a matter of debate. Stabilisation of the transition state and favourable conformations of the active site and the product(s) are probably part of the answer. We present here artificial catalysts and biomacromolecule hybrid catalysts which constitute good models towards the development of truly competitive artificial enzymes.

======== 405 : Abel2013

@title:    Hydrated Interfacial Ions and Electrons
@keywords: Air,Air: analysis,Electrons,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - NNFF{\_}H2O{\_}NaCl - motivation,Hydrophobic and Hydrophilic Interactions,Hydroxides,Hydroxides: chemistry,Models,Molecular,Onium Compounds,Onium Compounds: chemistry,Surface Properties,Water,Water: chemistry

@doi:      10.1146/annurev-physchem-040412-110038
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23561010{\%}5Cnhttp://www.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev-physchem-040412-110038 http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/10.1146/annurev-physchem-040412-110038
@abstract:
 Charged particles such as hydrated ions and transient hydrated electrons, the simplest anionic reducing agents in water, and the special hydronium and hydroxide ions at water interfaces play an important role in many fields of science, such as atmospheric chemistry, radiation chemistry, and biology, as well as biochemistry. This article focuses on these species near hydrophobic interfaces of water, such as the air or vacuum interface of water or water protein/membrane interfaces. Ions at interfaces as well as solvated electrons have been reviewed frequently during the past decade. Although all species have been known for some time with seemingly familiar features, recently the picture in all cases became increasingly diffuse rather than clearer. The current account gives a critical state-of-the art overview of what is known and what remains to be understood and investigated about hydrated interfacial ions and electrons.

======== 408 : Glover1989

@title:    Tabu Search—Part I
@keywords: Combinatorial Problems,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - GlobalOptimizatio,Integer Programming,TS,Tabu Search
@author:   Glover, Fred
@doi:      10.1287/ijoc.1.3.190
@url:      http://pubsonline.informs.org/doi/abs/10.1287/ijoc.1.3.190
@abstract:
 This paper presents the fundamental principles underlying tabu search as a strategy for combinatorial optimization problems. Tabu search has achieved impressive practical successes in applications ranging from scheduling and computer channel balancing to cluster analysis and space planning, and more recently has demonstrated its value in treating classical problems such as the traveling salesman and graph coloring problems. Nevertheless, the approach is still in its infancy, and a good deal remains to be discovered about its most effective forms of implementation and about the range of problems for which it is best suited. This paper undertakes to present the major ideas and findings to date, and to indicate challenges for future research. Part I of this study indicates the basic principles, ranging from the short-term memory process at the core of the search to the intermediate and long term memory processes for intensifying and diversifying the search. Included are illustrative data structures for implementing the tabu conditions (and associated aspiration criteria) that underlie these processes. Part I concludes with a discussion of probabilistic tabu search and a summary of computational experience for a variety of applications. Part II of this study (to appear in a subsequent issue) examines more advanced considerations, applying the basic ideas to special settings and outlining a dynamic move structure to insure finiteness. Part II also describes tabu search methods for solving mixed integer programming problems and gives a brief summary of additional practical experience, including the use of tabu search to guide other types of processes, such as those of neural networks.

@title:    “Majority Representation” of Alloy Electronic States
@keywords: Folder - Theory
@author:   Wang, L.-W. and Bellaiche, L. and Wei, S.-H. and Zunger, a.
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevLett.80.4725
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.80.4725
======== 411 : Ferradas2013

@title:    Symmetry-induced quantum interference effects in metalloporphyrin wires
@keywords: Folder - ElectronTransport,Folder - Molecular Electronics
@author:   Ferrad{\'{a}}s, R and Garc{\'{i}}a-Su{\'{a}}rez, V M and Ferrer, J
@doi:      10.1088/0953-8984/25/32/325501
@url:      http://stacks.iop.org/0953-8984/25/i=32/a=325501 http://stacks.iop.org/0953-8984/25/i=32/a=325501?key=crossref.cca61d9139823fa9d3868a5137915e9f
@abstract:
 We calculate the electronic and transport properties of a series of metalloporphyrin molecules sandwiched between gold electrodes using a combination of density functional theory and scattering theory. The impact of strong correlations at the central metallic atom is gauged by comparing our results obtained using conventional DFT andDFT + U approaches. The zero- and finite-bias transport properties may or may not show spin-filtering behavior, depending on the nature of the d state closest to the Fermi energy. The type of d state depends on the metallic atom and gives rise to interference effects that produce different Fano features. The inclusion of the U term opens a gap between the d states and changes the conductance and spin-filtering behavior qualitatively in some of the molecules. We explain the origin of the quantum interference effects found as due to the symmetry-dependent coupling between the d states and other molecular orbitals and propose the use of these systems as nanoscale chemical sensors. We also demonstrate that an adequate treatment of strong correlations is really necessary to correctly describe the transport properties of metalloporphyrins and similar molecular magnets.

======== 412 : Goedecker2004a

@title:    Minima hopping: Searching for the global minimum of the potential energy surface of complex molecular systems without invoking thermodynamics
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - GlobalOptimizatio
@author:   Goedecker, Stefan
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/cond-mat/0402136
@abstract:
 A method is presented that can find the global minimum of very complex condensed matter systems. It is based on the simple principle of exploring the configurational space as fast as possible and of avoiding revisiting known parts of this space. Even though it is not a genetic algorithm, it is not based on thermodynamics. The efficiency of the method depends strongly on the type of moves that are used to hop into new local minima. Moves that find low-barrier escape-paths out of the present minimum lead generally into low energy minima.

**Classification:**

7. Development of a novel method for global optimization without invoking thermodynamics

9. Potential applications in materials science, nanotechnology, and drug discovery
10. Advantages of minima hopping over traditional optimization methods.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on introducing the minima hopping method as a novel approach for finding the global minimum of complex molecular systems without relying on thermodynamic principles.

======== 413 : Anisimov1997

@title:    First-principles calculations of the electronic structure and spectra of strongly correlated systems: the LDA+ U method
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods - beyond dft,Folder - ComputationalMethods - beyond dft - LDA+U
@author:   Anisimov, VI
@doi:      10.1088/0953-8984/9/4/002
@url:      http://iopscience.iop.org/0953-8984/9/4/002 http://stacks.iop.org/0953-8984/9/i=4/a=002?key=crossref.fb949d5eca1b7900b10858389e3ab0c7
======== 414 : Pascal2013a

@title:    Towards an evolutionary theory of the origin of life based on kinetics and thermodynamics.
@keywords: Biogenesis,Biological Evolution,Evolution,Folder - Information{\_}physics,Kinetics,Models,Molecular,Thermodynamics
@author:   Pascal, Robert and Pross, Addy and Sutherland, John D
@doi:      10.1098/rsob.130156
@url:      http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=3843823{\&}tool=pmcentrez{\&}rendertype=abstract
@abstract:
 A sudden transition in a system from an inanimate state to the living state-defined on the basis of present day living organisms-would constitute a highly unlikely event hardly predictable from physical laws. From this uncontroversial idea, a self-consistent representation of the origin of life process is built up, which is based on the possibility of a series of intermediate stages. This approach requires a particular kind of stability for these stages-dynamic kinetic stability (DKS)-which is not usually observed in regular chemistry, and which is reflected in the persistence of entities capable of self-reproduction. The necessary connection of this kinetic behaviour with far-from-equilibrium thermodynamic conditions is emphasized and this leads to an evolutionary view for the origin of life in which multiplying entities must be associated with the dissipation of free energy. Any kind of entity involved in this process has to pay the energetic cost of irreversibility, but, by doing so, the contingent emergence of new functions is made feasible. The consequences of these views on the studies of processes by which life can emerge are inferred.

**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Research Type:** Theoretical Framework Development for Understanding the Origin of Life

**10 Keywords:**

1. Towards an evolutionary theory of the origin of life based on kinetics and thermodynamics
2. Sudden transition from inanimate to living state requires intermediate stages
3. Dynamic kinetic stability (DKS) necessary for self-reproduction and persistence
4. Connection between DKS, far-from-equilibrium thermodynamic conditions, and free energy dissipation
5. Emergence of new functions through the energetic cost of irreversibility
6. Contingent nature of life's origin due to the need for dissipative processes
7. Implications for understanding chemical evolution and information flow in living systems
8. Relationship between entropy production and the emergence of complex biological structures
9. Theoretical framework for studying the origins of life in a self-consistent manner
10. Integration of kinetic, thermodynamic, and evolutionary principles to explain the origin of life.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on developing a comprehensive theoretical framework that integrates kinetics, thermodynamics, and evolutionary principles to understand the origin of life as an emergent process.

======== 415 : Arzt2003

@title:    Materials become insensitive to flaws at nanoscale :
@keywords: Folder - sctructural{\_}tech - MaterialScience,Folder - sctructural{\_}tech - MaterialScience - Biom
@author:   Arzt, Eduard and Fratzl, Peter and Gao, Huajian and Ji, Baohua and Ja, Ingomar L
======== 416 : Deshpande2012a

@title:    Self-Assembly and Photopolymerization of Sub-2 nm One-Dimensional Organic Nanostructures on Graphene
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Engeneering - Molecular{\_}Constru,Folder - Molecular Engeneering - Templated{\_}synthes,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021,★
@author:   Deshpande, Aparna and Sham, Chun-Hong and Alaboson, Justice M P and Mullin, Jonathan M. and Schatz, George C. and Hersam, Mark C.
@doi:      10.1021/ja307061e
@url:      http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/ja307061e http://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/ja307061e https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/ja307061e
@abstract:
 While graphene has attracted significant attention from the research community due to its high charge carrier mobility, important issues remain unresolved that prevent its widespread use in technologically significant applications such as digital electronics. For example, the chemical inertness of graphene hinders integration with other materials, and the lack of a bandgap implies poor switching characteristics in transistors. The formation of ordered organic monolayers on graphene has the potential to address each of these challenges. In particular, functional groups incorporated into the constituent molecules enable tailored chemical reactivity, while molecular-scale ordering within the monolayer provides sub-2 nm templates with the potential to tune the electronic band structure of graphene via quantum confinement effects. Toward these ends, we report here the formation of well-defined one-dimensional organic nanostructures on epitaxial graphene via the self-assembly of 10,12-pentacosadiynoic acid (PCDA) in ultrahigh vacuum (UHV). Molecular resolution UHV scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) images confirm the one-dimensional ordering of the as-deposited PCDA monolayer and show domain boundaries with symmetry consistent with the underlying graphene lattice. In an effort to further stabilize the monolayer, in situ ultraviolet photopolymerization induces covalent bonding between neighboring PCDA molecules in a manner that maintains one-dimensional ordering as verified by UHV STM and ambient atomic force microscopy (AFM). Further quantitative insights into these experimental observations are provided by semiempirical quantum chemistry calculations that compare the molecular structure before and after photopolymerization.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Materials Science, Nanotechnology
- **Specific Domain:** Organic Chemistry, Molecular Engineering, Graphene Research
- **Research Type:** Experimental Study with a Focus on Self-Assembly and Photopolymerization of One-Dimensional Nanostructures

======== 419 : Hofmann2008

@title:    Development of tough, low-density titanium-based bulk metallic glass matrix composites with tensile ductility.
@keywords: Folder - Materials,Glass,Glass: chemistry,Mechanics,Tensile Strength,Titanium
@author:   Hofmann, Douglas C and Suh, Jin-Yoo and Wiest, Aaron and Lind, Mary-Laura and Demetriou, Marios D and Johnson, William L
@doi:      10.1073/pnas.0809000106
@url:      http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=2629257{\&}tool=pmcentrez{\&}rendertype=abstract
@abstract:
 The mechanical properties of bulk metallic glasses (BMGs) and their composites have been under intense investigation for many years, owing to their unique combination of high strength and elastic limit. However, because of their highly localized deformation mechanism, BMGs are typically considered to be brittle materials and are not suitable for structural applications. Recently, highly-toughened BMG composites have been created in a Zr-Ti-based system with mechanical properties comparable with high-performance crystalline alloys. In this work, we present a series of low-density, Ti-based BMG composites with combinations of high strength, tensile ductility, and excellent fracture toughness.

======== 420 : Mohn2013

@title:    Different tips for high-resolution atomic force microscopy and scanning tunneling microscopy of single molecules
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM
@author:   Mohn, Fabian and Schuler, Bruno and Gross, Leo and Meyer, Gerhard

======== 421 : Fuentes-Azcatl2016

@title:    Sodium Chloride, NaCl/{\{}$\backslash$epsilon{\}} : New Force Field
@author:   Fuentes-Azcatl, Raul and Barbosa, Marcia C.
@doi:      10.1021/acs.jpcb.5b12584
@url:      http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acs.jpcb.5b12584 https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.jpcb.5b12584 http://arxiv.org/abs/1508.01971
@abstract:
 A new computational model for Sodium Chloride, the NaCl/{\{}$\backslash$epsilon{\}}, is proposed. The Force Fields employed here for the description of the NaCl is based on a set of radial particle-particle pair potentials involving Lennard-Jones (LJ) and Coulombic forces. The parameterization is obtained fitting the density of the crystal and the density and the dielectric constant of the mixture of salt with water at diluted solution. Our model shows good agreement with the experimental values for the density and surface tension for the pure system and for the density, the viscosity, the diffusion, and the dielectric constant for the mixture with water at various molal concentrations. The NaCl/{\{}$\backslash$epsilon{\}} together with the water TIP4P/{\{}$\backslash$epsilon{\}} model provide a good approximation for studying electrolyte solutions.

======== 425 : Terrazas2013

@title:    Exploring programmable self-assembly in non-DNA based molecular computing
@keywords: Complex behaviour analysis,Complex systems,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021,Molecular computing,Self-assembly systems
@author:   Terrazas, Germ{\'{a}}n and Zenil, Hector and Krasnogor, Natalio
@doi:      10.1007/s11047-013-9397-2
@url:      http://link.springer.com/10.1007/s11047-013-9397-2
@abstract:
 Self-assembly is a phenomenon observed in nature at all scales where autonomous entities build complex structures, without external influences nor centralised master plan. Modelling such entities and programming correct interactions among them is crucial for controlling the manufacture of desired complex structures at the molecular and supramolecular scale. This work focuses on a programmability model for non DNA-based molecules and complex behaviour analysis of their self-assembled conformations. In particular, we look into modelling, programming and simulation of porphyrin molecules self-assembly and apply Kolgomorov complexity-based techniques to classify and assess simulation results in terms of information content. The analysis focuses on phase transition, clustering, variability and parameter discovery which as a whole pave the way to the notion of complex systems programmability. {\textcopyright} 2013 Springer Science+Business Media Dordrecht.

======== 426 : Gasevic2022

@title:    Optimization of the r2SCAN-3c Composite Electronic-Structure Method for Use with Slater-Type Orbital Basis Sets.
@author:   Gasevic, Thomas and St{\"{u}}ckrath, Julius B and Grimme, Stefan and Bursch, Markus
@doi:      10.1021/acs.jpca.2c02951
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/33588555 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/35654439 http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=PMC9255700
@abstract:
 The "Swiss army knife" composite density functional electronic-structure method r2SCAN-3c (J. Chem. Phys. 2021, 154, 064103) is extended and optimized for the use with Slater-type orbital basis sets. The meta generalized-gradient approximation (meta-GGA) functional r2SCAN by Furness et al. is combined with a tailor-made polarized triple-$\zeta$ Slater-type atomic orbital (STO) basis set (mTZ2P), the semiclassical London dispersion correction (D4), and a geometrical counterpoise (gCP) correction. Relativistic effects are treated explicitly with the scalar-relativistic zeroth-order regular approximation (SR-ZORA). The performance of the new implementation is assessed on eight geometry and 74 energy benchmark sets, including the extensive GMTKN55 database as well as recent sets such as ROST61 and IONPI19. In geometry optimizations, the STO-based r2SCAN-3c is either on par with or more accurate than the hybrid density functional approximation M06-2X-D3(0)/TZP. In energy calculations, the overall accuracy is similar to the original implementation of r2SCAN-3c with Gaussian-type atomic orbitals (GTO), but basic properties, intermolecular noncovalent interactions, and barrier heights are better described with the STO approach, resulting in a lower weighted mean absolute deviation (WTMAD-2(STO) = 7.15 vs 7.50 kcal mol-1 with the original method) for the GMTKN55 database. The STO-optimized r2SCAN-3c outperforms many conventional hybrid/QZ approaches in most common applications at a fraction of their cost. The reliable, robust, and accurate r2SCAN-3c implementation with STOs is a promising alternative to the original implementation with GTOs and can be generally used for a broad field of quantum chemical problems.

- **Subcategory:** Quantum Chemistry, Computational Chemistry
- **Specific Domain:** Electronic Structure Methods, Density Functional Theory (DFT), Slater-Type Orbital Basis Sets
- **Research Type:** Development of a New Implementation of the r2SCAN-3c Method

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on developing a new implementation of the r2SCAN-3c method that combines the meta-GGA functional with a tailor-made STO basis set, and assessing its performance on various benchmark sets.

======== 428 : Chan2009

@title:    Efficient first-principles simulation of noncontact atomic force microscopy for structural analysis
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM - models
@author:   Chan, T. L. and Wang, C. Z. and Ho, K. M. and Chelikowsky, James R.
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevLett.102.176101
@abstract:
 We propose an efficient scheme to simulate noncontact atomic force microscopy images by using first-principles self-consistent potential from the sample as input without explicit modeling of the atomic force microscopy tip. Our method is applied to various types of semiconductor surfaces including Si(111)-(7x7), TiO2(110)-(1x1), Ag/Si(111)-(sqrt[3]xsqrt[3])R30 degrees, and Ge/Si(105)-(1x2) surfaces. We obtain good agreement with experimental results and previous theoretical studies, and our method can aid in identifying different structural models for surface reconstruction.

======== 429 : Kumar2012

@title:    Thermal stability study of nitrogen functionalities in a graphene network.
@keywords: Folder - carbon graphene - Defects
@author:   Kumar, Ajay and Ganguly, Abhijit and Papakonstantinou, Pagona
@doi:      10.1088/0953-8984/24/23/235503
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22576101
@abstract:
 Catalyst-free vertically aligned graphene nanoflakes possessing a large amount of high density edge planes were functionalized using nitrogen species in a low energy N(+) ion bombardment process to achieve pyridinic, cyanide and nitrogen substitution in hexagonal graphitic coordinated units. The evolution of the electronic structure of the functionalized graphene nanoflakes over the temperature range 20-800 °C was investigated in situ, using high resolution x-ray photoemission spectroscopy. We demonstrate that low energy irradiation is a useful tool for achieving nitrogen doping levels up to 9.6 at.{\%}. Pyridinic configurations are found to be predominant at room temperature, while at 800 °C graphitic nitrogen configurations become the dominant ones. The findings have helped to provide an understanding of the thermal stability of nitrogen functionalities in graphene, and offer prospects for controllable tuning of nitrogen doping in device applications.

======== 430 : Iwata2015

@title:    Chemical structure imaging of a single molecule by atomic force microscopy at room temperature
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}source - Moje
@author:   Iwata, Kota and Yamazaki, Shiro and Mutombo, Pingo and Hapala, Prokop and Ondr{\'{a}}{\v{c}}ek, Martin and Jel{\'{i}}nek, Pavel and Sugimoto, Yoshiaki
@doi:      10.1038/ncomms8766
@url:      http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2015/150716/ncomms8766/full/ncomms8766.html?WT.ec{\_}id=NCOMMS-20150722{\&}spMailingID=49153727{\&}spUserID=ODkwMTM2NjQyNgS2{\&}spJobID=722828798{\&}spReportId=NzIyODI4Nzk4S0 http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/ncomms8766
@abstract:
 Atomic force microscopy is capable of resolving the chemical structure of a single molecule on a surface. In previous research, such high resolution has only been obtained at low temperatures. Here we demonstrate that the chemical structure of a single molecule can be clearly revealed even at room temperature. 3,4,9,10-perylene tetracarboxylic dianhydride, which is strongly adsorbed onto a corner-hole site of a Si(111)-(7 × 7) surface in a bridge-like configuration is used for demonstration. Force spectroscopy combined with first-principle calculations clarifies that chemical structures can be resolved independent of tip reactivity. We show that the submolecular contrast over a central part of the molecule is achieved in the repulsive regime due to differences in the attractive van der Waals interaction and the Pauli repulsive interaction between different sites of the molecule.

======== 431 : Giesa2011

@title:    Reoccurring Patterns in Hierarchical Protein Materials and Music: The Power of Analogies
@keywords: Folder - sctructural{\_}tech - MaterialScience - Biom,Folder - sctructural{\_}tech - MaterialScience - Hier,analogy,biomaterials,category theory,composition,hierarchical materials,music,nanostructure,natural materials,pattern
@author:   Giesa, Tristan and Spivak, David I. and Buehler, Markus J.
@doi:      10.1007/s12668-011-0022-5
@url:      http://link.springer.com/10.1007/s12668-011-0022-5
======== 432 : Spiwok2007a

@title:    Metadynamics in essential coordinates: free energy simulation of conformational changes.
@keywords: Alanine,Alanine: chemistry,Algorithms,Chemical,Chemistry,Computer Simulation,Dipeptides,Dipeptides: chemistry,Energy Transfer,Folder - ComputationalMethods - Global{\_}Opt{\_}and{\_}Sad,Folder - Numerics - Optimalization - GlobalOptimiz,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - GlobalOptimizatio,Models,Molecular Conformation,Physical,Physicochemical Phenomena,metadynamics
@author:   Spiwok, Vojtech and Lipovov{\'{a}}, Petra and Kr{\'{a}}lov{\'{a}}, Blanka
@doi:      10.1021/jp068587c
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17388445
@abstract:
 We propose an approach that combines an extraction of collective motions of a molecular system with a sampling of its free energy surface. A recently introduced method of metadynamics allows exploration of the free energy surface of a molecular system by means of coarse-grained dynamics with flooding of free energy minima. This free energy surface is defined as a function of a set of collective variables (e.g., interatomic distances, angles, torsions, and others). In this study, essential coordinates determined by essential dynamics (principle component analysis) were used as collective variables in metadynamics. First, dynamics of the model system (explicitly solvated alanine dipeptide, Ace-Ala-Nme) was simulated by a classical molecular dynamics simulation. The trajectory (1 ns) was then analyzed by essential dynamics to obtain essential coordinates. The free energy surface as a function of the first and second essential coordinates was then explored by metadynamics. The resulting free energy surface is in agreement with other studies of this system. We propose that a combination of these two methods (metadynamics and essential dynamics) has great potential in studies of conformational changes in peptides and proteins.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Physical Chemistry, Computational Chemistry, Molecular Dynamics
- **Specific Domain:** Metadynamics, Essential Coordinates, Free Energy Simulation, Conformational Changes in Peptides and Proteins
- **Research Type:** Development of a New Method for Simulating Conformational Changes using Metadynamics and Essential Dynamics

**10 Keywords:**

1. Metadynamics in essential coordinates: free energy simulation of conformational changes
2. Combination of metadynamics and essential dynamics for studying conformational changes
3. Use of collective variables (essential coordinates) to explore free energy surface
4. Application of this approach to the alanine dipeptide system
5. Exploration of the free energy surface using coarse-grained dynamics with flooding of free energy minima
6. Comparison of the resulting free energy surface with other studies of the same system
7. Proposal for the potential of combining metadynamics and essential dynamics in studying conformational changes in peptides and proteins
8. Identification of essential coordinates as a suitable set of collective variables for metadynamics
9. Development of a new method for simulating conformational changes using metadynamics and essential dynamics
10. Advancements in the field of molecular dynamics simulations, particularly in the study of conformational changes.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on developing a new approach that combines metadynamics and essential dynamics to simulate conformational changes in peptides and proteins.

======== 433 : Morawietz2013b

@title:    A Full-Dimensional Neural Network Potential-Energy Surface for Water Clusters up to the Hexamer
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods - Neural{\_}Networks
@author:   Morawietz, Tobias and Behler, J{\"{o}}rg
@doi:      10.1524/zpch.2013.0384
@url:      http://www.degruyter.com/view/j/zpch.2013.227.issue-9-11/zpch-2013-0384/zpch-2013-0384.xml
@abstract:
 Water clusters have attracted a lot of attention as prototype systems to study hydrogen bonded molecular aggregates but also to gain deeper insights into the properties of liquid water, the solvent of life. All these studies depend on an accurate description of the atomic interactions and countless potentials have been proposed in the literature in the past decades to represent the potential-energy surface (PES) of water. Many of these potentials employ drastic approximations like rigid water monomers and fixed point charges, while on the other hand also several attempts have been made to derive very accurate PESs by fitting data obtained in high-level electronic structure calculations. In recent years artificial neural networks (NNs) have been established as a powerful tool to construct high-dimensional PESs of a variety of systems, but to date no full-dimensional NN PES for water has been reported. Here, we present NN potentials for water clusters containing two to six water molecules trained to density functional theory (DFT) data employing two different exchange-correlation functionals, PBE and RPBE. In contrast to other potentials fitted to first principles data, these NN potentials are not based on a truncated many-body expansion of the energy but consider the interactions between all water molecules explicitly. For both functionals an excellent agreement with the underlying DFT calculations has been found with binding energy errors of only about 1{\%}.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry, Physical Chemistry, Molecular Dynamics
- **Specific Domain:** Neural Network Potentials, Potential-Energy Surface (PES), Water Clusters, Density Functional Theory (DFT)
- **Research Type:** Development of a New Method for Constructing Full-Dimensional Neural Network PESs for Water Clusters

**10 Keywords:**

1. A full-dimensional neural network potential-energy surface for water clusters up to the hexamer
2. Construction of high-dimensional PESs using artificial neural networks (NNs)
3. Application of NN potentials to water clusters containing two to six water molecules

7. Comparison of the accuracy of NN potentials to other potentials fitted to first principles data
8. Identification of the advantages of using NN potentials in molecular dynamics simulations
9. Potential applications of this approach to studying complex systems, such as aqueous solutions and biological molecules
10. Advancements in the field of molecular dynamics simulations, particularly in the construction of accurate potential-energy surfaces.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on developing a new method for constructing full-dimensional neural network potentials for water clusters using density functional theory data without truncation or approximation.

======== 438 : Masillamani2014

@title:    Light-induced reversible modification of the work function of a new perfluorinated biphenyl azobenzene chemisorbed on Au (111)
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Engeneering - Molecular switche
@author:   Masillamani, Appan Merari and Osella, Silvio and Liscio, Andrea and Fenwick, Oliver and Reinders, Federica and Mayor, Marcel and Palermo, Vincenzo and Cornil, J{\'{e}}r{\^{o}}me and Samor{\`{i}}, Paolo
@doi:      10.1039/C4NR01880J
@url:      http://xlink.rsc.org/?DOI=C4NR01880J
@abstract:
 We describe the synthesis of a novel biphenyl azobenzene derivative exhibiting: (i) a protected thiol anchoring group in the [small alpha]-position to readily form self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) on Au surfaces; and (ii) a terminal perfluorinated benzene ring in the [small omega]-position to modify the surface properties. The design of this molecule ensured both an efficient in situ photoswitching between the trans and cis isomers when chemisorbed on Au(111), due to the presence of a biphenyl bridge between the thiol protected anchoring group and the azo dye, and a significant variation of the work function of the SAM in the two isomeric states, induced by the perfluorinated phenyl head group. By exploiting the light responsive nature of the chemisorbed molecules, it is possible to dynamically modify in situ the work function of the SAM-covered electrode, as demonstrated both experimentally and by quantum-chemical calculations, revealing changes in work function up to 220 meV. These findings are relevant for tuning the work function of metallic electrodes, and hence to dynamically modulate charge injection at metal-semiconductor interfaces for organic opto-electronic applications.

======== 441 : Liu2017

@title:    Single-Molecule Imaging Using Atomistic Near-Field Tip-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy
@keywords: field-gradient effect,gap plasmons,near-field confinement,resonant Raman scattering,single-molecule imaging,tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy
@author:   Liu, Pengchong and Chulhai, Dhabih V. and Jensen, Lasse
@doi:      10.1021/acsnano.7b02058
@url:      https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acsnano.7b02058
@abstract:
 Advances in tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (TERS) have demonstrated ultrahigh spatial resolution so that the vibrational modes of individual molecules can be visualized. The spatial resolution of TERS is determined by the confinement of the plasmon-induced field in the junction; however, the conditions necessary for achieving the high spatial confinement required for imaging individual molecules are not fully understood. Here, we present a systematic theoretical study of TERS imaging of single molecules, using a hybrid atomistic electrodynamics-quantum mechanical method. This approach provides a consistent treatment of the molecule and the plasmonic near field under conditions where they cannot be treated separately. In our simulations, we demonstrate that TERS is capable of resolving intricate molecule vibrations with atomic resolution, although we find that TERS images are extremely sensitive to the near field in the junction. Achieving the atomic resolution requires the near field to be confined within a few {\aa}ngstroms in diameter and the near-field focal plane to be in the molecule plane. Furthermore, we demonstrate that the traditional surface selection rule of Raman spectroscopy is altered due to the significant field confinement that leads to significant field-gradient effects in the Raman scattering. This work provides insights into single-molecule imaging based on TERS and Raman scattering of molecules in nanojunctions with atomic dimensions.

**Classification:**

- **Specific Domain:** Tip-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (TERS), Near-Field Optics, Plasmonics, Single-Molecule Imaging
- **Research Type:** Theoretical Study of TERS Imaging of Single Molecules

**10 Keywords:**

1. Single-molecule imaging using atomistic near-field tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy
2. Advances in tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (TERS) for ultrahigh spatial resolution
3. Theoretical study of TERS imaging of single molecules using hybrid atomistic electrodynamics-quantum mechanical method
4. Demonstration of high spatial confinement required for imaging individual molecules
5. Significant field-gradient effects in the Raman scattering due to near-field confinement
6. Alteration of traditional surface selection rule of Raman spectroscopy
7. Near-field focal plane in the molecule plane and atomic resolution requirement
8. Achieving atomic resolution requires near field confined within a few angstroms in diameter
9. Insights into single-molecule imaging based on TERS and Raman scattering of molecules in nanojunctions with atomic dimensions

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the theoretical study of TERS imaging of single molecules using a hybrid atomistic electrodynamics-quantum mechanical method.

======== 442 : Hapala2016

@title:    Mapping the electrostatic force field of single molecules from high-resolution scanning probe images
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021,Folder - {\_}by{\_}source - Moje
@author:   Hapala, Prokop and {\v{S}}vec, Martin and Stetsovych, Oleksandr and van der Heijden, N.J. Nadine Jacoba and Ondr{\'{a}}{\v{c}}k, M. and {Van Der Lit}, Joost and Mutombo, Pingo and Swart, Ingmar and Jel{\'{i}}nek, Pavel and Ondr{\'{a}}{\v{c}}ek, Martin and {Van Der Lit}, Joost and Mutombo, Pingo and Swart, Ingmar and Jel{\'{i}}nek, Pavel
@doi:      10.1038/ncomms11560
@url:      http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/ncomms11560 http://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms11560
@abstract:
 How electronic charge is distributed over a molecule determines to a large extent its chemical properties. Here, we demonstrate how the electrostatic force field, originating from the inhomogeneous charge distribution in a molecule, can be measured with submolecular resolution. We exploit the fact that distortions typically observed in high-resolution atomic force microscopy images are for a significant part caused by the electrostatic force acting between charges of the tip and the molecule of interest. By finding a geometrical transformation between two high-resolution AFM images acquired with two different tips, the electrostatic force field or potential over individual molecules and self-assemblies thereof can be reconstructed with submolecular resolution.

- **Research Type:** Development of a New Method for Mapping the Electrostatic Force Field of Single Molecules

**10 Keywords:**

1. Mapping the electrostatic force field of single molecules from high-resolution scanning probe images

3. Geometrical transformation between two AFM images acquired with different tips to reconstruct electrostatic force field
4. Reconstruction of electrostatic potential over individual molecules and self-assemblies with submolecular resolution
5. Exploiting distortions in high-resolution AFM images caused by electrostatic forces for charge distribution mapping
6. Understanding the relationship between electronic charge distribution and chemical properties of molecules
7. Potential applications in fields such as materials science, nanotechnology, and biomedicine
