These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on developing a new method for mapping the electrostatic force field of single molecules using high-resolution AFM images.

======== 443 : Cheng2019

@title:    First principles-based multiscale atomistic methods for input into first principles nonequilibrium transport across interfaces
@keywords: Electron force field,Molecular dynamics,Multiscale simulation,Quantum mechanics,Reactive force fields
@author:   Cheng, Tao and Jaramillo-Botero, Andres and An, Qi and Ilyin, Daniil V. and Naserifar, Saber and Goddard, William A.
@doi:      10.1073/pnas.1800035115
@url:      http://www.pnas.org/lookup/doi/10.1073/pnas.1800035115 https://pnas.org/doi/full/10.1073/pnas.1800035115
@abstract:
 This issue of PNAS features “nonequilibrium transport and mixing across interfaces,” with several papers describing the nonequilibrium coupling of transport at interfaces, including mesoscopic and macroscopic dynamics in fluids, plasma, and other materials over scales from microscale to celestial. Most such descriptions describe the materials in terms of the density and equations of state rather than specific atomic structures and chemical processes. It is at interfacial boundaries where such atomistic information is most relevant. However, there is not yet a practical way to couple these phenomena with the atomistic description of chemistry. The starting point for including such information is the quantum mechanics (QM). However, practical QM calculations are limited to a hundred atoms for dozens of picoseconds, far from the scales required to inform the continuum level with the proper atomistic description. To bridge this enormous gap, we need to develop practical methods to extend the scale of the atomistic simulation by several orders of magnitude while retaining the level of QM accuracy in describing the chemical process. These developments would enable continuum modeling of turbulent transport at interfaces to incorporate the relevant chemistry. In this perspective, we will focus on recent progress in accomplishing these extensions in first principles-based atomistic simulations and the strategies being pursued to increase the accuracy of very large scales while dramatically decreasing the computational effort.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Condensed Matter Physics, Materials Science, Quantum Mechanics
- **Specific Domain:** Nonequilibrium Transport, Interfaces, Multiscale Simulation, First Principles Methods
- **Research Type:** Development of New Methods for Coupling Atomistic and Continuum Descriptions

**10 Keywords:**

1. First principles-based multiscale atomistic methods for input into first principles nonequilibrium transport across interfaces
2. Bridging the gap between quantum mechanics (QM) and continuum modeling using atomistic simulations
3. Developing practical methods to extend the scale of atomistic simulation by several orders of magnitude
4. Retaining QM accuracy in describing chemical processes while reducing computational effort
5. Coupling nonequilibrium transport at interfaces with atomistic description of chemistry
6. Incorporating relevant chemistry into continuum modeling of turbulent transport
7. Recent progress in first principles-based atomistic simulations for large-scale systems
8. Strategies for increasing accuracy and decreasing computational effort in multiscale simulations
9. Advances in the field of condensed matter physics, particularly in understanding nonequilibrium transport at interfaces
10. Development of new methods for simulating complex chemical processes at large scales.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on developing new methods to couple atomistic and continuum descriptions using first principles-based multiscale atomistic simulations.

======== 447 : Reichling1999

@title:    Scanning Force Imaging of Atomic Size Defects on the {\{}CaF{\$}{\_}2{\$}{\}}(111) Surface
@author:   Reichling, M and Barth, C
======== 448 : Hla2003a

@title:    STM control of chemical reaction: single-molecule synthesis.
@keywords: Chemical,Copper,Copper: chemistry,Electron Transport,Folder - Molecular Electronics - SPM control,Folder - SPM,Iodobenzenes,Iodobenzenes: chemistry,Microscopy,Microscopy- Scanning Tunneling,Microscopy- Scanning Tunneling: methods,Models,Models- Chemical,Models- Molecular,Molecular,Molecular Conformation,Nanotechnology,Scanning Tunneling,Scanning Tunneling: methods
@author:   Hla, Saw-Wai and Rieder, Karl-Heinz
@doi:      10.1146/annurev.physchem.54.011002.103852
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12626735
@abstract:
 The fascinating advances in single atom/molecule manipulation with a scanning tunneling microscope (STM) tip allow scientists to fabricate atomic-scale structures or to probe chemical and physical properties of matters at an atomic level. Owing to these advances, it has become possible for the basic chemical reaction steps, such as dissociation, diffusion, adsorption, readsorption, and bond-formation processes, to be performed by using the STM tip. Complete sequences of chemical reactions are able to induce at a single-molecule level. New molecules can be constructed from the basic molecular building blocks on a one-molecule-at-a-time basis by using a variety of STM manipulation schemes in a systematic step-by-step manner. These achievements open up entirely new opportunities in nanochemistry and nanochemical technology. In this review, various STM manipulation techniques useful in the single-molecule reaction process are reviewed, and their impact on the future of nanoscience and technology are discussed.

======== 450 : Ross2001

@title:    Near-Earth asteroid mining
@keywords: Folder - Space - asteroids
@author:   Ross, SD
@url:      http://www.isdc2007.org/settlement/asteroids/NearEarthAsteroidMining(Ross2001).pdf
======== 451 : Elstner1998

@title:    Self-consistent-charge density-functional tight-binding method for simulations of complex materials properties
@keywords: Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2016{\_}03{\_}21 - references{\_}Glob,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - Energy{\_}function
@author:   Elstner, M. and Porezag, D. and Jungnickel, G. and Elsner, J. and Haugk, M. and Frauenheim, Th. and Suhai, S. and Seifert, G.
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.58.7260
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.58.7260
@abstract:
 We outline details about an extension of the tight-binding (TB) approach to improve total energies, forces, and transferability. The method is based on a second-order expansion of the Kohn-Sham total energy in density-functional theory (DFT) with respect to charge density fluctuations. The zeroth order approach is equivalent to a common standard non-self-consistent (TB) scheme, while at second order a transparent, parameter-free, and readily calculable expression for generalized Hamiltonian matrix elements may be derived. These are modified by a self-consistent redistribution of Mulliken charges (SCC). Besides the usual "band structure" and shea-range repulsive terms the final approximate Kohn-Sham energy additionally includes a Coulomb interaction between charge fluctuations. At large distances this accounts for long-range electrostatic forces between two point charges and approximately includes self-interaction contributions of a given atom if the charges are located at one and the same atom. We apply the new SCC scheme to problems where deficiencies within the non-SCC standard TB approach become obvious. We thus considerably improve transferability.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Condensed Matter Physics, Materials Science
- **Specific Domain:** Density Functional Theory (DFT), Tight-Binding Methods, Charge Density Functional Calculations
- **Research Type:** Development of a New Method for Simulating Complex Materials Properties

**10 Keywords:**

1. Self-consistent-charge density-functional tight-binding method for simulations of complex materials properties
2. Extension of the tight-binding approach to improve total energies and forces
3. Second-order expansion of the Kohn-Sham total energy in density-functional theory (DFT)
4. Modification of generalized Hamiltonian matrix elements using a self-consistent redistribution of Mulliken charges (SCC)
5. Incorporation of Coulomb interaction between charge fluctuations into the approximate Kohn-Sham energy
6. Approximation of long-range electrostatic forces and self-interaction contributions in the SCC scheme
7. Application of the new SCC scheme to problems with deficiencies in non-SCC standard TB approach
8. Improvement of transferability using the SCC scheme
9. Development of a parameter-free and readily calculable expression for generalized Hamiltonian matrix elements
10. Extension of DFT-based tight-binding methods for simulations of complex materials properties.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on developing a new method for simulating complex materials properties by extending the tight-binding approach with a self-consistent-charge density-functional scheme.

======== 452 : Senftle2016

@title:    The ReaxFF reactive force-field: development, applications and future directions
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods - Force Fields,Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2016{\_}09{\_}26,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021,★
@author:   Senftle, Thomas P. and Hong, Sungwook and Islam, Md Mahbubul and Kylasa, Sudhir B. and Zheng, Yuanxia and Shin, Yun Kyung and Junkermeier, Chad and Engel-Herbert, Roman and Janik, Michael J. and Aktulga, Hasan Metin and Verstraelen, Toon and Grama, Ananth and van Duin, Adri C T
@doi:      10.1038/npjcompumats.2015.11
@url:      https://www.nature.com/articles/npjcompumats201511 http://www.nature.com/articles/npjcompumats201511
@abstract:
 {\textless}p{\textgreater}The reactive force-field (ReaxFF) interatomic potential is a powerful computational tool for exploring, developing and optimizing material properties. Methods based on the principles of quantum mechanics (QM), while offering valuable theoretical guidance at the electronic level, are often too computationally intense for simulations that consider the full dynamic evolution of a system. Alternatively, empirical interatomic potentials that are based on classical principles require significantly fewer computational resources, which enables simulations to better describe dynamic processes over longer timeframes and on larger scales. Such methods, however, typically require a predefined connectivity between atoms, precluding simulations that involve reactive events. The ReaxFF method was developed to help bridge this gap. Approaching the gap from the classical side, ReaxFF casts the empirical interatomic potential within a bond-order formalism, thus implicitly describing chemical bonding without expensive QM calculations. This article provides an overview of the development, application, and future directions of the ReaxFF method.{\textless}/p{\textgreater}

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Condensed Matter Physics, Materials Science
- **Specific Domain:** Computational Chemistry, Reactive Force Fields, Molecular Dynamics Simulations
- **Research Type:** Review of the ReaxFF Reactive Force Field Method

**10 Keywords:**

1. The ReaxFF reactive force-field: development, applications and future directions
2. Development of a new reactive force field method for simulating material properties
3. Comparison with quantum mechanics (QM) methods and empirical interatomic potentials
4. Bond-order formalism for describing chemical bonding in classical simulations
5. Implicit description of chemical bonding without expensive QM calculations
6. Applications of the ReaxFF method to various materials and systems
7. Simulation of dynamic processes over longer timeframes and larger scales
8. Bridging the gap between QM methods and empirical interatomic potentials
9. Future directions for the development and application of the ReaxFF method
10. Computational chemistry and molecular dynamics simulations using ReaxFF.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the development, applications, and future directions of the ReaxFF reactive force-field method, which is a powerful computational tool for simulating material properties and dynamic processes.

======== 453 : Emirates1996

@title:    Structural optimization of Lennard-Jones clusters by a genetic algorithm
@keywords: Folder - Numerics - Optimalization - Genetic Algor
@author:   Emirates, United Arab
======== 454 : England2013

@title:    Statistical physics of self-replication
@keywords: Bacteria,Bacteria: cytology,Bacteria: metabolism,Cell Division,Cell Physiological Phenomena,Folder - Evolution{\_}and{\_}Life{\_}Theory,Folder - Information{\_}physics,Nucleic Acids,Nucleic Acids: biosynthesis,Statistics as Topic,Thermodynamics
@author:   England, Jeremy L.
@doi:      10.1063/1.4818538
@url:      http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/jcp/139/12/10.1063/1.4818538 http://arxiv.org/abs/1209.1179 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24089735 https://pubs.aip.org/jcp/article/139/12/121923/74793/Statistical-physics-of-self-replication
@abstract:
 Self-replication is a capacity common to every species of living thing, and simple physical intuition dictates that such a process must invariably be fueled by the production of entropy. Here, we undertake to make this intuition rigorous and quantitative by deriving a lower bound for the amount of heat that is produced during a process of self-replication in a system coupled to a thermal bath. We find that the minimum value for the physically allowed rate of heat production is determined by the growth rate, internal entropy, and durability of the replicator, and we discuss the implications of this finding for bacterial cell division, as well as for the pre-biotic emergence of self-replicating nucleic acids.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Biology
- **Subcategory:** Theoretical Biology, Evolutionary Biology
- **Specific Domain:** Statistical Physics of Biological Systems, Self-Replication Theory
- **Research Type:** Mathematical Modeling of Biological Processes

**10 Keywords:**

1. Statistical physics of self-replication in living systems
2. Thermodynamic analysis of self-replication processes
3. Lower bound for heat production during self-replication
4. Growth rate, internal entropy, and durability of replicators
5. Implications for bacterial cell division
6. Emergence of self-replicating nucleic acids in pre-biotic systems
7. Mathematical modeling of biological processes using statistical physics
8. Thermodynamics and information theory in biology
9. Self-replication as a fundamental property of living systems
10. Quantitative analysis of self-replication mechanisms.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on applying statistical physics to understand the fundamental principles of self-replication in living systems, including bacterial cell division and pre-biotic emergence of nucleic acids.

======== 455 : Pyne2014

@title:    Single-Molecule Reconstruction of Oligonucleotide Secondary Structure by Atomic Force Microscopy
@keywords: DNA,Folder - {\_}Thesis - general{\_}intro,atomic force microscopy,biomolecules,biophysics,oligonucleotides
@author:   Pyne, Alice and Thompson, Ruth and Leung, Carl and Roy, Debdulal and Hoogenboom, Bart W.
@doi:      10.1002/smll.201400265
@url:      http://doi.wiley.com/10.1002/smll.201400265
@abstract:
 Based on soft-touch atomic force microscopy, a method is described to reconstruct the secondary structure of single extended biomolecules, without the need for crystallization. The method is tested by accurately reproducing the dimensions of the B-DNA crystal structure. Importantly, intramolecular variations in groove depth of the DNA double helix are resolved, which would be inaccessible for methods that rely on ensemble-averaging.

======== 456 : Bartok2013

@title:    On representing chemical environments
@keywords: Folder - Chemoinformatics - Descriptors - SOAP,Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - Berlin{\_}MSMJ{\_}2013
@author:   Bart{\'{o}}k, Albert P. and Kondor, Risi and Cs{\'{a}}nyi, G{\'{a}}bor
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.87.184115
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1209.3140 http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.87.184115 http://dx.doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevB.87.184115 https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.87.184115
@abstract:
 We review some recently published methods to represent atomic neighbourhood environments, and analyse their relative merits in terms of their faithfulness and suitability for fitting potential energy surfaces. The crucial properties that such representations (sometimes called descriptors) must have are differentiability with respect to moving the atoms, and invariance to the basic symmetries of physics: rotation, reflection, translation, and permutation of atoms of the same species. We demonstrate that certain widely used descriptors that initially look quite different are specific cases of a general approach, in which a finite set of basis functions with increasing angular wave numbers are used to expand the atomic neighbourhood density function. Using the example system of small clusters, we quantitatively show that this expansion needs to be carried to higher and higher wave numbers as the number of neighbours increases in order to obtain a faithful representation, and that variants of the descriptors converge at very different rates. We also propose an altogether new approach, called Smooth Overlap of Atomic Positions (SOAP), that sidesteps these difficulties by directly defining the similarity between any two neighbourhood environments, and show that it is still closely connected to the invariant descriptors. We test the performance of the various representations by fitting models to the potential energy surface of small silicon clusters and the bulk crystal.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry, Cheminformatics
- **Specific Domain:** Molecular Descriptors, Atomic Neighborhood Environments, Potential Energy Surfaces (PES)
- **Research Type:** Development of New Methods for Representing Chemical Environments

**10 Keywords:**

1. Representing chemical environments using molecular descriptors
2. Analysis of differentiability and symmetry invariance of descriptors
3. Review of recent methods for representing atomic neighbourhood environments
4. Faithfulness and suitability of descriptors for fitting potential energy surfaces (PES)
5. Smooth Overlap of Atomic Positions (SOAP) approach for comparing neighbourhood environments
6. Invariant descriptors and their connection to SOAP
7. Quantitative analysis of descriptor performance using small silicon clusters
8. Fitting models to PES of small silicon clusters and bulk crystal
9. Development of new methods for representing chemical environments with increased accuracy
10. Applications of molecular descriptors in computational chemistry and cheminformatics.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on developing new methods for representing chemical environments using molecular descriptors, and evaluating their performance using potential energy surfaces (PES) of small silicon clusters and bulk crystal.

======== 457 : Wang2006

@title:    The small planarization barriers for the amino group in the nucleic acid bases
@author:   Wang, Suyun and Schaefer, Henry F.
@doi:      10.1063/1.2162538
@url:      https://pubs.aip.org/aip/jcp/article/562288
@abstract:
 The amino group in the nucleic acid bases frequently interacts with other bases or with other molecular systems. Thus any nonplanarity of the amino group may affect the molecular recognition of nucleic acids. Ab initio Hartree-Fock (HF) and second-order M{\o}ller-Plesset perturbation (MP2) levels of theory have been used to obtain the equilibrium geometries of the Cl and Cs structures for five common nucleic acid bases. The energy barriers between the Cl and Cs structures have also been predicted. A series of correlation consistent basis sets up to cc-pCVQZ and aug-cc-pVQZ has been used to systematically study the dependence of the amino group nonplanarity. The equilibrium geometries of the nucleic acid bases with an amino group, including adenine, guanine, and cytosine, are examined carefully. At the MP2 level of theory, larger basis sets decrease the extent of nonplanarity of the amino group, but the decrease slows down when the QZ basis sets are used, demonstrating the intrinsic property of nonplanarity for guanine. For adenine and cytosine the situation is less clear; as the HF limit is approached, these two structures become planar. Addition of core correlation effects or diffuse functions further decreases the degree of nucleic acid base nonplanarity, in comparison to the original cc-pVXZ (X=D, T, and Q) basis sets. The aug-cc-pVXZ basis shows smaller degrees of nonplanarity than the cc-pCVXZ sets. The aug-cc-pVXZ basis is less size dependent than the cc-pVXZ and cc-pCVXZ sets in the prediction of the amino-group-related bond angles and dihedral angles and energy barriers for adenine, guanine, and cytosine. The cc-pCVQZ and aug-cc-pVQZ MP2 results may be regarded as benchmark predictions for the five common bases. The predicted classical barriers to planarization are 0.02 (adenine), 0.74 (guanine), and 0.03 (cytosine) kcal mol-1. {\textcopyright} 2006 American Institute of Physics.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry, Theoretical Chemistry
- **Specific Domain:** Molecular Geometry, Amino Group Nonplanarity, Nucleic Acid Bases
- **Research Type:** Quantum Mechanical Calculations of Molecular Geometries

**10 Keywords:**

1. Amino group nonplanarity in nucleic acid bases
2. Ab initio Hartree-Fock (HF) and MP2 calculations of molecular geometries
3. Equilibrium geometries of Cl and Cs structures for five common nucleic acid bases
4. Energy barriers between Cl and Cs structures predicted using HF and MP2 theory
5. Correlation consistent basis sets used to study dependence of amino group nonplanarity
6. Effects of core correlation, diffuse functions, and basis set size on amino group nonplanarity
7. Comparison of cc-pVXZ and aug-cc-pVXZ basis sets for predicting molecular geometries
8. Benchmark predictions of MP2 results using cc-pCVQZ and aug-cc-pVQZ basis sets
9. Classical barriers to planarization predicted for adenine, guanine, and cytosine
10. Implications of amino group nonplanarity for molecular recognition of nucleic acids.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on using quantum mechanical calculations to study the molecular geometries and amino group nonplanarity in five common nucleic acid bases, with a focus on predicting classical barriers to planarization and understanding the implications for molecular recognition.

@title:    Discrete mechanics and optimal control
@keywords: Folder - Space - Orbits - OrbitalTransfer,discrete mechanics,optimal control,orbital transfer,variational analysis

@url:      http://www-m3.ma.tum.de/foswiki/pub/Allgemeines/JuMaOb05-DMOC/JuMaOb-DMOC-IFAC05.pdf
======== 462 : Pracht2020

@title:    Automated exploration of the low-energy chemical space with fast quantum chemical methods
@author:   Pracht, Philipp and Bohle, Fabian and Grimme, Stefan
@doi:      10.1039/c9cp06869d
@abstract:
 We propose and discuss an efficient scheme for the in silico sampling for parts of the molecular chemical space by semiempirical tight-binding methods combined with a meta-dynamics driven search algorithm. The focus of this work is set on the generation of proper thermodynamic ensembles at a quantum chemical level for conformers, but similar procedures for protonation states, tautomerism and non-covalent complex geometries are also discussed. The conformational ensembles consisting of all significantly populated minimum energy structures normally form the basis of further, mostly DFT computational work, such as the calculation of spectra or macroscopic properties. By using basic quantum chemical methods, electronic effects or possible bond breaking/formation are accounted for and a very reasonable initial energetic ranking of the candidate structures is obtained. Due to the huge computational speedup gained by the fast low-cost quantum chemical methods, overall short computation times even for systems with hundreds of atoms (typically drug-sized molecules) are achieved. Furthermore, specialized applications, such as sampling with implicit solvation models or constrained conformational sampling for transition-states, metal-, surface-, or noncovalently bound complexes are discussed, opening many possible applications in modern computational chemistry and drug discovery. The procedures have been implemented in a freely available computer code called CREST, that makes use of the fast and reliable GFNn-xTB methods.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry, Quantum Chemistry
- **Specific Domain:** Molecular Conformational Sampling, Low-Energy Chemical Space Exploration
- **Research Type:** Development of New Methods for Automated In Silico Sampling

**10 Keywords:**

1. Automated exploration of low-energy chemical space with fast quantum chemical methods
2. Semiempirical tight-binding methods combined with meta-dynamics driven search algorithm
3. Generation of proper thermodynamic ensembles at a quantum chemical level for conformers
4. Conformational sampling and ensemble generation for protonation states, tautomerism, and non-covalent complex geometries
5. Fast and efficient low-cost quantum chemical methods for molecular properties calculation
6. Initial energetic ranking of candidate structures using basic quantum chemical methods
7. Huge computational speedup gained by fast low-cost quantum chemical methods
8. Short computation times achieved for systems with hundreds of atoms (drug-sized molecules)
9. Implementation in freely available computer code called CREST using GFNn-xTB methods
10. Applications in modern computational chemistry and drug discovery, such as sampling with implicit solvation models.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on developing new methods for automated in silico sampling of the low-energy chemical space using fast quantum chemical methods, with applications in modern computational chemistry and drug discovery.

======== 463 : Liebig2020

@title:    Quantifying the evolution of atomic interaction of a complex surface with a functionalized atomic force microscopy tip
@author:   Liebig, Alexander and Hapala, Prokop and Weymouth, A.J. Alfred J. and Giessibl, F.J. Franz J.
@doi:      10.1038/s41598-020-71077-9
@url:      https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-020-71077-9 http://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-020-71077-9
@abstract:
 Terminating the tip of an atomic force microscope with a CO molecule allows data to be acquired with a well-known and inert apex. Previous studies have shown conflicting results regarding the electrostatic interaction, indicating in some cases that the negative charge at the apex of the CO dominates, whereas in other cases the positive charge at the end of the metal tip dominates. To clarify this, we investigated CaF 2(111). CaF 2 is an ionic crystal and the (111) surface does not possess charge inversion symmetry. Far from the surface, the interaction is dominated by electrostatics via the negative charge at the apex. Closer to the surface, Pauli repulsion and CO bending dominate, which leads to an unexpected appearance of the complex 3-atom unit cell. We compare simulated data in which the electrostatics are modeled by point particles versus a charge density calculated by DFT. We also compare modeling Pauli repulsion via individual Lennard–Jones potentials versus a total charge density overlap. In doing so, we determine forcefield parameters useful for future investigations of biochemical processes.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Condensed Matter Physics, Surface Science
- **Specific Domain:** Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM), Functionalized AFM Tips, Electrostatic Interaction, Pauli Repulsion, CO Molecule Termination
- **Research Type:** Experimental and Theoretical Investigation of Atomic Interactions

**10 Keywords:**

1. Quantifying the evolution of atomic interaction between a complex surface and a functionalized AFM tip
2. Investigating electrostatic interaction using CaF 2(111) as a model system
3. Termination of an AFM tip with a CO molecule for data acquisition
4. Comparison of simulated data with point particle and charge density models
5. Modeling Pauli repulsion via individual Lennard-Jones potentials versus total charge density overlap
6. Determination of forcefield parameters for biochemical processes investigation
7. ionic crystal properties of CaF 2(111) surface without charge inversion symmetry
8. Electrostatics dominated by negative charge at the apex far from the surface
9. Pauli repulsion and CO bending dominate closer to the surface, leading to a complex 3-atom unit cell
10. Theoretical investigation of atomic interactions for AFM tip-surface systems.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the experimental and theoretical investigation of atomic interactions between a functionalized AFM tip and a complex surface, with a focus on understanding electrostatics, Pauli repulsion, and CO molecule termination effects.

======== 465 : Bardwell2011

@title:    Towards crystal structure prediction of complex organic compounds – a report on the fifth blind test
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - plymorphs,blind test,crystal structure prediction,polymorph,prediction
@author:   Bardwell, David A. and Adjiman, Claire S. and Arnautova, Yelena A. and Bartashevich, Ekaterina and Boerrigter, Stephan X M and Braun, Doris E. and Cruz-Cabeza, Aurora J. and Day, Graeme M. and {Della Valle}, Raffaele G. and Desiraju, Gautam R. and van Eijck, Bouke P. and Facelli, Julio C. and Ferraro, Marta B. and Grillo, Damian and Habgood, Matthew and Hofmann, Detlef W. M. and Hofmann, Fridolin and Jose, K. V Jovan and Karamertzanis, Panagiotis G. and Kazantsev, Andrei V. and Kendrick, John and Kuleshova, Liudmila N. and Leusen, Frank J J and Maleev, Andrey V. and Misquitta, Alston J. and Mohamed, Sharmarke and Needs, Richard J. and Neumann, Marcus A. and Nikylov, Denis and Orendt, Anita M. and Pal, Rumpa and Pantelides, Constantinos C. and Pickard, Chris J. and Price, Louise S. and Price, Sarah L. and Scheraga, Harold A. and van de Streek, Jacco and Thakur, Tejender S. and Tiwari, Siddharth and Venuti, Elisabetta and Zhitkov, Ilia K.
@doi:      10.1107/S0108768111042868
@url:      http://scripts.iucr.org/cgi-bin/paper?S0108768111042868
@abstract:
 Following on from the success of the previous crystal structure prediction blind tests (CSP1999, CSP2001, CSP2004 and CSP2007), a fifth such collaborative project (CSP2010) was organized at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. A range of methodologies was used by the participating groups in order to evaluate the ability of the current computational methods to predict the crystal structures of the six organic molecules chosen as targets for this blind test. The first four targets, two rigid molecules, one semi-flexible molecule and a 1:1 salt, matched the criteria for the targets from CSP2007, while the last two targets belonged to two new challenging categories - a larger, much more flexible molecule and a hydrate with more than one polymorph. Each group submitted three predictions for each target it attempted. There was at least one successful prediction for each target, and two groups were able to successfully predict the structure of the large flexible molecule as their first place submission. The results show that while not as many groups successfully predicted the structures of the three smallest molecules as in CSP2007, there is now evidence that methodologies such as dispersion-corrected density functional theory (DFT-D) are able to reliably do so. The results also highlight the many challenges posed by more complex systems and show that there are still issues to be overcome.

10. Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre collaborative project.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the evaluation and comparison of computational methods for crystal structure prediction using a blind test approach, highlighting the challenges and successes in predicting polymorphs and hydrate complex systems.

======== 466 : Zeller2014

@title:    What are the possible moir{\'{e}} patterns of graphene on hexagonally packed surfaces? Universal solution for hexagonal coincidence lattices, derived by a geometric construction
@author:   Zeller, Patrick and G{\"{u}}nther, Sebastian
@doi:      10.1088/1367-2630/16/8/083028

======== 467 : Brixner2017

@title:    Exciton Transport in Molecular Aggregates – From Natural Antennas to Synthetic Chromophore Systems
@keywords: dyes/pigments,excitons,molecular aggregates,optical excitations
@author:   Brixner, Tobias and Hildner, Richard and K{\"{o}}hler, J{\"{u}}rgen and Lambert, Christoph and W{\"{u}}rthner, Frank
@doi:      10.1002/aenm.201700236
@abstract:
 The transport of excitation energy in molecular aggregates is of crucial importance for the function of organic optoelectronic devices and next-generation solar cells. First, this review summarizes the theoretical background of the nature of the electronically excited states of molecular aggregates. For these systems, the electronic interaction between the monomers leads to the formation of exciton states. This goes along with a shift of the excitation energies and a redistribution of the oscillator strength with respect to the monomers. Next, a brief overview is provided over experimental techniques that allow to study the properties of excitons in molecular aggregates. This includes single-molecule spectroscopy, coherent two-dimensional (2D) spectroscopy, and single-molecule coherent spectroscopy. Finally, examples of molecular aggregates spanning the range from natural systems that act in photosynthesis as light-harvesting antennas to artificial aggregates built from synthetic chromophores are illustrated.

======== 470 : Gross2009

@title:    Measuring the charge state of an adatom with noncontact atomic force microscopy.
@keywords: Folder - SPM - KPFM,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021
@author:   Gross, Leo and Mohn, Fabian and Liljeroth, Peter and Repp, Jascha and Giessibl, Franz J and Meyer, Gerhard
@doi:      10.1126/science.1172273
@url:      https://www.sciencemag.org/lookup/doi/10.1126/science.1172273 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19520956
@abstract:
 Charge states of atoms can be investigated with scanning tunneling microscopy, but this method requires a conducting substrate. We investigated the charge-switching of individual adsorbed gold and silver atoms (adatoms) on ultrathin NaCl films on Cu(111) using a qPlus tuning fork atomic force microscope (AFM) operated at 5 kelvin with oscillation amplitudes in the subangstrom regime. Charging of a gold atom by one electron charge increases the force on the AFM tip by a few piconewtons. Moreover, the local contact potential difference is shifted depending on the sign of the charge and allows the discrimination of positively charged, neutral, and negatively charged atoms. The combination of single-electron charge sensitivity and atomic lateral resolution should foster investigations of molecular electronics, photonics, catalysis, and solar photoconversion.

**Classification:**

1. Measuring the charge state of an adatom with noncontact atomic force microscopy

@doi:      10.1038/nchem.2506

======== 473 : Zhang2019

@title:    Machine learning in electronic-quantum-matter imaging experiments
@author:   Zhang, Yi and Mesaros, A. and Fujita, K. and Edkins, S. D. and Hamidian, M. H. and Ch'ng, K. and Eisaki, H. and Uchida, S. and Davis, J. C.S{\'{e}}amus and Khatami, Ehsan and Kim, Eun Ah
@doi:      10.1038/s41586-019-1319-8
@abstract:
 For centuries, the scientific discovery process has been based on systematic human observation and analysis of natural phenomena1. Today, however, automated instrumentation and large-scale data acquisition are generating datasets of such large volume and complexity as to defy conventional scientific methodology. Radically different scientific approaches are needed, and machine learning (ML) shows great promise for research fields such as materials science2–5. Given the success of ML in the analysis of synthetic data representing electronic quantum matter (EQM)6–16, the next challenge is to apply this approach to experimental data—for example, to the arrays of complex electronic-structure images17 obtained from atomic-scale visualization of EQM. Here we report the development and training of a suite of artificial neural networks (ANNs) designed to recognize different types of order hidden in such EQM image arrays. These ANNs are used to analyse an archive of experimentally derived EQM image arrays from carrier-doped copper oxide Mott insulators. In these noisy and complex data, the ANNs discover the existence of a lattice-commensurate, four-unit-cell periodic, translational-symmetry-breaking EQM state. Further, the ANNs determine that this state is unidirectional, revealing a coincident nematic EQM state. Strong-coupling theories of electronic liquid crystals18,19 are consistent with these observations.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Condensed Matter Physics, Materials Science, Computational Physics
- **Specific Domain:** Electronic Quantum Matter (EQM), Machine Learning in Materials Science, Atomic-Scale Visualization of EQM
- **Research Type:** Application of Machine Learning to Experimental Data Analysis

**10 Keywords:**

1. Machine learning in electronic-quantum-matter imaging experiments
2. Automated analysis of large-scale datasets from atomic-scale visualization of EQM
3. Development and training of artificial neural networks (ANNs) for EQM image array recognition
4. Application of ANNs to experimentally derived EQM image arrays from copper oxide Mott insulators
5. Discovery of a lattice-commensurate, four-unit-cell periodic, translational-symmetry-breaking EQM state
6. Determination of a unidirectional and coincident nematic EQM state using ANN analysis
7. Consistency with strong-coupling theories of electronic liquid crystals in the observed EQM states
8. Machine learning as a tool for analyzing noisy and complex EQM image array data
9. Advancements in materials science research through the application of machine learning to experimental data
10. Potential applications of machine learning in the study of electronic quantum matter.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the development and application of machine learning techniques to analyze experimentally derived image arrays of electronic quantum matter, with a focus on the discovery of new EQM states and their consistency with theoretical predictions.

@title:    Interband Transitions and Maser Action
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs - Theory
@author:   Dumke, W. P.

@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRev.127.1559
======== 475 : Shankla2014a

@title:    Conformational transitions and stop-and-go nanopore transport of single-stranded DNA on charged graphene
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Engeneering - DNA{\_}sequencing
@author:   Shankla, Manish and Aksimentiev, Aleksei
@doi:      10.1038/ncomms6171
@url:      http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2014/141009/ncomms6171/full/ncomms6171.html{\%}5Cnhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25296960{\%}5Cnhttp://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=PMC4236004{\%}5Cnhttp://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/ncomms6171
@abstract:
 Control over interactions with biomolecules holds the key to applications of graphene in biotechnology. One such application is nanopore sequencing, where a DNA molecule is electrophoretically driven through a graphene nanopore. Here we investigate how interactions of single-stranded DNA and a graphene membrane can be controlled by electrically biasing the membrane. The results of our molecular dynamics simulations suggest that electric charge on graphene can force a DNA homopolymer to adopt a range of strikingly different conformations. The conformational response is sensitive to even very subtle nucleotide modifications, such as DNA methylation. The speed of DNA motion through a graphene nanopore is strongly affected by the graphene charge: a positive charge accelerates the motion, whereas a negative charge arrests it. As a possible application of the effect, we demonstrate stop-and-go transport of DNA controlled by the charge of graphene. Such on-demand transport of DNA is essential for realizing nanopore sequencing.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Research Type:** Simulation Study of Conformational Transitions and Stop-and-Go Transport of Single-stranded DNA

**10 Keywords:**

1. Control over interactions with biomolecules on graphene for biotechnological applications
2. Electrically biasing graphene to control single-stranded DNA transport through a nanopore
3. Molecular dynamics simulations of DNA-graphene interactions under varying electric charges
4. Conformational transitions in DNA homopolymers induced by graphene charge and nucleotide modifications
5. Sensitivity of DNA conformation to subtle nucleotide modifications, such as methylation
6. Stop-and-go transport of DNA through a graphene nanopore controlled by membrane charge
7. Acceleration or arrest of DNA motion through the graphene nanopore depending on membrane charge polarity
8. Potential application in nanopore sequencing for on-demand DNA transport and analysis
9. Understanding interactions between biomolecules and graphene for realizing biotechnological applications
10. Investigating the role of electric charges in controlling DNA-graphene interactions.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the simulation study of conformational transitions and stop-and-go transport of single-stranded DNA on charged graphene, with a focus on controlling DNA motion through a nanopore for potential applications in biotechnology and nanopore sequencing.

======== 476 : DelaTorre2018

@title:    Non-covalent control of spin-state in metal-organic complex by positioning on N-doped graphene
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021
@author:   de la Torre, Bruno and {\v{S}}vec, Martin and Hapala, Prokop and Redondo, Jesus and Krej{\v{c}}{\'{i}}, Ondřej and Lo, Rabindranath and Manna, Debashree and Sarmah, Amrit and Nachtigallov{\'{a}}, Dana and Tu{\v{c}}ek, Jiř{\'{i}} and B{\l}o{\'{n}}ski, Piotr and Otyepka, Michal and Zbořil, Radek and Hobza, Pavel and Jel{\'{i}}nek, Pavel
@doi:      10.1038/s41467-018-05163-y
@url:      http://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-018-05163-y
@abstract:
 Nitrogen doping of graphene significantly affects its chemical properties, which is particularly important in molecular sensing and electrocatalysis applications. However, detailed insight into interaction between N-dopant and molecules at the atomic scale is currently lacking. Here we demonstrate control over the spin state of a single iron(II) phthalocyanine molecule by its positioning on N-doped graphene. The spin transition was driven by weak intermixing between orbitals with z-component of N-dopant (pz of N-dopant) and molecule (dxz, dyz, dz2) with subsequent reordering of the Fe d-orbitals. The transition was accompanied by an electron density redistribution within the molecule, sensed by atomic force microscopy with CO-functionalized tip. This demonstrates the unique capability of the high-resolution imaging technique to discriminate between different spin states of single molecules. Moreover, we present a method for triggering spin state transitions and tuning the electronic properties of molecules through weak non-covalent interaction with suitably functionalized graphene.

**Classification:**

- **Research Type:** Experimental Study of Non-covalent Interaction between Molecules and N-doped Graphene

**10 Keywords:**

1. Non-covalent control of spin-state in metal-organic complex by positioning on N-doped graphene
2. Nitrogen doping of graphene for molecular sensing and electrocatalysis applications
3. Atomic-scale insight into interaction between N-dopant and molecules on graphene
4. Demonstration of spin-state transition in iron(II) phthalocyanine molecule on N-doped graphene

10. Potential applications of this method in molecular electronics and sensing devices.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the experimental study of non-covalent interaction between metal-organic complexes and N-doped graphene for controlling spin-state transitions and tuning electronic properties of molecules.

======== 477 : Schuh2007

@title:    Mechanical behavior of amorphous alloys
@keywords: Folder - Materials,Folder - Materials - Metals,amorphous metal,mechanical properties,metallic glass
@author:   Schuh, C and Hufnagel, T and Ramamurty, U
@doi:      10.1016/j.actamat.2007.01.052
@url:      http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S135964540700122X
======== 478 : Wales2012a

@title:    Quasi-continuous interpolation scheme for pathways between distant configurations
@keywords: Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2016{\_}03{\_}21 - references{\_}Glob,★
@author:   Wales, David J. and Carr, Joanne M.
@doi:      10.1021/ct3004832
@abstract:
 A quasi-continuous interpolation scheme is introduced for characterising physically realistic initial pathways from which to initiate transition state searches and construct kinetic transition networks. Applications are presented for peptides, proteins, and a morphological transformation in an atomic cluster. A simple interpolating potential is first defined, which preserves the covalent bonding framework for the biomolecules. This potential is used to identify an interpolating path by minimising contributions from a connected set of images along with terms corresponding to minima in the interatomic distances between them. This procedure, combined with repulsive terms between unconstrained atoms, helps to circumvent unphysical geometries in the line segments between images. The most difficult cases, where linear interpolation would involve chain crossings, are treated by growing the structure an atom at a time using the interpolating potential. A second optimisation phase then introduces a fraction of the true potential. Permutational alignment is achieved using a shortest augmenting path algorithm based on the local environment.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Subcategory:** Physical Chemistry, Computational Chemistry, Materials Science
- **Specific Domain:** Molecular Dynamics Simulations, Pathway Interpolation, Transition State Searches, Kinetic Transition Networks
- **Research Type:** Development of a Quasi-Continuous Interpolation Scheme for Molecular Dynamics

**10 Keywords:**

1. Quasi-continuous interpolation scheme for physically realistic initial pathways
2. Characterization of transition state searches and kinetic transition networks
3. Applications in peptides, proteins, and atomic cluster morphological transformations
4. Definition of an interpolating potential that preserves covalent bonding framework
5. Identification of an interpolating path by minimising contributions from connected set of images
6. Use of repulsive terms between unconstrained atoms to circumvent unphysical geometries
7. Treatment of difficult cases involving chain crossings using structure growth and optimisation phases
8. Introduction of a fraction of the true potential in the second optimisation phase
9. Permutational alignment achieved using shortest augmenting path algorithm based on local environment
10. Potential applications in molecular dynamics simulations, protein folding, and materials science.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the development of a quasi-continuous interpolation scheme for characterizing physically realistic initial pathways and constructing kinetic transition networks in various molecular systems.

======== 486 : There2003

@title:    10. Supersonic Aerodynamics 10.1
@keywords: Folder - Aerodynamics
@author:   There, Introduction and Sr-, Concorde and Rich, Ben and Sst, Russian and Aiaa, The
======== 487 : Goedecker2005a

@title:    Global Minimum Determination of the Born-Oppenheimer Surface within Density Functional Theory
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - GlobalOptimizatio
@author:   Goedecker, Stefan and Hellmann, Waldemar and Lenosky, Thomas
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevLett.95.055501
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.95.055501
@abstract:
 We present a novel method, which we refer to as the dual minima hopping method, that allows us to find the global minimum of the potential energy surface (PES) within density functional theory for systems where a fast but less accurate calculation of the PES is possible. This method can rapidly find the ground state configuration of clusters and other complex systems with present day computer power by performing a systematic search. We apply the new method to silicon clusters. Even though these systems have already been extensively studied by other methods, we find new global minimum candidates for Si16 and Si19, as well as new low-lying isomers for Si16, Si17, and Si18.

======== 490 : Cao2021

@title:    Energy funnelling within multichromophore architectures monitored with subnanometre resolution
@author:   Cao, Shuiyan and Ros{\l}awska, Anna and Doppagne, Benjamin and Romeo, Michelangelo and F{\'{e}}ron, Michel and Ch{\'{e}}rioux, Fr{\'{e}}d{\'{e}}ric and Bulou, Herv{\'{e}} and Scheurer, Fabrice and Schull, Guillaume

@abstract:
 The funnelling of energy within multichromophoric assemblies is at the heart of the efficient conversion of solar energy by plants. Here we used luminescence induced by scanning tunnelling microscopy to probe model multichromophoric structures assembled on a surface. Mimicking strategies developed by photosynthetic systems, individual molecules were used as ancillary, passive or blocking elements to promote and direct resonant energy transfer between distant donor and acceptor units. As it relies on organic chromophores as the elementary components, this approach constitutes a powerful model to address fundamental physical processes at play in natural light-harvesting complexes. [Figure not available: see fulltext.].

======== 493 : Morgan1996a

@title:    On restarting the Arnoldi method for large nonsymmetric eigenvalue problems
@keywords: Folder - Algorithms - LinearAlgebra - Sparse Solve,and phrases,arnoldi,eigenvalues,krylov subspaces,nonsymmet-,sparse matrices
@author:   Morgan, Ronald B.
@doi:      10.1090/S0025-5718-96-00745-4
@abstract:
 The Arnoldi method computes eigenvalues of large nonsymmetric matrices. Restarting is generally needed to reduce storage requirements and orthogonalization costs. However, restarting slows down the convergence and makes the choice of the new starting vector difficult if several eigenvalues are desired. We analyze several approaches to restarting and show why Sorensen's implicit QR approach is generally far superior to the others. Ritz vectors are combined in precisely the right way for an effective new starting vector. Also, a new method for restarting Arnoldi is presented. It is mathematically equivalent to the Sorensen approach but has additional uses.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Mathematics
- **Subcategory:** Numerical Analysis, Linear Algebra, Computational Mathematics
- **Specific Domain:** Eigenvalue Computation, Krylov Subspace Methods, Arnoldi Method
- **Research Type:** Algorithmic Improvements for Large Nonsymmetric Eigenvalue Problems

**10 Keywords:**

1. Arnoldi method for computing eigenvalues of nonsymmetric matrices

3. Comparison of various restarting approaches, including Sorensen's implicit QR approach
4. Analysis of the choice of new starting vector for restarting the Arnoldi method

6. Mathematical analysis of the equivalence between Sorensen's approach and a new restarting method

8. Applications of the new restarting method to large nonsymmetric eigenvalue problems

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the analysis and improvement of restarting techniques for the Arnoldi method used to compute eigenvalues of large nonsymmetric matrices.

@url:      http://iopscience.iop.org/0029-5515/28/12/009
======== 500 : Parvez2012

@title:    Nitrogen-doped graphene and its iron-based composite as efficient electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction reaction
@keywords: Folder - carbon graphene - Catalyst,graphene oxide,iron coordination,nitrogen-doped graphene,oxygen reduction reaction,stability
@author:   Parvez, Khaled and Yang, Shubin and Hernandez, Yenny and Winter, Andreas and Turchanin, Andrey and Feng, Xinliang and M??llen, Klaus
@doi:      10.1021/nn302674k
@abstract:
 The high cost of platinum-based electrocatalysts for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) has hindered the practical application of fuel cells. Thanks to its unique chemical and structural properties, nitrogen-doped graphene (NG) is among the most promising metal-free catalysts for replacing platinum. In this work, we have developed a cost-effective synthesis of NG by using cyanamide as a nitrogen source and graphene oxide as a precursor, which led to high and controllable nitrogen contents (4.0{\%} to 12.0{\%}) after pyrolysis. NG thermally treated at 900 °C shows a stable methanol crossover effect, high current density (6.67 mA cm(-2)), and durability (∼87{\%} after 10,000 cycles) when catalyzing ORR in alkaline solution. Further, iron (Fe) nanoparticles could be incorporated into NG with the aid of Fe(III) chloride in the synthetic process. This allows one to examine the influence of non-noble metals on the electrocatalytic performance. Remarkably, we found that NG supported with 5 wt {\%} Fe nanoparticles displayed an excellent methanol crossover effect and high current density (8.20 mA cm(-2)) in an alkaline solution. Moreover, Fe-incorporated NG showed almost four-electron transfer processes and superior stability in both alkaline (∼94{\%}) and acidic (∼85{\%}) solutions, which outperformed the platinum and NG-based catalysts.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Specific Domain:** Graphene-Based Catalysts, Nitrogen-Doped Graphene (NG), Oxygen Reduction Reaction (ORR)
- **Research Type:** Development of Efficient Electrocatalysts for ORR

**10 Keywords:**

1. Nitrogen-doped graphene (NG) as a metal-free catalyst for oxygen reduction reaction
2. Cost-effective synthesis of NG using cyanamide and graphene oxide precursors
3. High nitrogen content in NG achieved through pyrolysis at 900 °C
4. Development of iron-based composite with NG for enhanced electrocatalytic performance

8. Superior stability of NG-supported with 5 wt% Fe nanoparticles in alkaline and acidic solutions

10. Comparison of the performance of NG-based catalysts with platinum-based electrocatalysts.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the development of efficient electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) using nitrogen-doped graphene (NG) and iron-based composites.

@title:    High-Precision Atomic Force Microscopy with Atomically-Characterized Tips
@author:   Liebig, Alexander and Peronio, Angelo and Meuer, Daniel and Weymouth, Alfred J and Giessibl, Franz J
======== 503 : Walker2005

@title:    Ups and Downs of Nuclear Isomers Isomers are set apart from other nuclear excitations by their
@keywords: Folder - Nuclear - Nuclear{\_}isomers

======== 504 : Science2008

@title:    Atomic-scale investigation of MoS 2 -based hydrotreating model catalysts A scanning tunneling microscopy study
@author:   Science, Faculty O F
======== 505 : Kucharik2014

@title:    Basin Hopping Graph: a computational framework to characterize RNA folding landscapes
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - GlobalOptimizatio,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - plymorphs
@author:   Kucharik, M. and Hofacker, Ivo L. and Stadler, Peter F. and Qin, Jing
@doi:      10.1093/bioinformatics/btu156
@url:      http://bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/doi/10.1093/bioinformatics/btu156
@abstract:
 MOTIVATION RNA folding is a complicated kinetic process. The minimum free energy structure provides only a static view of the most stable conformational state of the system. It is insufficient to give detailed insights into the dynamic behavior of RNAs. A sufficiently sophisticated analysis of the folding free energy landscape, however, can provide the relevant information. RESULTS We introduce the basin hopping graph (BHG) as a novel coarse-grained model of folding landscapes. Each vertex of the BHG is a local minimum, which represents the corresponding basin in the landscape. Its edges connect basins when the direct transitions between them are "energetically favorable". Edge weights endcode the corresponding saddle heights and thus measure the difficulties of these favorable transitions. BHGs can be approximated accurately and efficiently for RNA molecules well beyond the length range accessible to enumerative algorithms. AVAILABILITY The algorithms described here are implemented in C++ as standalone programs. Its source code and supplemental material can be freely downloaded from http://www.tbi.univie.ac.at/bhg.html. CONTACT qin@imada.sdu.dk.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Bioinformatics
- **Subcategory:** Computational Biology, RNA Structure Prediction, Molecular Dynamics
- **Specific Domain:** RNA Folding Landscapes, Basin Hopping Graph (BHG) Model
- **Research Type:** Development of a Coarse-Grained Model for RNA Folding Landscapes

**10 Keywords:**

1. Basin hopping graph (BHG) model for coarse-graining RNA folding landscapes
2. Characterization of RNA folding dynamics using BHG analysis
3. Local minima and basins in the BHG represent stable conformations
4. Edges in the BHG connect basins with energetically favorable transitions
5. Saddle heights encode edge weights, measuring transition difficulties
6. Efficient approximation of BHGs for large RNA molecules (>100 nucleotides)
7. Comparison with enumerative algorithms for short RNA sequences (<50 nucleotides)
8. Availability of C++ source code and supplementary materials on http://www.tbi.univie.ac.at/bhg.html
9. Application of BHG analysis to understand RNA folding kinetics and dynamics
10. Potential use of BHGs in predicting RNA secondary structure and functional properties.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the development and application of the basin hopping graph (BHG) model for analyzing RNA folding landscapes and understanding the dynamic behavior of RNAs.

======== 510 : Guo2016a

@title:    Nuclear quantum effects of hydrogen bonds probed by tip-enhanced inelastic electron tunneling
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM - H2O,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - NNFF{\_}H2O{\_}NaCl - Exp,★
@author:   Guo, Jing and Lu, J.-T. and Feng, Yexin and Chen, Ji and Peng, Jinbo and Lin, Zeren and Meng, Xiangzhi and Wang, Z. and Li, X.-Z. and Wang, E.-G. and Jiang, Ying
@doi:      10.1126/science.aaf2042
@url:      http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/doi/10.1126/science.aaf2042
@abstract:
 We report the quantitative assessment of nuclear quantum effects on the strength of a single hydrogen bond formed at a water-salt interface, using tip-enhanced inelastic electron tunneling spectroscopy based on a scanning tunneling microscope. The inelastic scattering cross section was resonantly enhanced by “gating” the frontier orbitals of water via a chlorine-terminated tip, so the hydrogen-bonding strength can be determined with high accuracy from the red shift in the oxygen-hydrogen stretching frequency of water. Isotopic substitution experiments combined with quantum simulations reveal that the anharmonic quantum fluctuations of hydrogen nuclei weaken the weak hydrogen bonds and strengthen the relatively strong ones. However, this trend can be completely reversed when a hydrogen bond is strongly coupled to the polar atomic sites of the surface.

The nanoelectronic device is designed to consist of a self-assembled network of nanoparticles connected by two-terminal linker elements with hysteretic behaviour, allowing voltage-controlled switching between a linear and nonlinear current-voltage characteristic (IVC), making reconfigurable logic possible.

======== 519 : Moresco2004a

@title:    Manipulation of large molecules by low-temperature STM: model systems for molecular electronics
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Electronics,molecular electronics,review,scanning tunneling microscopy,single molecule manipulation
@author:   Moresco, Francesca
@doi:      10.1016/j.physrep.2004.08.001
@url:      http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0370157304002947
======== 520 : Eremtchenko2003a

@title:    Understanding and tuning the epitaxy of large aromatic adsorbates by molecular design.
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM - PTCDA
@author:   Eremtchenko, M and Schaefer, J A and Tautz, F S
@doi:      10.1038/nature01901
@url:      http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v425/n6958/abs/nature01901.html http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/14534582
@abstract:
 If the rich functionality of organic molecules is to be exploited in devices such as light-emitting diodes or field-effect transistors, interface properties of organic materials with various (metallic and insulating) substrates must be tailored carefully. In many cases, this calls for well-ordered interfaces. Organic epitaxy-that is, the growth of molecular films with a commensurate structural relationship to their crystalline substrates--relies on successful recognition of preferred epitaxial sites. For some large pi-conjugated molecules ('molecular platelets') this works surprisingly well, even if the substrate exhibits no template structure into which the molecules can lock. Here we present an explanation for site recognition in non-templated organic epitaxy, and thus resolve a long-standing puzzle. We propose that this form of site recognition relies on the existence of a local molecular reaction centre in the extended pi-electron system of the molecule. Its activity can be controlled by appropriate side groups and--in a certain regime--may also be probed by molecularly sensitized scanning tunnelling microscopy. Our results open the possibility of engineering epitaxial interfaces, as well as other interfacial nanostructures for which specific site recognition is essential.

**Classification:**

- **Subcategory:** Physical Chemistry, Materials Science, Organic Electronics

- **Research Type:** Investigation of Site Recognition in Non-Templated Organic Epitaxy

**10 Keywords:**

1. Understanding and tuning the epitaxy of large aromatic adsorbates by molecular design
2. Explanation for site recognition in non-templated organic epitaxy using local molecular reaction centers
3. Role of pi-electron systems in controlling site recognition and epitaxial growth
4. Proposal of a molecular reaction center-based model for site recognition
5. Application of scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) to probe molecular reaction centers

10. Resolution of long-standing puzzle in non-templated organic epitaxy.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the investigation and understanding of site recognition in non-templated organic epitaxy, and the development of a molecular reaction center-based model to explain this phenomenon.

======== 521 : Genc1964a

@title:    Low Reynolds Number Flows and Transition
@keywords: Folder - Aerodynamics,low Re
@author:   Gen{\c{c}}, M Serdar and A{\c{c}}ıkel, H Hakan and Tu, M
======== 522 : Perdew1992c

@title:    Atoms, molecules, solids, and surfaces: Applications of the generalized gradient approximation for exchange and correlation
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods - DFT
@author:   Perdew, John P. and Chevary, J. A. and Vosko, S. H. and Jackson, Koblar A. and Pederson, Mark R. and Singh, D. J. and Fiolhais, Carlos
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.46.6671
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.48.4978.2 http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.46.6671
@abstract:
 Generalized gradient approximations (GGA's) seek to improve upon the accuracy of the local-spin-density (LSD) approximation in electronic-structure calculations. Perdew and Wang have developed a GGA based on real-space cutoff of the spurious long-range components of the second-order gradient expansion for the exchange-correlation hole. We have found that this density functional performs well in numerical tests for a variety of systems: (1) Total energies of 30 atoms are highly accurate. (2) Ionization energies and electron affinities are improved in a statistical sense, although significant interconfigurational and interterm errors remain. (3) Accurate atomization energies are found for seven hydrocarbon molecules, with a rms error per bond of 0.1 eV, compared with 0.7 eV for the LSD approximation and 2.4 eV for the Hartree-Fock approximation. (4) For atoms and molecules, there is a cancellation of error between density functionals for exchange and correlation, which is most striking whenever the Hartree-Fock result is furthest from experiment. (5) The surprising LSD underestimation of the lattice constants of Li and Na by 3–4 {\%} is corrected, and the magnetic ground state of solid Fe is restored. (6) The work function, surface energy (neglecting the long-range contribution), and curvature energy of a metallic surface are all slightly reduced in comparison with LSD. Taking account of the positive long-range contribution, we find surface and curvature energies in good agreement with experimental or exact values. Finally, a way is found to visualize and understand the nonlocality of exchange and correlation, its origins, and its physical effects.

**Classification:**

- **Subcategory:** Computational Physics, Condensed Matter Physics, Materials Science

3. Numerical tests of the GGA performance in various systems, including atoms, molecules, and solids
4. Comparison with local-spin-density (LSD) and Hartree-Fock approximations

8. Investigation of surface and curvature energies using the GGA
9. Visualization and understanding of nonlocality of exchange and correlation using the GGA
10. Physical effects and origins of nonlocality in exchange and correlation.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the development and application of a generalized gradient approximation (GGA) for electronic structure calculations, with emphasis on its performance and physical implications.

======== 523 : Krejci2017

@title:    Principles and simulations of high-resolution STM imaging with a flexible tip apex
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021,Folder - {\_}by{\_}source - Moje
@author:   Krej{\v{c}}{\'{i}}, Ondrej and Hapala, Prokop and Ondr{\'{a}}{\v{c}}ek, Martin and Jel{\'{i}}nek, Pavel
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.95.045407
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1609.09462 https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.95.045407
@abstract:
 We present a robust but still efficient simulation approach for high-resolution scanning tunneling microscopy with a flexible tip apex showing sharp submolecular features. The approach takes into account the electronic structure of sample and tip and relaxation of the tip apex. We validate our model by achieving good agreement with various experimental images which allows us to explain the origin of several observed features. Namely, we have found that high-resolution STM mechanism consists of the standard STM imaging, convolving electronic states of the sample and the tip apex orbital structure, with the contrast heavily distorted by the relaxation of the flexible apex caused by interaction with the substrate.

======== 524 : lindsay2010recognition

@title:    Recognition tunneling.
@keywords: DNA,DNA: analysis,DNA: genetics,Folder - {\_}by{\_}source - Moje,Hydrogen Bonding,Microscopy,Scanning Tunneling
@author:   Lindsay, Stuart and He, Jin and Sankey, Otto and Hapala, Prokop and Jelinek, Pavel and Zhang, Peiming and Chang, Shuai and Huang, Shuo
@doi:      10.1088/0957-4484/21/26/262001
@url:      http://stacks.iop.org/0957-4484/21/i=26/a=262001?key=crossref.63a76c35fed6e4dc152fe8dddf740056 http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=2891988{\&}tool=pmcentrez{\&}rendertype=abstract
@abstract:
 Single molecules in a tunnel junction can now be interrogated reliably using chemically functionalized electrodes. Monitoring stochastic bonding fluctuations between a ligand bound to one electrode and its target bound to a second electrode ('tethered molecule-pair' configuration) gives insight into the nature of the intermolecular bonding at a single molecule-pair level, and defines the requirements for reproducible tunneling data. Simulations show that there is an instability in the tunnel gap at large currents, and this results in a multiplicity of contacts with a corresponding spread in the measured currents. At small currents (i.e. large gaps) the gap is stable, and functionalizing a pair of electrodes with recognition reagents (the 'free-analyte' configuration) can generate a distinct tunneling signal when an analyte molecule is trapped in the gap. This opens up a new interface between chemistry and electronics with immediate implications for rapid sequencing of single DNA molecules.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Physical Chemistry, Materials Science, Analytical Chemistry
- **Specific Domain:** Single Molecule Recognition, Scanning Tunneling Microscopy (STM), DNA Analysis
- **Research Type:** Development of a Novel Interface between Chemistry and Electronics for Rapid Sequencing of Single DNA Molecules

**10 Keywords:**

1. Recognition tunneling: A new interface between chemistry and electronics
2. Chemically functionalized electrodes for single molecule interrogation
3. Stochastic bonding fluctuations in tethered molecule-pairs
4. Simulations showing instability in the tunnel gap at large currents
5. Multiplicity of contacts with spread in measured currents at high currents
6. Stable gaps at small currents, enabling recognition tunneling signals
7. Use of recognition reagents to generate distinct tunneling signals
8. Free-analyte configuration for rapid sequencing of single DNA molecules
9. Applications in rapid DNA sequencing and analysis
10. Potential implications for future developments in bioelectronics.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the development of a novel interface between chemistry and electronics for rapid sequencing of single DNA molecules using recognition tunneling.

======== 525 : Klakow1997

@title:    Semiclassical Dynamics in a Fluctuating Potential
@author:   Klakow, D. and Reinhard, P.-G. and Toepffer, C.
@doi:      10.1006/aphy.1997.5714
@url:      https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0003491697957146
@abstract:
 We investigate the Vlasov equation as a semiclassical approximation to quantum dynamics. The effect of the self-consistent mean field is modeled by a spatially fluctuating potential given in the form of randomly distributed Gaussians. The comparison of the quantum dynamics to its semiclassical approximation is done using the emittance of a wave packet as an observable. The analysis concentrates on the h{\l}→0 limit of TDHF by considering a representative test particle problem. We check a formal estimate of the quality of the semiclassical expansion against practical results. The quality of the semiclassical approach depends much on the observable of interest {\textcopyright} 1997 Academic Press.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Quantum Mechanics, Condensed Matter Physics, Computational Physics
- **Specific Domain:** Semiclassical Approximations, Vlasov Equation, Time-Dependent Hartree-Fock (TDHF) Theory
- **Research Type:** Investigation of the Accuracy and Limitations of Semiclassical Dynamics in a Fluctuating Potential

**10 Keywords:**

1. Semiclassical dynamics in a fluctuating potential using the Vlasov equation
2. Quantum-to-classical correspondence with a spatially fluctuating mean field

======== 527 : Shunn2012

@title:    Symmetric quadrature rules for tetrahedra based on a cubic close-packed lattice arrangement
@keywords: Cubatures for tetrahedra,Cubic close-packed,Numerical integration
@author:   Shunn, Lee and Ham, Frank
@doi:      10.1016/j.cam.2012.03.032
@url:      http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cam.2012.03.032 https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0377042712001604
@abstract:
 A family of quadrature rules for integration over tetrahedral volumes is developed. The underlying structure of the rules is based on the cubic close-packed (CCP) lattice arrangement using 1, 4, 10, 20, 35, and 56 quadrature points. The rules are characterized by rapid convergence, positive weights, and symmetry. Each rule is an optimal approximation in the sense that lower-order terms have zero contribution to the truncation error and the leading-order error term is minimized. Quadrature formulas up to order 9 are presented with relevant numerical examples. {\textcopyright} 2012 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

======== 530 : Kolmer2020

@title:    Rational synthesis of atomically precise graphene nanoribbons directly on metal oxide surfaces
@author:   Kolmer, Marek and Steiner, Ann-Kristin and Izydorczyk, Irena and Ko, Wonhee and Engelund, Mads and Szymonski, Marek and Li, An-Ping and Amsharov, Konstantin
@doi:      10.1126/science.abb8880
@url:      https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.abb8880
@abstract:
 Atomically precise graphene nanoribbons (GNRs) attract great interest because of their highly tunable electronic, optical, and transport properties. However, on-surface synthesis of GNRs is typically based on metal surface-assisted chemical reactions, where metallic substrates strongly screen their designer electronic properties and limit further applications. Here, we present an on-surface synthesis approach to forming atomically precise GNRs directly on semiconducting metal oxide surfaces. The thermally triggered multistep transformations preprogrammed in our precursors' design rely on highly selective and sequential activations of carbon-bromine (C-Br) and carbon-fluorine (C-F) bonds and cyclodehydrogenation. The formation of planar armchair GNRs terminated by well-defined zigzag ends is confirmed by scanning tunneling microscopy and spectroscopy, which also reveal weak interaction between GNRs and the rutile titanium dioxide substrate.

======== 531 : Arsenault2014a

@title:    Machine learning for Many-Body Physics: the case of the Anderson impurity model
@keywords: Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2015{\_}06{\_}29 - Machine{\_}learing
@author:   Arsenault, Louis-Fran{\c{c}}ois and Lopez-Bezanilla, Alejandro and von Lilienfeld, O. Anatole and Millis, Andrew J.
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.90.155136
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1408.1143
@abstract:
 Machine learning methods are applied to finding the Green function of the Anderson impurity model, a basic model system of quantum many-body condensed matter physics. Different methods of parametrizing the Green function are investigated; a representation in terms of Legendre polynomials is found to be superior due to its limited number of coefficients and its applicability to state of the art methods of solution. The dependence of the errors on the size of the training set is determined. The results indicate that a machine-learning approach to dynamical mean field theory may be feasible.
