======== 534 : Meier2006

@title:    Analyses in Support of Z-Pinch IFE and Actinide Transmutation - LLNL Progress Report for FY-06
@keywords: Folder - Fusion
@author:   Meier, W R and Moir, R W
======== 535 : Bannwarth2021

@title:    Extended {\textless}scp{\textgreater}tight‐binding{\textless}/scp{\textgreater} quantum chemistry methods
@keywords: density functional tight-binding theory,multilevel quantum chemistry,semiempirical molecular orbital theory
@author:   Bannwarth, Christoph and Caldeweyher, Eike and Ehlert, Sebastian and Hansen, Andreas and Pracht, Philipp and Seibert, Jakob and Spicher, Sebastian and Grimme, Stefan
@doi:      10.1002/wcms.1493
@url:      https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/wcms.1493
@abstract:
 This review covers a family of atomistic, mostly quantum chemistry (QC) based semiempirical methods for the fast and reasonably accurate description of large molecules in gas and condensed phase. The theory is derived from a density functional (DFT) perturbation expansion of the electron density in fluctuation terms to various orders similar to the original density functional tight binding model. The term “eXtended” in their name (xTB) emphasizes the parameter availability for almost the entire periodic table of elements (Z ≤ 86) and improvements of the underlying theory regarding, for example, the atomic orbital basis set, the level of multipole approximation and the treatment of the important electrostatic and dispersion interactions. A common feature of most members is their consistent parameterization on accurate gas phase theoretical reference data for geometries, vibrational frequencies and noncovalent interactions, which are the primary properties of interest in typical applications to systems composed of up to a few thousand atoms. Further specialized versions were developed for the description of electronic spectra and corresponding response properties. Besides a provided common theoretical background with some important implementation details in the efficient and free xtb program, various benchmarks for structural and thermochemical properties including (transition-)metal systems are discussed. The review is completed by recent extensions of the model to the force-field (FF) level as well as its application to solids under periodic boundary conditions. The general applicability together with the excellent cost-accuracy ratio and the high robustness make the xTB family of methods very attractive for various fields of computer-aided chemical research. This article is categorized under: Electronic Structure Theory {\textgreater} Ab Initio Electronic Structure Methods Electronic Structure Theory {\textgreater} Semiempirical Electronic Structure Methods Software {\textgreater} Quantum Chemistry.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

- **Specific Domain:** Density Functional Theory (DFT), Tight-Binding Methods, Semiempirical Molecular Orbital Theory
- **Research Type:** Development of Extended Semiempirical Methods for Quantum Chemistry

**10 Keywords:**

1. Extended semiempirical methods for quantum chemistry (xTB)
2. Density functional tight-binding theory and its extensions
3. Multilevel quantum chemistry approaches for large molecules
4. Parameterization on accurate gas phase theoretical reference data
5. Description of geometries, vibrational frequencies, and noncovalent interactions
6. Specialized versions for electronic spectra and response properties
7. Application to systems composed of up to a few thousand atoms
8. Recent extensions to the force-field level and periodic boundary conditions
9. Excellent cost-accuracy ratio and high robustness of the xTB family of methods
10. Applicability to various fields of computer-aided chemical research.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the development and application of extended semiempirical methods for quantum chemistry (xTB), which are used to describe large molecules in gas and condensed phase with reasonable accuracy and fast computation times.

======== 536 : Wu2006a

@title:    Atomic-scale coupling of photons to single-molecule junctions.
@author:   Wu, S W and Ogawa, N and Ho, W
@doi:      10.1126/science.1124881
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16627700
@abstract:
 Spatial resolution at the atomic scale has been achieved in the coupling of light to single molecules adsorbed on a surface. Electron transfer to a single molecule induced by green to near-infrared light in the junction of a scanning tunneling microscope (STM) exhibited spatially varying probability that is confined within the molecule. The mechanism involves photo-induced resonant tunneling in which a photoexcited electron in the STM tip is transferred to the molecule. The coupling of photons to the tunneling process provides a pathway to explore molecular dynamics with the combined capabilities of lasers and the STM.

======== 537 : Xue2003

@title:    Microscopic study of electrical transport through individual molecules with metallic contacts. II. Effect of the interface structure
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Electronics - applications
@author:   Xue, Yongqiang and Ratner, Mark A.
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.68.115407
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/cond-mat/0303180 http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.68.115407
@abstract:
 We investigate the effect on molecular transport due to the different structural aspects of metal-molecule interfaces. The example system chosen is the prototypical molecular device formed by sandwiching the phenyl dithiolate molecule (PDT) between two gold electrodes with different metal-molecule distance, atomic structure at the metallic surface, molecular adsorption geometry and with an additional hydrogen end atom. We find the dependence of the conductance on the metal-molecule interface structure is determined by the competition between the modified metal-molecule coupling and the corresponding modified energy level lineup at the molecular junction. The results of the detailed microscopic calculation can all be understood qualitatively from the equilibrium energy level lineup and the knowledge of the voltage drop across the molecular junction at finite bias voltages.

======== 542 : Grimme2021

@title:    R2SCAN-3c: A "swiss army knife" composite electronic-structure method
@author:   Grimme, Stefan and Hansen, Andreas and Ehlert, Sebastian and Mewes, Jan Michael
@doi:      10.1063/5.0040021
@url:      https://doi.org/10.1063/5.0040021
@abstract:
 The recently proposed r2SCAN meta-generalized-gradient approximation (mGGA) of Furness and co-workers is used to construct an efficient composite electronic-structure method termed r2SCAN-3c. To this end, the unaltered r2SCAN functional is combined with a tailor-made triple-$\zeta$ Gaussian atomic orbital basis set as well as with refitted D4 and geometrical counter-poise corrections for London-dispersion and basis set superposition error. The performance of the new method is evaluated for the GMTKN55 database covering large parts of chemical space with about 1500 data points, as well as additional benchmarks for non-covalent interactions, organometallic reactions, and lattice energies of organic molecules and ices, as well as for the adsorption on polar salt and non-polar coinage-metal surfaces. These comprehensive tests reveal a spectacular performance and robustness of r2SCAN-3c: It by far surpasses its predecessor B97-3c at only twice the cost and provides one of the best results of all semi-local density-functional theory (DFT)/QZ methods ever tested for the GMTKN55 database at one-tenth of the cost. Specifically, for reaction and conformational energies as well as non-covalent interactions, it outperforms prominent hybrid-DFT/QZ approaches at two to three orders of magnitude lower cost. Perhaps, the most relevant remaining issue of r2SCAN-3c is self-interaction error (SIE), owing to its mGGA nature. However, SIE is slightly reduced compared to other (m)GGAs, as is demonstrated in two examples. After all, this remarkably efficient and robust method is chosen as our new group default, replacing previous composite DFT and partially even expensive high-level methods in most standard applications for systems with up to several hundreds of atoms.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Condensed Matter Physics, Quantum Mechanics, Computational Materials Science
- **Specific Domain:** Density Functional Theory (DFT), Meta-Generalized Gradient Approximations (mGGAs), Composite Electronic Structure Methods
- **Research Type:** Development and Evaluation of a Novel Composite Electronic Structure Method

**10 Keywords:**

1. R2SCAN-3c: A new composite electronic structure method
2. r2SCAN meta-generalized gradient approximation (mGGA) as the core functional
3. Tailor-made triple-$\zeta$ Gaussian atomic orbital basis set for improved efficiency
4. Refitted D4 and geometrical counter-poise corrections for London-dispersion and basis set superposition error
5. Evaluation of performance on GMTKN55 database with over 1500 data points
6. Comprehensive benchmarks for non-covalent interactions, organometallic reactions, lattice energies, and adsorption on surfaces
7. Spectacular performance and robustness of R2SCAN-3c compared to previous methods
8. Comparison with prominent hybrid-DFT/QZ approaches at significantly lower cost
9. Remaining issue of self-interaction error (SIE) in R2SCAN-3c due to its mGGA nature
10. New group default method replacing previous composite DFT and high-level methods for systems with up to hundreds of atoms.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the development and evaluation of a novel composite electronic structure method called R2SCAN-3c, which combines the r2SCAN meta-GGA functional with additional refinements for improved efficiency and accuracy.

======== 543 : Iftimie2004

@title:    On-the-fly localization of electronic orbitals in Car-Parrinello molecular dynamics
@author:   Iftimie, Radu and Thomas, Jordan W. and Tuckerman, Mark E.
@doi:      10.1063/1.1636697
@abstract:
 The ab initio molecular-dynamics formalism of Car and Parrinello is extended to preserve the locality of the orbitals. The supplementary term in the Lagrangian does not affect the nuclear dynamics, but ensures "on the fly" localization of the electronic orbitals within a periodic supercell in the Gamma-point approximation. The relationship between the resulting equations of motion and the formation of a gauge-invariant Lagrangian combined with a gauge-fixing procedure is briefly discussed. The equations of motion can be used to generate a very stable and easy to implement numerical integration algorithm. It is demonstrated that this algorithm can be used to compute the trajectory of the maximally localized orbitals, known as Wannier orbitals, in ab initio molecular dynamics with only a modest increase in the overall computer time. In the present paper, the new method is implemented within the generalized gradient approximation to Kohn-Sham density-functional theory employing plane wave basis sets and atomic pseudopotentials. In the course of the presentation, we briefly discuss how the present approach can be combined with localized basis sets to design fast linear scaling ab initio molecular-dynamics methods.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Condensed Matter Physics, Quantum Mechanics, Computational Materials Science
- **Specific Domain:** Ab Initio Molecular Dynamics (AIMD), Car-Parrinello Method, Electronic Structure Theory
- **Research Type:** Development and Implementation of a Novel AIMD Method with On-the-Fly Localization of Electronic Orbitals

**10 Keywords:**

1. Extended Car-Parrinello method for on-the-fly localization of electronic orbitals
2. Ab initio molecular dynamics formalism with localized orbitals within a periodic supercell
3. Gamma-point approximation and its implications for the Lagrangian and equations of motion
4. Gauge-invariant Lagrangian combined with gauge-fixing procedure to ensure orbital localization
5. Relationship between resulting equations of motion and Wannier orbital formation
6. Implementation of new method within generalized gradient approximation (GGA) to Kohn-Sham density-functional theory (DFT)
7. Use of plane wave basis sets and atomic pseudopotentials in GGA-DFT calculations
8. Possibility of combining present approach with localized basis sets for fast linear scaling AIMD methods
9. Increased stability and ease of implementation of numerical integration algorithm
10. Application of new method to compute trajectory of maximally localized orbitals (Wannier orbitals) in AIMD.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the development and implementation of a novel ab initio molecular dynamics method with on-the-fly localization of electronic orbitals, which extends the Car-Parrinello formalism to preserve orbital locality within a periodic supercell.

======== 546 : Ostrovsky2003

@title:    A reduced dimension branch-and-bound algorithm for molecular design
@keywords: Branch-and-bound procedure,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - GlobalOptimizatio,Global optimization,Linear underestimators,Mixed-integer nonlinear programming,Molecular design
@author:   Ostrovsky, G.M. and Achenie, Luke E.K. and Sinha, Manish
@doi:      10.1016/S0098-1354(02)00233-8
@url:      http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0098135402002338 https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0098135402002338
@abstract:
 This paper addresses the solution of mixed-integer nonlinear mathematical programs in which the number of linear constraints far exceed the number of nonlinear constraints, and with most variables participating in the nonconvex terms. Some computer-aided molecular design models have these features. A branch-and-bound (BB) algorithm is proposed that is specifically tailored to solving such problems. In a conventional BB algorithm, branching is performed on all the search variables that appear in the nonlinear terms. This translates to a large number of node traversals. To overcome this problem, we have proposed a new strategy for branching on a set of branching functions, which depend linearly on the search variables. The branching functions are determined from a special tree function (STF) representation of both the objective function and constraints. In order to construct the corresponding linear underestimators, we have developed the Sweep method. The proposed algorithm scales well with problem size. Specifically, as the problem size increases, the computational effort increases almost linearly. The computational efficiency of the algorithm is demonstrated by solving a molecular design problem to global optimality. ?? 2002 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Computer Science
- **Subcategory:** Operations Research, Optimization, Computational Intelligence
- **Specific Domain:** Global Optimization, Mixed-Integer Nonlinear Programming (MINLP), Molecular Design, Branch-and-Bound Algorithms
- **Research Type:** Development and Implementation of a Reduced Dimension Branch-and-Bound Algorithm for Molecular Design

**10 Keywords:**

1. Reduced dimension branch-and-bound algorithm for molecular design
2. Tailored approach to solving mixed-integer nonlinear mathematical programs
3. Linear constraints exceeding number of nonlinear constraints in molecular design models
4. Most variables participating in nonconvex terms in molecular design problems
5. Branching on a set of branching functions depending linearly on search variables
6. Determination of branching functions from special tree function (STF) representation
7. Development of Sweep method for constructing linear underestimators
8. Computational efficiency of proposed algorithm demonstrated by solving molecular design problem to global optimality
9. Scalability of algorithm with problem size, increasing almost linearly
10. Application of reduced dimension branch-and-bound algorithm in computer-aided molecular design.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the development and implementation of a novel branch-and-bound algorithm tailored for molecular design problems with mixed-integer nonlinear constraints. The proposed approach reduces the computational effort by branching on a set of linear functions, making it scalable with problem size.

======== 547 : Quardokus2013

@title:    Adsorption of diferrocenylacetylene on Au(111) studied by scanning tunneling microscopy
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - SAMs
@author:   Quardokus, Rebecca C and Wasio, Natalie A and Forrest, Ryan P and Lent, Craig S and Corcelli, Steven A and Christie, John A and Henderson, Kenneth W and {Alex Kandel}, S.
@doi:      10.1039/c3cp50225b
@url:      http://xlink.rsc.org/?DOI=c3cp50225b{\%}5Cnpapers3://publication/doi/10.1039/c3cp50225b http://xlink.rsc.org/?DOI=c3cp50225b
@abstract:
 Scanning tunneling microscopy images of diferrocenylacetylene (DFA) coadsorbed with benzene on Au(111) show individual and close-packed DFA molecules, either adsorbed alongside benzene or on top of a benzene monolayer. Images acquired over a range of positive and negative tip–sample bias voltages show a shift in contrast, with the acetylene linker appearing brighter than the ferrocenes at positive sample bias (where unoccupied states primarily contribute) and the reverse contrast at negative bias. Density functional theory was used to calculate the electronic structure of the gas-phase DFA molecule, and simulated images produced through two-dimensional projections of these calculations approximate the experimental images. The symmetry of both experimental and calculated molecular features for DFA rules out a cis adsorption geometry, and comparison of experiment to simulation indicates torsion around the inter-ferrocene axis between 90° and 180° (trans); the cyclopentadienyl rings are thus angled with respect to the surface.

**10 Keywords:**

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on an experimental and theoretical study of DFA adsorption on Au(111), using STM to investigate molecular arrangement and structure, and DFT calculations to understand electronic properties and simulate STM images.

======== 550 : Peng2018natComm

@title:    Weakly perturbative imaging of interfacial water with submolecular resolution by atomic force microscopy
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021,Folder - {\_}by{\_}source - Moje
@author:   Peng, Jinbo and Guo, Jing and Hapala, Prokop and Cao, Duanyun and Ma, Runze and Cheng, Bowei and Xu, Limei and Ondr{\'{a}}{\v{c}}ek, Martin and Jel$\backslash$'$\backslash$inek, Pavel and Wang, Enge and Jiang, Ying and Jel{\'{i}}nek, Pavel and Wang, Enge and Jiang, Ying
@doi:      10.1038/s41467-017-02635-5
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1703.04400 http://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-017-02635-5
@abstract:
 Scanning probe microscopy (SPM) has been extensively applied to probe interfacial water in many interdisciplinary fields but the disturbance of the probes on the hydrogen-bonding structure of water has remained an intractable problem. Here we report submolecular-resolution imaging of the water clusters on a NaCl(001) surface within the nearly non-invasive region by a qPlus-based noncontact atomic force microscopy. Comparison with theoretical simulations reveals that the key lies in probing the weak high-order electrostatic force between the quadrupole-like CO-terminated tip and the polar water molecules at large tip-water distances. This interaction allows the imaging and structural determination of the weakly bonded water clusters and even of their metastable states without inducing any disturbance. This work may open up new possibility of studying the intrinsic structure and electrostatics of ice or water on bulk insulating surfaces, ion hydration and biological water with atomic precision.

- **Research Type:** Development of a Novel AFM Method for Imaging Interfacial Water with Submolecular Resolution

**10 Keywords:**

1. Weakly perturbative imaging of interfacial water by atomic force microscopy (AFM)
2. Submolecular-resolution imaging of water clusters on NaCl(001) surface
3. qPlus-based noncontact AFM used to minimize disturbance on hydrogen-bonding structure of water
4. Quadrupole-like CO-terminated tip and its interaction with polar water molecules at large tip-water distances
5. High-order electrostatic force between tip and water molecules allows imaging without inducing disturbance
6. Structural determination of weakly bonded water clusters and metastable states using AFM
7. Comparison with theoretical simulations reveals importance of quadrupole-like CO-terminated tip
8. Potential for studying intrinsic structure and electrostatics of ice or water on bulk insulating surfaces
9. Applications in ion hydration, biological water, and other fields requiring atomic precision imaging
10. Novel possibility opened up by this work for understanding interfacial water at the molecular level.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the development of a novel AFM method that uses a quadrupole-like CO-terminated tip to image interfacial water with submolecular resolution without disturbing its hydrogen-bonding structure.

======== 553 : Barin2012c

@title:    Mechanostereochemistry and the mechanical bond
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Engeneering,catenanes,chemical topology,integrated functional systems,molecular switches,rotaxanes,template-directed synthesis
@author:   Barin, G. and Forgan, R. S. and Stoddart, J. F.
@doi:      10.1098/rspa.2012.0117
@url:      http://rspa.royalsocietypublishing.org/cgi/doi/10.1098/rspa.2012.0117
@abstract:
 The chemistry of mechanically interlocked molecules (MIMs), in which two or more covalently linked components are held together by mechanical bonds, has led to the coining of the term mechanostereochemistry to describe a new field of chemistry that embraces many aspects of MIMs, including their syntheses, properties, topologies where relevant and functions where operative. During the rapid development and emergence of the field, the synthesis of MIMs has witnessed the forsaking of the early and grossly inefficient statistical approaches for template-directed protocols, aided and abetted by molecular recognition processes and the tenets of self-assembly. The resounding success of these synthetic protocols, based on templation, has facilitated the design and construction of artificial molecular switches and machines, resulting more and more in the creation of integrated functional systems. This review highlights (i) the range of template-directed synthetic methods being used currently in the preparation of MIMs; (ii) the syntheses of topologically complex knots and links in the form of stable molecular compounds; and (iii) the incorporation of bistable MIMs into many different device settings associated with surfaces, nanoparticles and solid-state materials in response to the needs of particular applications that are perceived to be fair game for mechanostereochemistry.

- **Specific Domain:** Mechanically Interlocked Molecules (MIMs), Template-Directed Synthesis, Molecular Switches, Rotaxanes, Catenanes, and Knots
- **Research Type:** Review Article on the Field of Mechanostereochemistry

**10 Keywords:**

1. Mechanostereochemistry: a new field of chemistry embracing mechanically interlocked molecules (MIMs)
2. Template-directed synthesis of MIMs using molecular recognition processes
3. Self-assembly in the preparation of MIMs and artificial molecular switches
4. Design and construction of integrated functional systems using MIMs
5. Synthesis of topologically complex knots and links in molecular compounds
6. Stable molecular compounds with mechanical bonds, including catenanes, rotaxanes, and knots
7. Incorporation of bistable MIMs into device settings on surfaces, nanoparticles, and solid-state materials
8. Application of mechanostereochemistry to specific fields, such as surface science and nanotechnology
9. Use of molecular recognition in the design and synthesis of MIMs with specific properties
10. Emergence of mechanostereochemistry as a distinct field of chemistry.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the development and application of mechanostereochemistry to the study of mechanically interlocked molecules (MIMs) and their potential uses in device settings. The review highlights the key concepts, methods, and applications of this new field of chemistry.

======== 554 : Stoyanov2009

@title:    Transition metal and nitrogen doped carbon nanostructures
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Engeneering,Folder - carbon graphene,Folder - carbon graphene - Catalyst,graphene,★
@author:   Stoyanov, Stanislav R. and Titov, Alexey V. and Kr{\'{a}}l, Petr
@doi:      10.1016/j.ccr.2009.03.011
@url:      http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S001085450900085X
======== 555 : Fernandez2014

@title:    Fast ignition with laser-driven proton and ion beams
@keywords: Folder - Fusion - fast ignition,★
@author:   Fern{\'{a}}ndez, J.C. and Albright, B.J. and Beg, F.N. and Foord, M.E. and Hegelich, B.M. and Honrubia, J.J. and Roth, M. and Stephens, R.B. and Yin, L.
@doi:      10.1088/0029-5515/54/5/054006
@url:      http://iopscience.iop.org/0029-5515/54/5/054006/article/ http://stacks.iop.org/0029-5515/54/i=5/a=054006?key=crossref.596b2fcaa3a1906b11f9cbb550e286ac
@abstract:
 Fusion fast ignition (FI) initiated by a laser-driven particle beam promises a path to high-yield and high-gain for inertial fusion energy. FI can readily leverage the proven capability of inertial confinement fusion (ICF) drivers, such as the National Ignition Facility, to assemble DT fusion fuel at the relevant high densities. FI provides a truly alternate route to ignition, independent of the difficulties with achieving the ignition hot spot in conventional ICF. FI by laser-driven ion beams provides attractive alternatives that sidestep the present difficulties with laser-driven electron-beam FI, while leveraging the extensive recent progress in generating ion beams with high-power density on existing laser facilities. Whichever the ion species, the ignition requirements are similar: delivering a power density ≈1022 W cm−3 (∼10 kJ in ≈20 ps within a volume of linear dimension ≈20 µm), to the DT fuel compressed to ∼400 g cm−3 with areal density ∼2 g cm−2. High-current, laser-driven beams of many ion species are promising candidates to deliver such high-power densities. The reason is that high energy, high-power laser drivers can deliver high-power fluxes that can efficiently make ion beams that are born neutralized in ∼fs–ps timescales, making them immune to the charge and current limits of conventional beams. In summary, we find that there are many possible paths to success with FI based on laser-driven ion beams. Although many ion species could be used for ignition, we concentrate here on either protons or C ions, which are technologically convenient species. We review the work to date on FI design studies with those species. We also review the tremendous recent progress in discovering, characterizing and developing many ion-acceleration mechanisms relevant to FI. We also summarize key recent technological advances and methods underwriting that progress. Based on the design studies and on the increased understanding of the physics of laser-driven ion acceleration, we provide laser and ion-generation laser-target design points based on several distinct ion-acceleration mechanisms.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Plasma Physics, Fusion Energy, Laser-Matter Interactions
- **Specific Domain:** Fast Ignition (FI) with Laser-Driven Particle Beams, Inertial Confinement Fusion (ICF), High-Power Lasers, Ion Beam Acceleration
- **Research Type:** Review Article on the Feasibility of FI using Laser-Driven Proton and Ion Beams

**10 Keywords:**

1. Fast Ignition (FI) with laser-driven particle beams for inertial fusion energy
2. Alternative route to ignition independent of conventional ICF challenges
3. Leverage existing ICF driver capabilities, such as National Ignition Facility
4. FI initiated by laser-driven proton and ion beams provides attractive alternatives
5. High-power density required for ignition (∼10 kJ in ≈20 ps within a volume of linear dimension ≈20 µm)
6. High-current, laser-driven beams of many ion species promising candidates for delivery
7. Ion acceleration mechanisms relevant to FI, including neutralized ion beams in fs-ps timescales
8. Technological advances and methods underwriting recent progress in ion-acceleration mechanisms
9. Design studies on FI with protons or C ions, technologically convenient species for ignition
10. Laser and ion-generation laser-target design points based on distinct ion-acceleration mechanisms.

These keywords specify the research topic, focusing on the review of FI using laser-driven proton and ion beams as an alternative route to ignition in inertial fusion energy. The article highlights the promising candidates for delivering high-power densities required for ignition, including high-current, laser-driven beams of many ion species.

======== 556 : Wang1995

@title:    Local-density-derived semiempirical pseudopotentials
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs - Theory,icle
@author:   Wang, Lin-Wang and Zunger, Alex
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.51.17398
@url:      http://ebooks.cambridge.org/ref/id/CBO9781107415324A009 http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.51.17398
@abstract:
 Predicting the binding mode of flexible polypeptides to proteins is an important task that falls outside the domain of applicability of most small molecule and protein−protein docking tools. Here, we test the small molecule flexible ligand docking program Glide on a set of 19 non-$\alpha$-helical peptides and systematically improve pose prediction accuracy by enhancing Glide sampling for flexible polypeptides. In addition, scoring of the poses was improved by post-processing with physics-based implicit solvent MM- GBSA calculations. Using the best RMSD among the top 10 scoring poses as a metric, the success rate (RMSD ≤ 2.0 {\AA} for the interface backbone atoms) increased from 21{\%} with default Glide SP settings to 58{\%} with the enhanced peptide sampling and scoring protocol in the case of redocking to the native protein structure. This approaches the accuracy of the recently developed Rosetta FlexPepDock method (63{\%} success for these 19 peptides) while being over 100 times faster. Cross-docking was performed for a subset of cases where an unbound receptor structure was available, and in that case, 40{\%} of peptides were docked successfully. We analyze the results and find that the optimized polypeptide protocol is most accurate for extended peptides of limited size and number of formal charges, defining a domain of applicability for this approach.

======== 559 : Lent1993

@title:    Quantum cellular automata
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Electronics - mQCA
@author:   Lent, C S and Tougaw, P D and Porod, W and Bernstein, G H
@doi:      10.1088/0957-4484/4/1/004

@abstract:
 Quantum cellular automata (QCA) are reviewed, including early and more recent proposals. QCA are a generalization of (classical) cellular automata (CA) and in particular of reversible CA. The latter are reviewed shortly. An overview is given over early attempts by various authors to define one-dimensional QCA. These turned out to have serious shortcomings which are discussed as well. Various proposals subsequently put forward by a number of authors for a general definition of one- and higher-dimensional QCA are reviewed and their properties such as universality and reversibility are discussed.

======== 561 : Cervantes-Sodi2008

@title:    Edge-functionalized and substitutionally doped graphene nanoribbons: Electronic and spin properties
@keywords: Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - Berlin{\_}MSMJ{\_}2013
@author:   Cervantes-Sodi, F. and Cs{\'{a}}nyi, G. and Piscanec, S. and Ferrari, a.
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.77.165427
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.77.165427
======== 562 : Reed2015a

@title:    Neural Programmer-Interpreters
@keywords: Folder - Computers - QuantumComputing
@author:   Reed, Scott and de Freitas, Nando
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1511.06279
@abstract:
 We propose the neural programmer-interpreter (NPI): a recurrent and compositional neural network that learns to represent and execute programs. NPI has three learnable components: a task-agnostic recurrent core, a persistent key-value program memory, and domain-specific encoders that enable a single NPI to operate in multiple perceptually diverse environments with distinct affordances. By learning to compose lower-level programs to express higher-level programs, NPI reduces sample complexity and increases generalization ability compared to sequence-to-sequence LSTMs. The program memory allows efficient learning of additional tasks by building on existing programs. NPI can also harness the environment (e.g. a scratch pad with read-write pointers) to cache intermediate results of computation, lessening the long-term memory burden on recurrent hidden units. In this work we train the NPI with fully-supervised execution traces; each program has example sequences of calls to the immediate subprograms conditioned on the input. Rather than training on a huge number of relatively weak labels, NPI learns from a small number of rich examples. We demonstrate the capability of our model to learn several types of compositional programs: addition, sorting, and canonicalizing 3D models. Furthermore, a single NPI learns to execute these programs and all 21 associated subprograms.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Computer Science
- **Subcategory:** Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, Programming Languages
- **Specific Domain:** Neural Networks, Recurrent Neural Networks, Compositional Programs, Program Execution, Task-Agnostic Reasoning
- **Research Type:** Article on the Proposal of a Neural Programmer-Interpreter (NPI) Model

**10 Keywords:**

1. Neural programmer-interpreter (NPI): a recurrent and compositional neural network for program execution
2. Recurrent core and task-agnostic reasoning in NPI
3. Persistent key-value program memory for efficient learning and caching intermediate results
4. Domain-specific encoders for operating in multiple environments with distinct affordances
5. Compositional programs: addition, sorting, and canonicalizing 3D models learned by a single NPI
6. Reduced sample complexity and increased generalization ability compared to sequence-to-sequence LSTMs
7. Efficient learning of additional tasks by building on existing programs in the program memory
8. Harnessing the environment (e.g., scratch pad with read-write pointers) for caching intermediate results
9. Supervised execution traces for training NPI, rather than weak labels or reinforcement learning
10. Demonstration of a single NPI learning multiple types of compositional programs and associated subprograms.

**Specific Topic:** Neural Networks - NPI

======== 563 : Blair2011a

@title:    Signal Energy in Quantum-Dot Cellular Automata Bit Packets
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Electronics - mQCA,bit packet,cost,fan-out,molecular,qca,quantum-dot cellular automata,★

@doi:      10.1166/jctn.2011.1777
@url:      http://openurl.ingenta.com/content/xref?genre=article{\&}issn=1546-1955{\&}volume=8{\&}issue=6{\&}spage=972
======== 564 : Jaramillo-Botero2011

@title:    Large‐scale, long‐term nonadiabatic electron molecular dynamics for describing material properties and phenomena in extreme environments
@keywords: catalysis,concentration,energetic span model,kinetics,tof
@author:   Jaramillo‐Botero, Andres and Su, Julius and Qi, An and Goddard, William A.
@doi:      10.1002/jcc.21637
@url:      http://doi.wiley.com/10.1002/jcc.21637 https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jcc.21637
@abstract:
 We describe the first principle‐based electron force field (eFF) methodology for modeling the simultaneous dynamics of electrons and nuclei (eMD) evolving nonadiabatically under transient extreme conditions. We introduce the parallel implementation of eFF (pEFF) that makes it practical to perform simulations of the nonadiabatic dynamics of materials in extreme environments involving millions of nuclei and electrons, over multi‐picoseconds time scales, and demonstrate its application to: (i) accurately determine density and predict percent ionization of hydrogen at high pressure (∼61 GPa) and temperatures up to 15,300 K and (ii) determine, the single shock Hugoniot for lithium metal directly from the shock wave kinematics, i.e., mass velocities ( U p ) and shock wave velocities ( U s ), and shock density data. For (i), the density and ionization fractions of hydrogen atoms were calculated using the isobaric–isothermal ensemble at an isotropic pressure of 61.4 GPa and for temperatures between 300 K and 15,300 K. The results at 15,300 K describe a molecular fluid with density $\rho$ = 0.36 g/cm 3 , in close agreement with existing experiments and theory, and ∼0.5{\%} ionization. This result provides no indication of the existence of a critical plasma phase‐transition point at this particular temperature and pressure, as previously predicted by others. For (ii), the relationship between U p and U s was characterized to be linear and plastic in the range 1–20 km/s, and the single shock Hugoniot was determined in close agreement with published results for experimentally reported U p s. In addition to this, we provide a description of the materials' behavior for large U p s in terms of the appearance of a weak metallic plasma phase by U p = 10 km/s, with ≃ 8{\%} ionization, gradually transitioning to a denser plasma with an estimated ≃ 35{\%} ionization by U p = 15 km/s. Last but not least, we confirm the computational efficiency and scalability of pEFF by comparing its single processor performance against the fastest existing serial code, which results in a linear speedup ∼10× faster for every 16,000 particles in favor of pEFF, and by evaluating its parallel performance in terms of its strong and weak scaling capabilities. Our results, on Los Alamos's Lobo supercomputer (a 38TFLOPSs Linux HPC with Quad‐core AMD Opteron nodes interconnected with an Infiniband), show strong scaling with near ideal speedups for loads {\textgreater}62 particles per processor. Weak scaling is shown to be close to linear under the same per‐processor load range. As an absolute reference, an NVT run with 2 million particle lithium bulk system (0.5 M nuclei and 1.5 M electrons) on Lobo takes ∼0.44 s/timestep on 1024 processors (∼1 day/ps using an integration timestep of 0.005 fs). {\textcopyright} 2010 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Comput Chem, 2011

======== 565 : Tao2015

@title:    Silicene field-effect transistors operating at room temperature.
@keywords: Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2015{\_}03{\_}08
@author:   Tao, Li and Cinquanta, Eugenio and Chiappe, Daniele and Grazianetti, Carlo and Fanciulli, Marco and Dubey, Madan and Molle, Alessandro and Akinwande, Deji
@doi:      10.1038/nnano.2014.325
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25643256
@abstract:
 Free-standing silicene, a silicon analogue of graphene, has a buckled honeycomb lattice and, because of its Dirac bandstructure combined with its sensitive surface, offers the potential for a widely tunable two-dimensional monolayer, where external fields and interface interactions can be exploited to influence fundamental properties such as bandgap and band character for future nanoelectronic devices. The quantum spin Hall effect, chiral superconductivity, giant magnetoresistance and various exotic field-dependent states have been predicted in monolayer silicene. Despite recent progress regarding the epitaxial synthesis of silicene and investigation of its electronic properties, to date there has been no report of experimental silicene devices because of its air stability issue. Here, we report a silicene field-effect transistor, corroborating theoretical expectations regarding its ambipolar Dirac charge transport, with a measured room-temperature mobility of ∼100 cm(2) V(-1) s(-1) attributed to acoustic phonon-limited transport and grain boundary scattering. These results are enabled by a growth-transfer-fabrication process that we have devised-silicene encapsulated delamination with native electrodes. This approach addresses a major challenge for material preservation of silicene during transfer and device fabrication and is applicable to other air-sensitive two-dimensional materials such as germanene and phosphorene. Silicene's allotropic affinity with bulk silicon and its low-temperature synthesis compared with graphene or alternative two-dimensional semiconductors suggest a more direct integration with ubiquitous semiconductor technology.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Materials Science, Nanotechnology, Condensed Matter Physics
- **Specific Domain:** Two-Dimensional Materials, Silicene, Graphene Analogues, Field-Effect Transistors (FETs)
- **Research Type:** Article on the Experimental Demonstration of a Silicene Field-Effect Transistor Operating at Room Temperature

**10 Keywords:**

1. Free-standing silicene with buckled honeycomb lattice and Dirac bandstructure
2. Potential for widely tunable two-dimensional monolayer with external field and interface interactions
3. Quantum spin Hall effect, chiral superconductivity, and giant magnetoresistance in silicene
4. Experimental demonstration of silicene field-effect transistor (FET) operating at room temperature
5. Measured room-temperature mobility of ∼100 cm² V⁻¹ s⁻¹ attributed to acoustic phonon-limited transport
6. Grain boundary scattering and ambipolar Dirac charge transport in silicene FETs
7. Growth-transfer-fabrication process for silicene encapsulated delamination with native electrodes
8. Preservation of silicene during transfer and device fabrication using this approach
9. Applicability to other air-sensitive two-dimensional materials such as germanene and phosphorene
10. Integration of silicene with ubiquitous semiconductor technology due to its allotropic affinity with bulk silicon.

======== 569 : Setvin2013a

@title:    Reaction of O2 with subsurface oxygen vacancies on TiO2 anatase (101).
@author:   Setv{\'{i}}n, Martin and Aschauer, Ulrich and Scheiber, Philipp and Li, Ye-Fei and Hou, Weiyi and Schmid, Michael and Selloni, Annabella and Diebold, Ulrike
@doi:      10.1126/science.1239879
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23990556
@abstract:
 Oxygen (O2) adsorbed on metal oxides is important in catalytic oxidation reactions, chemical sensing, and photocatalysis. Strong adsorption requires transfer of negative charge from oxygen vacancies (V(O)s) or dopants, for example. With scanning tunneling microscopy, we observed, transformed, and, in conjunction with theory, identified the nature of O2 molecules on the (101) surface of anatase (titanium oxide, TiO2) doped with niobium. V(O)s reside exclusively in the bulk, but we pull them to the surface with a strongly negatively charged scanning tunneling microscope tip. O2 adsorbed as superoxo (O2(-)) at fivefold-coordinated Ti sites was transformed to peroxo (O2(2-)) and, via reaction with a VO, placed into an anion surface lattice site as an (O2)O species. This so-called bridging dimer also formed when O2 directly reacted with V(O)s at or below the surface.

@title:    Ferroelectric Properties of Porous Silicon
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs,SiNC
@author:   Chen, Q. and Li, X. and Zhang, Y. and Qian, Y.

======== 571 : Walker1993

@title:    Molecular electron density Lego approach to molecule building
@author:   Walker, P. Duane and Mezey, Paul G.
@doi:      10.1021/ja00079a025
@url:      https://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/ja00079a025
@abstract:
 A new method is presented for the construction of ab initio quality approximate electronic charge distributions for large molecules from charge distributions of small molecular fragments. This method is reminiscent to building structures using Lego blocks. The electronic density distribution calculated using the method is quantitatively shown to be very similar to that calculated for entire molecules using conventional ab initio packages with standard basis sets such as 6-31G**, while requiring only a fraction of the computational time. The pre-calculated fuzzy electron distributions of base molecular fragments, stored in a data bank, are merged (rotated, translated, and subsequently added together) to calculate these approximate charge distributions for the molecule. The method requires only the Cartesian coordinates of the nuclei for the construction of molecular charge distributions. The speed of the method makes it potentially useful for molecular modeling applications where construction of electron densities of large molecules is especially important. The technique can be used to replace fused sphere models of large molecules with more realistic electron density contours. One additional advantage is that these contours can be displayed for a whole range of density values, from tight, high-density contours, representing the bonding pattern, to loose, low-density contours representing the peripheral shape and size features of molecules. {\textcopyright} 1993, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

**Classification:**

- **Research Type:** Article on a New Method for Constructing Ab Initio Quality Approximate Electronic Charge Distributions for Large Molecules

**10 Keywords:**

10. Advantages over conventional methods in terms of speed and accuracy.

======== 572 : Lee2019

@title:    Visualizing vibrational normal modes of a single molecule with atomically confined light
@author:   Lee, Joonhee and Crampton, Kevin T. and Tallarida, Nicholas and Apkarian, V. Ara
@doi:      10.1038/s41586-019-1059-9
@url:      http://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-019-1059-9
@abstract:
 The internal vibrations of molecules drive the structural transformations that underpin chemistry and cellular function. While vibrational frequencies are measured by spectroscopy, the normal modes of motion are inferred through theory because their visualization would require microscopy with {\aa}ngstr{\"{o}}m-scale spatial resolution—nearly three orders of magnitude smaller than the diffraction limit in optics1. Using a metallic tip to focus light and taking advantage of the surface-enhanced Raman effect2 to amplify the signal from individual molecules, tip-enhanced Raman spectromicroscopy (TER-SM)3,4 reaches the requisite sub-molecular spatial resolution5, confirming that light can be confined in picocavities6–10 and anticipating the direct visualization of molecular vibrations11–13. Here, by using TER-SM at the precisely controllable junction of a cryogenic ultrahigh-vacuum scanning tunnelling microscope14–16, we show that {\aa}ngstr{\"{o}}m-scale resolution is attained at subatomic separation between the tip atom and a molecule in the quantum tunnelling regime of plasmons6,8,9,17. We record vibrational spectra within a single molecule, obtain images of normal modes and atomically parse the intramolecular charges and currents driven by vibrations. Our analysis provides a paradigm for optics in the atomistic near-field.

======== 573 : Majzik2013

@title:    Combined AFM and STM measurements of a silicene sheet grown on the Ag(111) surface.
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}source - Moje
@author:   Majzik, Zsolt and {Rachid Tchalala}, M. and Svec, M and Hapala, Prokop and Enriquez, Hanna and Kara, Abdelkader and Mayne, Andrew J A.J. and Dujardin, G{\'{e}}rald and Jel{\'{i}}nek, Pavel and Oughaddou, Hamid and Tchalala, M Rachid and {\v{S}}vec, Martin and Hapala, Prokop and Enriquez, Hanna and Kara, Abdelkader and Mayne, Andrew J A.J. and Dujardin, G{\'{e}}rald and Jel{\'{i}}nek, Pavel and Oughaddou, Hamid and {Rachid Tchalala}, M. and {\v{S}}vec, Martin and Hapala, Prokop and Enriquez, Hanna and Kara, Abdelkader and Mayne, Andrew J A.J. and Dujardin, G{\'{e}}rald and Jel{\'{i}}nek, Pavel and Oughaddou, Hamid

@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23674193
@abstract:
 In this paper, we present the first non-contact atomic force microscopy (nc-AFM) of a silicene on a silver (Ag) surface, obtained by combining non-contact atomic force microscopy and scanning tunneling microscopy (STM). STM images over large areas of silicene grown on the Ag(111) surface show both (√13 × √13)R13.9° and (4 × 4) superstructures. For the widely observed (4 × 4) structure, the observed nc-AFM image is very similar to the one recorded by STM. The structure resolved by nc-AFM is compatible with only one out of two silicon atoms being visible. This indicates unambiguously a strong buckling of the silicene honeycomb layer.

======== 574 : Moriarty1997

@title:    First-principles interatomic potentials for transition-metal aluminides: Theory and trends across the {\textless}math display="inline"{\textgreater} {\textless}mn{\textgreater}3{\textless}/mn{\textgreater} {\textless}mi{\textgreater}d{\textless}/mi{\textgreater} {\textless}/math{\textgreater} series
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods - Force Fields
@author:   Moriarty, John A and Widom, Mike
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.56.7905
@url:      http://prb.aps.org/abstract/PRB/v56/i13/p7905{\_}1 http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.56.7905
@abstract:
 In this paper the first-principles generalized pseudopotential theory (GPT) of transition-metal interatomic potentials [J. A. Moriarty, Phys. Rev. B 38, 3199 (1988)] is extended to AB binary compounds and alloys. For general transition-metal (TM) systems, the GPT total-energy functional involves a volume term, central-force pair potentials, and angular-force multi-ion potentials, which are both volume (?) and concentration (x) dependent and include all sp, sp-d, and d-d interactions within local density-functional quantum mechanics. The formalism is developed here in detail for intermetallic systems where A is a simple metal and B is a transition metal and applied to the prominent special case of the transition-metal aluminides TMxAl1-x, where sp-d hybridization is especially important. Emphasis is given to the aluminum-rich 3d binary systems for x{\textless}0.30, which appear to be well described at the pair-potential level without angular forces and for which the present GPT potentials can be used directly in atomistic simulations. Volume terms and pair potentials for all of the 3d aluminides have been calculated and their behavior with atomic number, ?, and x is elaborated through illustrative applications to the cohesive and structural trends across the 3d series. More extensive applications to the Co-Al and Ni-Al phase diagrams will be given elsewhere.

======== 575 : VanEijck1997

@title:    Fast clustering of equivalent structures in crystal structure prediction
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - hashing,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - similarity metic,crystal structure prediction,equivalent structures,fast clustering,organic-compounds,packing
@author:   {Van Eijck}, Bouke P. and Kroon, Jan
@doi:      10.1002/(SICI)1096-987X(199706)18:8<1036::AID-JCC7>3.0.CO;2-U
@url:      http://doi.wiley.com/10.1002/{\%}28SICI{\%}291096-987X{\%}28199706{\%}2918{\%}3A8{\%}3C1036{\%}3A{\%}3AAID-JCC7{\%}3E3.0.CO{\%}3B2-U
@abstract:
 Most methods of crystal structure prediction generate many trial structures. Because these may differ in choice of unit cell, it is not always immediately obvious whether or not two such structures are equivalent. A method to answer this question is described for the case where the asymmetric unit contains one molecule in a general position, defined by the rotation and translation of that molecule with respect to some reference geometry. In the comparison of two structures, the rotation needed to transform one orientation into the other is determined first. Then it is checked whether this rotation corresponds to a transformation that is compatible with the imposed space group symmetry. A final test compares the cell lengths, the cell angles, and the molecular centers of gravity after the transformation of one structure into the other. The method is implemented for triclinic, monoclinic, and orthorhombic systems and is found to be very fast in tests on hypothetical crystal structures of acetic acid. (C) 1997 by John Wiley {\&} Sons, Inc.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Materials Science, Computational Chemistry
- **Specific Domain:** Crystal Structure Prediction, Equivalent Structures, Clustering Algorithms, Organic Compounds, Packing Theory
- **Research Type:** Article on a Method for Fast Clustering of Equivalent Structures in Crystal Structure Prediction

**10 Keywords:**

1. Crystal structure prediction using computational methods
2. Identification and clustering of equivalent structures
3. Rotation and transformation of trial structures to determine equivalence
4. Imposed space group symmetry and compatibility check
5. Final test comparing cell lengths, angles, and molecular centers of gravity
6. Implementation for triclinic, monoclinic, and orthorhombic systems
7. Fast clustering algorithm for large numbers of trial structures
8. Application to hypothetical crystal structures of acetic acid
9. Potential applications in materials science and chemistry research
10. Development of efficient methods for crystal structure prediction.

======== 578 : Lafferentz2012

@title:    Controlling on-surface polymerization by hierarchical and substrate-directed growth
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - SAMs
@author:   Lafferentz, L. and Eberhardt, V. and Dri, C. and Africh, C. and Comelli, G. and Esch, F. and Hecht, S. and Grill, L.
@doi:      10.1038/nchem.1242
@url:      http://www.nature.com/articles/nchem.1242
@abstract:
 A key challenge in the field of nanotechnology, in particular in the design of molecular machines, novel materials or molecular electronics, is the bottom-up construction of covalently bound molecular architectures in a well-defined arrangement. To date, only rather simple structures have been obtained because of the limitation of one-step connection processes. Indeed, for the formation of sophisticated structures, step-by-step connection of molecules is required. Here, we present a strategy for the covalent connection of molecules in a hierarchical manner by the selective and sequential activation of specific sites, thereby generating species with a programmed reactivity. This approach leads to improved network quality and enables the fabrication of heterogeneous architectures with high selectivity. Furthermore, substrate-directed growth and a preferred orientation of the molecular nanostructures are achieved on an anisotropic surface. The demonstrated control over reactivity and diffusion during covalent bond formation constitutes a promising route towards the creation of sophisticated multi-component molecular nanostructures.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry

- **Research Type:** Article on a Strategy for Controlling On-Surface Polymerization by Hierarchical and Substrate-Directed Growth

======== 579 : DeSantana1999

@title:    Green's function calculation of through-bond electronic coupling in donor–bridge–acceptor model systems
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Electronics
@author:   de Santana, O.L. and da Gama, A.A.S.
@doi:      10.1016/S0009-2614(99)01183-5
@url:      http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0009261499011835 https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0009261499011835
======== 580 : Nochebuena2017

@title:    Origin of cooperativity in hydrogen bonding.
@author:   Nochebuena, Jorge and Cuautli, Cristina and Ireta, Joel
@doi:      10.1039/c7cp01695f
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28569317
@abstract:
 The origin of non-additivity in hydrogen bonds (H-bonds), usually termed as H-bond cooperativity, is investigated in H-bonded linear chains. It is shown that H-bond cooperativity originates solely from classical electrostatics. The latter is corroborated by comparing the H-bond cooperativity in infinitely-long H-bonded hydrogen cyanide, 4-pyridone and formamide chains, assessed using density functional theory (DFT), against the strengthening of the dipole-dipole interaction upon the formation of an infinite chain of effective point-dipoles. It is found that the magnitude of these effective point-dipoles is a consequence of mutual polarization and additional effects beyond a polarizable point-dipole model. Nevertheless, the effective point-dipoles are fully determined once a single H-bond is formed, indicating that quantum effects involved in H-bonding are circumscribed to nearest-neighbor interactions only; i.e. in a linear chain of H-bonds, quantum effects do not contribute to the H-bond non-additivity. This finding is verified by estimating cooperativity along the dissociation path of H-bonds in the infinite chains, using two empirical parameters that account for polarizability, together with DFT association energies and molecular dipoles of solely monomers and dimers.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Physical Chemistry, Computational Chemistry
- **Specific Domain:** Hydrogen Bonding, Cooperativity, Electrostatics, Density Functional Theory (DFT), Polarizability, Molecular Interactions
- **Research Type:** Article on the Origin of Cooperativity in Hydrogen Bonding

**10 Keywords:**

1. Hydrogen bonding (H-bond) cooperativity and non-additivity
2. Classical electrostatics as origin of H-bond cooperativity
3. Comparison with density functional theory (DFT) calculations for HCN, 4-pyridone, and formamide chains
4. Effective point-dipole model for dipole-dipole interaction in infinite H-bonded chains
5. Mutual polarization and additional effects beyond polarizable point-dipole model
6. Determination of effective point-dipoles once a single H-bond is formed
7. Quantum effects involved in H-bonding are circumscribed to nearest-neighbor interactions only
8. Estimation of cooperativity along dissociation path of H-bonds using empirical parameters and DFT association energies
9. Verification of findings through calculations for monomers, dimers, and infinite chains
10. Insights into the nature of hydrogen bonding and its cooperativity.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Physical Chemistry

======== 581 : Amsler2010

@title:    Crystal structure prediction using the minima hopping method
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - GlobalOptimizatio
@author:   Amsler, Maximilian and Goedecker, Stefan
@doi:      10.1063/1.3512900
@url:      http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/jcp/133/22/10.1063/1.3512900 http://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.3512900
@abstract:
 A structure prediction method is presented based on the minima hopping method. To escape local minima, moves on the configurational enthalpy surface are performed by variable cell shape molecular dynamics. To optimize the escape steps the initial atomic and cell velocities are aligned to low curvature directions of the current local minimum. The method is applied to both silicon crystals and well-studied binary Lennard-Jones mixtures. For the latter new putative ground state structures are presented. It is shown that a high success rate is achieved and a reliable prediction of unknown ground state structures is possible.

======== 584 : Hybertsen2008

@title:    Amine-linked single-molecule circuits: systematic trends across molecular families.
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM - Gold Stiffness
@author:   Hybertsen, Mark S and Venkataraman, Latha and Klare, Jennifer E and Whalley, Adam C and Steigerwald, Michael L and Nuckolls, Colin
@doi:      10.1088/0953-8984/20/37/374115
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21694422
@abstract:
 A comprehensive review is presented of single-molecule junction conductance measurements across families of molecules measured while breaking a gold point contact in a solution of molecules with amine end groups. A theoretical framework unifies the picture for the amine-gold link bonding and the tunnel coupling through the junction using density functional theory based calculations. The reproducible electrical characteristics and utility for many molecules is shown to result from the selective binding between the gold electrodes and amine link groups through a donor-acceptor bond to undercoordinated gold atoms. While the bond energy is modest, the maximum force sustained by the junction is comparable to, but less than, that required to break gold point contacts. The calculated tunnel coupling provides conductance trends for all 41 molecule measurements presented here, as well as insight into the variability of conductance due to the conformational changes within molecules with torsional degrees of freedom. The calculated trends agree to within a factor of 2 with the measured values for conductance ranging from 10(-7)G(0) to 10(-2)G(0), where G(0) is the quantum of conductance (2e(2)/h).

**Classification:**

**10 Keywords:**

1. Single-molecule junction conductance measurements across molecular families

======== 585 : Koskinen2009

@title:    Density-functional tight-binding for beginners
@keywords: DFTB,Density-functional theory,Electronic structure simulations,Tight-binding
@author:   Koskinen, Pekka and M{\"{a}}kinen, Ville
@doi:      10.1016/j.commatsci.2009.07.013
@url:      http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.commatsci.2009.07.013 https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0927025609003036 http://arxiv.org/abs/0910.5861
@abstract:
 This article is a pedagogical introduction to density-functional tight-binding (DFTB) method. We derive it from the density-functional theory, give the details behind the tight-binding formalism, and give practical recipes for parametrization: how to calculate pseudo-atomic orbitals and matrix elements, and especially how to systematically fit the short-range repulsions. Our scope is neither to provide a historical review nor to make performance comparisons, but to give beginner's guide for this approximate, but in many ways invaluable, electronic structure simulation method--now freely available as an open-source software package, hotbit.

======== 588 : Kulish2016a

@title:    F1 rotary motor of ATP synthase is driven by the torsionally-asymmetric drive shaft
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Engeneering - Molecular Motors,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Stochastic Nanomachines - m
@author:   Kulish, O. and Wright, a. D. and Terentjev, E. M.
@doi:      10.1038/srep28180
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1601.08078 http://www.nature.com/articles/srep28180
@abstract:
 F1F0 ATP synthase (ATPase) either facilitates the synthesis of ATP in the mitochondrial membranes and bacterial inner membranes in a process driven by the proton moving force (pmf), or uses the energy from ATP hydrolysis to pump protons against the concentration gradient across the membrane. ATPase is composed of two rotary motors, F0 and F1, which generate the opposing rotation and compete for control of their shared central gamma-shaft. Here we present a self-consistent physical model of the F1 motor as a simplified two-state Brownian ratchet based on the asymmetry of torsional elastic energy of the coiled-coil gamma-shaft. This stochastic model unifies the physical description of linear and rotary motors and explains the stepped unidirectional rotation of the {\$}\backslashgamma{\$}-shaft, in agreement with the `binding-change' ideas of Boyer. Substituting the model parameters, all independently known from recent experiments, our model quantitatively reproduces the ATPase operation, e.g. the `no-load' angular velocity is ca. 400{\~{}}rad/s anticlockwise at 4 mM ATP, in close agreement with experiment. Increasing the pmf torque exerted by F0 can slow, stop and overcome the torque generated by F1, switching from ATP hydrolysis to synthesis at a very low value of `stall torque'. We discuss the matters of the motor efficiency, which is very low if calculated from the useful mechanical work it produces - but is quite high when the `useful outcome' is measured in the number of H+ pushed against the chemical gradient in the F1 ATP-driven operation.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Biology
- **Subcategory:** Molecular Biology, Biochemistry
- **Specific Domain:** Molecular Motors, ATP Synthase, Mitochondrial Function, Bacterial Inner Membranes
- **Research Type:** Article on a Physical Model of the F1 Rotary Motor of ATP Synthase

**10 Keywords:**

1. F1F0 ATP synthase (ATPase) and its rotary motors
2. Torsionally-asymmetric drive shaft in the F1 motor
3. Simplified two-state Brownian ratchet model for the F1 motor
4. Unification of physical description of linear and rotary motors
5. Stepped unidirectional rotation of the gamma-shaft explained by binding-change ideas
6. Quantitative reproduction of ATPase operation using independently known model parameters
7. No-load angular velocity and stall torque values calculated from the model
8. Discussion on motor efficiency, measured in mechanical work or number of H+ pushed against chemical gradient
9. Potential implications for understanding mitochondrial function and bacterial inner membrane processes
10. Stochastic models for molecular motors and their applications.

**Specific Topic:** Biology - Molecular Biology

Recent advances in combining quantum-mechanical calculations with machine learning provide powerful tools for exploring wide swathes of chemical compound space. We present our perspective on this exciting and quickly developing field by discussing key advances in the development and applications of quantum-mechanics-based machine-learning methods to diverse compounds and properties, and outlining the challenges ahead. We argue that significant progress in the exploration and understanding of chemical compound space can be made through a systematic combination of rigorous physical theories, comprehensive synthetic data sets of microscopic and macroscopic properties, and modern machine-learning methods that account for physical and chemical knowledge. ======== 595 : Orlov2012

@title:    Experimental Test of Landauer's Principle at the Sub-{\$}k{\_}{\{}\backslashtext{\{}B{\}}{\}} T{\$} Level
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Electronics - mQCA,Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2014{\_}11{\_}03
@author:   Orlov, Alexei O. and Lent, Craig S. and Thorpe, Cameron C. and Boechler, Graham P. and Snider, Gregory L.
@doi:      10.1143/JJAP.51.06FE10
@url:      http://stacks.iop.org/1347-4065/51/06FE10
======== 596 : Neuman2018c

@title:    Coupling of Molecular Emitters and Plasmonic Cavities beyond the Point-Dipole Approximation
@author:   Neuman, Tom{\'{a}}{\v{s}} and Esteban, Ruben and Casanova, David and Garc{\'{i}}a-Vidal, Francisco J. and Aizpurua, Javier
@doi:      10.1021/acs.nanolett.7b05297
@url:      https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.nanolett.7b05297
@abstract:
 As the size of a molecular emitter becomes comparable to the dimensions of a nearby optical resonator, the standard approach that considers the emitter to be a point-like dipole breaks down. By adoption of a quantum description of the electronic transitions of organic molecular emitters, coupled to a plasmonic electromagnetic field, we are able to accurately calculate the position-dependent coupling strength between a plasmon and an emitter. The spatial distribution of excitonic and photonic quantum states is found to be a key aspect in determining the dynamics of molecular emission in ultrasmall cavities both in the weak and strong coupling regimes. Moreover, we show that the extreme localization of plasmonic fields leads to the selection rule breaking of molecular excitations.

======== 598 : Greengard1987

@title:    A fast algorithm for particle simulations
@keywords: Folder - Algorithms - Nbody,L. Greengard and V. Rokhlin
@author:   Greengard, L and Rokhlin, V and Rokhlin, L. Greengard and V.
@doi:      10.1016/0021-9991(87)90140-9
@url:      http://ac.els-cdn.com/0021999187901409/1-s2.0-0021999187901409-main.pdf?{\_}tid=679b26b0-5ae4-11e5-8234-00000aacb361{\&}acdnat=1442237454{\_}f6867439347a63629fe376b91185a193{\%}5Cnhttp://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0021999187901409
@abstract:
 An algorithm is presented for the rapid evaluation of the potential and force fields in systems involving large numbers of particles whose interactions are Coulombic or gravitational in nature. For a system of N particles, an amount of work of the order O(N2) has traditionally been required to evaluate all pairwise interactions, unless some approximation or truncation method is used. The algorithm of the present paper requires an amount of work proportional to N to evaluate all interactions to within roundoff error, making it considerably more practical for large-scale problems encountered in plasma physics, fluid dynamics, molecular dynamics, and celestial mechanics.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Computational Physics, Algorithms, Particle Simulations
- **Specific Domain:** N-body Problems, Coulombic Interactions, Gravitational Interactions, Fast Algorithm for Evaluating Potential and Force Fields
- **Research Type:** Article on a Novel Algorithm for Rapid Evaluation of Pairwise Interactions in Large-Scale Particle Systems

**10 Keywords:**

1. Fast algorithm for particle simulations involving large numbers of particles
2. Coulombic or gravitational interactions between particles
3. Traditional O(N^2) complexity for evaluating pairwise interactions
4. Novel algorithm requiring only O(N) work to evaluate all interactions
5. Applications in plasma physics, fluid dynamics, molecular dynamics, and celestial mechanics
6. Rapid evaluation of potential and force fields in large-scale particle systems

======== 599 : Municha

@title:    G ¨ odel Machines : Towards a Technical Justification of Consciousness
@keywords: Folder - Artificial{\_}Inteligence{\_}Robotocs - Creativ
@author:   Munich, T U
======== 600 : Leonidas2007

@title:    Please wait ...
@author:   Leonidas, John C and Ver o ppt diretamente and Leonidas, John C
@doi:      10.1148/radiol.2421060140
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17185678
@abstract:
 In order to determine the role of subregions of the hippocampus in spatial working memory, this study combined selective neurotoxic lesions of the hippocampal subregions with a simple delayed nonmatching-to-place task on a radial maze in rats. Lesions of the dentate gyrus or the CA3, but not the CA1, subregion of the hippocampus induced a deficit in the acquisition of the task with short-term delays (i.e., 10 sec) and impaired performance of the task in a novel environment. All subregional lesions produced sustained impairment in performing the task with intermediate-term delays (i.e., 5 min) when rats were tested in a familiar environment. The results suggest a dynamic interaction among the dorsal hippocampal subregions in processing spatial working memory, with the time window (i.e., delay) of a task recognized as an essential controlling factor.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Biology
- **Subcategory:** Neuroscience, Psychology
- **Specific Domain:** Hippocampus, Spatial Working Memory, Neurotoxic Lesions, Animal Behavior (Rats)
- **Research Type:** Article on the Role of Hippocampal Subregions in Spatial Working Memory

**10 Keywords:**

1. Spatial working memory and hippocampal subregions
2. Selective neurotoxic lesions of dentate gyrus and CA3 subregions
3. Deficits in delayed nonmatching-to-place task with short-term delays (10 sec)
4. Impaired performance in novel environment after subregional lesions
5. Sustained impairment in performing task with intermediate-term delays (5 min) in familiar environment
6. Dynamic interaction among dorsal hippocampal subregions in processing spatial working memory
7. Essential role of time window (delay) in controlling task performance
8. Hippocampal CA1 subregion not affected by lesions
9. Implications for understanding neural mechanisms of spatial working memory

======== 601 : DAvezac2012a

@title:    Genetic-Algorithm Discovery of a Direct-Gap and Optically Allowed Superstructure from Indirect-Gap Si and Ge Semiconductors
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs
@author:   D'Avezac, Mayeul and Luo, Jun-Wei and Chanier, Thomas and Zunger, Alex
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevLett.108.027401
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.108.027401
======== 602 : Berger2016

@title:    Study of Ferrocene Dicarboxylic Acid on Substrates of Varying Chemical Activity
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - Examples of syste
@author:   Berger, J. and Ko{\'{s}}mider, K. and Stetsovych, O. and Vondr{\'{a}}{\v{c}}ek, M. and Hapala, P. and Spadafora, E.J. J. and {\v{S}}vec, M. and Jel{\'{i}}nek, P.
@doi:      10.1021/acs.jpcc.6b05978
@url:      https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.jpcc.6b05978 http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acs.jpcc.6b05978
@abstract:
 Ferrocene-based molecules are extremely appealing as they offer a prospect of having built-in spin or charge functionality. However, there are only limited number of studies of structural and electronic properties on surfaces so far. We investigated the self-assembly processes of 1,1′-ferrocene dicarboxylic acid molecules (C12H10FeO4) on both metallic (Ag(111), Au(111), and Cu(110)) and insulating (Cu3N/Cu(110)) surfaces with high-resolution ncAFM/STM, XPS, and NEXAFS. The experimental evidence is corroborated with total energy DFT calculations and ncAFM simulations. The combined experimental and theoretical analysis allows detailed understanding of the unique arrangement and adsorption geometries of the molecules on different substrates, as well as the different chemical stability of the carboxylic (COOH) groups. The molecules on noble (Ag, Au) surfaces show only a weak interaction with the substrate forming a complex self-assembled pattern, driven by weak intermolecular interactions. In contrast, the analysis reveals the carboxylic groups undergo dehydrogenation on the Cu(110) and Cu3N/Cu(110). As a result, the oxygen atoms form strong chemical bonds to the substrate Cu atoms and impose an orientation on the ferrocene cyclopentadienyl rings perpendicular to the substrate.

======== 603 : Gong2003a

@title:    Double-Network Hydrogels with Extremely High Mechanical Strength
@keywords: Folder - Materials
@author:   Gong, J.P. and Katsuyama, Y. and Kurokawa, T. and Osada, Y.
@doi:      10.1002/adma.200304907

======== 604 : Kissel2014

@title:    A nanoporous two-dimensional polymer by single-crystal-to-single-crystal photopolymerization
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - SAMs
@author:   Kissel, Patrick and Murray, Daniel J. and Wulftange, William J. and Catalano, Vincent J. and King, Benjamin T.
@doi:      10.1038/nchem.2008
@url:      http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nchem.2008
@abstract:
 In contrast to the wide number and variety of available synthetic routes to conventional linear polymers, the synthesis of two-dimensional polymers and unambiguous proof of their structure remains a challenge. Two-dimensional polymers—single-layered polymers that form a tiling network in exactly two dimensions—have potential for use in nanoporous membranes and other applications. Here, we report the preparation of a fluorinated hydrocarbon two-dimensional polymer that can be exfoliated into single sheets, and its characterization by high-resolution single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The procedure involves three steps: preorganization in a lamellar crystal of a rigid monomer bearing three photoreactive arms, photopolymerization of the crystalline monomers by [4 + 4] cycloaddition, and isolation of individual two-dimensional polymer sheets. This polymer is a molecularly thin ({\~{}}1 nm) material that combines precisely defined monodisperse pores of {\~{}}9 {\AA} with a high pore density of 3.3 × 1013 pores cm−2. Atomic-resolution single-crystal X-ray structures of the monomer, an intermediate dimer and the final crystalline two-dimensional polymer were obtained and prove the single-crystal-to-single-crystal nature and molecular precision of the two-dimensional photopolymerization.

- **Research Type:** Article on the Preparation and Characterization of a Nanoporous Two-Dimensional Polymer

**10 Keywords:**

1. Synthesis of two-dimensional polymers by single-crystal-to-single-crystal photopolymerization
2. Preparation of a fluorinated hydrocarbon two-dimensional polymer with nanopores
3. High-resolution single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis for structural characterization
4. Use of preorganized monomers with photoreactive arms for efficient photopolymerization
5. [4 + 4] cycloaddition as the photopolymerization mechanism
6. Isolation of individual two-dimensional polymer sheets for further study
7. Characterization of the nanoporous material's structure and properties
8. Potential applications in fields such as membrane technology, catalysis, and energy storage
9. Importance of molecular precision and single-crystal-to-single-crystal nature of the photopolymerization process
