======== 773 : Barja2016

@title:    Charge density wave order in 1D mirror twin boundaries of single-layer MoSe2
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM
@author:   Barja, Sara and Wickenburg, Sebastian and Liu, Zhen-fei and Zhang, Yi and Ryu, Hyejin and Ugeda, Miguel M. and Hussain, Zahid and Shen, Zhi-Xun and Mo, Sung-kwan and Wong, Ed and Salmeron, Miquel B. and Wang, Feng and Crommie, Michael F and Ogletree, D Frank and Neaton, Jeffrey B. and Weber-Bargioni, Alexander
@doi:      10.1038/nphys3730
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1603.05558 http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nphys3730 http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nphys3730
@abstract:
 Properties of two-dimensional transition metal dichalcogenides are highly sensitive to the presence of defects in the crystal structure. A detailed understanding of defect structure may lead to control of material properties through defect engineering. Here we provide direct evidence for the existence of isolated, one-dimensional charge density waves at mirror twin boundaries in single-layer MoSe2. Our low-temperature scanning tunneling microscopy/spectroscopy measurements reveal a substantial bandgap of 60 - 140 meV opening at the Fermi level in the otherwise one dimensional metallic structure. We find an energy-dependent periodic modulation in the density of states along the mirror twin boundary, with a wavelength of approximately three lattice constants. The modulations in the density of states above and below the Fermi level are spatially out of phase, consistent with charge density wave order. In addition to the electronic characterization, we determine the atomic structure and bonding configuration of the one-dimensional mirror twin boundary by means of high-resolution non-contact atomic force microscopy. Density functional theory calculations reproduce both the gap opening and the modulations of the density of states.

**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Specific Domain:** Two-Dimensional Transition Metal Dichalcogenides (TMDs), Charge Density Wave Order, Mirror Twin Boundaries
- **Research Type:** Experimental Investigation of Electronic Properties using Scanning Tunneling Microscopy/Spectroscopy

**10 Keywords:**

1. Charge density wave order in 1D mirror twin boundaries of single-layer MoSe2
2. Defect structure and properties of two-dimensional transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs)
3. Direct evidence for isolated, one-dimensional charge density waves at mirror twin boundaries
4. Low-temperature scanning tunneling microscopy/spectroscopy measurements revealing a substantial bandgap
5. Energy-dependent periodic modulation in the density of states along the mirror twin boundary
6. Density functional theory calculations reproducing both gap opening and modulations of the density of states
7. High-resolution non-contact atomic force microscopy determining the atomic structure and bonding configuration
8. Electronic characterization of the one-dimensional metallic structure at mirror twin boundaries
9. Spatial out-of-phase modulation in the density of states above and below the Fermi level consistent with charge density wave order
10. Implications for defect engineering and control of material properties in TMDs.

**Specific Topic:** Materials Science - Condensed Matter Physics

**Note:** The article provides direct evidence for the existence of isolated, one-dimensional charge density waves at mirror twin boundaries in single-layer MoSe2 using low-temperature scanning tunneling microscopy/spectroscopy measurements. The results reveal a substantial bandgap and energy-dependent periodic modulation in the density of states, which is consistent with charge density wave order. Density functional theory calculations reproduce both the gap opening and modulations of the density of states.

======== 781 : SanPaulo2000

@title:    High-resolution imaging of antibodies by tapping-mode atomic force microscopy: attractive and repulsive tip-sample interaction regimes.
@keywords: Folder - SPM - supramolecular
@author:   {San Paulo}, a and Garc{\'{i}}a, R
@doi:      10.1016/S0006-3495(00)76712-9
@abstract:
 A force microscope operated with an amplitude modulation feedback (usually known as tapping-mode atomic force microscope) has two tip-sample interaction regimes, attractive and repulsive. We have studied the performance of those regimes to imaging single antibody molecules. The attractive interaction regime allows determination of the basic morphologies of the antibodies on the support. More importantly, this regime is able to resolve the characteristic Y-shaped domain structure of antibodies and the hinge region between domains. Imaging in the repulsive interaction regime is associated with the irreversible deformation of the molecules. This causes a significant loss in resolution and contrast. Two major physical differences distinguish the repulsive interaction regime from the attractive interaction regime: the existence of tip-sample contact and the strength of the forces involved.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Biophysics
- **Subcategory:** Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM), Molecular Recognition, Single Molecule Imaging
- **Specific Domain:** Supramolecular Assemblies, Antibody Structure and Dynamics
- **Research Type:** Experimental Investigation of AFM Imaging Regimes

**10 Keywords:**

1. High-resolution imaging of antibodies by tapping-mode atomic force microscopy
2. Attractive and repulsive tip-sample interaction regimes in AFM
3. Single molecule imaging of antibody molecules using AFM
4. Determination of basic morphologies of antibodies on the support
5. Resolution of characteristic Y-shaped domain structure of antibodies
6. Hinge region between domains resolved by attractive interaction regime
7. Irreversible deformation of molecules in repulsive interaction regime
8. Loss of resolution and contrast in repulsive interaction regime
9. Physical differences between attractive and repulsive interaction regimes
10. Importance of tip-sample contact and force strength in AFM imaging.

**Specific Topic:** Biophysics - Atomic Force Microscopy

**Note:** The article explores the performance of two tip-sample interaction regimes (attractive and repulsive) in tapping-mode atomic force microscopy for high-resolution imaging of single antibody molecules. The results show that the attractive regime allows determination of basic morphologies, characteristic Y-shaped domain structure, and hinge region between domains, while the repulsive regime is associated with irreversible deformation, loss of resolution, and contrast.

@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM - PTCDA

@url:      http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0009261402007741
======== 785 : Jung2004

@title:    Scaled opposite-spin second order M{\o}ller–Plesset correlation energy: An economical electronic structure method
@author:   Jung, Yousung and Lochan, Rohini C. and Dutoi, Anthony D. and Head-Gordon, Martin
@doi:      10.1063/1.1809602
@url:      https://pubs.aip.org/aip/jcp/article/121/20/9793-9802/532630
@abstract:
 A simplified approach to treating the electron correlation energy is suggested in which only the $\alpha$-$\beta$ component of the second order M{\o}ller-Plesset energy is evaluated, and then scaled by an empirical factor which is suggested to be 1.3. This scaled opposite-spin second order energy (SOS-MP2), where MP2 is M{\o}ller-Plesset theory, yields results for relative energies and derivative properties that are statistically improved over the conventional MP2 method. Furthermore, the SOS-MP2 energy can be evaluated without the fifth order computational steps associated with MP2 theory, even without exploiting any spatial locality. A fourth order algorithm is given for evaluating the opposite spin MP2 energy using auxiliary basis expansions, and a Laplace approach, and timing comparisons are given. {\textcopyright} 2004 American Institute of Physics.

**Specific Topic:** Theoretical Chemistry - Computational Methods

This method involves evaluating only the $\alpha$-$\beta$ component of the MP2 energy, scaling it by an empirical factor, and eliminating fifth order computational steps. The results show that SOS-MP2 yields improved relative energies and derivative properties compared to conventional MP2, making it a more efficient alternative for electronic structure calculations.

======== 788 : Barth2001

@title:    Contrast Formation in Atomic Resolution Scanning Force Microscopy on {\{}CaF{\$}{\_}2{\$}{\}}(111): Experiment and Theory
@author:   Barth, C and Foster, A S and Reichling, M and Shluger, A L
======== 789 : Morawietz2012

@title:    A neural network potential-energy surface for the water dimer based on environment-dependent atomic energies and charges
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods - Neural{\_}Networks
@author:   Morawietz, Tobias and Sharma, Vikas and Behler, Jörg
@doi:      10.1063/1.3682557
@url:      http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/jcp/136/6/10.1063/1.3682557
@abstract:
 Understanding the unique properties of water still represents a significant challenge for theory and experiment. Computer simulations by molecular dynamics require a reliable description of the atomic interactions, and in recent decades countless water potentials have been reported in the literature. Still, most of these potentials contain significant approximations, for instance a frozen internal structure of the individual water monomers.Artificial neural networks (NNs) offer a promising way for the construction of very accurate potential-energysurfaces taking all degrees of freedom explicitly into account. These potentials are based on electronic structure calculations for representative configurations, which are then interpolated to a continuous energy surface that can be evaluated many orders of magnitude faster. We present a full-dimensional NN potential for the water dimer as a first step towards the construction of a NN potential for liquid water. This many-body potential is based on environment-dependent atomic energy contributions, and long-range electrostatic interactions are incorporated employing environment-dependent atomic charges. We show that the potential and derived properties like vibrational frequencies are in excellent agreement with the underlying reference density-functional theory calculations.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Computational Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs), Potential-Energy Surfaces (PES), Molecular Dynamics Simulations
- **Specific Domain:** Water-Water Interactions, DFT-Based Potentials, Environment-Dependent Atomic Energies and Charges
- **Research Type:** Development of a New Computational Method

**10 Keywords:**

1. Neural network potential-energy surface for the water dimer
2. Environment-dependent atomic energies and charges in molecular interactions
3. Construction of a full-dimensional NN potential for liquid water
4. Use of electronic structure calculations for representative configurations as reference data
5. Interpolation to a continuous energy surface for fast evaluation
6. Comparison with underlying reference density-functional theory (DFT) calculations
7. Evaluation of vibrational frequencies and other derived properties
8. Improvement over previous water potentials with frozen internal structure approximations
9. Potential applications in molecular dynamics simulations, materials science, and chemistry
10. Future directions for developing more accurate NN potentials for complex systems.

**Specific Topic:** Computational Chemistry - Artificial Neural Networks

**Note:** The article presents a new approach to constructing a potential-energy surface (PES) for the water dimer using artificial neural networks (ANNs). The method takes into account environment-dependent atomic energies and charges, allowing for more accurate simulations of molecular interactions. The results show excellent agreement with reference DFT calculations and highlight the potential of ANNs in developing more accurate PES models for complex systems like liquid water.

======== 790 : Frantsuzov2008

@title:    Universal emission intermittency in quantum dots, nanorods and nanowires
@author:   Frantsuzov, Pavel and Kuno, Masaru and Jank{\'{o}}, Boldizs{\'{a}}r and Marcus, Rudolph a.
@doi:      10.1038/nphys1001
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/0810.2509 http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nphys1001
@abstract:
 Virtually all known fluorophores, including semiconductor nanoparticles, nanorods and nanowires exhibit unexplainable episodes of intermittent emission blinking. A most remarkable feature of the fluorescence intermittency is a universal power law distribution of on- and off-times. For nanoparticles the resulting power law extends over an extraordinarily wide dynamic range: nine orders of magnitude in probability density and five to six orders of magnitude in time. The exponents hover about the ubiquitous value of -3/2. Dark states routinely last for tens of seconds, which are practically forever on quantum mechanical time scales. Despite such infinite states of darkness, the dots miraculously recover and start emitting again. Although the underlying mechanism responsible for this phenomenon remains an enduring mystery and many questions remain, we argue that substantial theoretical progress has been made.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Condensed Matter Physics
- **Subcategory:** Quantum Mechanics, Nanophotonics, Semiconductor Nanoparticles

- **Research Type:** Theoretical Analysis or Review Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Universal emission intermittency in semiconductor nanoparticles
2. Power law distribution of on- and off-times in quantum dot emission
3. Wide dynamic range of probability density and time scales
4. Exponents hovering around the value of -3/2 for power law distributions
5. Dark states lasting tens of seconds, but potentially "forever" from a quantum perspective
6. Mechanism behind fluorescence intermittency remains an open question
7. Theoretical progress made in understanding this phenomenon
8. Potential applications in nanophotonics and optoelectronics
9. Implications for our understanding of quantum mechanics at the nanoscale
10. Future directions for research into the underlying mechanisms.

**Specific Topic:** Condensed Matter Physics - Nanophotonics

**Note:** The article presents a theoretical analysis or review of the phenomenon of fluorescence intermittency in semiconductor nanoparticles, including quantum dots, nanorods, and nanowires. It highlights the universal power law distribution of on- and off-times, which extends over an extremely wide dynamic range. Despite the lack of understanding of the underlying mechanism, substantial progress has been made, and the article argues for further research into this intriguing phenomenon.

@title:    Consistent approaches to van der Waals radii for the metallic elements
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM - forcefield
@author:   Hu, Sheng-Zhi and Zhou, Zhao-Hui and Robertson, B. E.
@doi:      10.1524/zkri.2009.1158
@url:      http://www.degruyter.com/view/j/zkri.2009.224.issue-8/zkri.2009.1158/zkri.2009.1158.xml
======== 793 : Wales1997

@title:    Global Optimization by Basin-Hopping and the Lowest Energy Structures of Lennard-Jones Clusters Containing up to 110 Atoms
@keywords: Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2016{\_}03{\_}21 - references{\_}Glob,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021
@author:   Wales, David J. and Doye, Jonathan P. K.
@doi:      10.1021/jp970984n
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/cond-mat/9803344 http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/jp970984n https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/jp970984n
@abstract:
 We describe a global optimization technique using `basin-hopping' in which the potential energy surface is transformed into a collection of interpenetrating staircases. This method has been designed to exploit the features which recent work suggests must be present in an energy landscape for efficient relaxation to the global minimum. The transformation associates any point in configuration space with the local minimum obtained by a geometry optimization started from that point, effectively removing transition state regions from the problem. However, unlike other methods based upon hypersurface deformation, this transformation does not change the global minimum. The lowest known structures are located for all Lennard-Jones clusters up to 110 atoms, including a number that have never been found before in unbiased searches.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Computational Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Global Optimization Algorithms, Molecular Clusters, Potential Energy Surfaces (PES)

- **Research Type:** Development of a New Computational Method

**10 Keywords:**

1. Global optimization technique using basin-hopping algorithm
2. Transformation of potential energy surface into interpenetrating staircases
3. Elimination of transition state regions from the problem
4. Preservation of global minimum in the transformation process
5. Application to Lennard-Jones clusters up to 110 atoms
6. Location of new lowest known structures for clusters of different sizes
7. Comparison with previous unbiased searches and identification of novel structures
8. Potential energy surface deformation methods, such as basin-hopping, are explored
9. Understanding the global minimum structure and its properties is crucial in cluster studies
10. Implications of this work on understanding cluster behavior and designing new materials.

**Specific Topic:** Computational Chemistry - Global Optimization

**Note:** The article presents a novel global optimization technique using the basin-hopping algorithm, which transforms the potential energy surface into interpenetrating staircases to facilitate efficient relaxation to the global minimum. This method is applied to Lennard-Jones clusters up to 110 atoms and successfully locates new lowest known structures for clusters of different sizes. The results demonstrate the power of this approach in understanding cluster behavior and designing new materials.

======== 794 : Yam2010

@title:    Towards a high fidelity direct transcription method for optimisation of low-thrust trajectories
@keywords: 6,Folder - Space{\_}Tech - OrbitalTransfer,Folder - Space{\_}Tech - OrbitalTransfer - pyKEP,direct opti-,integration,low-thrust trajectories,mesh adaptation,methods in place of,misaton,ployed runge-kutta-fehlberg scheme,reducing the,the commonly em-
@author:   Yam, CH and Izzo, Dario and Biscani, Francesco
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1004.4539
======== 795 : Kim2015

@title:    Imaging and three-dimensional reconstruction of chemical groups inside a protein complex using atomic force microscopy.
@keywords: Folder - SPM - supramolecular,Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2015{\_}03{\_}08
@author:   Kim, Duckhoe and Sahin, Ozgur
@doi:      10.1038/nnano.2014.335
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25664622
@abstract:
 Scanning probe microscopes can be used to image and chemically characterize surfaces down to the atomic scale. However, the localized tip-sample interactions in scanning probe microscopes limit high-resolution images to the topmost atomic layer of surfaces, and characterizing the inner structures of materials and biomolecules is a challenge for such instruments. Here, we show that an atomic force microscope can be used to image and three-dimensionally reconstruct chemical groups inside a protein complex. We use short single-stranded DNAs as imaging labels that are linked to target regions inside a protein complex, and T-shaped atomic force microscope cantilevers functionalized with complementary probe DNAs allow the labels to be located with sequence specificity and subnanometre resolution. After measuring pairwise distances between labels, we reconstruct the three-dimensional structure formed by the target chemical groups within the protein complex using simple geometric calculations. Experiments with the biotin-streptavidin complex show that the predicted three-dimensional loci of the carboxylic acid groups of biotins are within 2 {\AA} of their respective loci in the corresponding crystal structure, suggesting that scanning probe microscopes could complement existing structural biological techniques in solving structures that are difficult to study due to their size and complexity.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Biophysics
- **Subcategory:** Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM), Scanning Probe Microscopy (SPM), Molecular Imaging
- **Specific Domain:** Protein Structure, Supramolecular Assembly, DNA-Protein Interactions
- **Research Type:** Development of a New Method

**10 Keywords:**

1. Imaging and three-dimensional reconstruction of chemical groups inside proteins using AFM
2. Use of short single-stranded DNAs as imaging labels for protein complexes
3. T-shaped atomic force microscope cantilevers functionalized with complementary probe DNAs
4. Sequence-specific localization of imaging labels within protein complexes

6. Reconstruction of three-dimensional structure formed by target chemical groups

9. Potential applications in structural biology and materials science
10. Method complements existing techniques for solving difficult-to-study structures.

**Specific Topic:** Biophysics - Atomic Force Microscopy

**Note:** The article presents a novel method using atomic force microscopy to image and three-dimensionally reconstruct chemical groups inside protein complexes with subnanometre resolution. This is achieved by linking short single-stranded DNAs to target regions within the complex and using T-shaped cantilevers functionalized with complementary probe DNAs for sequence-specific localization. The reconstructed structures show good agreement with crystallographic data, suggesting that this method could complement existing structural biology techniques in solving difficult-to-study structures.

======== 798 : Li2017

@title:    Metal Ion Modeling Using Classical Mechanics
@author:   Li, Pengfei and Merz, Kenneth M.
@doi:      10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00440
@url:      https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00440
@abstract:
 Metal ions play significant roles in numerous fields including chemistry, geochemistry, biochemistry, and materials science. With computational tools increasingly becoming important in chemical research, methods have emerged to effectively face the challenge of modeling metal ions in the gas, aqueous, and solid phases. Herein, we review both quantum and classical modeling strategies for metal ion-containing systems that have been developed over the past few decades. This Review focuses on classical metal ion modeling based on unpolarized models (including the nonbonded, bonded, cationic dummy atom, and combined models), polarizable models (e.g., the fluctuating charge, Drude oscillator, and the induced dipole models), the angular overlap model, and valence bond-based models. Quantum mechanical studies of metal ion-containing systems at the semiempirical, ab initio, and density functional levels of theory are reviewed as well with a particular focus on how these methods inform classical modeling efforts. Finally, conclusions and future prospects and directions are offered that will further enhance the classical modeling of metal ion-containing systems.

- **Research Type:** Review Article

5. Comparison between quantum and classical modeling approaches
6. Importance of metal ions in chemistry, geochemistry, biochemistry, and materials science
7. Computational tools for chemical research
8. Classical models (nonbonded, bonded, cationic dummy atom, combined)
9. Polarizable models (fluctuating charge, Drude oscillator, induced dipole)
10. Future directions for classical modeling of metal ion-containing systems.

**Specific Topic:** Computational Chemistry - Metal Ion Modeling

**Note:** The article is a review of both quantum and classical modeling strategies for metal ion-containing systems. ======== 799 : Ternes2011

@title:    Interplay of Conductance, Force, and Structural Change in Metallic Point Contacts
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}source - Moje
@author:   Ternes, Markus and Gonz{\'{a}}lez, C{\'{e}}sar and Lutz, C.P. Christopher P. and Hapala, Prokop and Giessibl, Franz J F.J. Franz J. and Jel{\'{i}}nek, Pavel and Heinrich, A.J. Andreas J.
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevLett.106.016802
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.106.016802
@abstract:
 The coupling between two atomically sharp nanocontacts provides tunable access to a fundamental underlying interaction: the formation of the bond between two atoms as they are brought into contact. Here we report a detailed experimental and theoretical analysis of the relation between the chemical force and the tunneling current during bond formation in atom-scale metallic junctions and their dependence on distance, junction structure, and material. We found that the short-range force as well as the conductance in two prototypical metal junctions depend exponentially on the distance and that they have essentially the same exponents. In the transition regime between tunneling and point contact, large short-range forces generate structural relaxations which are concomitant with modifications of the surface electronic structure and the collapse of the tunneling barrier. {\textcopyright} 2010 The American Physical Society.

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Specific Domain:** Metallic Point Contacts, Interplay of Conductance, Force, and Structural Change
- **Research Type:** Experimental and Theoretical Analysis

**10 Keywords:**

1. Interplay of conductance, force, and structural change in metallic point contacts
2. Atomically sharp nanocontacts for tunable access to bond formation between two atoms
3. Coupling between two atomically sharp nanocontacts during bond formation
4. Dependence of chemical force and tunneling current on distance, junction structure, and material
5. Exponential dependence of short-range force and conductance on distance
6. Same exponents for short-range force and conductance in two prototypical metal junctions
7. Transition regime between tunneling and point contact generates large short-range forces
8. Structural relaxations concomitant with modifications of surface electronic structure and collapse of tunneling barrier
9. Experimental and theoretical analysis of bond formation in atom-scale metallic junctions
10. Fundamental underlying interaction: formation of bond between two atoms as they are brought into contact.

**Specific Topic:** Condensed Matter Physics - Nanotechnology

**Note:** The article presents a detailed experimental and theoretical analysis of the interplay between conductance, force, and structural change during bond formation in atom-scale metallic junctions. The study reveals an exponential dependence of short-range force and conductance on distance and demonstrates the collapse of the tunneling barrier during transition from tunneling to point contact.

@doi:      10.1021/acs.nanolett.5b05251
@url:      http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acs.nanolett.5b05251
======== 806 : Isayev2016a

@title:    Universal Fragment Descriptors for Predicting Electronic Properties of Inorganic Crystals
@keywords: Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2017{\_}07{\_}03,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Behler
@author:   Isayev, Olexandr and Oses, Corey and Toher, Cormac and Gossett, Eric and Curtarolo, Stefano and Tropsha, Alexander
@doi:      10.1038/ncomms15679
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1608.04782
@abstract:
 Historically, materials discovery has been driven by a laborious trial-and-error process. The growth of materials databases and emerging informatics approaches finally offer the opportunity to transform this practice into data- and knowledge-driven rational design. By using data from the AFLOW repository for high-throughput ab-initio calculations, we have generated Quantitative Materials Structure-Property Relationship (QMSPR) models to predict eight critical electronic and thermomechanical materials properties, such as the metal/insulator classification, band gap energy, bulk and shear moduli, Debye temperature, and heat capacity. The prediction accuracy obtained with these QMSPR models approaches training data for virtually any stoichiometric inorganic crystalline material. The success and universality of these models is attributed to the construction of new materials descriptors---referred to as the universal Property-Labeled Materials Fragments (PLMF). The representation requires only minimal structural input and affords straightforward model interpretation in terms of simple heuristic design rules that guide rational materials design. This study demonstrates the power of materials informatics to dramatically accelerate the search for new materials.

@title:    Nuclear salt water rockets - High thrust at 10,000 sec I(sp)
@keywords: Folder - Space{\_}Tech - space propulsion,★

@doi:      10.2514/6.1990-2371
@url:      http://arc.aiaa.org/doi/abs/10.2514/6.1990-2371
======== 809 : Vazquez2012

@title:    Probing the conductance superposition law in single-molecule circuits with parallel paths
@author:   Vazquez, H. and Skouta, R. and Schneebeli, S. and Kamenetska, M. and Breslow, R. and Venkataraman, L. and Hybertsen, M.S.
@doi:      10.1038/nnano.2012.147
@url:      http://www.nature.com/articles/nnano.2012.147
@abstract:
 According to Kirchhoff's circuit laws, the net conductance of two parallel components in an electronic circuit is the sum of the individual conductances. However, when the circuit dimensions are comparable to the electronic phase coherence length, quantum interference effects play a critical role, as exemplified by the Aharonova-Bohm effect in metal rings. At the molecular scale, interference effects dramatically reduce the electron transfer rate through a meta-connected benzene ring when compared with a para-connected benzene ring. For longer conjugated and cross-conjugated molecules, destructive interference effects have been observed in the tunnelling conductance through molecular junctions. Here, we investigate the conductance superposition law for parallel components in single-molecule circuits, particularly the role of interference. We synthesize a series of molecular systems that contain either one backbone or two backbones in parallel, bonded together cofacially by a common linker on each end. Single-molecule conductance measurements and transport calculations based on density functional theory show that the conductance of a double-backbone molecular junction can be more than twice that of a single-backbone junction, providing clear evidence for constructive interference.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Condensed Matter Physics
- **Subcategory:** Single-Molecule Electronics, Quantum Interference Effects
- **Specific Domain:** Conductance Superposition Law, Parallel Components in Electronic Circuits
- **Research Type:** Experimental and Theoretical Study

**10 Keywords:**

1. Probing the conductance superposition law in single-molecule circuits with parallel paths
2. Investigating the role of quantum interference effects on electron transfer rate
3. Synthesizing molecular systems with one or two backbones in parallel for conductance measurements
4. Single-molecule conductance measurements using density functional theory calculations
5. Evidence for constructive interference in double-backbone molecular junctions
6. Conductance of double-backbone junctions more than twice that of single-backbone junctions
7. Quantum interference effects in metal rings and molecular systems
8. Aharonov-Bohm effect and its relevance to this study
9. Electron transfer rate through meta-connected benzene ring reduced by destructive interference
10. Importance of understanding quantum interference effects in electronic circuits.

**Specific Topic:** Condensed Matter Physics - Single-Molecule Electronics

**Note:** The article presents an experimental and theoretical study on the conductance superposition law for parallel components in single-molecule circuits, with a focus on the role of quantum interference effects. The authors synthesize molecular systems with one or two backbones in parallel and measure their conductance using density functional theory calculations. The results provide evidence for constructive interference in double-backbone molecular junctions, which is not predicted by classical circuit laws.

======== 810 : Ellner2019

@title:    Molecular Identification, Bond Order Discrimination, and Apparent Intermolecular Features in Atomic Force Microscopy Studied with a Charge Density Based Method
@keywords: CO molecule,DFT,bond order,chemical identification,hydrogen bonds,non-contact atomic force microscopy,tip functionalization

@url:      https://doi.org/10.1021/acsnano.8b08209
@abstract:
 We introduce an efficient method to simulate high-resolution atomic force microscopy (HR-AFM) images with CO probes. Our model explicitly takes into account the charge densities of the sample and the probe for the calculation of the short-range (SR) interaction and retains ab initio accuracy with only two parameters, that are essentially universal, independent of the number of chemical species and the complexity of the bonding topology. The application to molecular images shows a strong dependence on the stoichiometry and bonding configuration that precludes the chemical identification of individual atoms based on local force--distance curves. However, we have identified features in the 2D images and 3D force maps that reflect the highly anisotropic spatial decay of the molecular charge density and provide a way towards molecular identification. The model treats SR and electrostatics interactions on an equal footing and correctly pinpoints the Pauli repulsion as the underlying interaction responsible for ...

@title:    ELECTRICAL TRANSPORT IN
@keywords: Folder - ElectronTransport,Folder - World{\_}Problems - food
@author:   Ventra, Massimiliano Di
======== 814 : Allahverdyan2013

@title:    Understanding quantum measurement from the solution of dynamical models
@keywords: Apparatus,Collapse of the wavefunction,Decoherence,Dynamical models,Folder - Information{\_}physics,Ideal and imperfect measurements,Pointer,Quantum measurement problem,Reduction,Registration,Statistical interpretation,Truncation
@author:   Allahverdyan, Armen E. and Balian, Roger and Nieuwenhuizen, Theo M.
@doi:      10.1016/j.physrep.2012.11.001
@url:      http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0370157312004085
@abstract:
 The quantum measurement problem, to wit, understanding why a unique outcome is obtained in each individual experiment, is currently tackled by solving models. After an introduction we review the many dynamical models proposed over the years for elucidating quantum measurements. The approaches range from standard quantum theory, relying for instance on quantum statistical mechanics or on decoherence, to quantum-classical methods, to consistent histories and to modifications of the theory. Next, a flexible and rather realistic quantum model is introduced, describing the measurement of the z-component of a spin through interaction with a magnetic memory simulated by a Curie-Weiss magnet, including N ??? 1 spins weakly coupled to a phonon bath. Initially prepared in a metastable paramagnetic state, it may transit to its up or down ferromagnetic state, triggered by its coupling with the tested spin, so that its magnetization acts as a pointer. A detailed solution of the dynamical equations is worked out, exhibiting several time scales. Conditions on the parameters of the model are found, which ensure that the process satisfies all the features of ideal measurements. Various imperfections of the measurement are discussed, as well as attempts of incompatible measurements. The first steps consist in the solution of the Hamiltonian dynamics for the spin-apparatus density matrix over(D, ??) (t). Its off-diagonal blocks in a basis selected by the spin-pointer coupling, rapidly decay owing to the many degrees of freedom of the pointer. Recurrences are ruled out either by some randomness of that coupling, or by the interaction with the bath. On a longer time scale, the trend towards equilibrium of the magnet produces a final state over(D, ??) (tf) that involves correlations between the system and the indications of the pointer, thus ensuring registration. Although over(D, ??) (tf) has the form expected for ideal measurements, it only describes a large set of runs. Individual runs are approached by analyzing the final states associated with all possible subensembles of runs, within a specified version of the statistical interpretation. There the difficulty lies in a quantum ambiguity: There exist many incompatible decompositions of the density matrix over(D, ??) (tf) into a sum of sub-matrices, so that one cannot infer from its sole determination the states that would describe small subsets of runs. This difficulty is overcome by dynamics due to suitable interactions within the apparatus, which produce a special combination of relaxation and decoherence associated with the broken invariance of the pointer. Any subset of runs thus reaches over a brief delay a stable state which satisfies the same hierarchic property as in classical probability theory; the reduction of the state for each individual run follows. Standard quantum statistical mechanics alone appears sufficient to explain the occurrence of a unique answer in each run and the emergence of classicality in a measurement process. Finally, pedagogical exercises are proposed and lessons for future works on models are suggested, while the statistical interpretation is promoted for teaching. ?? 2012 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

@title:    Theory of the quantum confinement effect on excitons in quantum dots of indirect-gap materials

======== 816 : Martonak2003

@title:    Predicting Crystal Structures: The Parrinello-Rahman Method Revisited
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - GlobalOptimizatio
@author:   Martoň{\'{a}}k, R. and Laio, A and Parrinello, M
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevLett.90.075503
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.90.075503
@abstract:
 By suitably adapting a recent approach [A. Laio and M. Parrinello, Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 99, 12 562 (2002)]] we develop a powerful molecular dynamics method for the study of pressure-induced structural transformations. We use the edges of the simulation cell as collective variables and define a metadynamics that drives the system away from the local minimum towards a new crystal structure. In contrast to the Parrinello-Rahman method, our approach shows no hysteresis, and crystal structure transformations can occur at the equilibrium pressure. We illustrate the power of the method by studying the pressure-induced diamond to simple hexagonal phase transition in a model of silicon.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Materials Science

**Note:** The article presents a new approach to predicting crystal structures, building upon the Parrinello-Rahman method but with significant improvements. By using collective variables and metadynamics, the authors develop an efficient method that eliminates hysteresis and allows for the prediction of crystal structure transformations at equilibrium pressure. ======== 817 : Bitzek2006

@title:    Structural Relaxation Made Simple
@keywords: Algorithms,Chemical,Fenretinide,Fenretinide: chemistry,Fire,Folder - Numerics - Optimalization - Gradient,MD,Models,Molecular Conformation,Thermodynamics,gradient,★
@author:   Bitzek, Erik and Koskinen, Pekka and G{\"{a}}hler, Franz and Moseler, Michael and Gumbsch, Peter
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevLett.97.170201
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23005357 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17155444 http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.97.170201
@abstract:
 We introduce a simple local atomic structure optimization algorithm which is significantly faster than standard implementations of the conjugate gradient method and often competitive with more sophisticated quasi-Newton schemes typically used in ab initio calculations. It is based on conventional molecular dynamics with additional velocity modifications and adaptive time steps. The surprising efficiency and especially the robustness and versatility of the method is illustrated using a variety of test cases from nanoscience, solid state physics, materials research, and biochemistry.

@title:    ReaxFF Potential Functions

@title:    Topological insulators
@keywords: Folder - Theory
@author:   National, Berkeley
======== 827 : Wang2017

@title:    Molecular weaving via surface-templated epitaxy of crystalline coordination networks.
@keywords: Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2017{\_}07{\_}03,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021
@author:   Wang, Zhengbang and B?aszczyk, Alfred and Fuhr, Olaf and Heissler, Stefan and W?ll, Christof and Mayor, Marcel
@doi:      10.1038/ncomms14442
@url:      http://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms14442 http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/ncomms14442
@abstract:
 One of the dream reactions in polymer chemistry is the bottom-up, self-assembled synthesis of polymer fabrics, with interwoven, one-dimensional fibres of monomolecular thickness forming planar pieces of textiles. We have made a major step towards realizing this goal by assembling sophisticated, quadritopic linkers into surface-mounted metal-organic frameworks. By sandwiching these quadritopic linkers between sacrificial metal-organic framework thin films, we obtained multi-heteroepitaxial, crystalline systems. In a next step, Glaser-Hay coupling of triple bonds in the quadritopic linkers yields linear, interwoven polymer chains. X-ray diffraction studies revealed that this topochemical reaction leaves the MOF backbone completely intact. After removing the metal ions, the textile sheets can be transferred onto different supports and imaged using scanning electron microscopy and atomic-force microscopy. The individual polymer strands forming the two-dimensional textiles have lengths on the order of 200 nm, as evidenced by atomic-force microscopy images recorded from the disassembled textiles.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Materials Science, Polymer Chemistry
- **Specific Domain:** Surface-Templated Epitaxy of Crystalline Coordination Networks
- **Research Type:** Development of New Methodology

**10 Keywords:**

1. Molecular weaving via surface-templated epitaxy of crystalline coordination networks
2. Self-assembled synthesis of polymer fabrics with monomolecular thickness fibers
3. Quadritopic linkers assembled into surface-mounted metal-organic frameworks
4. Multi-heteroepitaxial, crystalline systems obtained by sandwiching quadritopic linkers
5. Glaser-Hay coupling of triple bonds in quadritopic linkers yields linear polymer chains
6. X-ray diffraction studies reveal topochemical reaction leaves MOF backbone intact
7. Individual polymer strands forming 2D textiles have lengths on the order of 200 nm
8. Atomic-force microscopy images record from disassembled textiles demonstrate fiber structure
9. Transferable, textile sheets can be imaged using scanning electron microscopy and AFM
10. Surface-templated epitaxy method enables production of crystalline polymer networks.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Materials Science

**Note:** The article presents a novel approach to molecular weaving, enabling the synthesis of planar pieces of textiles with interwoven, one-dimensional fibers of monomolecular thickness. This is achieved through surface-templated epitaxy of crystalline coordination networks, where quadritopic linkers are assembled into multi-heteroepitaxial systems and then subjected to topochemical reactions to produce linear polymer chains. The resulting textile sheets can be transferred onto different supports and imaged using microscopy techniques, demonstrating the feasibility of this approach for producing crystalline polymer networks.

======== 828 : Giraud-Carrier2004a

@title:    Optimal Ordered Problem Solver
@keywords: Folder - Artificial{\_}Inteligence{\_}Robotocs - Creativ,bias-optimality,efficient planning and backtracking,in,incremental optimal universal search,metasearching and metalearning,oops,program space,self-improvement
@author:   Giraud-Carrier, Christophe and Vilalta, Ricardo and Brazdil, Pavel
@abstract:
 We introduce a general and in a certain sense time-optimal way of solving one problem after another, efficiently searching the space of programs that compute solution candidates, including those programs that organize and manage and adapt and reuse earlier acquired knowledge. The Optimal Ordered Problem Solver (OOPS) draws inspiration from Levin's Universal Search designed for single problems and universal Turing machines. It spends part of the total search time for a new problem on testing programs that exploit previous solution-computing programs in computable ways. If the new problem can be solved faster by copy-editing/invoking previous code than by solving the new problem from scratch, then OOPS will find this out. If not, then at least the previous solutions will not cause much harm. We introduce an efficient, recursive, backtracking-based way of implementing OOPS on realistic computers with limited storage. Experiments illustrate how OOPS can greatly profit from metalearning or metasearching, that is, searching for faster search procedures. Keywords: OOPS, bias-optimality, incremental optimal universal search, efficient planning and backtracking in program space, metasearching and metalearning, self-improvement

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Computer Science
- **Subcategory:** Artificial Intelligence, Automated Reasoning
- **Specific Domain:** Optimal Problem Solving, Meta-Learning and Meta-Searching
- **Research Type:** Development of New Algorithm

**10 Keywords:**

1. Optimal Ordered Problem Solver (OOPS) introduced for solving one problem after another
2. Time-optimal way of searching program space for solution candidates and exploiting previous knowledge
3. Draws inspiration from Levin's Universal Search for single problems and universal Turing machines
4. OOPS spends part of search time testing programs that exploit previous solution-computing programs
5. Efficient, recursive, backtracking-based implementation on realistic computers with limited storage
6. Experiments illustrate profit from meta-learning or metasearching, searching for faster search procedures
7. Bias-optimality and incremental optimal universal search techniques used in OOPS
8. Efficient planning and backtracking in program space enabled by OOPS
9. Metasearching and metalearning capabilities of OOPS allow self-improvement over time
10. Optimal problem solving via exploitation of previous knowledge and learning.

**Specific Topic:** Computer Science - Artificial Intelligence

**Note:** The article presents a novel approach to optimal problem solving, introducing the Optimal Ordered Problem Solver (OOPS) that efficiently searches program space for solution candidates and exploits previous knowledge in computable ways. OOPS is based on Levin's Universal Search and incorporates bias-optimality, incremental optimal universal search, efficient planning, backtracking, metasearching, and metalearning techniques to enable self-improvement over time. Experiments illustrate the benefits of using OOPS for solving problems efficiently and adapting to changing conditions.

======== 830 : Riss2014a

@title:    Supplementary: Local Electronic and Chemical Structure of Oligo-acetylene Derivatives Formed Through Radical Cyclizations at a Surface
@keywords: Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2014{\_}07{\_}28,Supplementary,as well as their,c1,c5 thermal enediyne cyclization,conducting polymers,considerable interest,density functional theory,dft,into their fundamental properties,nc-afm,noncontact atomic force microscopy,onjugated polymers have attracted,potential,radical step-growth polymerization,scanning tunneling microscopy,stm
@author:   Riss, Alexander and Wickenburg, Sebastian and Gorman, Patrick and Tan, Liang Z LZ and Tsai, Hsin-Zon and de Oteyza, Dimas G and Chen, Yen-Chia and Bradley, Aaron J and Ugeda, Miguel M and Etkin, Grisha and Louie, Steven G and Fischer, Felix R and Crommie, Michael F
@doi:      10.1021/nl403791q
@url:      http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=4022646{\&}tool=pmcentrez{\&}rendertype=abstract http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/nl403791q
@abstract:
 Semiconducting $\pi$-conjugated polymers have attracted significant interest for applications in light-emitting diodes, field-effect transistors, photovoltaics, and nonlinear optoelectronic devices. Central to the success of these functional organic materials is the facile tunability of their electrical, optical, and magnetic properties along with easy processability and the outstanding mechanical properties associated with polymeric structures. In this work we characterize the chemical and electronic structure of individual chains of oligo-(E)-1,1'-bi(indenylidene), a polyacetylene derivative that we have obtained through cooperative C1-C5 thermal enediyne cyclizations on Au(111) surfaces followed by a step-growth polymerization of the (E)-1,1'-bi(indenylidene) diradical intermediates. We have determined the combined structural and electronic properties of this class of oligomers by characterizing the atomically precise chemical structure of individual monomer building blocks and oligomer chains (via noncontact atomic force microscopy (nc-AFM)), as well as by imaging their localized and extended molecular orbitals (via scanning tunneling microscopy and spectroscopy (STM/STS)). Our combined structural and electronic measurements reveal that the energy associated with extended $\pi$-conjugated states in these oligomers is significantly lower than the energy of the corresponding localized monomer orbitals, consistent with theoretical predictions.

This work contributes to our understanding of the properties and behavior of polyacetylene derivatives and their potential applications in organic electronics and materials science.

======== 833 : Liu2013

@title:    Investigation of photosynthetic membrane structure using atomic force microscopy.
@keywords: Atomic Force,Atomic Force: methods,Bacteria,Bacteria: chemistry,Bacteria: metabolism,Bacteria: ultrastructure,Cell Membrane,Cell Membrane: chemistry,Cell Membrane: metabolism,Cell Membrane: ultrastructure,Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2015{\_}06{\_}29 - ambient{\_}AFM,Microscopy,Microscopy- Atomic Force,Microscopy- Atomic Force: methods,Photosynthesis,Photosynthetic Reaction Center Complex Proteins,Photosynthetic Reaction Center Complex Proteins: c,Photosynthetic Reaction Center Complex Proteins: m,Photosynthetic Reaction Center Complex Proteins: u
@author:   Liu, Lu-Ning and Scheuring, Simon
@doi:      10.1016/j.tplants.2013.03.001
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23562040
@abstract:
 Photosynthetic processes, including light capture, electron transfer, and energy conversion, are not only ensured by the activities of individual photosynthetic complexes but also substantially determined and regulated by the composition and assembly of the overall photosynthetic apparatus at the supramolecular level. In recent years, atomic force microscopy (AFM) has matured as a unique and powerful tool for directly assessing the supramolecular assembly of integral membrane protein complexes in their native membrane environment at submolecular resolution. This review highlights the major contributions and advances of AFM studies to our understanding of the structure of the bacterial photosynthetic machinery and its regulatory arrangement during chromatic adaptation. AFM topographs of other biological membrane systems and potential future applications of AFM are also discussed.

======== 835 : Terrones2012a

@title:    The role of defects and doping in 2D graphene sheets and 1D nanoribbons.
@keywords: Crystallization,Crystallization: methods,Folder - carbon graphene - Defects,Graphite,Graphite: chemistry,Macromolecular Substances,Macromolecular Substances: chemistry,Materials Testing,Molecular Conformation,Nanostructures,Nanostructures: chemistry,Nanostructures: ultrastructure,Nanotechnology,Nanotechnology: methods,Particle Size,Surface Properties
@author:   Terrones, Humberto and Lv, Ruitao and Terrones, Mauricio and Dresselhaus, Mildred S
@doi:      10.1088/0034-4885/75/6/062501
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22790648
@abstract:
 Defects are usually seen as imperfections in materials that could significantly degrade their performance. However, at the nanoscale, defects could be extremely useful since they could be exploited to generate novel, innovative and useful materials and devices. Graphene and graphene nanoribbons are no exception. This review therefore tries to categorize defects, emphasize their importance, introduce the common routes to study and identify them and to propose new ways to construct novel devices based on 'defective' graphene-like materials. In particular, we will discuss defects in graphene-like systems including (a) structural (sp(2)-like) defects, (b) topological (sp(2)-like) defects, (c) doping or functionalization (sp(2)- and sp(3)-like) defects and (d) vacancies/edge type defects (non-sp(2)-like). It will be demonstrated that defects play a key role in graphene physicochemical properties and could even be critical to generate biocompatible materials. There are numerous challenges in this emerging field, and we intend to provide a stimulating account which could trigger new science and technological developments based on defective graphene-like materials that could be introduced into other atomic layered materials, such as BN, MoS(2) and WS(2), not discussed in this review.

@keywords: Folder - sctructural{\_}tech - MaterialScience - fieb
@author:   Northolt, M G and Sikkema, D J and Zegers, H C and Klop, E A
======== 839 : Yazdani1996a

@title:    Off-Resonance Conduction Through Atomic Wires
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM - Xe-tip
@author:   Yazdani, a. and Eigler, D. M. and Lang, N. D.
@doi:      10.1126/science.272.5270.1921
@abstract:
 The electrical resistance of wires consisting of either a single xenon atom or two xenon atoms in series was measured and calculated on the basis of an atom-jellium model. Both the measurement and the calculation yielded a resistance of 10(5) ohms for the single-xenon atom system and 10(7) ohms for the two-xenon atom system. These resistances greatly exceeded the 12,900-ohm resistance of an ideal one-dimensional conduction channel because conduction through the xenon atoms occurs through the tail of the xenon 6s resonance, which lies far above the Fermi level. This conduction process in an atom-sized system can now be understood in terms of the electronic states of individual atoms.

======== 840 : Lee2005a

@title:    Comparison of Multi-Objective Genetic Algorithms in Optimizing Q-Law Low-Thrust Orbit Transfers
@keywords: Folder - Space - Orbits - OrbitalTransfer,low-thrust orbit transfer,multi-objective genetic algorithms,non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm,orbital transfer,q-law
@author:   Lee, Seungwon and Fink, Wolfgang and Petropoulos, Anastassios E and Terrile, Richard J
======== 841 : Dolezal2022

@title:    Real Space Visualization of Entangled Excitonic States in Charged Molecular Assemblies
@keywords: AFM,PTCDA,STM-induced luminescence,STML,delocalization,entanglement,exciton
@author:   Dole{\v{z}}al, Jiř{\'{i}} and Canola, Sofia and Hapala, Prokop and {de Campos Ferreira}, Rodrigo Cezar R.C. and Merino, Pablo and {\v{S}}vec, Martin
@doi:      10.1021/acsnano.1c08816
@url:      https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acsnano.1c08816
@abstract:
 Entanglement of excitons holds great promise for the future of quantum computing, which would use individual molecular dyes as building blocks of their circuitry. Even though entangled excitonic eigenstates emerging in coupled molecular assemblies can be detected by far-field spectroscopies, access to the individual modes in real space will bring the much needed insight into the photophysics of these fascinating quantum phenomena. Here we combine tip-enhanced spectromicroscopy with atomic force microscopy to inspect delocalized single-exciton states of charged molecular assemblies engineered from individual perylenetetracarboxylic dianhydride molecules. Hyperspectral mapping of the eigenstates and comparison with calculated many-body optical transitions reveals a second low-lying excited state of the anion monomers and its role in the exciton entanglement within the assemblies. We also demonstrate control over the coupling by switching the assembly charge states. Our results reveal the possibility of tailoring excitonic properties of organic dye aggregates for advanced functionalities and establish the methodology to address them individually at the nanoscale.

======== 842 : Husband2003

@title:    Logic and memory with nanocell circuits
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Electronics - Nanocell,Folder - Molecular Electronics - molecular{\_}circuit
@author:   Husband, CP
@doi:      10.1109/TED.2003.815860
@url:      http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpls/abs{\_}all.jsp?arnumber=1224487 http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/lpdocs/epic03/wrapper.htm?arnumber=1224487
======== 843 : Marek2014a

@title:    The ELPA library: scalable parallel eigenvalue solutions for electronic structure theory and computational science.
@keywords: Folder - Algorithms - LinearAlgebra - Sparse Solve,Folder - FHI-aims
@author:   Marek, a and Blum, V and Johanni, R and Havu, V and Lang, B and Auckenthaler, T and Heinecke, a and Bungartz, H-J and Lederer, H
@doi:      10.1088/0953-8984/26/21/213201
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24786764
@abstract:
 Obtaining the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of large matrices is a key problem in electronic structure theory and many other areas of computational science. The computational effort formally scales as O(N(3)) with the size of the investigated problem, N (e.g. the electron count in electronic structure theory), and thus often defines the system size limit that practical calculations cannot overcome. In many cases, more than just a small fraction of the possible eigenvalue/eigenvector pairs is needed, so that iterative solution strategies that focus only on a few eigenvalues become ineffective. Likewise, it is not always desirable or practical to circumvent the eigenvalue solution entirely. We here review some current developments regarding dense eigenvalue solvers and then focus on the Eigenvalue soLvers for Petascale Applications (ELPA) library, which facilitates the efficient algebraic solution of symmetric and Hermitian eigenvalue problems for dense matrices that have real-valued and complex-valued matrix entries, respectively, on parallel computer platforms. ELPA addresses standard as well as generalized eigenvalue problems, relying on the well documented matrix layout of the Scalable Linear Algebra PACKage (ScaLAPACK) library but replacing all actual parallel solution steps with subroutines of its own. For these steps, ELPA significantly outperforms the corresponding ScaLAPACK routines and proprietary libraries that implement the ScaLAPACK interface (e.g. Intel's MKL). The most time-critical step is the reduction of the matrix to tridiagonal form and the corresponding backtransformation of the eigenvectors. ELPA offers both a one-step tridiagonalization (successive Householder transformations) and a two-step transformation that is more efficient especially towards larger matrices and larger numbers of CPU cores. ELPA is based on the MPI standard, with an early hybrid MPI-OpenMPI implementation available as well. Scalability beyond 10,000 CPU cores for problem sizes arising in the field of electronic structure theory is demonstrated for current high-performance computer architectures such as Cray or Intel/Infiniband. For a matrix of dimension 260,000, scalability up to 295,000 CPU cores has been shown on BlueGene/P.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Computer Science
- **Subcategory:** Algorithms, Linear Algebra
- **Specific Domain:** High-Performance Computing, Parallel Computing
- **Research Type:** Research Review, Software Development

**10 Keywords:**

1. Efficient eigenvalue solutions for electronic structure theory and computational science
2. Scalable parallel eigenvalue solvers for large matrices
3. ELPA library facilitates algebraic solution of symmetric and Hermitian eigenvalue problems
4. Parallel computation on CPU platforms using MPI standard
5. Hybrid MPI-OpenMPI implementation available in ELPA library
6. One-step tridiagonalization (successive Householder transformations) vs. two-step transformation
7. Efficient reduction of matrix to tridiagonal form and backtransformation of eigenvectors
8. ELPA outperforms ScaLAPACK and proprietary libraries for large-scale eigenvalue problems
9. Scalability demonstrated on high-performance computer architectures (Cray, Intel/Infiniband)
10. Large-scale eigenvalue solutions enabled by ELPA library for electronic structure theory.

**Specific Topic:** Computer Science - Algorithms

**Note:** The article reviews the current state of dense eigenvalue solvers and presents the Eigenvalue soLvers for Petascale Applications (ELPA) library, which facilitates efficient algebraic solution of symmetric and Hermitian eigenvalue problems on parallel computer platforms. ELPA is designed to outperform existing libraries such as ScaLAPACK and proprietary implementations, enabling large-scale eigenvalue solutions for electronic structure theory and other areas of computational science. The article highlights the scalability and performance of ELPA on current high-performance computer architectures.

@title:    Module‐based design method using clocking scheme for quantum‐dot cellular automata
@author:   Deng, Feifei and Xie, Guangjun and Zhang, Yongqiang and Chen, Song
@doi:      10.1002/cta.3185
@url:      https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cta.3185
======== 846 : Lochan2005

@title:    Scaled opposite spin second order M{\o}ller-Plesset theory with improved physical description of long-range dispersion interactions
@author:   Lochan, Rohini C. and Jung, Yousung and Head-Gordon, Martin
@doi:      10.1021/jp0514426
@abstract:
 Separate scaling of the same-spin and opposite spin contributions to the second-order M{\o}ller-Plesset energy can yield statistically improved performance for a variety of chemical problems. If only the opposite spin contribution is scaled, it is also possible to reduce the computational complexity from fifth order to fourth order in system size, with very little degradation of the results. However neither of these scaled MP2 energies recovers the full MP2 result for the dispersion energy of nonoverlapping systems. This deficiency is addressed in this work by using a distance-dependent scaling of the opposite spin correlation energy. The resulting method is compared against the previously proposed scaled MP2 methods on a range of problems involving both short and long-range interactions. {\textcopyright} 2005 American Chemical Society.

======== 848 : Zhang2021a

@title:    Chemical Identification and Bond Control of $\pi$-Skeletons in a Coupling Reaction
@author:   Zhang, Chi and Jaculbia, Rafael B. and Tanaka, Yusuke and Kazuma, Emiko and Imada, Hiroshi and Hayazawa, Norihiko and Muranaka, Atsuya and Uchiyama, Masanobu and Kim, Yousoo
@doi:      10.1021/jacs.1c02624
@url:      https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/jacs.1c02624
@abstract:
 Highly unsaturated I -rich carbon skeletons afford versatile tuning of structural and optoelectronic properties of low-dimensional carbon nanostructures. However, methods allowing more precise chemical identification and controllable integration of target sp-/sp2-carbon skeletons during synthesis are required. Here, using the coupling of terminal alkynes as a model system, we demonstrate a methodology to visualize and identify the generated I -skeletons at the single-chemical-bond level on the surface, thus enabling further precise bond control. The characteristic electronic features together with localized vibrational modes of the carbon skeletons are resolved in real space by a combination of scanning tunneling microscopy/spectroscopy (STM/STS) and tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (TERS). Our approach allows single-chemical-bond understanding of unsaturated carbon skeletons, which is crucial for generating low-dimensional carbon nanostructures and nanomaterials with atomic precision.

@doi:      10.1002/smll.201200477

======== 852 : Cimrman2018

@title:    Isogeometric analysis in electronic structure calculations
@keywords: Density functional theory,Electronic structure calculation,Finite element method,Isogeometric analysis
@author:   Cimrman, Robert and Nov{\'{a}}k, Maty{\'{a}}{\v{s}} and Kolman, Radek and Tůma, Miroslav and Vack{\'{a}}ř, Jiř{\'{i}}
@doi:      10.1016/j.matcom.2016.05.011
@abstract:
 In electronic structure calculations, various material properties can be obtained by means of computing the total energy of a system as well as derivatives of the total energy w.r.t. atomic positions. The derivatives, also known as Hellman–Feynman forces, require, because of practical computational reasons, the discretized charge density and wave functions having continuous second derivatives in the whole solution domain. We describe an application of isogeometric analysis (IGA), a spline modification of finite element method (FEM), to achieve the required continuity. The novelty of our approach is in employing the technique of B{\'{e}}zier extraction to add the IGA capabilities to our FEM based code for ab initio calculations of electronic states of non-periodic systems within the density-functional framework, built upon the open source finite element package SfePy. We compare FEM and IGA in benchmark problems and several numerical results are presented.

4. Bézier extraction technique for IGA capabilities
5. Ab initio calculations of electronic states with SfePy
6. Hellman–Feynman forces in electronic structure calculations
7. Computational requirements for charge density and wave functions
8. Continuity of second derivatives in discretized charge density and wave functions
9. Numerical results comparing FEM and IGA methods
10. Method development for improved accuracy in electronic structure calculations.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Computational Physics

**Note:** The article presents a method development for isogeometric analysis (IGA) in electronic structure calculations, specifically within the density-functional framework. The approach aims to achieve continuous second derivatives of the discretized charge density and wave functions, improving the accuracy of computational results. The authors employ Bézier extraction to add IGA capabilities to their FEM-based code built upon SfePy, and present numerical results comparing FEM and IGA methods.

======== 853 : Zerze2021a

@title:    Thermodynamics of DNA Hybridization from Atomistic Simulations
@author:   Zerze, G{\"{u}}l H. and Stillinger, Frank H. and Debenedetti, Pablo G.
@doi:      10.1021/acs.jpcb.0c09237
@url:      https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.jpcb.0c09237 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/33434025
@abstract:
 Studying DNA hybridization equilibrium at atomistic length scales, either via molecular dynamics (MD) or through commonly used advanced sampling approaches, is notoriously difficult. In this work, we describe an order-parameter-based advanced sampling technique to calculate the free energy of hybridization, and estimate the melting temperature of DNA oligomers at atomistic resolution. The free energy landscapes are reported as a function of a native-topology-based order parameter for the Drew-Dickerson dodecamer and for a range of DNA decamer sequences of different GC content. Our estimated melting temperatures match the experimental numbers within ±15 °C. As a test of the numerical reliability of the procedures employed, it was verified that the predicted free energy surfaces and melting temperatures of the d- A nd l-enantiomers of the Drew-Dickerson dodecamer were indistinguishable within numerical accuracy.

======== 856 : Gervasio2005

@title:    Flexible docking in solution using metadynamics.
@keywords: Benzamidines,Benzamidines: chemistry,Benzamidines: metabolism,CDC2-CDC28 Kinases,CDC2-CDC28 Kinases: chemistry,CDC2-CDC28 Kinases: metabolism,Computer Simulation,Cyclin-Dependent Kinase 2,Folder - ComputationalMethods - Global{\_}Opt{\_}and{\_}Sad,Folder - Numerics - Optimalization - GlobalOptimiz,Immunoglobulins,Immunoglobulins: chemistry,Immunoglobulins: metabolism,Kinetics,Ligands,Models,Molecular,Phosphorylcholine,Phosphorylcholine: chemistry,Phosphorylcholine: metabolism,Staurosporine,Staurosporine: chemistry,Staurosporine: metabolism,Thermodynamics,Trypsin,Trypsin: chemistry,Trypsin: metabolism,metadynamics

@doi:      10.1021/ja0445950
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15725015
@abstract:
 We apply our recently developed metadynamics method to the docking of ligands on flexible receptors in water solution. This method mimics the real dynamics of a ligand exiting or entering an enzyme and in so doing reconstructs the free energy surface. We apply it to four docking cases: beta-trypsin/benzamidine, beta-trypsin/chlorobenzamidine, immunoglobulin McPC-603/phosphocholine, and cyclin-dependent kinase 2/staurosporine. In every case studied, the method is able to predict the docked geometry and the free energy of docking. Its added value with respect to many other available methods is that it reconstructs the complete free energy surface, including all the relevant minima and the barriers between them.

======== 857 : Kubar2013c

@title:    Efficient algorithms for the simulation of non-adiabatic electron transfer in complex molecular systems: application to DNA.
@keywords: Algorithms,Base Sequence,DNA,DNA: chemistry,Electron Transport,Electrons,Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - Berlin{\_}MSMJ{\_}2013,Molecular Dynamics Simulation,Oligonucleotides,Oligonucleotides: chemistry,Quantum Theory,Static Electricity
@author:   Kubař, Tom{\'{a}}{\v{s}} and Elstner, Marcus
@doi:      10.1039/c3cp44619k
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23493847
@abstract:
 In this work, a fragment-orbital density functional theory-based method is combined with two different non-adiabatic schemes for the propagation of the electronic degrees of freedom. This allows us to perform unbiased simulations of electron transfer processes in complex media, and the computational scheme is applied to the transfer of a hole in solvated DNA. It turns out that the mean-field approach, where the wave function of the hole is driven into a superposition of adiabatic states, leads to over-delocalization of the hole charge. This problem is avoided using a surface hopping scheme, resulting in a smaller rate of hole transfer. The method is highly efficient due to the on-the-fly computation of the coarse-grained DFT Hamiltonian for the nucleobases, which is coupled to the environment using a QM/MM approach. The computational efficiency and partial parallel character of the methodology make it possible to simulate electron transfer in systems of relevant biochemical size on a nanosecond time scale. Since standard non-polarizable force fields are applied in the molecular-mechanics part of the calculation, a simple scaling scheme was introduced into the electrostatic potential in order to simulate the effect of electronic polarization. It is shown that electronic polarization has an important effect on the features of charge transfer. The methodology is applied to two kinds of DNA sequences, illustrating the features of transfer along a flat energy landscape as well as over an energy barrier. The performance and relative merit of the mean-field scheme and the surface hopping for this application are discussed.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

7. Importance of electronic polarization in simulating charge transfer processes
8. Introduction of simple scaling scheme for electrostatic potential to account for electronic polarization
9. Simulation of electron transfer in DNA sequences with flat energy landscape and energy barrier
10. Discussion on the performance and relative merit of mean-field and surface hopping schemes.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents a method development study on efficient algorithms for non-adiabatic electron transfer simulations in complex molecular systems, with a focus on DNA dynamics. The authors combine a fragment-orbital density functional theory-based method with two non-adiabatic schemes and apply it to the simulation of hole transfer in solvated DNA. They demonstrate the importance of electronic polarization in simulating charge transfer processes and compare the performance of mean-field and surface hopping schemes.

@keywords: Folder - SiNCs - response,SiNC

@doi:      10.1021/j100059a032

======== 861 : Lochan2007

@title:    Quartic-scaling analytical energy gradient of scaled opposite-spin second-order M{\o}ller-plesset perturbation theory
@author:   Lochan, Rohini C. and Shao, Yihan and Head-Gordon, Martin
@doi:      10.1021/ct600292h
@abstract:
 The analytical gradient of the "scaled opposite spin" (SOS-) and "modified opposite spin" (MOS-) second-order M{\o}ller-Plesset perturbation theory (MP2) methods is derived and implemented. Both energy and the first derivative can be evaluated efficiently with a fourth-order scaling algorithm by using a combination of auxiliary basis expansions and Laplace transformation techniques as opposed to the traditional fifth-order approach of MP2. A statistical analysis of 178 small molecules suggests that the new gradient scheme provides geometries of MP2 quality, indicating the reliability of the method in general chemical applications. A more specific study of the group VI transition metal carbonyl complexes indicates that the new scheme improves the MP2 description relative to available experimental data and higher-order theories. The proposed gradient scheme thus endeavors to obtain improved structural features at reduced computational cost. {\textcopyright} 2007 American Chemical Society.

======== 865 : Dohnalova2014

@title:    Silicon quantum dots: surface matters.
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs - Background{\_}Thesis,Folder - SiNCs - projection,in colour only in,quantum confinement,quantum dot,silicon quantum dots,some figures may appear,surface chemistry,the online journal
@author:   Dohnalov{\'{a}}, K and Gregorkiewicz, T and Kůsov{\'{a}}, K
@doi:      10.1088/0953-8984/26/17/173201
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24713583 http://stacks.iop.org/0953-8984/26/i=17/a=173201?key=crossref.3a6ae234474acc4d6d38d1dd867a53a7
@abstract:
 Silicon quantum dots (SiQDs) hold great promise for many future technologies. Silicon is already at the core of photovoltaics and microelectronics, and SiQDs are capable of efficient light emission and amplification. This is crucial for the development of the next technological frontiers-silicon photonics and optoelectronics. Unlike any other quantum dots (QDs), SiQDs are made of non-toxic and abundant material, offering one of the spectrally broadest emission tunabilities accessible with semiconductor QDs and allowing for tailored radiative rates over many orders of magnitude. This extraordinary flexibility of optical properties is achieved via a combination of the spatial confinement of carriers and the strong influence of surface chemistry. The complex physics of this material, which is still being unraveled, leads to new effects, opening up new opportunities for applications. In this review we summarize the latest progress in this fascinating research field, with special attention given to surface-induced effects, such as the emergence of direct bandgap transitions, and collective effects in densely packed QDs, such as space separated quantum cutting.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Condensed Matter Physics
- **Specific Domain:** Nanotechnology, Quantum Dots, Surface Chemistry
- **Research Type:** Review Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Silicon quantum dots (SiQDs) for future technologies in photovoltaics and optoelectronics
2. Surface chemistry's influence on optical properties of SiQDs
3. Spatial confinement of carriers and tailored radiative rates
4. Spectrally broad emission tunability and non-toxic material
5. Emergence of direct bandgap transitions due to surface-induced effects
6. Collective effects in densely packed QDs, such as space separated quantum cutting
7. Review of the latest progress in SiQD research field
8. Complex physics of SiQDs with strong influence of surface chemistry
9. Opportunities for applications arising from new effects and flexibility of optical properties
10. Importance of surface chemistry for achieving desired optical properties.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Condensed Matter Physics

**Note:** The article presents a review of the latest progress in silicon quantum dots (SiQDs) research, with special attention given to surface-induced effects and collective effects in densely packed QDs. The authors highlight the importance of surface chemistry for achieving desired optical properties and explore opportunities for applications arising from new effects and flexibility of optical properties.

======== 866 : Krasheninnikov2007a

@title:    Engineering of nanostructured carbon materials with electron or ion beams.
@keywords: Folder - carbon graphene - Defects
@author:   Krasheninnikov, a V and Banhart, F
@doi:      10.1038/nmat1996
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17906658
@abstract:
 Irradiating solids with energetic particles is usually thought to introduce disorder, normally an undesirable phenomenon. But recent experiments on electron or ion irradiation of various nanostructures demonstrate that it can have beneficial effects and that electron or ion beams may be used to tailor the structure and properties of nanosystems with high precision. Moreover, in many cases irradiation can lead to self-organization or self-assembly in nanostructures. In this review we survey recent advances in the rapidly evolving area of irradiation effects in nanostructured materials, with particular emphasis on carbon systems because of their technological importance and the unique ability of graphitic networks to reconstruct under irradiation. We dwell not only on the physics behind irradiation of nanostructures but also on the technical applicability of irradiation for nanoengineering of carbon and other systems.
