5. Improvements in optimization efficiency observed with redundant internal coordinates
6. Substantial speed-up achieved for flexible and polycyclic systems
7. Cartesian and nonredundant internal coordinates compared to redundant internal coordinates
8. Quadratic synchronous transit approach used to guide transition state searches
9. Redundant coordinates enhance performance of transition structure searches
10. Efficient optimization methods developed for complex molecular geometries.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry and Theoretical Methods

**Note:** The article presents a new method for optimizing molecular geometries using redundant internal coordinates. The authors develop a system constructed from all bonds, valence angles, and dihedral angles between bonded atoms and demonstrate substantial improvements in optimization efficiency over Cartesian and nonredundant internal coordinates. Additionally, the use of redundant coordinates enhances the performance of transition structure searches, making this method a valuable tool for computational chemists.

======== 966 : Peng2017

@title:    Submolecular-resolution non-invasive imaging of interfacial water with atomic force microscopy
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}source - Moje
@author:   Peng, Jinbo and Guo, Jing and Hapala, Prokop and Cao, Duanyun and Ma, Runze and Cheng, Bowei and Xu, Limei and Ondr{\'{a}}{\v{c}}ek, Martin and Jel{\'{i}}nek, Pavel and Wang, Enge and Jiang, Ying
@url:      https://arxiv.org/abs/1703.04400 http://arxiv.org/abs/1703.04400
@abstract:
 Scanning probe microscopy (SPM) has been extensively applied to probe interfacial water in many interdisciplinary fields but the disturbance of the probes on the hydrogen-bonding structure of water has remained an intractable problem. Here we report submolecular-resolution imaging of the water clusters on a NaCl(001) surface within the nearly non-invasive region by a qPlus-based noncontact atomic force microscopy. Comparison with theoretical simulations reveals that the key lies in probing the weak high-order electrostatic force between the quadrupole-like CO-terminated tip and the polar water molecules at large tip-water distances. This interaction allows the imaging and structural determination of the weakly bonded water clusters and even of their metastable states without inducing any disturbance. This work may open up new possibility of studying the intrinsic structure and electrostatics of ice or water on bulk insulating surfaces, ion hydration and biological water with atomic precision.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Specific Domain:** Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM), Scanning Probe Microscopy (SPM), Interfacial Water, Hydrogen Bonding, Non-invasive Imaging, qPlus-based AFM
- **Research Type:** Experimental Study

**10 Keywords:**

1. Submolecular-resolution imaging of interfacial water achieved with noncontact AFM
2. qPlus-based AFM used to probe water clusters on a NaCl(001) surface
3. Weak high-order electrostatic force between CO-terminated tip and polar water molecules identified
4. Key to non-invasive imaging lies in probing this weak interaction at large tip-water distances
5. Theoretical simulations compared with experimental results to validate the approach
6. Structural determination of weakly bonded water clusters achieved without disturbing their hydrogen bonding structure
7. Metastable states of water clusters imaged and characterized using noncontact AFM
8. New possibilities for studying intrinsic structure and electrostatics of ice or water on insulating surfaces opened up
9. Ion hydration and biological water can be studied with atomic precision using this approach
10. Non-invasive imaging of interfacial water may lead to new insights in various fields.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Nanotechnology and Materials Science

**Note:** The article presents a new noncontact AFM technique that allows for submolecular-resolution imaging of interfacial water without disturbing its hydrogen bonding structure. The qPlus-based AFM is used to probe the weak high-order electrostatic force between the CO-terminated tip and polar water molecules, enabling the imaging and structural determination of weakly bonded water clusters and their metastable states. This work has the potential to open up new possibilities for studying interfacial water in various fields with atomic precision.

======== 975 : Lyons2012

@title:    SPACE POWER AND ENERGY STORAGE ROADMAP Technology Area 03
@keywords: Folder - Space,nasa
@author:   Lyons, Valerie J and Gonzalez, Guillermo A and Houts, Michael G
======== 976 : Rondina2013a

@title:    Revised basin-hopping monte carlo algorithm for structure optimization of clusters and nanoparticles
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods - Global{\_}Opt{\_}and{\_}Sad
@author:   Rondina, Gustavo G. and {Da Silva}, Juarez L F
@doi:      10.1021/ci400224z
@abstract:
 Suggestions for improving the Basin-Hopping Monte Carlo (BHMC) algorithm for unbiased global optimization of clusters and nanoparticles are presented. The traditional basin-hopping exploration scheme with Monte Carlo sampling is improved by bringing together novel strategies and techniques employed in different global optimization methods, however, with the care of keeping the underlying algorithm of BHMC unchanged. The improvements include a total of eleven local and nonlocal trial operators tailored for clusters and nanoparticles that allow an efficient exploration of the potential energy surface, two different strategies (static and dynamic) of operator selection, and a filter operator to handle unphysical solutions. In order to assess the efficiency of our strategies, we applied our implementation to several classes of systems, including Lennard-Jones and Sutton-Chen clusters with up to 147 and 148 atoms, respectively, a set of Lennard-Jones nanoparticles with sizes ranging from 200 to 1500 atoms, binary Lennard-Jones clusters with up to 100 atoms, (AgPd)55 alloy clusters described by the Sutton-Chen potential, and aluminum clusters with up to 30 atoms described within the density functional theory framework. Using unbiased global search our implementation was able to reproduce successfully the great majority of all published results for the systems considered and in many cases with more efficiency than the standard BHMC. We were also able to locate previously unknown global minimum structures for some of the systems considered. This revised BHMC method is a valuable tool for aiding theoretical investigations leading to a better understanding of atomic structures of clusters and nanoparticles.

6. Lennard-Jones clusters with up to 147 atoms optimized
7. Sutton-Chen clusters with up to 148 atoms optimized
8. Binary Lennard-Jones clusters with up to 100 atoms optimized
9. (AgPd)55 alloy clusters and aluminum clusters described using DFT framework
10. Global minimum structures located for some systems, including previously unknown ones.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry and Theoretical Methods

**Note:** The article presents a revised Basin-Hopping Monte Carlo (BHMC) algorithm for global optimization of clusters and nanoparticles. The improvements include 11 tailored trial operators, two operator selection strategies, and a filter operator to handle unphysical solutions. The authors assess the efficiency of their implementation by applying it to various systems, including Lennard-Jones and Sutton-Chen clusters, binary Lennard-Jones clusters, (AgPd)55 alloy clusters, and aluminum clusters described using density functional theory framework. The revised BHMC method is a valuable tool for aiding theoretical investigations leading to a better understanding of atomic structures of clusters and nanoparticles.

======== 977 : Geiregat2015a

@title:    A phonon scattering bottleneck for carrier cooling in lead chalcogenide nanocrystals
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs - no{\_}Si,PbS,PbSe,electron-phonon interaction,multiple exciton generation,quantum dots,transient absorption spectroscopy
@author:   Geiregat, Pieter and Delerue, Christophe and Justo, Yolanda and Aerts, Michiel and Spoor, Frank and {Van Thourhout}, Dries and Siebbeles, Laurens D a and Allan, Guy and Houtepen, Arjan J. and Hens, Zeger
@doi:      10.1021/nn5062723
@abstract:
 The cooling dynamics of hot charge carriers in colloidal lead chalcogenide nanocrystals is studied by hyperspectral transient absorption spectroscopy. We demonstrate a transient accumulation of charge carriers at a high energy critical point in the Brillouin zone. Using a theoretical study of the cooling rate in lead chalcogenides, we attribute this slowing down of charge carrier cooling to a phonon scattering bottleneck around this critical point. The relevance of this observation for the possible harvesting of the excess energy of hot carriers by schemes such as multiexciton generation is discussed.

@title:    Teorie plazmatu

@title:    Adsorption and electronic properties of PTCDA molecules on Si(111)-(7×7): Scanning tunneling microscopy and first-principles calculations
@author:   Nicoara, Nicoleta and Paz, {\'{O}}scar and M{\'{e}}ndez, Javier and Bar{\'{o}}, Arturo M. and Soler, Jos{\'{e}} M. and G{\'{o}}mez-Rodr{\'{i}}guez, Jos{\'{e}} M.
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.82.075402
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.82.075402
======== 982 : Meier2017

@title:    No Title
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021,atomic force microscopy,coordination,force spectroscopy,fused donor-acceptor molecules,local contact potential difference,scanning tunneling microscopy,single molecule
@author:   Meier, T. and Pawlak, R. and Kawai, S. and Geng, Y. and Liu, X. and Decurtins, S. and Hapala, P. and Baratoff, A. and Liu, S.-X. and Jel{\'{i}}nek, P. and Meyer, E. and Glatzel, T.
@doi:      10.1021/acsnano.7b03954
@url:      https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acsnano.7b03954
@abstract:
 Electron donor-acceptor molecules are of outstanding interest in molecular electronics and organic solar cells for their intramolecular charge transfer controlled via electrical or optical excitation. The preservation of their electronic character in the ground state upon adsorption on a surface is cardinal for their implementation in such single-molecule devices. Here, we investigate by atomic force microscopy and scanning tunneling microscopy a prototypical system consisting of a $\pi$-conjugated tetrathiafulvalene-fused dipyridophenazine molecule adsorbed on thin NaCl films on Cu(111). Depending on the adsorption site, the molecule is found either in a nearly undisturbed free state or in a bound state. In the latter case, the molecule adopts a specific adsorption site, leading to the formation of a chelate complex with a single Na+ alkali cation pulled out from the insulating film. Although expected to be electronically decoupled, the charge distribution of the complex is drastically modified, leading to the loss of the intrinsic donor-acceptor character. The chelate complex formation is reversible with respect to lateral manipulations, enabling tunable donor-acceptor molecular switches activated by on-surface coordination.

The authors demonstrate the formation of a chelate complex with a single Na+ cation, which leads to a drastic modification of the charge distribution and loss of intrinsic donor-acceptor character. However, this chelate complex formation is reversible, enabling tunable molecular switches activated by on-surface coordination.

======== 983 : Buehler2009a

@title:    Deformation and failure of protein materials in physiologically extreme conditions and disease.
@keywords: Biological,Biomechanical Phenomena,Disease,Disease: etiology,Folder - sctructural{\_}tech - MaterialScience - Biom,Manufactured Materials,Models,Models- Biological,Nanotechnology,Protein Structure,Protein Structure- Tertiary,Proteins,Proteins: chemistry,Proteins: genetics,Proteins: physiology,Tertiary
@author:   Buehler, Markus J and Yung, Yu Ching
@doi:      10.1038/nmat2387
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19229265
@abstract:
 Biological protein materials feature hierarchical structures that make up a diverse range of physiological materials. The analysis of protein materials is an emerging field that uses the relationships between biological structures, processes and properties to probe deformation and failure phenomena at the molecular and microscopic level. Here we discuss how advanced experimental, computational and theoretical methods can be used to assess structure-process-property relations and to monitor and predict mechanisms associated with failure of protein materials. Case studies are presented to examine failure phenomena in the progression of disease. From this materials science perspective, a de novo basis for understanding biological processes can be used to develop new approaches for treating medical disorders. We highlight opportunities to use knowledge gained from the integration of multiple scales with physical, biological and chemical concepts for potential applications in materials design and nanotechnology.

**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

Case studies are presented to examine failure phenomena in disease progression, highlighting opportunities for developing new approaches for treating medical disorders through a de novo basis in materials science.

======== 985 : Gross2014

@title:    Investigating atomic contrast in atomic force microscopy and Kelvin probe force microscopy on ionic systems using functionalized tips
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM,Folder - SPM - KPFM
@author:   Gross, Leo and Schuler, Bruno and Mohn, Fabian and Moll, Nikolaj and Pavli{\v{c}}ek, Niko and Steurer, Wolfram and Scivetti, Ivan and Kotsis, Konstantinos and Persson, Mats and Meyer, Gerhard and Pavliˇ, Niko and Scivetti, Ivan and Kotsis, Konstantinos and Persson, Mats and Meyer, Gerhard and Pavli{\v{c}}ek, Niko and Steurer, Wolfram and Scivetti, Ivan and Kotsis, Konstantinos and Persson, Mats and Meyer, Gerhard
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.90.155455
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.90.155455 http://arxiv.org/abs/1408.7053
@abstract:
 Noncontact atomic force microscopy (NC-AFM) and Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) have become important tools for nanotechnology; however, their contrast mechanisms on the atomic scale are not entirely understood. Here we used chlorine vacancies in NaCl bilayers on Cu(111) as a model system to investigate atomic contrast as a function of applied voltage, tip height, and tip functionalization. We demonstrate that the AFM contrast on the atomic scale decisively depends on both the tip termination and the sample voltage. On the contrary, the local contact potential difference (LCPD) acquired with KPFM showed the same qualitative contrast for all tip terminations investigated, which resembled the contrast of the electric field of the sample. We find that the AFM contrast stems mainly from electrostatic interactions but its tip dependence cannot be explained by the tip dipole alone. With the aid of a simple electrostatic model and by density functional theory we investigate the underlying contrast mechanisms.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Condensed Matter Physics and Materials Science
- **Specific Domain:** Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM), Kelvin Probe Force Microscopy (KPFM), Functionalized Tips, Ionic Systems, Electrostatic Interactions
- **Research Type:** Experimental Study

3. Effects of applied voltage, tip height, and tip functionalization on AFM contrast examined
4. Local contact potential difference (LCPD) measured with KPFM shows similar qualitative contrast for all tip terminations
5. Electrostatic interactions dominate the AFM contrast on the atomic scale
6. Tip dependence of AFM contrast cannot be explained by the tip dipole alone
7. Simple electrostatic model and density functional theory used to investigate underlying mechanisms
8. Contrast mechanisms in noncontact AFM and KPFM studied at atomic scale

10. Atomic resolution imaging using functionalized tips demonstrated for ionic systems.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Condensed Matter Physics and Materials Science

**Note:** The article presents experimental results from noncontact atomic force microscopy (NC-AFM) and Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) studies on chlorine vacancies in NaCl bilayers on Cu(111). The authors investigate the atomic contrast mechanisms as a function of applied voltage, tip height, and tip functionalization. They demonstrate that the AFM contrast is dominated by electrostatic interactions but its tip dependence cannot be explained by the tip dipole alone. A simple electrostatic model and density functional theory are used to investigate the underlying mechanisms, highlighting the importance of tip termination and sample voltage on AFM contrast.

======== 986 : Dargys1994

@title:    Handbook on physical properties of Ge, Si, GaAs and InP
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs,Folder - SiNCs - books,SiNC
@author:   Dargys, Adolfas and Kundrotas, Jurgis
======== 987 : Capozzi2015

@title:    Single-molecule diodes with high rectification ratios through environmental control
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Electronics - Molecular{\_}memory
@author:   Capozzi, Brian and Xia, Jianlong and Adak, Olgun and Dell, Emma J. and Liu, Zhen-Fei and Taylor, Jeffrey C. and Neaton, Jeffrey B. and Campos, Luis M. and Venkataraman, Latha
@doi:      10.1038/nnano.2015.97
@url:      http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nnano.2015.97
@abstract:
 Molecular electronics aims to miniaturize electronic devices by using subnanometre-scale active components. A single-molecule diode, a circuit element that directs current flow, was first proposed more than 40 years ago and consisted of an asymmetric molecule comprising a donor-bridge-acceptor architecture to mimic a semiconductor p-n junction. Several single-molecule diodes have since been realized in junctions featuring asymmetric molecular backbones, molecule-electrode linkers or electrode materials. Despite these advances, molecular diodes have had limited potential for applications due to their low conductance, low rectification ratios, extreme sensitivity to the junction structure and high operating voltages. Here, we demonstrate a powerful approach to induce current rectification in symmetric single-molecule junctions using two electrodes of the same metal, but breaking symmetry by exposing considerably different electrode areas to an ionic solution. This allows us to control the junction's electrostatic environment in an asymmetric fashion by simply changing the bias polarity. With this method, we reliably and reproducibly achieve rectification ratios in excess of 200 at voltages as low as 370 mV using a symmetric oligomer of thiophene-1,1-dioxide. By taking advantage of the changes in the junction environment induced by the presence of an ionic solution, this method provides a general route for tuning nonlinear nanoscale device phenomena, which could potentially be applied in systems beyond single-molecule junctions.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Condensed Matter Physics and Materials Science
- **Specific Domain:** Molecular Electronics, Single-Molecule Devices, Rectification Ratios, Electrostatic Environment, Ionic Solutions
- **Research Type:** Experimental Study

**10 Keywords:**

1. Single-molecule diodes with high rectification ratios demonstrated through environmental control
2. Asymmetric molecular backbones used to create single-molecule diodes in the past
3. New approach uses two identical metal electrodes but different electrode areas exposed to ionic solution for symmetry breaking
4. Electrostatic environment controlled using bias polarity to induce current rectification
5. Rectification ratios in excess of 200 achieved at low operating voltages (370 mV)
6. Symmetric oligomer of thiophene-1,1-dioxide used as the single-molecule device
7. Method provides a general route for tuning nonlinear nanoscale device phenomena
8. Potential applications beyond single-molecule junctions highlighted
9. Ionic solutions and electrostatic environment play key roles in controlling rectification ratios
10. Single-molecule devices with improved performance demonstrated using this novel approach.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Condensed Matter Physics and Materials Science

**Note:** The article presents experimental results from a new approach to create single-molecule diodes with high rectification ratios by controlling the electrostatic environment of the junction through exposure to an ionic solution. This method allows for symmetry breaking using two identical metal electrodes but different electrode areas, enabling current rectification at low operating voltages and achieving rectification ratios in excess of 200. The results demonstrate a powerful approach for tuning nonlinear nanoscale device phenomena, which could have potential applications beyond single-molecule junctions.

======== 996 : Ido2014

@title:    Immunoactive two-dimensional self-assembly of monoclonal antibodies in aqueous solution revealed by atomic force microscopy.
@keywords: Animals,Antibodies,Antibodies- Monoclonal,Antibodies- Monoclonal: chemistry,Atomic Force,Atomic Force: methods,Crystallization,Folder - SPM - supramolecular,Hydrogen-Ion Concentration,Mice,Microscopy,Microscopy- Atomic Force,Microscopy- Atomic Force: methods,Monoclonal,Monoclonal: chemistry,Solutions,Temperature,Water,Water: chemistry
@author:   Ido, Shinichiro and Kimiya, Hirokazu and Kobayashi, Kei and Kominami, Hiroaki and Matsushige, Kazumi and Yamada, Hirofumi
@doi:      10.1038/nmat3847
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24441879
@abstract:
 The conformational flexibility of antibodies in solution directly affects their immune function. Namely, the flexible hinge regions of immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies are essential in epitope-specific antigen recognition and biological effector function. The antibody structure, which is strongly related to its functions, has been partially revealed by electron microscopy and X-ray crystallography, but only under non-physiological conditions. Here we observed monoclonal IgG antibodies in aqueous solution by high-resolution frequency modulation atomic force microscopy (FM-AFM). We found that monoclonal antibodies self-assemble into hexamers, which form two-dimensional crystals in aqueous solution. Furthermore, by directly observing antibody-antigen interactions using FM-AFM, we revealed that IgG molecules in the crystal retain immunoactivity. As the self-assembled monolayer crystal of antibodies retains immunoactivity at a neutral pH and is functionally stable at a wide range of pH and temperature, the antibody crystal is applicable to new biotechnological platforms for biosensors or bioassays.

3. Flexible hinge regions of immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies essential for epitope-specific antigen recognition
4. High-resolution frequency modulation AFM used to observe monoclonal IgG antibodies in solution

The immunoactivity of the antibodies in the crystal is retained at a neutral pH and wide temperature range, making it applicable to new biotechnological platforms for biosensors or bioassays.

======== 997 : Ponder2010

@title:    Current status of the AMOEBA polarizable force field
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - NNFF{\_}H2O{\_}NaCl - FF{\_}polariza
@author:   Ponder, J W and Wu, C and Ren, P and Pande, Vijay S
@doi:      10.1021/jp910674d.Current
@url:      http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/jp910674d{\%}5Cnfile:///ente{\_}w5/florian/lit/2010/Ponder et al. - 2010 - The Journal of.pdf
======== 998 : Maia2012

@title:    GPU Linear Algebra Libraries and GPGPU Programming for Accelerating MOPAC Semiempirical Quantum Chemistry Calculations
@author:   Maia, Julio Daniel Carvalho and {Urquiza Carvalho}, Gabriel Aires and Mangueira, Carlos Peixoto and Santana, Sidney Ramos and Cabral, Lucidio Anjos Formiga and Rocha, Gerd B.
@doi:      10.1021/ct3004645
@url:      https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/ct3004645
@abstract:
 In this study, we present some modifications in the semiempirical quantum chemistry MOPAC2009 code that accelerate single-point energy calculations (1SCF) of medium-size (up to 2500 atoms) molecular systems using GPU coprocessors and multithreaded shared-memory CPUs. Our modifications consisted of using a combination of highly optimized linear algebra libraries for both CPU (LAPACK and BLAS from Intel MKL) and GPU (MAGMA and CUBLAS) to hasten time-consuming parts of MOPAC such as the pseudodiagonalization, full diagonalization, and density matrix assembling. We have shown that it is possible to obtain large speedups just by using CPU serial linear algebra libraries in the MOPAC code. As a special case, we show a speedup of up to 14 times for a methanol simulation box containing 2400 atoms and 4800 basis functions, with even greater gains in performance when using multithreaded CPUs (2.1 times in relation to the single-threaded CPU code using linear algebra libraries) and GPUs (3.8 times). This degree of acceleration opens new perspectives for modeling larger structures which appear in inorganic chemistry (such as zeolites and MOFs), biochemistry (such as polysaccharides, small proteins, and DNA fragments), and materials science (such as nanotubes and fullerenes). In addition, we believe that this parallel (GPU-GPU) MOPAC code will make it feasible to use semiempirical methods in lengthy molecular simulations using both hybrid QM/MM and QM/QM potentials. {\textcopyright} 2012 American Chemical Society.

3. Large speedups obtained using CPU serial linear algebra libraries in the MOPAC code

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry and Quantum Mechanics

The authors show large speedups by using optimized linear algebra libraries for both CPU and GPU, making it feasible to use semiempirical methods in lengthy molecular simulations with both hybrid QM/MM and QM/QM potentials.

@keywords: Folder - Space - Orbits - OrbitalTransfer,aeroassisted orbital maneuvers,astrodynamics,multiple-pass,numerical methods,optimal trajectories,orbital transfer

======== 1003 : Cai2010a

@title:    Atomically precise bottom-up fabrication of graphene nanoribbons.
@keywords: Carbon,Carbon: chemistry,Electronics,Electronics: instrumentation,Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - Berlin{\_}MSMJ{\_}2013,Graphite,Graphite: chemistry,Hydrogenation,Models,Models- Molecular,Molecular,Molecular Conformation,Nanotubes,Nanotubes- Carbon,Nanotubes- Carbon: chemistry
@author:   Cai, Jinming and Ruffieux, Pascal and Jaafar, Rached and Bieri, Marco and Braun, Thomas and Blankenburg, Stephan and Muoth, Matthias and Seitsonen, Ari P and Saleh, Moussa and Feng, Xinliang and M{\"{u}}llen, Klaus and Fasel, Roman
@doi:      10.1038/nature09211
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20651687
@abstract:
 Graphene nanoribbons-narrow and straight-edged stripes of graphene, or single-layer graphite-are predicted to exhibit electronic properties that make them attractive for the fabrication of nanoscale electronic devices. In particular, although the two-dimensional parent material graphene exhibits semimetallic behaviour, quantum confinement and edge effects should render all graphene nanoribbons with widths smaller than 10 nm semiconducting. But exploring the potential of graphene nanoribbons is hampered by their limited availability: although they have been made using chemical, sonochemical and lithographic methods as well as through the unzipping of carbon nanotubes, the reliable production of graphene nanoribbons smaller than 10 nm with chemical precision remains a significant challenge. Here we report a simple method for the production of atomically precise graphene nanoribbons of different topologies and widths, which uses surface-assisted coupling of molecular precursors into linear polyphenylenes and their subsequent cyclodehydrogenation. The topology, width and edge periphery of the graphene nanoribbon products are defined by the structure of the precursor monomers, which can be designed to give access to a wide range of different graphene nanoribbons. We expect that our bottom-up approach to the atomically precise fabrication of graphene nanoribbons will finally enable detailed experimental investigations of the properties of this exciting class of materials. It should even provide a route to graphene nanoribbon structures with engineered chemical and electronic properties, including the theoretically predicted intraribbon quantum dots, superlattice structures and magnetic devices based on specific graphene nanoribbon edge states.

The method is expected to facilitate detailed experimental investigations of graphene nanoribbon properties and enable the creation of devices with engineered chemical and electronic properties.

======== 1004 : Tikhomirov2017a

@title:    Fractal assembly of micrometre-scale DNA origami arrays with arbitrary patterns
@author:   Tikhomirov, Grigory and Petersen, Philip and Qian, Lulu
@doi:      10.1038/nature24655
@url:      https://www.nature.com/articles/nature24655 http://www.nature.com/articles/nature24655
@abstract:
 Self-assembled DNA nanostructures1 enable nanometre-precise patterning that can be used to create programmable molecular machines2-6 and arrays of functional materials7-9. DNA origami10 is particularly versatile in this context because each DNA strand in the origami nanostructure occupies a unique position and can serve as a uniquely addressable pixel. However, the scale of such structures11-14 has been limited to about 0.05 square micrometres, hindering applications that demand a larger layout15 and integration with more conventional patterning methods. Hierarchical multistage assembly of simple sets of tiles16,17 can in principle overcome this limitation, but so far has not been sufficiently robust to enable successful implementation of larger structures using DNA origami tiles. Here we show that by using simple local assembly rules18 that are modified and applied recursively throughout a hierarchical, multistage assembly process, a small and constant set of unique DNA strands can be used to create DNA origami arrays of increasing size and with arbitrary patterns. We illustrate this method, which we term 'fractal assembly', by producing DNA origami arrays with sizes of up to 0.5 square micrometres and with up to 8,704 pixels, allowing us to render images such as the Mona Lisa and a rooster. We find that self-assembly of the tiles into arrays is unaffected by changes in surface patterns on the tiles, and that the yield of the fractal assembly process corresponds to about 0.95m1 for arrays containing m tiles. When used in conjunction with a software tool that we developed that converts an arbitrary pattern into DNA sequences and experimental protocols, our assembly method is readily accessible and will facilitate the construction of sophisticated materials and devices with sizes similar to that of a bacterium using DNA nanostructures.

- **Research Type:** Experimental Study

**10 Keywords:**

1. Fractal assembly of micrometre-scale DNA origami arrays with arbitrary patterns using simple local assembly rules
2. Hierarchical multistage assembly of DNA origami tiles to create larger structures and arrays
3. Use of a small and constant set of unique DNA strands for hierarchical assembly
4. Recursive application of modified local assembly rules throughout the assembly process
5. Production of DNA origami arrays with sizes up to 0.5 square micrometres and up to 8,704 pixels
6. Rendering images such as the Mona Lisa and a rooster using large-scale DNA origami arrays
7. Self-assembly of tiles into arrays unaffected by changes in surface patterns on the tiles
8. High yield (about 0.95m1) of fractal assembly process for arrays containing m tiles
9. Software tool developed to convert arbitrary patterns into DNA sequences and experimental protocols
10. Facilitation of construction of sophisticated materials and devices using DNA nanostructures with sizes similar to that of a bacterium.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Nanotechnology and Biochemistry

**Note:** The article presents a method for fractal assembly of micrometre-scale DNA origami arrays with arbitrary patterns, using simple local assembly rules applied recursively throughout a hierarchical multistage assembly process. This approach enables the creation of large-scale structures with high yield and allows for rendering images using DNA origami arrays. The method is accessible through a software tool that converts patterns into DNA sequences and experimental protocols, facilitating the construction of sophisticated materials and devices with sizes similar to that of a bacterium using DNA nanostructures.

======== 1005 : Parrinello1981

@title:    Polymorphic transitions in single crystals: A new molecular dynamics method
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - GlobalOptimizatio
@author:   Parrinello, M.
@doi:      10.1063/1.328693
@url:      http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/jap/52/12/10.1063/1.328693
@abstract:
 A new Lagrangian formulation is introduced. It can be used to make molecular dynamics (MD) calculations on systems under the most general, externally applied, conditions of stress. In this formulation the MD cell shape and size can change according to dynamical equations given by this Lagrangian. This new MD technique is well suited to the study of structural transformations in solids under external stress and at finite temperature. As an example of the use of this technique we show how a single crystal of Ni behaves under uniform uniaxial compressive and tensile loads. This work confirms some of the results of static (i.e., zero temperature) calculations reported in the literature. We also show that some results regarding the stress‐strain relation obtained by static calculations are invalid at finite temperature. We find that, under compressive loading, our model of Ni shows a bifurcation in its stress‐strain relation; this bifurcation provides a link in configuration space between cubic and hexagonal close packing. It is suggested that such a transformation could perhaps be observed experimentally under extreme conditions of shock.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Materials Science and Solid-State Physics
- **Specific Domain:** Molecular Dynamics Simulations, Polymorphic Transitions, Single Crystals, Stress-Strain Relations, Finite Temperature Effects
- **Research Type:** Computational Study

**10 Keywords:**

1. New Lagrangian formulation for molecular dynamics (MD) calculations under external stress conditions
2. Dynamically changing MD cell shape and size according to the Lagrangian equations
3. Application of the new MD technique to study structural transformations in solids at finite temperature
4. Single crystal Ni behavior under uniform uniaxial compressive and tensile loads studied using the new method
5. Confirmation of some static calculations results, but invalidation of others due to finite temperature effects
6. Bifurcation in stress-strain relation found for Ni under compressive loading, linking cubic and hexagonal close packing configurations
7. Potential observation of such a transformation experimentally under extreme shock conditions
8. Link between configuration space and stress-strain relations provided by the new MD method
9. Comparison with static calculations results highlights the importance of finite temperature effects in polymorphic transitions
10. New MD technique enables more accurate modeling of structural transformations in solids under external stress.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Materials Science and Solid-State Physics

**Note:** The article introduces a new Lagrangian formulation for molecular dynamics (MD) simulations that allows for dynamically changing cell shape and size, enabling the study of structural transformations in solids at finite temperature. As an example, the behavior of single crystal Ni under uniaxial compressive and tensile loads is studied using this method, confirming some static calculations results but highlighting the invalidation of others due to finite temperature effects. The new MD technique provides a link between configuration space and stress-strain relations, potentially enabling the observation of polymorphic transformations experimentally under extreme conditions.

======== 1006 : Ambrosi2012

@title:    Metallic impurities in graphenes prepared from graphite can dramatically influence their properties.
@keywords: Folder - carbon graphene,★

======== 1007 : Trani2005

@title:    Tight-binding calculation of the optical absorption cross section of spherical and ellipsoidal silicon nanocrystals
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs,Folder - SiNCs - Computations,SiNC
@author:   Trani, F. and Cantele, G. and Ninno, D. and Iadonisi, G.
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.72.075423
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.72.075423
======== 1008 : Kumar2023

@title:    GPU-Enhanced DFTB Metadynamics for Efficiently Predicting Free Energies of Biochemical Systems
@keywords: DFTB,GPUs,cloud computing,free energies,metadynamics,thermodynamics
@author:   Kumar, Anshuman and Arantes, Pablo R. and Saha, Aakash and Palermo, Giulia and Wong, Bryan M.
@doi:      10.3390/molecules28031277
@url:      https://www.mdpi.com/1420-3049/28/3/1277
@abstract:
 Metadynamics calculations of large chemical systems with ab initio methods are computationally prohibitive due to the extensive sampling required to simulate the large degrees of freedom in these systems. To address this computational bottleneck, we utilized a GPU-enhanced density functional tight binding (DFTB) approach on a massively parallelized cloud computing platform to efficiently calculate the thermodynamics and metadynamics of biochemical systems. To first validate our approach, we calculated the free-energy surfaces of alanine dipeptide and showed that our GPU-enhanced DFTB calculations qualitatively agree with computationally-intensive hybrid DFT benchmarks, whereas classical force fields give significant errors. Most importantly, we show that our GPU-accelerated DFTB calculations are significantly faster than previous approaches by up to two orders of magnitude. To further extend our GPU-enhanced DFTB approach, we also carried out a 10 ns metadynamics simulation of remdesivir, which is prohibitively out of reach for routine DFT-based metadynamics calculations. We find that the free-energy surfaces of remdesivir obtained from DFTB and classical force fields differ significantly, where the latter overestimates the internal energy contribution of high free-energy states. Taken together, our benchmark tests, analyses, and extensions to large biochemical systems highlight the use of GPU-enhanced DFTB simulations for efficiently predicting the free-energy surfaces/thermodynamics of large biochemical systems.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry and Biochemistry
- **Specific Domain:** Density Functional Tight Binding (DFTB), GPU-accelerated Computing, Cloud Computing, Metadynamics Simulations, Free Energy Calculations, Thermodynamics of Biochemical Systems
- **Research Type:** Computational Study

**10 Keywords:**

1. GPU-enhanced DFTB approach for efficient prediction of free energies in biochemical systems
2. Utilization of massively parallelized cloud computing platform to accelerate calculations
3. Validation of GPU-DFTB against hybrid DFT benchmarks for alanine dipeptide
4. Comparison with classical force fields shows significant errors in thermodynamics predictions
5. Significantly faster calculations by up to two orders of magnitude compared to previous approaches
6. 10 ns metadynamics simulation of remdesivir performed using GPU-enhanced DFTB approach
7. Differences between free-energy surfaces obtained from DFTB and classical force fields identified
8. Classical force fields overestimate internal energy contribution of high free-energy states
9. Extension of GPU-DFTB approach to large biochemical systems demonstrated
10. Potential applications of GPU-DFTB for predicting thermodynamics and metadynamics of complex biochemical systems.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry and Biochemistry

**Note:** The article presents a GPU-enhanced density functional tight binding (DFTB) approach that efficiently predicts free energies in biochemical systems using massively parallelized cloud computing. Validation against hybrid DFT benchmarks and comparison with classical force fields demonstrate the accuracy and speed of this method, which is up to two orders of magnitude faster than previous approaches. The study highlights the potential applications of GPU-DFTB for predicting thermodynamics and metadynamics of complex biochemical systems.

======== 1019 : Chan2010

@title:    Solution-grown silicon nanowires for lithium-ion battery anodes.
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs,a conducting addi-,carbon nanotubes,lithium-ion battery anodes,material is mixed with,silicon nanowires,suspended into a slurry,tive and binder,trode coating processes,where the active
@author:   Chan, Candace K and Patel, Reken N and O'Connell, Michael J and Korgel, Brian a and Cui, Yi
@doi:      10.1021/nn901409q
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20201547
@abstract:
 Composite electrodes composed of silicon nanowires synthesized using the supercritical fluid-liquid-solid (SFLS) method mixed with amorphous carbon or carbon nanotubes were evaluated as Li-ion battery anodes. Carbon coating of the silicon nanowires using the pyrolysis of sugar was found to be crucial for making good electronic contact to the material. Using multiwalled carbon nanotubes as the conducting additive was found to be more effective for obtaining good cycling behavior than using amorphous carbon. Reversible capacities of 1500 mAh/g were observed for 30 cycles.

======== 1020 : Hawthorne2004

@title:    Electrical or photocontrol of the rotary motion of a metallacarborane.
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Engeneering - Molecular Motors,★
@author:   Hawthorne, M Frederick and Zink, Jeffrey I and Skelton, Johnny M and Bayer, Michael J and Liu, Chris and Livshits, Ester and Baer, Roi and Neuhauser, Daniel
@doi:      10.1126/science.1093846
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15031500
@abstract:
 Rotary motion around a molecular axis has been controlled by simple electron transfer processes and by photoexcitation. The basis of the motion is intramolecular rotation of a carborane cage ligand (7,8-dicarbollide) around a nickel axle. The Ni(III) metallacarborane structure is a transoid sandwich with two pairs of carbon vertices reflected through a center of symmetry, but that of the Ni(IV) species is cisoid. The interconversion of the two provides the basis for controlled, rotational, oscillatory motion. The energies of the Ni(III) and Ni(IV) species are calculated as a function of the rotation angle.

======== 1022 : Barney2012

@title:    SCIENCE INSTRUMENTS, OBSERVATORIES, AND SENSOR SYSTEMS ROADMAP Technology Area 08
@keywords: Folder - Space,nasa
@author:   Barney, Richard D and Bauman, Jill J and Feinberg, Lee D
======== 1023 : Gramada2008

@title:    Resolving a distribution of charge into intrinsic multipole moments: A rankwise distributed multipole analysis
@author:   Gramada, Apostol and Bourne, Philip E.
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevE.78.066601
@url:      https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevE.78.066601
@abstract:
 We present a method for the rankwise distributed multipole analysis of an arbitrary distribution of charge and its surrounding field. Using the superposition principle, the electrostatic field created by a distribution of charge can be resolved recursively into the contributions of a set of intrinsic multipole moments "tied to" their rank-specific multipole centers. The positions of the multipole centers, which are fixed with respect to the distribution of charge, are determined from a term-by-term optimization of the Taylor's expansion of the electrostatic potential with respect to the charge coordinates. We describe the recursive construction of the intrinsic multipole moments and derive the algebraic expression of the multipole centers. The resulting distributed multipole expansion provides a conceptual framework for the analysis and modeling of the electrostatic field and of its associated distribution of charge. {\textcopyright} 2008 The American Physical Society.

**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Research Type:** Mathematical Modeling

6. Distributed multipole expansion for electrostatic field analysis
7. Conceptual framework for modeling electrostatic fields and charges
8. Mathematical modeling of electromagnetic phenomena
9. Computational methods for electromagnetism and physics
10. Multipole analysis for resolving charge distributions.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Electromagnetism and Computational Physics

**Note:** The article presents a method for the rankwise distributed multipole analysis of an arbitrary distribution of charge, which is based on the recursive construction of intrinsic multipole moments using the superposition principle and the optimization of Taylor's expansion for electrostatic potential. The resulting distributed multipole expansion provides a conceptual framework for analyzing and modeling the electrostatic field and its associated charge distribution.

======== 1024 : Aviram1974

@title:    Molecular rectifiers
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021
@author:   Aviram, Arieh and Ratner, Mark A.
@doi:      10.1016/0009-2614(74)85031-1
@url:      https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/0009261474850311
======== 1025 : Foreman2005

@title:    First-principles envelope-function theory for lattice-matched semiconductor heterostructures
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs - Theory,SiNC,k.p
@author:   Foreman, Bradley A
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.72.165345
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.72.165345
@abstract:
 In this paper a multi-band envelope-function Hamiltonian for lattice-matched semiconductor heterostructures is derived from first-principles norm-conserving pseudopotentials. The theory is applicable to isovalent or heterovalent heterostructures with macroscopically neutral interfaces and no spontaneous bulk polarization. The key assumption -- proved in earlier numerical studies -- is that the heterostructure can be treated as a weak perturbation with respect to some periodic reference crystal, with the nonlinear response small in comparison to the linear response. Quadratic response theory is then used in conjunction with k.p perturbation theory to develop a multi-band effective-mass Hamiltonian (for slowly varying envelope functions) in which all interface band-mixing effects are determined by the linear response. To within terms of the same order as the position dependence of the effective mass, the quadratic response contributes only a bulk band offset term and an interface dipole term, both of which are diagonal in the effective-mass Hamiltonian. Long-range multipole Coulomb fields arise in quantum wires or dots, but have no qualitative effect in two-dimensional systems beyond a dipole contribution to the band offsets.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Condensed Matter Physics
- **Specific Domain:** Semiconductor Heterostructures, Envelope-Function Theory, First-Principles Calculations, k.p Perturbation Theory, Effective-Mass Hamiltonian
- **Research Type:** Theoretical Modeling

**10 Keywords:**

1. Multi-band envelope-function theory for lattice-matched semiconductor heterostructures
2. First-principles norm-conserving pseudopotentials used in calculations
3. Applicability to isovalent or heterovalent heterostructures with neutral interfaces
4. Key assumption of weak perturbation with respect to a periodic reference crystal
5. Quadratic response theory combined with k.p perturbation theory
6. Development of multi-band effective-mass Hamiltonian for slowly varying envelope functions
7. Interface band-mixing effects determined by linear response and position dependence of effective mass
8. Bulk band offset term and interface dipole term in the effective-mass Hamiltonian
9. Long-range multipole Coulomb fields in quantum wires or dots, but negligible in two-dimensional systems
10. Diagonal contribution to band offsets from quadratic response.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Condensed Matter Physics

**Note:** The article presents a first-principles envelope-function theory for lattice-matched semiconductor heterostructures, which is applicable to various types of heterostructures and interfaces. The theory uses the superposition principle and k.p perturbation theory to develop an effective-mass Hamiltonian that captures the effects of interface band mixing. The authors demonstrate that long-range multipole Coulomb fields have a negligible impact on two-dimensional systems beyond a dipole contribution to the band offsets.

======== 1026 : Draeger2004

@title:    Optical properties of passivated silicon nanoclusters: the role of synthesis.
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs,Folder - SiNCs - Computations,SiNC
@author:   Draeger, Erik W and Grossman, Jeffrey C and Williamson, Andrew J and Galli, Giulia
@doi:      10.1063/1.1738633
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15268108
@abstract:
 The effect of preparation conditions on the structural and optical properties of silicon nanoparticles is investigated. Nanoscale reconstructions, unique to curved nanosurfaces, are presented for silicon nanocrystals and shown to have lower energy and larger optical gaps than bulk-derived structures. We find that high-temperature synthesis processes can produce metastable noncrystalline nanostructures with different core structures than bulk-derived crystalline clusters. The type of core structure that forms from a given synthesis process may depend on the passivation mechanism and time scale. The effect of oxygen on the optical of different types of silicon structures is calculated. In contrast to the behavior of bulklike nanostructures, for noncrystalline and reconstructed crystalline structures surface oxygen atoms do not decrease the gap. In some cases, the presence of oxygen atoms at the nanocluster surface can significantly increase the optical absorption gap, due to decreased angular distortion of the silicon bonds. The relationship between strain and the optical gap in silicon nanoclusters is discussed.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Materials Science
- **Subcategory:** Nanomaterials and Semiconductors
- **Specific Domain:** Silicon Nanoclusters (SiNCs), Passivation Mechanisms, Synthesis Conditions, Optical Properties, Structural Reconstructions
- **Research Type:** Experimental and Theoretical Studies

**10 Keywords:**

1. Effect of synthesis conditions on SiNC optical properties
2. Role of passivation mechanisms in shaping SiNC structures
3. High-temperature synthesis processes producing metastable noncrystalline nanostructures
4. Nanoscale reconstructions unique to curved nanosurfaces
5. Lower energy and larger optical gaps in reconstructed crystalline structures
6. Impact of oxygen on the optical properties of different SiNC types
7. Surface oxygen atoms not decreasing the gap for noncrystalline and reconstructed structures
8. Increased optical absorption gap due to reduced angular distortion of silicon bonds
9. Relationship between strain and optical gap in SiNCs discussed
10. Synthesis-dependent core structure formation in SiNCs.

**Specific Topic:** Materials Science - Nanomaterials and Semiconductors

**Note:** The article investigates the effect of synthesis conditions on the structural and optical properties of silicon nanoparticles, including the role of passivation mechanisms, nanoscale reconstructions, and oxygen's impact on the optical properties. The authors find that high-temperature synthesis processes can produce metastable noncrystalline nanostructures with unique core structures, and discuss the relationship between strain and the optical gap in SiNCs.

======== 1027 : Nurbawono2015

@title:    Modeling optical properties of silicon clusters by first principles: From a few atoms to large nanocrystals
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs
@author:   Nurbawono, Argo and Liu, Shuanglong and Zhang, Chun
@doi:      10.1063/1.4918588
@url:      http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/jcp/142/15/10.1063/1.4918588
======== 1028 : Sanchez2012a

@title:    Assessment on the feasibility of future shepherding of asteroid resources
@keywords: Asteroid mining,Folder - Space{\_}Tech - asteroides,Near-Earth asteroids,Near-Earth objects,Space utilisation,asteroid exploitation
@author:   Sanchez, J.P. and McInnes, C.R.
@doi:      10.1016/j.actaastro.2011.12.010
@url:      http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0094576511003614
======== 1029 : Cranford2010

@title:    Materiomics: biological protein materials, from nano to macro.
@keywords: Folder - sctructural{\_}tech - MaterialScience - Biom,advances in imaging methods,biological materials,cre-,deformation,diversity,failure,functional material properties,have revealed that biology,hierarchies,introduction,materiomics,motivated by nature,multiscale,over the past decades,peptide,protein,universality
@author:   Cranford, Steven and Buehler, Markus J
@doi:      10.2147/NSA.S9037
@url:      http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=3781696{\&}tool=pmcentrez{\&}rendertype=abstract
@abstract:
 Materiomics is an emerging field of science that provides a basis for multiscale material system characterization, inspired in part by natural, for example, protein-based materials. Here we outline the scope and explain the motivation of the field of materiomics, as well as demonstrate the benefits of a materiomic approach in the understanding of biological and natural materials as well as in the design of de novo materials. We discuss recent studies that exemplify the impact of materiomics - discovering Nature's complexity through a materials science approach that merges concepts of material and structure throughout all scales and incorporates feedback loops that facilitate sensing and resulting structural changes at multiple scales. The development and application of materiomics is illustrated for the specific case of protein-based materials, which constitute the building blocks of a variety of biological systems such as tendon, bone, skin, spider silk, cells, and tissue, as well as natural composite material systems (a combination of protein-based and inorganic constituents) such as nacre and mollusk shells, and other natural multiscale systems such as cellulose-based plant and wood materials. An important trait of these materials is that they display distinctive hierarchical structures across multiple scales, where molecular details are exhibited in macroscale mechanical responses. Protein materials are intriguing examples of materials that balance multiple tasks, representing some of the most sustainable material solutions that integrate structure and function despite severe limitations in the quality and quantity of material building blocks. However, up until now, our attempts to analyze and replicate Nature's materials have been hindered by our lack of fundamental understanding of these materials' intricate hierarchical structures, scale-bridging mechanisms, and complex material components that bestow protein-based materials their unique properties. Recent advances in analytical tools and experimental methods allow a holistic view of such a hierarchical biological material system. The integration of these approaches and amalgamation of material properties at all scale levels to develop a complete description of a material system falls within the emerging field of materiomics. Materiomics is the result of the convergence of engineering and materials science with experimental and computational biology in the context of natural and synthetic materials. Through materiomics, fundamental advances in our understanding of structure-property-process relations of biological systems contribute to the mechanistic understanding of certain diseases and facilitate the development of novel biological, biologically inspired, and completely synthetic materials for applications in medicine (biomaterials), nanotechnology, and engineering.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Materials Science
- **Subcategory:** Biomaterials and Biomedical Engineering
- **Specific Domain:** Materiomics, Protein-Based Materials, Biological Systems, Natural Materials, Multiscale Characterization
- **Research Type:** Review Article and Emerging Field Overview

**10 Keywords:**

======== 1030 : Schuler2014

@title:    Contrast formation in Kelvin probe force microscopy of single $\pi$-conjugated molecules.
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM - KPFM,Folder - SPM - KPFM,Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM),acceptor molecules,charge distribution,charge-transfer complex,charge-transfer complex (CTC),complexes,ctc,detailed charge,distribution in individual charge-transfer,donor,donor-acceptor molecules,easuring and understanding the,kelvin probe force microscopy,kpfm,nc-afm,noncontact atomic force microscopy,noncontact atomic force microscopy (NC-AFM)
@author:   Schuler, Bruno and Liu, Shi-Xia and Geng, Yan and Decurtins, Silvio and Meyer, Gerhard and Gross, Leo
@doi:      10.1021/nl500805x
@url:      https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/nl500805x http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24849457
@abstract:
 We report the contrast formation in the local contact potential difference (LCPD) measured by Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) on single charge-transfer complexes (CTCs) on a NaCl bilayer on Cu(111). At different tip heights, we found quantitatively different LCPD contrasts that characterize different properties of the molecule. In the small distance regime, the tip penetrates the electron density of the molecule, and the contrast is related to the size and topography of the electron shell of the molecule. For larger distances, the LCPD contrast corresponds to the electrostatic field above the molecule. However, in the medium-distance regime, that is, for tip heights similar to the size of the molecule, the nonspherical distribution of $\pi$- and $\sigma$-electrons often conceals the effect of the partial charges within the molecule. Only for large distances does the LCPD map converge toward the simple field of a dipole for a polar molecule.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Condensed Matter Physics
- **Specific Domain:** Scanning Probe Microscopy (SPM), Kelvin Probe Force Microscopy (KPFM), Noncontact Atomic Force Microscopy (NC-AFM)
- **Research Type:** Experimental Study

**10 Keywords:**

1. Contrast formation in Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) of single molecules
2. Local contact potential difference (LCPD) measured by KPFM on charge-transfer complexes (CTCs)
3. Quantitative analysis of LCPD contrasts at different tip heights and distances
4. Relation between LCPD contrast and electron density, topography, and electrostatic field
5. Electron shell size and shape affecting LCPD contrast in small distance regime
6. Electrostatic field above the molecule influencing LCPD contrast for larger distances
7. Nonspherical distribution of π- and σ-electrons concealing partial charges within the molecule
8. Medium-distance regime showing complex LCPD map due to molecular structure
9. Convergence toward dipole field at large distances for polar molecules
10. KPFM enabling detailed understanding of charge distribution in individual CTCs.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Condensed Matter Physics

**Note:** The article presents an experimental study on the contrast formation in Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) of single π-conjugated molecules, with a focus on charge-transfer complexes (CTCs). The authors demonstrate that the local contact potential difference (LCPD) measured by KPFM depends on the tip height and distance from the molecule, and that different properties of the molecule are characterized at different regimes.

======== 1032 : Merkel2004

@title:    Controlled Extraction of Energy from Nuclear Isomers
@keywords: Folder - Nuclear - Nuclear{\_}isomers
@author:   Merkel, G and Litz, MS
@url:      http://www.stormingmedia.us/84/8433/A843334.html
======== 1033 : Huybrechs2009

@title:    Stable high-order quadrature rules with equidistant points
@keywords: Discrete orthogonal polynomials,Least squares approximation,Numerical integration
@author:   Huybrechs, Daan
@doi:      10.1016/j.cam.2009.05.018
@url:      http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cam.2009.05.018
@abstract:
 Newton-Cotes quadrature rules are based on polynomial interpolation in a set of equidistant points. They are very useful in applications where sampled function values are only available on a regular grid. Yet, these rules rapidly become unstable for high orders. In this paper we review two techniques to construct stable high-order quadrature rules using equidistant quadrature points. The stability follows from the fact that all coefficients are positive. This result can be achieved by allowing the number of quadrature points to be larger than the polynomial order of accuracy. The computed approximations then implicitly correspond to the integral of a least squares approximation of the integrand. We show how the underlying discrete least squares approximation can be optimised for the purpose of numerical integration. {\textcopyright} 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

- **Research Type:** Review Article

2. Newton-Cotes quadrature rules based on polynomial interpolation
3. Stability issues in high-order quadrature rules
4. Techniques for constructing stable quadrature rules
5. Positive coefficients ensuring stability
6. Larger number of quadrature points than polynomial order of accuracy
7. Implicit least squares approximation of the integrand
8. Optimisation of discrete least squares approximation for numerical integration
9. Review of techniques for stable high-order quadrature rules
10. Application to regular grids with sampled function values.

**Specific Topic:** Mathematics - Numerical Analysis

**Note:** The article reviews two techniques for constructing stable high-order quadrature rules using equidistant points, which are widely used in applications where sampled function values are available on a regular grid. The authors discuss the stability issues in high-order quadrature rules and present methods to achieve positive coefficients, ensuring the stability of the rules. They also show how the discrete least squares approximation can be optimised for numerical integration.

======== 1040 : Sweetman2014

@title:    Mapping the force field of a hydrogen-bonded assembly.
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM,★
@author:   Sweetman, a M and Jarvis, S P and Sang, Hongqian and Lekkas, I and Rahe, P and Wang, Yu and Wang, Jianbo and Champness, N R and Kantorovich, L and Moriarty, P
@doi:      10.1038/ncomms4931
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24875276
@abstract:
 Hydrogen bonding underpins the properties of a vast array of systems spanning a wide variety of scientific fields. From the elegance of base pair interactions in DNA to the symmetry of extended supramolecular assemblies, hydrogen bonds play an essential role in directing intermolecular forces. Yet fundamental aspects of the hydrogen bond continue to be vigorously debated. Here we use dynamic force microscopy (DFM) to quantitatively map the tip-sample force field for naphthalene tetracarboxylic diimide molecules hydrogen-bonded in two-dimensional assemblies. A comparison of experimental images and force spectra with their simulated counterparts shows that intermolecular contrast arises from repulsive tip-sample interactions whose interpretation can be aided via an examination of charge density depletion across the molecular system. Interpreting DFM images of hydrogen-bonded systems therefore necessitates detailed consideration of the coupled tip-molecule system: analyses based on intermolecular charge density in the absence of the tip fail to capture the essential physical chemistry underpinning the imaging mechanism.

======== 1046 : Esat2018

@title:    A standing molecule as a single-electron field emitter
@author:   Esat, Taner and Friedrich, Niklas and Tautz, F. Stefan and Temirov, Ruslan
@doi:      10.1038/s41586-018-0223-y
@url:      http://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-018-0223-y
@abstract:
 Scanning probe microscopy makes it possible to image and spectroscopically characterize nanoscale objects, and to manipulate 1-3 and excite 4-8 them; even time-resolved experiments are now routinely achieved 9,10 . This combination of capabilities has enabled proof-of-principle demonstrations of nanoscale devices, including logic operations based on molecular cascades 11, a single-atom transistor 12, a single-atom magnetic memory cell 13 and a kilobyte atomic memory 14 . However, a key challenge is fabricating device structures that can overcome their attraction to the underlying surface and thus protrude from the two-dimensional flatlands of the surface. Here we demonstrate the fabrication of such a structure: we use the tip of a scanning probe microscope to lift a large planar aromatic molecule (3,4,9,10-perylenetetracarboxylic-dianhydride) into an upright, standing geometry on a pedestal of two metal (silver) adatoms. This atypical and surprisingly stable upright orientation of the single molecule, which under all known circumstances adsorbs flat on metals 15,16, enables the system to function as a coherent single-electron field emitter. We anticipate that other metastable adsorbate configurations might also be accessible, thereby opening up the third dimension for the design of functional nanostructures on surfaces.

@title:    Tetracene Formation by On-Surface Reduction
@keywords: 1,2 their unique,Folder - HR-SPM,acenes,afm,atomic force microscopy,atomic force microscopy (AFM),deoxygenation,derivatives o ff ers,great promise for application,he precise fabrication of,in,large acenes and their,on-surface reaction,organic and molecular electronics,single-molecule chemistry

@abstract:
 We present the on-surface reduction of diepoxytetracenes to form genuine tetracene on Cu(111). The conversion is achieved by scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) tip-induced manipulation as well as thermal activation and is conclusively demonstrated by means of atomic force microscopy (AFM) with atomic resolution. We observe that the metallic surface plays an important role in the deoxygenation and for the planarization after bond cleavage.

======== 1048 : Izzo2012

@title:    SOURCE TOOLS FOR MASSIVELY PARALLEL OPTIMIZATION IN ASTRODYNAMICS (THE CASE OF INTERPLANETARY TRAJECTORY OPTIMIZATION)
@keywords: Folder - Space{\_}Tech - OrbitalTransfer - pyKEP

@url:      http://www.esa.int/gsp/ACT/doc/MAD/pub/ACT-RPR-MAD-2012-(ICATT)PyKEP-PaGMO-SOCIS.pdf
======== 1049 : Li2012a

@title:    An oxygen reduction electrocatalyst based on carbon nanotube-graphene complexes.
@keywords: Ammonia,Ammonia: chemistry,Carbon,Carbon: chemistry,Catalysis,Electric Conductivity,Folder - carbon graphene - Catalyst,Graphite,Graphite: chemistry,Hot Temperature,Nanotubes,Nanotubes- Carbon,Nanotubes- Carbon: chemistry,Oxidation-Reduction,Oxygen,Oxygen: chemistry
@author:   Li, Yanguang and Zhou, Wu and Wang, Hailiang and Xie, Liming and Liang, Yongye and Wei, Fei and Idrobo, Juan-Carlos and Pennycook, Stephen J and Dai, Hongjie
@doi:      10.1038/nnano.2012.72
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22635099
@abstract:
 Oxygen reduction reaction catalysts based on precious metals such as platinum or its alloys are routinely used in fuel cells because of their high activity. Carbon-supported materials containing metals such as iron or cobalt as well as nitrogen impurities have been proposed to increase scalability and reduce costs, but these alternatives usually suffer from low activity and/or gradual deactivation during use. Here, we show that few-walled carbon nanotubes, following outer wall exfoliation via oxidation and high-temperature reaction with ammonia, can act as an oxygen reduction reaction electrocatalyst in both acidic and alkaline solutions. Under a unique oxidation condition, the outer walls of the few-walled carbon nanotubes are partially unzipped, creating nanoscale sheets of graphene attached to the inner tubes. The graphene sheets contain extremely small amounts of irons originated from nanotube growth seeds, and nitrogen impurities, which facilitate the formation of catalytic sites and boost the activity of the catalyst, as revealed by atomic-scale microscopy and electron energy loss spectroscopy. Whereas the graphene sheets formed from the unzipped part of the outer wall of the nanotubes are responsible for the catalytic activity, the inner walls remain intact and retain their electrical conductivity, which facilitates charge transport during electrocatalysis.

**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

4. Creation of graphene sheets attached to inner tubes via unzipping process
5. Facilitation of catalytic sites by iron impurities in graphene sheets
6. Boosting activity of electrocatalyst through nitrogen impurities
7. Atomic-scale microscopy and electron energy loss spectroscopy for characterization
8. Electrical conductivity retained in intact inner walls of carbon nanotubes
9. Charge transport facilitated during electrocatalysis through electrical conductivity
10. Scalability and cost reduction potential of carbon-supported electrocatalysts.

**Specific Topic:** Materials Science - Nanotechnology

**Note:** The article presents an experimental study on the development of a carbon nanotube-graphene complex-based oxygen reduction electrocatalyst. The authors demonstrate that few-walled carbon nanotubes, after oxidation and high-temperature reaction with ammonia, can act as an efficient electrocatalyst in both acidic and alkaline solutions. The graphene sheets formed from the unzipped part of the outer wall of the nanotubes facilitate catalytic activity, while the inner walls retain their electrical conductivity, facilitating charge transport during electrocatalysis.

======== 1052 : Jiang2015

@title:    Thermodynamic and Transport Properties of H 2 O + NaCl from Polarizable Force Fields
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - NNFF{\_}H2O{\_}NaCl - FF{\_}polariza
@author:   Jiang, Hao and Mester, Zoltan and Moultos, Othonas a and Economou, Ioannis G and Panagiotopoulos, Athanassios Z
@doi:      10.1021/acs.jctc.5b00421
@url:      http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/acs.jctc.5b00421 http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acs.jctc.5b00421
@abstract:
 Molecular dynamics and Monte Carlo simulations were performed to obtain thermodynamic and transport properties of the binary H2O + NaCl system using the polarizable force fields of Kiss and Baranyai ( J. Chem. Phys. 2013 , 138 , 204507 and 2014 , 141 , 114501 ). In particular, liquid densities, electrolyte and crystal chemical potentials of NaCl, salt solubilities, mean ionic activity coefficients, vapor pressures, vapor-liquid interfacial tensions, and viscosities were obtained as functions of temperature, pressure, and salt concentration. We compared the performance of the polarizable force fields against fixed-point-charge (nonpolarizable) models. Most of the properties of interest are better represented by the polarizable models, which also remain physically realistic at elevated temperatures.

======== 1053 : Schwarz1998

@title:    Consequences of the stick-slip movement for the scanning force microscopy imaging of graphite
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM

@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.57.2477

======== 1054 : Fujioka2013

@title:    Kilotesla magnetic field due to a capacitor-coil target driven by high power laser.
@keywords: Folder - Extreme{\_}Power{\_}Physics
@author:   Fujioka, Shinsuke and Zhang, Zhe and Ishihara, Kazuhiro and Shigemori, Keisuke and Hironaka, Youichiro and Johzaki, Tomoyuki and Sunahara, Atsushi and Yamamoto, Naoji and Nakashima, Hideki and Watanabe, Tsuguhiro and Shiraga, Hiroyuki and Nishimura, Hiroaki and Azechi, Hiroshi
@doi:      10.1038/srep01170
@url:      http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=3558719{\&}tool=pmcentrez{\&}rendertype=abstract
@abstract:
 Laboratory generation of strong magnetic fields opens new frontiers in plasma and beam physics, astro- and solar-physics, materials science, and atomic and molecular physics. Although kilotesla magnetic fields have already been produced by magnetic flux compression using an imploding metal tube or plasma shell, accessibility at multiple points and better controlled shapes of the field are desirable. Here we have generated kilotesla magnetic fields using a capacitor-coil target, in which two nickel disks are connected by a U-turn coil. A magnetic flux density of 1.5 kT was measured using the Faraday effect 650 $\mu$m away from the coil, when the capacitor was driven by two beams from the GEKKO-XII laser (at 1 kJ (total), 1.3 ns, 0.53 or 1 $\mu$m, and 5 × 10(16) W/cm(2)).

======== 1055 : Lherbier2013a

@title:    Electronic and transport properties of unbalanced sublattice N-doping in graphene.
@keywords: Electron Transport,Electronic,Electronics,Folder - carbon graphene - Carbon Nitride,Graphite,Graphite: chemistry,Nanostructures,Nanostructures: chemistry,Nitrogen,Nitrogen: chemistry,Particle Size,Transistors,Transistors- Electronic
@author:   Lherbier, Aur{\'{e}}lien and Botello-M{\'{e}}ndez, Andr{\'{e}}s Rafael and Charlier, Jean-Christophe
@doi:      10.1021/nl304351z
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23477418
@abstract:
 Using both first-principles techniques and a real-space Kubo-Greenwood approach, electronic and transport properties of nitrogen-doped graphene with a single sublattice preference are investigated. Such a breaking of the sublattice symmetry leads to the appearance of a true band gap in graphene electronic spectrum even for a random distribution of the N dopants. More surprisingly, a natural spatial separation of both types of charge carriers at the band edge is predicted, leading to a highly asymmetric electronic transport. Both the presence of a band gap, allowing large on/off ratio, and an asymmetric transport pave a new route toward efficient graphene-based field-effect transistors.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Condensed Matter Physics
- **Specific Domain:** Graphene, Nitrogen-Doping, Electronic Transport Properties, Sublattice Symmetry Breaking
- **Research Type:** Computational Study

**10 Keywords:**

1. Electronic and transport properties of nitrogen-doped graphene with sublattice preference
2. First-principles techniques for electronic structure calculations
3. Real-space Kubo-Greenwood approach for transport property simulations
4. Appearance of a true band gap in graphene electronic spectrum due to sublattice symmetry breaking
5. Asymmetric electronic transport due to natural spatial separation of charge carriers
6. Efficient graphene-based field-effect transistors with large on/off ratio
7. Potential applications in nanoelectronics and spintronics
8. Impact of sublattice symmetry breaking on electronic properties of doped graphene
9. Electronic structure and transport property calculations for nitrogen-doped graphene
10. Novel route toward efficient graphene-based electronics.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Condensed Matter Physics

**Note:** The article presents a computational study on the electronic and transport properties of nitrogen-doped graphene with sublattice preference using first-principles techniques and real-space Kubo-Greenwood approach. The authors demonstrate the appearance of a true band gap in graphene electronic spectrum due to sublattice symmetry breaking, leading to asymmetric electronic transport and efficient field-effect transistors.

======== 1057 : Gomez2014

@title:    Experimental Demonstration of Fusion-Relevant Conditions in Magnetized Liner Inertial Fusion
@keywords: Folder - Fusion
@author:   Gomez, M. R. and Slutz, Stephen A. and Sefkow, Adam B. and Sinars, Daniel B. and Hahn, K. D. and Hansen, S. B. and Harding, E. C. and Knapp, P. F. and Schmit, P. F. and Jennings, C. A. and Awe, Thomas J. and Geissel, M. and Rovang, Dean C. and Chandler, G. A. and Cooper, G. W. and Cuneo, Michael E. and Harvey-Thompson, A. J. and Herrmann, Mark C. and Hess, M. H. and Johns, O. and Lamppa, Derek C. and Martin, M. R. and McBride, Ryan D. and Peterson, Kyle J. and Porter, J. L. and Robertson, G. K. and Rochau, G. A. and Ruiz, C. L. and Savage, Mark E. and Smith, Ian C. and Stygar, W. A. and Vesey, Roger A.
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevLett.113.155003
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.113.155003
@abstract:
 This Letter presents results from the first fully integrated experiments testing the magnetized liner inertial fusion concept [S. A. Slutz et al., Phys. Plasmas 17, 056303 (2010)], in which a cylinder of deuterium gas with a preimposed 10 Taxial magnetic field is heated by Z beamlet, a 2.5 kJ, 1 TWlaser, and magnetically imploded by a 19 MA, 100 ns rise time current on the Z facility. Despite a predicted peak implosion velocity of only 70 km=s, the fuel reaches a stagnation temperature of approximately 3 keV, with Te ≈ Ti, and produces up to 2 × 1012 thermonuclear deuterium-deuterium neutrons. X-ray emission indicates a hot fuel region with full width at half maximum ranging from 60 to 120 $\mu$m over a 6mm height and lasting approximately 2 ns. Greater than 1010 secondary deuterium-tritium neutrons were observed, indicating significant fuel magnetization given that the estimated radial areal density of the plasma is only 2 mg=cm2.
