======== 1061 : Koller2007

@title:    Intra- and Intermolecular Band Dispersion in an Organic Crystal
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs - projection,★
@author:   Koller, G and Berkebile, S and Oehzelt, M and Puschnig, P and Ambrosch-Draxl, C and Netzer, F P and Ramsey, M G
@doi:      10.1126/science.1143239
@url:      http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/doi/10.1126/science.1143239
@abstract:
 The high crystallinity of many inorganic materials allows their band structures to be determined through angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES). Similar studies of conjugated organic molecules of interest in optoelectronics are often hampered by difficulties in growing well-ordered and well-oriented crystals or films. We have grown crystalline films of uniaxially oriented sexiphenyl molecules and obtained ARPES data. Supported by density-functional calculations, we show that, in the direction parallel to the principal molecular axis, a quasi-one-dimensional band structure of a system of well-defined finite size develops out of individual molecular orbitals. In contrast, perpendicular to the molecules, the band structure reflects the periodicity of the molecular crystal, and continuous bands with a large dispersion were observed.

7. Continuous bands with large dispersion perpendicular to the molecules

======== 1063 : Zakaria2002

@title:    Ferrocene-1,1′-dicarboxylic acid as a building block in supramolecular chemistry: supramolecular structures in one, two and three dimensions
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - SAMs - ferrocene
@author:   Zakaria, Choudhury M. and Ferguson, George and Lough, Alan J. and Glidewell, Christopher
@doi:      10.1107/S010876810200976X
@url:      http://scripts.iucr.org/cgi-bin/paper?S010876810200976X
@abstract:
 The supramolecular structures have been determined for nine adducts formed between organic diamines and ferrocene-1,1'-dicarboxylic acid. In the salt-like 1:1 adduct (1) formed with methylamine, the supramolecular structure is one-dimensional, whereas in the 1:1 adducts formed with 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane, (2), and 4,4'-bipyridyl, (4), and in the hydrated 2:1 adduct (3) formed with morpholine, the hard hydrogen bonds form one-dimensional structures, which are expanded to two dimensions by soft C-H...O hydrogen bonds. The hard hydrogen bonds generate two-dimensional structures in the 2:1 adduct (5) formed with octylamine, where the ferrocene component lies across a centre of inversion, in the 1:1 adduct (6) formed with piperidine and in the tetrahydrofuran-solvated 1:1 adduct (7) formed with di(cyclohexyl)amine. In the 2:3 adduct (8) formed by tris-(2-aminoethyl)amine, and in the 2:1 adduct (9) formed with 2-(4'-hydroxyphenyl)ethylamine (tyramine), where Z' = 1.5 in space group P-1, the hard hydrogen bonds generate three-dimensional structures. No H transfer from O to N occurs in (4) and only partial transfer of H occurs in (2); in (1), (6) and (7), one H is transferred to N from each acid molecule, and in (3), (5), (8) and (9), two H are transferred from each acid molecule.

======== 1064 : Leifer2011a

@title:    Optogenetic manipulation of neural activity in freely moving Caenorhabditis elegans.
@keywords: Animals,Caenorhabditis elegans,Caenorhabditis elegans: physiology,Folder - Artificial{\_}Inteligence{\_}Robotocs - Brain{\_}C,Movement,Muscle Cells,Muscle Cells: physiology,Neurons,Neurons: physiology,Optical Processes,Photobiology,Photobiology: methods
@author:   Leifer, Andrew M and Fang-Yen, Christopher and Gershow, Marc and Alkema, Mark J and Samuel, Aravinthan D T
@doi:      10.1038/nmeth.1554
@url:      http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=3032981{\&}tool=pmcentrez{\&}rendertype=abstract
@abstract:
 We present an optogenetic illumination system capable of real-time light delivery with high spatial resolution to specified targets in freely moving Caenorhabditis elegans. A tracking microscope records the motion of an unrestrained worm expressing channelrhodopsin-2 or halorhodopsin in specific cell types. Image processing software analyzes the worm's position in each video frame, rapidly estimates the locations of targeted cells and instructs a digital micromirror device to illuminate targeted cells with laser light of the appropriate wavelengths to stimulate or inhibit activity. Because each cell in an unrestrained worm is a rapidly moving target, our system operates at high speed (∼50 frames per second) to provide high spatial resolution (∼30 $\mu$m). To test the accuracy, flexibility and utility of our system, we performed optogenetic analyses of the worm motor circuit, egg-laying circuit and mechanosensory circuits that have not been possible with previous methods.

This system is used to perform optogenetic analyses of various neural circuits in the worm, including motor, egg-laying, and mechanosensory circuits, which have not been possible with previous methods.

======== 1066 : Mandi2015

@title:    Chen's derivative rule revisited: Role of tip-orbital interference in STM
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM - STM,★
@author:   M{\'{a}}ndi, G{\'{a}}bor and Palot{\'{a}}s, Kriszti{\'{a}}n
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.91.165406
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.91.165406
======== 1067 : Neese2009

@title:    Efficient and accurate local approximations to coupled-electron pair approaches: An attempt to revive the pair natural orbital method.
@keywords: Algorithms,Computer Simulation,Electrons,Folder - Theory - beyon{\_}HF{\_}DFT,Kinetics,Models,Models- Molecular,Molecular,Molecular Structure,Thermodynamics
@author:   Neese, Frank and Wennmohs, Frank and Hansen, Andreas
@doi:      10.1063/1.3086717
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19317532
@abstract:
 Coupled-electron pair approximations (CEPAs) and coupled-pair functionals (CPFs) have been popular in the 1970s and 1980s and have yielded excellent results for small molecules. Recently, interest in CEPA and CPF methods has been renewed. It has been shown that these methods lead to competitive thermochemical, kinetic, and structural predictions. They greatly surpass second order Moller-Plesset and popular density functional theory based approaches in accuracy and are intermediate in quality between CCSD and CCSD(T) in extended benchmark studies. In this work an efficient production level implementation of the closed shell CEPA and CPF methods is reported that can be applied to medium sized molecules in the range of 50-100 atoms and up to about 2000 basis functions. The internal space is spanned by localized internal orbitals. The external space is greatly compressed through the method of pair natural orbitals (PNOs) that was also introduced by the pioneers of the CEPA approaches. Our implementation also makes extended use of density fitting (or resolution of the identity) techniques in order to speed up the laborious integral transformations. The method is called local pair natural orbital CEPA (LPNO-CEPA) (LPNO-CPF). The implementation is centered around the concepts of electron pairs and matrix operations. Altogether three cutoff parameters are introduced that control the size of the significant pair list, the average number of PNOs per electron pair, and the number of contributing basis functions per PNO. With the conservatively chosen default values of these thresholds, the method recovers about 99.8{\%} of the canonical correlation energy. This translates to absolute deviations from the canonical result of only a few kcal mol(-1). Extended numerical test calculations demonstrate that LPNO-CEPA (LPNO-CPF) has essentially the same accuracy as parent CEPA (CPF) methods for thermochemistry, kinetics, weak interactions, and potential energy surfaces but is up to 500 times faster. The method performs best in conjunction with large and flexible basis sets. These results open the way for large-scale chemical applications.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry
- **Specific Domain:** Coupled-Electron Pair Approaches, Pair Natural Orbital Method, Local Approximations, Quantum Chemical Calculations
- **Research Type:** Development of New Methods and Implementation

**10 Keywords:**

1. Efficient and accurate local approximations to coupled-electron pair approaches
2. Revival of the pair natural orbital method for quantum chemical calculations
3. Closed-shell CEPA and CPF methods with localized internal orbitals
4. Pair natural orbitals (PNOs) for compressing the external space
5. Density fitting techniques for speeding up integral transformations
6. Local pair natural orbital CEPA (LPNO-CEPA) and LPNO-CPF implementations
7. Electron pairs and matrix operations in the implementation
8. Cutoff parameters controlling the significant pair list, PNOs per electron pair, and basis functions per PNO
9. Recovery of 99.8% of canonical correlation energy with default threshold values
10. Improved accuracy and speed compared to parent CEPA and CPF methods.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents the development and implementation of a new local approximation method called LPNO-CEPA (LPNO-CPF) for coupled-electron pair approaches. This method is designed to revive the pair natural orbital method, which was popular in the 1970s and 1980s but fell out of favor due to computational limitations. The LPNO-CEPA implementation uses localized internal orbitals, pair natural orbitals, and density fitting techniques to achieve high accuracy and speed for quantum chemical calculations on medium-sized molecules.

@title:    Imaging the halogen bond in self-assembled halogenbenzenes on silver
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM,Wilsonho.Ho

@doi:      10.1126/science.aai8625
@url:      http://www.sciencemag.org/lookup/doi/10.1126/science.aai8625
======== 1072 : Morawietz2016

@title:    How van der Waals interactions determine the unique properties of water
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Behler
@author:   Morawietz, T. and Singraber, a. and Dellago, C. and Behler, J.
@doi:      10.1073/pnas.1602375113
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1606.07775
@abstract:
 While the interactions between water molecules are dominated by strongly directional hydrogen bonds (HBs), it was recently proposed that relatively weak, isotropic van der Waals (vdW) forces are essential for understanding the properties of liquid water and ice. This insight was derived from ab initio computer simulations, which provide an unbiased description of water at the atomic level and yield information on the underlying molecular forces. However, the high computational cost of such simulations prevents the systematic investigation of the influence of vdW forces on the thermodynamic anomalies of water. Here we develop efficient ab initio-quality neural network potentials and use them to demonstrate that vdW interactions are crucial for the formation of water's density maximum and its negative volume of melting. Both phenomena can be explained by the flexibility of the HB network, which is the result of a delicate balance of weak vdW forces, causing e.g. a pronounced contraction of the second solvation shell upon cooling that induces the density maximum.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

- **Research Type:** Theoretical Study

3. Ab initio computer simulations providing unbiased description of water at atomic level
4. Efficient ab initio-quality neural network potentials for systematic investigation of vdW effects
5. Role of vdW forces in forming water's density maximum and negative volume of melting
6. Flexibility of hydrogen bond network due to delicate balance of weak vdW forces
7. Contraction of second solvation shell upon cooling inducing density maximum
8. Importance of understanding vdW interactions for accurate modeling of water properties
9. Development of neural network potentials for efficient and accurate simulations
10. Insights into the unique behavior of water from ab initio simulations and neural network potentials.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Condensed Matter Physics

**Note:** The article presents a theoretical study on the importance of van der Waals interactions in determining the unique properties of water. Ab initio computer simulations are used to demonstrate that vdW forces play a crucial role in forming water's density maximum and negative volume of melting, which can be explained by the flexibility of the hydrogen bond network. Efficient ab initio-quality neural network potentials are developed for systematic investigation of the influence of vdW forces on water properties.

======== 1073 : Grisham1991

@title:    Scaling of confinement with major and minor radius in the Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor
@keywords: Folder - Nuclear - Fussion
@author:   Grisham, LR and Scott, SD and Goldston, RJ and Bell, MG
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.67.66
======== 1074 : Heeger1988a

@title:    Solitons in conducting polymers
@keywords: Folder - ElectronTransport - electron{\_}phonon
@author:   Heeger, a. J. and Kivelson, S. and Schrieffer, J. R. and Su, W. P.
@doi:      10.1103/RevModPhys.60.781
@abstract:
 Self-localized nonlinear excitations (solitons, polarons, and bipolarons) are fundamental and inherent features of quasi-one-dimensional conducting polymers. Their signatures are evident in many aspects of the physical and chemical properties of this growing class of novel materials. As a result, these polymers represent an opportunity for exploring the novel phenomena associated with topological solitons and their linear confinement which results from weakly lifting the ground-state degeneracy. The authors review the theoretical models that have been developed to describe the physics of polyacetylene and related conducting polymers and summarize the relevant experimental results obtained for these materials. An attempt is made to assess the validity of the soliton model of polyacetylene and its generalization to related systems in which the ground-state degeneracy has been lifted.

- **Research Type:** Review Article

4. Polyacetylene and related conducting polymers
5. Theoretical models for describing the physics of conducting polymers
6. Electron-phonon interactions in conducting polymers
7. Topological solitons and their linear confinement
8. Ground-state degeneracy lifting in conducting polymers
9. Experimental results on polyacetylene and related materials
10. Assessment of the validity of the soliton model for conducting polymers.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Condensed Matter Physics

**Note:** The article presents a review of the theoretical models and experimental results related to solitons in conducting polymers, with a focus on polyacetylene and its relatives. The authors assess the validity of the soliton model for these materials and discuss the implications of topological excitations on their physical properties.

======== 1077 : Monig2018

@title:    Quantitative Assessment of Intermolecular Interactions by Atomic Force Microscopy Imaging Using Copper Oxide Tips
@author:   M{\"{o}}nig, Harry and Amirjalayer, Saeed and Timmer, Alexander and Hu, Zhixin and Liu, Lacheng and {D{\'{i}}az Arado}, Oscar and Cnudde, Marvin and Strassert, Cristian Alejandro and Ji, Wei and Rohlfing, Michael and Fuchs, Harald
======== 1078 : DingxinFan*YukiSakai1389

@title:    Chemical and Steric Effects in Simulating Non-contact Atomic Force Microscopy Images of Organic Molecules on a Cu (111) Substrate
@author:   {Dingxin Fan, *,† Yuki Sakai}, ‡ and James R. Chelikowsky †
@abstract:
 Non-contact mode of atomic force microscopy (nc-AFM) employing a CO-functionalized tip is a very powerful tool for studying molecular structures. However, interpreting nc-AFM images for nonplanar molecules can sometimes be problematic. To illustrate and resolve the nature of such problematic systems, we employ real-space pseudopotentials constructed within density functional theory to simulate nc-AFM images. We focus on several representative nonplanar organic molecules (pentacene, naphthanthrone, olympicene and 6-phenylhexa-1,3,5-triynybenzene (PHTB)) on a typical substrate: the Cu (111) surface. This substrate results in significant distortions in the molecular geometries of pentacene and naphthanthrone. Including these distortions in simulated nc-AFM imaging notably improves the agreement between the simulated and measured images. In naphthanthrone, the relatively large interaction between the O atom and the Cu substrate offers a straightforward explanation for the absence of the C=O bond in the measured image. Nonplanar features such as tilting or twisting are also apparent in olympicene and PHTB. A “triangular” bright feature associated with the -CH2 group in olympicene appears in simulated and measured nc-AFM images. This feature is directly related to the tilting angle of the molecule with respect to the Cu substrate. The “defective” benzene ring feature and the faint ellipsoidal C≡C feature in PHTB can be ascribed to its twisted nature. The ability to simulate such subatomic images in nc-AFM reflects the accuracy and efficiency of calculating quantum forces in real space.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

- **Subcategory:** Physical Chemistry
- **Specific Domain:** Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM), Organic Molecules, Density Functional Theory (DFT)
- **Research Type:** Computational Study

**10 Keywords:**

1. Chemical and Steric Effects in Simulating Non-contact Atomic Force Microscopy Images
2. Non-planar organic molecules on a Cu(111) substrate
3. Real-space pseudopotentials constructed within density functional theory
4. Simulated nc-AFM images of pentacene, naphthanthrone, olympicene and PHTB
5. Distortions in molecular geometries due to Cu substrate interactions
6. Comparison between simulated and measured nc-AFM images
7. Influence of non-planar features such as tilting or twisting on AFM images
8. Identification of specific features in AFM images using DFT calculations
9. Triangular bright feature associated with -CH2 group in olympicene
10. Accuracy and efficiency of calculating quantum forces in real space.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Physical Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents a computational study on the simulation of non-contact atomic force microscopy (nc-AFM) images of non-planar organic molecules on a Cu(111) substrate using density functional theory (DFT). The authors focus on several representative molecules and demonstrate how chemical and steric effects influence the appearance of these molecules in nc-AFM images. By comparing simulated and measured images, they identify specific features associated with molecular distortions and provide insights into the accuracy and efficiency of calculating quantum forces in real space.

======== 1081 : Zhao2011a

@title:    Visualizing individual nitrogen dopants in monolayer graphene.
@author:   Zhao, Liuyan and He, Rui and Rim, Kwang Taeg and Schiros, Theanne and Kim, Keun Soo and Zhou, Hui and Guti{\'{e}}rrez, Christopher and Chockalingam, S P and Arguello, Carlos J and P{\'{a}}lov{\'{a}}, Lucia and Nordlund, Dennis and Hybertsen, Mark S and Reichman, David R and Heinz, Tony F and Kim, Philip and Pinczuk, Aron and Flynn, George W and Pasupathy, Abhay N
@doi:      10.1126/science.1208759
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21852495
@abstract:
 In monolayer graphene, substitutional doping during growth can be used to alter its electronic properties. We used scanning tunneling microscopy, Raman spectroscopy, x-ray spectroscopy, and first principles calculations to characterize individual nitrogen dopants in monolayer graphene grown on a copper substrate. Individual nitrogen atoms were incorporated as graphitic dopants, and a fraction of the extra electron on each nitrogen atom was delocalized into the graphene lattice. The electronic structure of nitrogen-doped graphene was strongly modified only within a few lattice spacings of the site of the nitrogen dopant. These findings show that chemical doping is a promising route to achieving high-quality graphene films with a large carrier concentration.

======== 1083 : Chen2014

@title:    An unconventional bilayer ice structure on a NaCl(001) film.
@keywords: Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2015{\_}11{\_}09,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - NNFF{\_}H2O{\_}NaCl - Exp
@author:   Chen, Ji and Guo, Jing and Meng, Xiangzhi and Peng, Jinbo and Sheng, Jiming and Xu, Limei and Jiang, Ying and Li, Xin-Zheng and Wang, En-Ge
@doi:      10.1038/ncomms5056
@url:      http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/ncomms5056 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24874452
@abstract:
 Water-solid interactions are of broad importance both in nature and technology. The hexagonal bilayer model based on the Bernal-Fowler-Pauling ice rules has been widely adopted to describe water structuring at interfaces. Using a cryogenic scanning tunnelling microscope, here we report a new type of two-dimensional ice-like bilayer structure built from cyclic water tetramers on an insulating NaCl(001) film, which is completely beyond this conventional bilayer picture. A novel bridging mechanism allows the interconnection of water tetramers to form chains, flakes and eventually a two-dimensional extended ice bilayer containing a regular array of Bjerrum D-type defects. Ab initio density functional theory calculations substantiate this bridging growth mode and reveal a striking proton-disordered ice structure. The formation of the periodic Bjerrum defects with unusually high density may have a crucial role as H donor sites in directing multilayer ice growth and in catalysing heterogeneous chemical reactions on water-coated salt surfaces.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Physical Chemistry

The authors identify a bridging mechanism that allows the interconnection of water tetramers and propose a proton-disordered ice structure with implications for heterogeneous chemical reactions. Computational verification using ab initio density functional theory calculations substantiates the findings and highlights the potential significance of the new ice structure.

======== 1085 : Levy

@title:    Improving Distributional Similarity with Lessons Learned from Word Embeddings
@keywords: Folder - Artificial{\_}Inteligence{\_}Robotocs - Sematic
@author:   Levy, Omer
======== 1086 : Verlinde2017a

@title:    Emergent Gravity and the Dark Universe
@author:   Verlinde, Erik
@doi:      10.21468/SciPostPhys.2.3.016
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1611.02269 https://scipost.org/10.21468/SciPostPhys.2.3.016
@abstract:
 Recent theoretical progress indicates that spacetime and gravity emerge together from the entanglement structure of an underlying microscopic theory. These ideas are best understood in Anti-de Sitter space, where they rely on the area law for entanglement entropy. The extension to de Sitter space requires taking into account the entropy and temperature associated with the cosmological horizon. Using insights from string theory, black hole physics and quantum information theory we argue that the positive dark energy leads to a thermal volume law contribution to the entropy that overtakes the area law precisely at the cosmological horizon. Due to the competition between area and volume law entanglement the microscopic de Sitter states do not thermalise at sub-Hubble scales: they exhibit memory effects in the form of an entropy displacement caused by matter. The emergent laws of gravity contain an additional ‘dark' gravitational force describing the ‘elastic' response due to the entropy displacement. We derive an estimate of the strength of this extra force in terms of the baryonic mass, Newton's constant and the Hubble acceleration scale a{\_}0 =cH{\_}0 a 0 = c H 0 , and provide evidence for the fact that this additional ‘dark gravity force' explains the observed phenomena in galaxies and clusters currently attributed to dark matter.

3. Area law for entanglement entropy in Anti-de Sitter space
4. Extension to de Sitter space and cosmological horizon effects
5. Insights from string theory, black hole physics, and quantum information theory
6. Thermal volume law contribution to the entropy due to dark energy
7. Competition between area and volume law entanglement and memory effects
8. Emergent laws of gravity with an additional ‘dark' gravitational force
9. Extra force describing the ‘elastic' response due to entropy displacement
10. Estimate of the strength of this extra force in terms of baryonic mass, Newton's constant, and Hubble acceleration scale.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Theoretical Physics

**Note:** The article presents a theoretical study on emergent gravity and its connection to the dark universe, drawing insights from string theory, black hole physics, and quantum information theory. The authors argue that the positive dark energy leads to a thermal volume law contribution to the entropy, which overtakes the area law at the cosmological horizon. They derive an estimate of the strength of an additional ‘dark' gravitational force caused by entropy displacement and provide evidence for its ability to explain observed phenomena in galaxies and clusters attributed to dark matter.

======== 1087 : Simic-Milosevic2016

@title:    Imaging the Bonds of Dehalogenated Benzene Radicals on Cu(111) and Au(111)
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM - Stochastics,chemical physics,physical chemistry,radicals,scanning probe microscopy,transition metals
@author:   Simic-Milosevic, Violeta and Mehlhorn, Michael and Morgenstern, Karina
@doi:      10.1002/cphc.201600495
@abstract:
 Dissociative adsorption of doubly substituted benzene molecules leads to formation of benzyne radicals. In this study, co- adsorbed hydrogen molecules are used in scanning tunneling hydrogen microscopy to enhance the contrast of the meta- and the para-isomers of these radicals on Cu(111) and Au(111). Up to three hydrogen molecules are attached to one radical. One hydrogen molecule reveals the orientation of the carbon ring and its adsorption site, allowing discrimination between the two radicals. Two hydrogen molecules reflect the bond picture of the carbon skeleton and reveals that adsorption on Cu(111) distorts the meta- isomer differently from its gas-phase distortion. Three hydrogen molecules allow us to determine the bond picture of a minor species.

======== 1088 : Heerklotz2001a

@title:    Detergent-like action of the antibiotic peptide surfactin on lipid membranes.
@keywords: Bacterial Proteins,Bacterial Proteins: metabolism,Calorimetry,Cyclic,Detergents,Detergents: metabolism,Folder - by{\_}Project - Speed{\_}of{\_}Life(blog),Lipopeptides,Liposomes,Liposomes: chemistry,Liposomes: metabolism,Micelles,Peptides,Phosphatidylcholines,Phosphatidylcholines: metabolism,Solubility,Temperature,Thermodynamics
@author:   Heerklotz, H and Seelig, J
@doi:      10.1016/S0006-3495(01)75808-0
@url:      http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=1301632{\&}tool=pmcentrez{\&}rendertype=abstract
@abstract:
 Surfactin is a bacterial lipopeptide with powerful surfactant-like properties. High-sensitivity isothermal titration calorimetry was used to study the self association and membrane partitioning of surfactin. The critical micellar concentration (CMC), was 7.5 microM, the heat of micellization was endothermic with DeltaH(w--{\textgreater}m)(Su) = +4.0 kcal/mol, and the free energy of micellization DeltaG(O,w--{\textgreater}m)(Su) = -9.3 kcal/mol (25 degrees C; 100 mM NaCl; 10 mM TRIS, 1 mM EDTA; pH 8.5). The specific heat capacity of micellization was deduced from temperature dependence of DeltaH(w--{\textgreater}m)(Su) as DeltaC(w--{\textgreater}m)(P) = -250 +/- 10 cal/(mol.K). The data can be explained by combining the hydrophobicity of the fatty acyl chain with that of the hydrophobic amino acids. The membrane partition equilibrium was studied using small (30 nm) and large (100 nm) unilamellar POPC vesicles. At 25 degrees C, the partition coefficient, K, was (2.2 +/- 0.2) x 10(4) M(-1) for large vesicles leading to a free energy of DeltaG(O, w--{\textgreater}b)(Su) = -8.3 kcal/mol. The partition enthalpy was again endothermic, with DeltaH(w--{\textgreater}b)(Su) = 9 +/- 1 kcal/mol. The strong preference of surfactin for micelle formation over membrane insertion explains the high membrane-destabilizing activity of the peptide. For surfactin and a variety of non-ionic detergents, the surfactant-to-lipid ratio, inducing membrane solubilization, R(sat)(b), can be predicted by the simple relationship R(sat)(b) approximately K. CMC.

6. Specific heat capacity of micellization DeltaC(w--{\textgreater}m)(P) = -250 +/- 10 cal/(mol.K)

======== 1089 : Schwartz2011a

@title:    Status of high temperature superconductor based magnets and the conductors they depend upon
@keywords: Folder - Superconductors - HTS{\_}magnets,HTS,magnet,superconductors
@author:   Schwartz, J and Hunte, F and Chan, WK and Gou, XF
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1108.1634
@abstract:
 This paper reviews the status of high temperature superconductors for high field magnets for future devices such as a high energy LHC or a muon collider. Some of the primary challenges faced for the implementation of systems are discussed. Two conductor technologies, Bi{\$}{\_}2{\$}Sr{\$}{\_}2{\$}CaCu{\$}{\_}2{\$}O{\$}{\_}{\{}8+x{\}}{\$} and YBa{\$}{\_}2{\$}Cu{\$}{\_}3{\$}O{\$}{\_}{\{}7-\backslashdelta{\}}{\$}, have emerged as high field conductor options, but their relative advantages and disadvantages for high field magnets are quite different. These are reviewed from an engineering perspective, including coil manufacturing, electromechanical behaviour and quench behaviour. Lastly, the important roles of "system pull" upon conductor and magnet technology development, and of interactions between the materials and magnet communities for accelerating development, are discussed.

======== 1090 : Podeszwa2019

@title:    Correcting long-range electrostatics in DFTB
@author:   Podeszwa, Rafa{\l} and Jankiewicz, Wojciech and Krzu{\'{s}}, Magdalena and Witek, Henryk A.
@doi:      10.1063/1.5099694
@url:      http://dx.doi.org/10.1063/1.5099694
@abstract:
 We demonstrate that the atom-based charge model implemented in the current versions of the density functional tight binding (DFTB) method fails to reproduce the correct charge distribution of a range of systems, including homonuclear molecules, graphene, and nanotubes, resulting in serious distortions in the electrostatic interactions for such systems caused by the missing quadrupole moments. In particular, this failure seriously impacts the long- and medium-range interaction energies of the DFTB plus dispersion (DFTB-D) model, leading to incorrect predictions of translational or rotational barriers in such systems. We show explicitly on examples of H2 and N2 that correct quadrupole moments - and consequently correct electrostatic interactions - can be restored in such systems by adding additional bond (ghost) sites to the homonuclear molecules. Attempts to determine the point charges associated with the additional sites using the usual Mulliken population analysis lead to unphysical results. Instead, these charges can be determined using the actual DFTB densities used in the parameterization process. For homonuclear molecules, we propose an extension to the DFTB-D model by adding charges that reproduce the physically correct quadrupolar charge distribution. The resulting DFTB-D-Q model greatly improves the rotational barriers for interactions of molecular hydrogen and nitrogen with benzene.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Computational Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Density Functional Theory (DFT) Methods
- **Specific Domain:** Density Functional Tight Binding (DFTB) Methodology
- **Research Type:** Method Development and Improvement

**10 Keywords:**

1. Correcting long-range electrostatics in DFTB
2. Atom-based charge model limitations in current DFTB versions
3. Failure to reproduce correct charge distribution for various systems
4. Distortions in electrostatic interactions due to missing quadrupole moments
5. Impact on long- and medium-range interaction energies in DFTB-D model
6. Incorrect predictions of translational or rotational barriers in certain systems
7. Restoring correct quadrupole moments using additional bond (ghost) sites
8. Determination of charges associated with ghost sites using DFTB densities
9. Extension to the DFTB-D model: adding charges for homonuclear molecules
10. Development of the DFTB-D-Q model for improved rotational barriers.

**Specific Topic:** Computational Chemistry - Density Functional Theory Methods

**Note:** The article presents a study on the limitations of the current atom-based charge model in DFTB and proposes an extension to the method by adding charges that reproduce the physically correct quadrupolar charge distribution. This leads to the development of the DFTB-D-Q model, which improves the rotational barriers for interactions of molecular hydrogen and nitrogen with benzene.

======== 1091 : Bandyopadhyay2010a

@title:    Massively parallel computing on an organic molecular layer
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Electronics - mQCA
@author:   Bandyopadhyay, Anirban and Pati, Ranjit and Sahu, Satyajit and Peper, Ferdinand and Fujita, Daisuke
@doi:      10.1038/nphys1636
@url:      http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nphys1636
@abstract:
 Modern computers operate at enormous speeds - capable of executing in excess of 10{\^{}}13 instructions per second - but their sequential approach to processing, by which logical operations are performed one after another, has remained unchanged since the 1950s. In contrast, although individual neurons of the human brain fire at around just 10{\^{}}3 times per second, the simultaneous collective action of millions of neurons enables them to complete certain tasks more efficiently than even the fastest supercomputer. Here we demonstrate an assembly of molecular switches that simultaneously interact to perform a variety of computational tasks including conventional digital logic, calculating Voronoi diagrams, and simulating natural phenomena such as heat diffusion and cancer growth. As well as representing a conceptual shift from serial-processing with static architectures, our parallel, dynamically reconfigurable approach could provide a means to solve otherwise intractable computational problems.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Nanotechnology
- **Subcategory:** Molecular Electronics
- **Specific Domain:** Molecular Logic Gates, Quantum Computing, Organic Molecular Layers
- **Research Type:** Experimental Study with Computational Modeling Implications

**10 Keywords:**

1. Massively parallel computing on an organic molecular layer
2. Conceptual shift from serial-processing to parallel, dynamically reconfigurable approach
3. Assembly of molecular switches for simultaneous interaction and computation
4. Digital logic gates based on molecular interactions

**Note:** The article presents an experimental study on the assembly of molecular switches that can simultaneously interact to perform various computational tasks, including digital logic, Voronoi diagrams calculation, and simulation of natural phenomena. This approach represents a conceptual shift from traditional serial-processing with static architectures and could provide a means to solve otherwise intractable computational problems.

======== 1092 : Sobczak2012

@title:    Rapid Folding of DNA into Nanoscale Shapes at Constant Temperature
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Engeneering - Molecular assembl
@author:   Sobczak, Jean-Philippe J and Martin, Thomas G and Gerling, Thomas and Dietz, Hendrik
@doi:      10.1126/science.1229919
@url:      http://www.sciencemag.org/content/338/6113/1458.abstract http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/doi/10.1126/science.1229919
@abstract:
 We demonstrate that, at constant temperature, hundreds of DNA strands can cooperatively fold a long template DNA strand within minutes into complex nanoscale objects. Folding occurred out of equilibrium along nucleation-driven pathways at temperatures that could be influenced by the choice of sequences, strand lengths, and chain topology. Unfolding occurred in apparent equilibrium at higher temperatures than those for folding. Folding at optimized constant temperatures enabled the rapid production of three-dimensional DNA objects with yields that approached 100{\%}. The results point to similarities with protein folding in spite of chemical and structural differences. The possibility for rapid and high-yield assembly will enable DNA nanotechnology for practical applications.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Nanotechnology
- **Subcategory:** Molecular Engineering
- **Specific Domain:** DNA Origami, DNA Folding, DNA Self-Assembly
- **Research Type:** Experimental Study with Theoretical Modeling Implications

**10 Keywords:**

1. Rapid folding of DNA into nanoscale shapes at constant temperature
2. Cooperative folding of hundreds of DNA strands within minutes
3. Nucleation-driven pathways for out-of-equilibrium folding
4. Influence of sequence, strand length, and chain topology on folding temperatures
5. Unfolding in apparent equilibrium at higher temperatures
6. High-yield assembly of three-dimensional DNA objects
7. Comparison with protein folding mechanisms
8. Similarities between DNA and protein folding despite chemical differences
9. Potential applications of rapid and high-yield DNA assembly
10. Implications for DNA nanotechnology.

**Specific Topic:** Nanotechnology - Molecular Engineering

**Note:** The article presents an experimental study on the rapid folding of long template DNA strands into complex nanoscale objects through cooperative interactions between hundreds of DNA strands. This process occurs out-of-equilibrium at constant temperature and is influenced by sequence, strand length, and chain topology. The results point to similarities with protein folding mechanisms and suggest that rapid and high-yield assembly will enable practical applications in DNA nanotechnology.

@title:    Carbon nanotubes: present and future commercial applications.
@keywords: Biosensing Techniques,Biotechnology,Carbon,Carbon: chemistry,Commerce,Commerce: trends,Folder - carbon graphene,Nanotubes,Nanotubes- Carbon,Nanotubes- Carbon: chemistry,Polymers,Polymers: chemistry

@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23372006
@abstract:
 Worldwide commercial interest in carbon nanotubes (CNTs) is reflected in a production capacity that presently exceeds several thousand tons per year. Currently, bulk CNT powders are incorporated in diverse commercial products ranging from rechargeable batteries, automotive parts, and sporting goods to boat hulls and water filters. Advances in CNT synthesis, purification, and chemical modification are enabling integration of CNTs in thin-film electronics and large-area coatings. Although not yet providing compelling mechanical strength or electrical or thermal conductivities for many applications, CNT yarns and sheets already have promising performance for applications including supercapacitors, actuators, and lightweight electromagnetic shields.

======== 1095 : Dong2015

@title:    Two-Dimensional Hierarchical Supramolecular Assembly of a Silole Derivative and Surface-Assisted Chemical Transformations
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - Examples of syste
@author:   Dong, Lei and Wang, Weihua and Lin, Tao and Diller, Katharina and Barth, Johannes V. and Liu, Jianzhao and Tang, Ben Zhong and Klappenberger, Florian and Lin, Nian
@doi:      10.1021/acs.jpcc.5b00116
@url:      http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acs.jpcc.5b00116
@abstract:
 The bonding and organization of 1,1,2,3,4,5-hexapheny- silole (HPS) molecules adsorbed on Cu(111) and Ag(111) surfaces has been investigated using low-temperature scanning tunneling microscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. In room-temperature-prepared samples, HPS molecules form extended networks that exhibit hierarchical organization stabilized by $\pi$−$\pi$ interaction between exocyclic phenyl groups. After 430 K annealing on Cu(111), the compound is chemically altered as evidenced by Si 2p core level shift. This change is accompanied by a different adsorption configuration and a transformation of the assembled structures from networks to uniformly sized chiral clusters. The clusters, each composed of three molecules, are dispersively distributed on the surface. Monte Carlo simulations signal that this new phase can be understood as a result of competing long-range repulsions and short-range attractions. After even higher annealing at 520 K, the clusters dissolve and the exocyclic phenyl moieties undergo a cyclodehydrogenation reaction to form a polycyclic aromatic compound incorporating a silole moiety. In sharp contrast, on Ag(111), the HPS molecules do not show these changes but desorb from the surface at elevated temperatures. Our results demonstrate that the two-dimensional supramolecular assembly of intact HPS is insensitive to the choice of substrate at room temperature, but at high temperatures, the substrate's chemical activity can induce selective chemical transformations resulting in a significantly different assembly behavior

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Materials Science
- **Subcategory:** Surface Chemistry, Supramolecular Assembly
- **Specific Domain:** 2D Hierarchical Assemblies, Silole Derivatives, Surface-Assisted Chemical Transformations
- **Research Type:** Experimental Study with Theoretical Modeling Implications

**10 Keywords:**

1. Two-dimensional hierarchical supramolecular assembly of a silole derivative
2. HPS molecule adsorption on Cu(111) and Ag(111) surfaces
3. Low-temperature scanning tunneling microscopy (LT-STM) characterization
4. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of surface chemistry
5. Room-temperature-prepared samples exhibit hierarchical organization
6. Annealing-induced chemical transformations and structural changes on Cu(111)
7. Formation of uniformly sized chiral clusters on Cu(111) at high temperatures
8. Cyclodehydrogenation reaction on Cu(111) resulting in polycyclic aromatic compound
9. Ag(111) surface shows no significant changes to HPS molecules at elevated temperatures
10. Substrate-dependent chemical transformations and assembly behavior.

**Specific Topic:** Materials Science - Surface Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents an experimental study on the 2D hierarchical supramolecular assembly of a silole derivative (HPS) molecules adsorbed on Cu(111) and Ag(111) surfaces. The results demonstrate that at high temperatures, the substrate's chemical activity can induce selective chemical transformations resulting in a significantly different assembly behavior. The study highlights the importance of the choice of substrate in surface-assisted chemical transformations and supramolecular assembly.

======== 1100 : Bose2015

@title:    Evolution of a designless nanoparticle network into reconfigurable Boolean logic
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Electronics - Nanocell,Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2017{\_}07{\_}03,Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2017{\_}07{\_}03 (1),Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021
@author:   Bose, S. K. and Lawrence, C. P. and Liu, Z. and Makarenko, K. S. and van Damme, R. M. J. and Broersma, H. J. and van der Wiel, W. G.
@doi:      10.1038/nnano.2015.207
@url:      http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nnano.2015.207 http://www.nature.com/articles/nnano.2015.207
@abstract:
 Natural computers exploit the emergent properties and massive parallelism of interconnected networks of locally active components. Evolution has resulted in systems that compute quickly and that use energy efficiently, utilizing whatever physical properties are exploitable. Man-made computers, on the other hand, are based on circuits of functional units that follow given design rules. Hence, potentially exploitable physical processes, such as capacitive crosstalk, to solve a problem are left out. Until now, designless nanoscale networks of inanimate matter that exhibit robust computational functionality had not been realized. Here we artificially evolve the electrical properties of a disordered nanomaterials system (by optimizing the values of control voltages using a genetic algorithm) to perform computational tasks reconfigurably. We exploit the rich behaviour that emerges from interconnected metal nanoparticles, which act as strongly nonlinear single-electron transistors, and find that this nanoscale architecture can be configured in situ into any Boolean logic gate. This universal, reconfigurable gate would require about ten transistors in a conventional circuit. Our system meets the criteria for the physical realization of (cellular) neural networks: universality (arbitrary Boolean functions), compactness, robustness and evolvability, which implies scalability to perform more advanced tasks. Our evolutionary approach works around device-to-device variations and the accompanying uncertainties in performance. Moreover, it bears a great potential for more energy-efficient computation, and for solving problems that are very hard to tackle in conventional architectures.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Nanotechnology
- **Subcategory:** Molecular Electronics, Nanoscale Computing
- **Specific Domain:** Artificial Evolution of Nanoparticle Networks, Reconfigurable Boolean Logic, Single-Electron Transistors
- **Research Type:** Experimental Study with Theoretical Modeling Implications

**10 Keywords:**

1. Evolution of a designless nanoparticle network into reconfigurable Boolean logic
2. Emergent properties and parallelism in interconnected networks of locally active components
3. Artificial evolution of electrical properties using genetic algorithm
4. Disordered nanomaterials system as a computational platform
5. Exploiting capacitive crosstalk and other physical processes for computation
6. Reconfigurable Boolean logic gate using metal nanoparticles as single-electron transistors
7. Universality, compactness, robustness, and evolvability of the nanoparticle network architecture
8. Potential for energy-efficient computation and solving complex problems
9. Implications for the development of cellular neural networks and advanced computing architectures
10. Novel approach to overcoming device-to-device variations and uncertainties in performance.

**Specific Topic:** Nanotechnology - Molecular Electronics

**Note:** The article presents an innovative approach to creating reconfigurable Boolean logic gates using artificially evolved nanoparticle networks. By leveraging emergent properties and parallelism, this system has the potential to revolutionize computing by solving complex problems efficiently and compactly.

======== 1102 : Junquera2001a

@title:    Numerical atomic orbitals for linear-scaling calculations
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods,SIESTA,basiset
@author:   Junquera, Javier and Paz, {\'{O}}scar and S{\'{a}}nchez-Portal, Daniel and Artacho, Emilio
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.64.235111
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.64.235111
======== 1103 : Stroscio2004

@title:    Controlling the dynamics of a single atom in lateral atom manipulation.
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM - point{\_}contact
@author:   Stroscio, Joseph a and Celotta, Robert J
@doi:      10.1126/science.1102370
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15358867
@abstract:
 We studied the dynamics of a single cobalt (Co) atom during lateral manipulation on a copper (111) surface in a low-temperature scanning tunneling microscope. The Co binding site locations were revealed in a detailed image that resulted from lateral Co atom motion within the trapping potential of the scanning tip. Random telegraph noise, corresponding to the Co atom switching between hexagonal close-packed (hcp) and face-centered cubic (fcc) sites, was seen when the tip was used to try to position the Co atom over the higher energy hcp site. Varying the probe tip height modified the normal copper (111) potential landscape and allowed the residence time of the Co atom in these sites to be varied. At low tunneling voltages (less than approximately 5 millielectron volts), the transfer rate between sites was independent of tunneling voltage, current, and temperature. At higher voltages, the transfer rate exhibited a strong dependence on tunneling voltage, indicative of vibrational heating by inelastic electron scattering.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Subcategory:** Surface Science, Atomic Manipulation
- **Specific Domain:** Lateral Atom Manipulation, Single-Atom Dynamics, Scanning Tunneling Microscopy (STM)
- **Research Type:** Experimental Study with Theoretical Modeling Implications

**10 Keywords:**

1. Controlling the dynamics of a single atom in lateral atom manipulation
2. Lateral Co atom motion within the trapping potential of a scanning tip
3. Co binding site locations revealed through detailed image analysis
4. Random telegraph noise due to Co atom switching between hcp and fcc sites
5. Modifying probe tip height to vary Co atom residence time in different sites
6. Varying tunneling voltage, current, and temperature to study transfer rate behavior
7. Transfer rate independence of tunneling voltage at low voltages (less than 5 mV)
8. Vibrational heating by inelastic electron scattering at higher tunneling voltages
9. Strong dependence of transfer rate on tunneling voltage at high voltages (above 5 mV)
10. Implications for understanding atomic dynamics and manipulation techniques.

**Specific Topic:** Condensed Matter Physics - Surface Science

**Note:** The article presents a detailed study of the dynamics of a single Co atom during lateral manipulation on a Cu(111) surface using STM. The results provide insights into the behavior of individual atoms under controlled conditions, which is essential for understanding and manipulating atomic-scale structures.

======== 1104 : Jones2011

@title:    Modular and predictable assembly of porous organic molecular crystals
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - plymorphs
@author:   Jones, James T a and Hasell, Tom and Wu, Xiaofeng and Bacsa, John and Jelfs, Kim E and Schmidtmann, Marc and Chong, Samantha Y and Adams, Dave J and Trewin, Abbie and Schiffman, Florian and Cora, Furio and Slater, Ben and Steiner, Alexander and Day, Graeme M and Cooper, Andrew I
@doi:      10.1038/nature10125
@url:      http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature10125 http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nature10125
@abstract:
 Nanoporous molecular frameworks 1–7 are important in applica-tions such as separation, storage and catalysis. Empirical rules exist for their assembly but it is still challenging to place and segregate functionality in three-dimensional porous solids in a predictable way. Indeed, recent studies of mixed crystalline frameworks suggest a preference for the statistical distribution of functionalities throughout the pores 7 rather than, for example, the functional group localization found in the reactive sites of enzymes 8 . This is a potential limitation for 'one-pot' chemical syntheses of porous frameworks from simple starting materials. An alternative strategy is to prepare porous solids from synthetically preorganized molecu-lar pores 9–15 . In principle, functional organic pore modules could be covalently prefabricated and then assembled to produce materials with specific properties. However, this vision of mix-and-match assembly is far from being realized, not least because of the chal-lenge in reliably predicting three-dimensional structures for molecular crystals, which lack the strong directional bonding found in networks. Here we show that highly porous crystalline solids can be produced by mixing different organic cage modules that self-assemble by means of chiral recognition. The structures of the resulting materials can be predicted computationally 16,17

10. Implications for the development of materials with specific properties.

**Specific Topic:** Materials Science - Crystal Engineering

**Note:** The article presents a study on the modular and predictable assembly of porous organic molecular crystals using chiral recognition as a mechanism for self-assembly. The results demonstrate that highly porous crystalline solids can be produced by mixing different organic cage modules, and the structures of the resulting materials can be predicted computationally. This research has implications for the development of materials with specific properties.

======== 1105 : KondatiNatarajan2015

@title:    Representing the potential-energy surface of protonated water clusters by high-dimensional neural network potentials
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods - Neural{\_}Networks
@author:   {Kondati Natarajan}, Suresh and Morawietz, Tobias and Behler, J{\"{o}}rg
@doi:      10.1039/C4CP04751F
@url:      http://dx.doi.org/10.1039/C4CP04751F http://xlink.rsc.org/?DOI=C4CP04751F
@abstract:
 Investigating the properties of protons in water is essential for$\backslash$nunderstanding many chemical processes in aqueous solution. While$\backslash$nimportant insights can in principle be gained by accurate and well-established$\backslash$nmethods like ab initio molecular dynamics simulations, the computational$\backslash$ncosts of these techniques are often very high. This prevents studying$\backslash$nlarge systems on long time scales, which is severely limiting the$\backslash$napplicability of computer simulations to address a wide range of$\backslash$ninteresting phenomena. Developing more efficient potentials enabling$\backslash$nthe simulation of water including dissociation and recombination$\backslash$nevents with first-principles accuracy is a very challenging task.$\backslash$nIn particular protonated water clusters have become important model$\backslash$nsystems to assess the reliability of such potentials, as the presence$\backslash$nof the excess proton induces substantial changes in the local hydrogen$\backslash$nbond patterns and many energetically similar isomers exist, which$\backslash$nare extremely difficult to describe. In recent years it has been$\backslash$ndemonstrated for a number of systems including neutral water clusters$\backslash$nof varying size that neural networks (NNs) can be used to construct$\backslash$npotentials with close to first-principles accuracy. Based on density-functional$\backslash$ntheory (DFT) calculations, here we present a reactive full-dimensional$\backslash$nNN potential for protonated water clusters up to the octamer. A detailed$\backslash$ninvestigation of this potential shows that the energetic, structural,$\backslash$nand vibrational properties are in excellent agreement with DFT results$\backslash$nmaking the NN approach a very promising candidate for developing$\backslash$na high-quality potential for water. This finding is further supported$\backslash$nby first preliminary but very encouraging NN-based simulations of$\backslash$nthe bulk liquid.

======== 1108 : Chavent2011

@title:    GPU-powered tools boost molecular visualization
@keywords: Binding site highlighting,GPU visualization,Huge systems visualization,Molecular representations,Molecular shape enhancement
@author:   Chavent, Matthieu and L{\'{e}}vy, Bruno and Krone, Michael and Bidmon, Katrin and Nomin{\'{e}}, Jean Philippe and Ertl, Thomas and Baaden, Marc
@doi:      10.1093/bib/bbq089
@abstract:
 Recent advances in experimental structure determination provide a wealth of structural data on huge macromolecular assemblies such as the ribosome or viral capsids, available in public databases. Further structural models arise from reconstructions using symmetry orders or fitting crystal structures into low-resolution maps obtained by electron-microscopy or small angle X-ray scattering experiments. Visual inspection of these huge structures remains an important way of unravelling some of their secrets. However, such visualization cannot conveniently be carried out using conventional rendering approaches, either due to performance limitations or due to lack of realism. Recent developments, in particular drawing benefit from the capabilities of Graphics Processing Units (GPUs), herald the next generation of molecular visualization solutions addressing these issues. In this article, we present advances in computer science and visualization that help biologists visualize, understand and manipulate large and complex molecular systems, introducing concepts that remain little-known in the bioinformatics field. Furthermore, we compile currently available software and methods enhancing the shape perception of such macromolecular assemblies, for example based on surface simplification or lighting ameliorations. {\textcopyright} The Author 2011. Published by Oxford University Press.

@url:      http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=2690042{\&}tool=pmcentrez{\&}rendertype=abstract
@abstract:
 Spider silks are renowned for their excellent mechanical properties and biomimetic and industrial potentials. They are formed from the natural refolding of water-soluble fibroins with alpha-helical and random coil structures in silk glands into insoluble fibers with mainly beta-structures. The structures of the fibroins at atomic resolution and silk formation mechanism remain largely unknown. Here, we report the 3D structures of individual domains of a approximately 366-kDa eggcase silk protein that consists of 20 identical type 1 repetitive domains, one type 2 repetitive domain, and conserved nonrepetitive N- and C-terminal domains. The structures of the individual domains in solution were determined by using NMR techniques. The domain interactions were investigated by NMR and dynamic light-scattering techniques. The formation of micelles and macroscopic fibers from the domains was examined by electron microscopy. We find that either of the terminal domains covalently linked with at least one repetitive domain spontaneously forms micelle-like structures and can be further transformed into fibers at {\textgreater} or = 37 degrees C and a protein concentration of {\textgreater} 0.1 wt{\%}. Our biophysical and biochemical experiments indicate that the less hydrophilic terminal domains initiate the assembly of the proteins and form the outer layer of the micelles whereas the more hydrophilic repetitive domains are embedded inside to ensure the formation of the micelle-like structures that are the essential intermediates in silk formation. Our results establish the roles of individual silk protein domains in fiber formation and provide the basis for designing miniature fibroins for producing artificial silks.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Materials Science
- **Subcategory:** Biomaterials, Biomechanics
- **Specific Domain:** Silk Protein Structure, Fibroin Assembly, Micelle Formation, Fiber Morphology
- **Research Type:** Experimental Study with Theoretical Modeling Implications

**10 Keywords:**

1. Solution structure of eggcase silk protein and its implications for silk fiber formation
2. Amino acid sequence analysis of spider silks
3. Structure determination of individual domains of a 366-kDa eggcase silk protein by NMR techniques
4. Investigation of domain interactions using NMR and dynamic light-scattering techniques
5. Electron microscopy examination of micelle and fiber formation from domains
6. Role of terminal domains in initiating assembly and forming outer layer of micelles
7. Importance of hydrophobic and hydrophilic properties of repetitive domains
8. Essential intermediates in silk formation: micelle-like structures
9. Basis for designing miniature fibroins for producing artificial silks
10. Potential applications of understanding silk protein structure and fiber assembly.

**Specific Topic:** Materials Science - Biomaterials

**Note:** The article presents an experimental study on the solution structure of eggcase silk protein and its implications for silk fiber formation. The researchers used NMR techniques to determine the 3D structures of individual domains, investigated domain interactions, and examined micelle and fiber formation using electron microscopy. Their results provide insights into the roles of individual silk protein domains in fiber assembly and suggest a basis for designing artificial silks with specific properties.

======== 1111 : Sonter1997

@title:    The technical and economic feasibility of mining the near-earth asteroids
@keywords: Folder - Space - asteroids
@author:   Sonter, MJ
@url:      http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0094576598000873
======== 1112 : Hapala2014

@title:    Origin of High-Resolution IETS-STM Images of Organic Molecules with Functionalized Tips
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021,Folder - {\_}by{\_}source - Moje
@author:   Hapala, Prokop and Temirov, Ruslan and Tautz, F.S. Stefan and Jel{\'{i}}nek, Pavel
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevLett.113.226101
@url:      https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.113.226101 http://journals.aps.org/prl/abstract/10.1103/PhysRevLett.113.226101 http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.113.226101
@abstract:
 Recently, the family of high-resolution scanning probe imaging techniques using decorated tips has been complemented by a method based on inelastic electron tunneling spectroscopy (IETS). The new technique resolves the inner structure of organic molecules by mapping the vibrational energy of a single carbon monoxide (CO) molecule positioned at the apex of a scanning tunneling microscope (STM) tip. Here, we explain high-resolution IETS imaging by extending a model developed earlier for STM and atomic force microscopy (AFM) imaging with decorated tips. In particular, we show that the tip decorated with CO acts as a nanoscale sensor that changes the energy of its frustrated translation mode in response to changes of the local curvature of the surface potential. In addition, we show that high resolution AFM, STM, and IETS-STM images can deliver information about the charge distribution within molecules deposited on a surface. To demonstrate this, we extend our mechanical model by taking into account electrostatic forces acting on the decorated tip in the surface Hartree potential.

**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Scanning Probe Microscopy (SPM), Surface Science
- **Specific Domain:** High-Resolution Imaging Techniques, Inelastic Electron Tunneling Spectroscopy (IETS), Functionalized Tips, Organic Molecules
- **Research Type:** Theoretical Modeling and Experimental Study

**10 Keywords:**

1. Origin of high-resolution IETS-STM images of organic molecules with functionalized tips
2. Extension of a model for STM and AFM imaging with decorated tips to IETS-STM
3. Nanoscale sensor properties of CO-decorated tips in IETS-STM
4. Response of frustrated translation mode to changes in surface potential curvature
5. High-resolution AFM, STM, and IETS-STM images deliver information about charge distribution within molecules
6. Incorporation of electrostatic forces into mechanical model of decorated tip
7. Interaction between decorated tip and surface Hartree potential
8. Implications for understanding charge distribution in organic molecules
9. Development of new imaging techniques for molecular-scale characterization
10. Potential applications in fields such as materials science, chemistry, and nanotechnology.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Surface Science

**Note:** The article presents a theoretical modeling study that explains the origin of high-resolution IETS-STM images of organic molecules with functionalized tips. The researchers extend their earlier model for STM and AFM imaging to include the effects of inelastic electron tunneling spectroscopy (IETS) and demonstrate that high-resolution images can deliver information about charge distribution within molecules. This work has implications for understanding molecular-scale properties and has potential applications in various fields.

======== 1113 : Liebig

@title:    Keywords
@author:   Liebig, Alexander and Hapala, Prokop and Weymouth, Alfred J and Franz, J
======== 1114 : Shu2015b

@title:    Nonradiative recombination via conical intersections arising at defects on the oxidized silicon surface
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs - Quenching Defects
@author:   Shu, Yinan and Levine, Benjamin G.
@doi:      10.1021/jp5114202
@abstract:
 Nonradiative recombination of excitations in semiconductors limits the performance of photovoltaics, light-emitting diodes, photocatalysts, and other devices. Herein we investigate the role that two known defects on the oxidized surface of silicon play in nonradiative recombination in silicon nanocrystals. We apply ab initio multiple spawning and multireference electronic structure methods to model the nonradiative processes which follow excitation of two cluster models of silicon epoxide defects that differ in the oxidation state of their respective silicon atoms. We find conical intersections in both clusters, and these intersections are found to be accessible at energies corresponding to visible wavelengths. In both cases, photochemical opening of the epoxide ring precedes nonradiative decay. These results support the hypothesis that conical intersections associated with specific defect structures on the oxidized surface of silicon nanocrystals facilitate nonradiative recombination. Discussion regarding how this hypothesis can be tested experimentally is presented.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Theoretical Chemistry

The researchers used ab initio methods to model the nonradiative processes and found conical intersections accessible at energies corresponding to visible wavelengths, supporting the hypothesis that these intersections facilitate nonradiative recombination. This work has implications for understanding and mitigating nonradiative recombination in various devices.

======== 1118 : Entler2018c

@title:    Approximation of the economy of fusion energy
@keywords: Economy,External costs,Fusion energy,LCOE,NPV,Nuclear fusion
@author:   Entler, Slavomir and Horacek, Jan and Dlouhy, Tomas and Dostal, Vaclav
@doi:      10.1016/j.energy.2018.03.130
@url:      https://doi.org/10.1016/j.energy.2018.03.130
@abstract:
 Conceptual design activities of the first fusion power plants were launched in recent years with a view to putting them into operation by 2050. Nuclear fusion offers significant benefits in comparison with exploited energy sources, especially limitless fuel reserves, inherent nuclear safety, and negligible impact on the environment. The challenge is a high heat and neutron loading of the fusion reactors nuclear zone. The paper brings the ex-ante economic analysis of the fusion power plant model DEMO2 in terms of the cost of electricity. The model investment and operating costs are presented. The limit sales price of electricity was found using the net present value method. The levelized cost of electricity LCOE method with the inclusion of external costs is used for a comparison of selected power plant types based on the OECD statistical data and the EU ExternE project results. The comparison shows the levelized cost of electricity of fusion power plants competitive to the actual renewable resources. After internalisation of external costs, the fusion power plants should become even the second cheapest power source.

======== 1120 : Fuchs2016a

@title:    Stochastic thermodynamics of Learning
@keywords: Folder - Information{\_}physics
@author:   Fuchs, Jaco and Goldt, Sebastian and Seifert, Udo
@doi:      10.1209/0295-5075/113/60009

======== 1121 : Green2007

@title:    A 160-kilobit molecular electronic memory patterned at 1011 bits per square centimetre
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Electronics - Molecular{\_}memory,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Stochastic Nanomachines - m
@author:   Green, Jonathan E and {Wook Choi}, Jang and Boukai, Akram and Bunimovich, Yuri and Johnston-Halperin, Ezekiel and DeIonno, Erica and Luo, Yi and Sheriff, Bonnie a and Xu, Ke and {Shik Shin}, Young and Tseng, Hsian-Rong and Stoddart, J Fraser and Heath, James R
@doi:      10.1038/nature05462
@url:      http://www.nature.com/articles/nature05462 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17251976
@abstract:
 The primary metric for gauging progress in the various semiconductor integrated circuit technologies is the spacing, or pitch, between the most closely spaced wires within a dynamic random access memory (DRAM) circuit. Modern DRAM circuits have 140 nm pitch wires and a memory cell size of 0.0408 mum(2). Improving integrated circuit technology will require that these dimensions decrease over time. However, at present a large fraction of the patterning and materials requirements that we expect to need for the construction of new integrated circuit technologies in 2013 have 'no known solution'. Promising ingredients for advances in integrated circuit technology are nanowires, molecular electronics and defect-tolerant architectures, as demonstrated by reports of single devices and small circuits. Methods of extending these approaches to large-scale, high-density circuitry are largely undeveloped. Here we describe a 160,000-bit molecular electronic memory circuit, fabricated at a density of 10(11) bits cm(-2) (pitch 33 nm; memory cell size 0.0011 microm2), that is, roughly analogous to the dimensions of a DRAM circuit projected to be available by 2020. A monolayer of bistable, [2]rotaxane molecules served as the data storage elements. Although the circuit has large numbers of defects, those defects could be readily identified through electronic testing and isolated using software coding. The working bits were then configured to form a fully functional random access memory circuit for storing and retrieving information.

**Specific Topic:** Materials Science - Molecular Electronics

The results demonstrate the feasibility of molecular electronics for integrated circuit technology advances, particularly in terms of defect-tolerant architectures and high-density circuitry. The study highlights the potential applications of molecular electronics in fields such as data storage, computing, and communication.

======== 1122 : DeOteyza2013

@title:    Direct imaging of covalent bond structure in single-molecule chemical reactions.
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM,Folder - SPM - Key{\_}Experiments
@author:   de Oteyza, Dimas G and Gorman, Patrick and Chen, Yen-Chia and Wickenburg, Sebastian and Riss, Alexander and Mowbray, Duncan J and Etkin, Grisha and Pedramrazi, Zahra and Tsai, Hsin-Zon and Rubio, Angel and Crommie, Michael F and Fischer, Felix R
@doi:      10.1126/science.1238187
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23722428
@abstract:
 Observing the intricate chemical transformation of an individual molecule as it undergoes a complex reaction is a long-standing challenge in molecular imaging. Advances in scanning probe microscopy now provide the tools to visualize not only the frontier orbitals of chemical reaction partners and products, but their internal covalent bond configurations as well. We used noncontact atomic force microscopy to investigate reaction-induced changes in the detailed internal bond structure of individual oligo-(phenylene-1,2-ethynylenes) on a (100) oriented silver surface as they underwent a series of cyclization processes. Our images reveal the complex surface reaction mechanisms underlying thermally induced cyclization cascades of enediynes. Calculations using ab initio density functional theory provide additional support for the proposed reaction pathways.

======== 1124 : Patera2019a

@title:    Accessing a Charged Intermediate State Involved in the Excitation of Single Molecules
@author:   Patera, Laerte L and Queck, Fabian and Scheuerer, Philipp and Moll, Nikolaj and Repp, Jascha
======== 1125 : Lee2022

@title:    MolE8: finding DFT potential energy surface minima values from force-field optimised organic molecules with new machine learning representations
@author:   Lee, Sanha and Ermanis, Kristaps and Goodman, Jonathan M.
@doi:      10.1039/d1sc06324c
@abstract:
 The use of machine learning techniques in computational chemistry has gained significant momentum since large molecular databases are now readily available. Predictions of molecular properties using machine learning have advantages over the traditional quantum mechanics calculations because they can be cheaper computationally without losing the accuracy. We present a new extrapolatable and explainable molecular representation based on bonds, angles and dihedrals that can be used to train machine learning models. The trained models can accurately predict the electronic energy and the free energy of small organic molecules with atom types C, H N and O, with a mean absolute error of 1.2 kcal mol−1. The models can be extrapolated to larger organic molecules with an average error of less than 3.7 kcal mol−1 for 10 or fewer heavy atoms, which represent a chemical space two orders of magnitude larger. The rapid energy predictions of multiple molecules, up to 7 times faster than previous ML models of similar accuracy, has been achieved by sampling geometries around the potential energy surface minima. Therefore, the input geometries do not have to be located precisely on the minima and we show that accurate density functional theory energy predictions can be made from force-field optimised geometries with a mean absolute error 2.5 kcal mol−1

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry, Machine Learning
- **Specific Domain:** Molecular Energy Prediction, Density Functional Theory (DFT), Force-Field Optimisation, Machine Learning Representations
- **Research Type:** Method Development Study with Theoretical Modeling Implications

1. MolE8: finding DFT potential energy surface minima values from force-field optimised organic molecules

3. Extrapolatable and explainable molecular representation based on bonds, angles, and dihedrals
4. Accurate predictions of electronic energy and free energy using machine learning models
