8. Sampling geometries around potential energy surface minima for accurate energy predictions
9. Force-field optimised geometries can be used as input for DFT energy predictions with a mean absolute error of 2.5 kcal mol^-1
10. Potential applications in fields such as materials science, pharmaceuticals, and chemical engineering.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents research on developing new machine learning representations for molecular energy prediction using density functional theory (DFT) and force-field optimisation. The study demonstrates the ability to accurately predict electronic energies and free energies of small organic molecules with a mean absolute error of 1.2 kcal mol^-1, and extrapolates this accuracy to larger organic molecules with an average error of less than 3.7 kcal mol^-1. The results highlight the potential for machine learning models to rapidly predict molecular energy properties up to 7 times faster than previous ML models of similar accuracy.

======== 1126 : Cao2010

@title:    Accelerated similarity searching and clustering of large compound sets by geometric embedding and locality sensitive hashing
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - hashing
@author:   Cao, Yiqun and Jiang, Tao and Girke, Thomas
@doi:      10.1093/bioinformatics/btq067
@url:      http://bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/doi/10.1093/bioinformatics/btq067 https://academic.oup.com/bioinformatics/article-lookup/doi/10.1093/bioinformatics/btq067
@abstract:
 MOTIVATION: Similarity searching and clustering of chemical compounds by structural similarities are important computational approaches for identifying drug-like small molecules. Most algorithms available for these tasks are limited by their speed and scalability, and cannot handle today's large compound databases with several million entries. RESULTS: In this article, we introduce a new algorithm for accelerated similarity searching and clustering of very large compound sets using embedding and indexing (EI) techniques. First, we present EI-Search as a general purpose similarity search method for finding objects with similar features in large databases and apply it here to searching and clustering of large compound sets. The method embeds the compounds in a high-dimensional Euclidean space and searches this space using an efficient index-aware nearest neighbor search method based on locality sensitive hashing (LSH). Second, to cluster large compound sets, we introduce the EI-Clustering algorithm that combines the EI-Search method with Jarvis-Patrick clustering. Both methods were tested on three large datasets with sizes ranging from about 260 000 to over 19 million compounds. In comparison to sequential search methods, the EI-Search method was 40-200 times faster, while maintaining comparable recall rates. The EI-Clustering method allowed us to significantly reduce the CPU time required to cluster these large compound libraries from several months to only a few days. AVAILABILITY: Software implementations and online services have been developed based on the methods introduced in this study. The online services provide access to the generated clustering results and ultra-fast similarity searching of the PubChem Compound database with subsecond response time.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry, Cheminformatics, Data Mining
- **Specific Domain:** Similarity Searching, Clustering of Chemical Compounds, Geometric Embedding, Locality Sensitive Hashing (LSH)
- **Research Type:** Method Development Study with Practical Applications

**10 Keywords:**

1. Accelerated similarity searching and clustering of large compound sets using geometric embedding and LSH
2. EI-Search method for efficient similarity search in high-dimensional Euclidean space
3. Locality sensitive hashing (LSH) for nearest neighbor search and indexing
4. EI-Clustering algorithm combining EI-Search with Jarvis-Patrick clustering
5. Significant speedup of similarity searching by 40-200 times compared to sequential methods
6. Comparable recall rates maintained despite the speedup
7. Reduced CPU time required for clustering large compound libraries from months to days
8. Online services providing access to clustering results and ultra-fast similarity searching
9. Subsecond response time achieved for PubChem Compound database queries
10. Potential applications in fields such as drug discovery, cheminformatics, and materials science.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents research on developing efficient methods for similarity searching and clustering of large compound sets using geometric embedding and locality sensitive hashing (LSH). The EI-Search method is introduced as a general-purpose similarity search method, while the EI-Clustering algorithm combines this method with Jarvis-Patrick clustering. The results demonstrate significant speedup of similarity searching by 40-200 times compared to sequential methods, and reduced CPU time required for clustering large compound libraries from months to days.

======== 1129 : Albrecht2020

@title:    Intramolecular Coupling of Terminal Alkynes by Atom Manipulation
@keywords: C−C coupling,atom manipulation,atomic force microscopy,on-surface synthesis,scanning tunneling microscopy
@author:   Albrecht, Florian and Rey, Dulce and Fatayer, Shadi and Schulz, Fabian and P{\'{e}}rez, Dolores and Pe{\~{n}}a, Diego and Gross, Leo
@doi:      10.1002/anie.202009200
@url:      https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/anie.202009200
@abstract:
 Glaser-like coupling of terminal alkynes by thermal activation is extensively used in on-surface chemistry. Here we demonstrate an intramolecular version of this reaction performed by atom manipulation. We used voltage pulses from the tip to trigger a Glaser-like coupling between terminal alkyne carbons within a custom-synthesized precursor molecule adsorbed on bilayer NaCl on Cu(111). Different conformations of the precursor molecule and the product were characterized by molecular structure elucidation with atomic force microscopy and orbital density mapping with scanning tunneling microscopy, accompanied by density functional theory calculations. We revealed partially dehydrogenated intermediates, providing insight into the reaction pathway.

======== 1130 : Usachov2011a

@title:    Nitrogen-doped graphene: efficient growth, structure, and electronic properties.
@keywords: Folder - carbon graphene - Catalyst,arpes,electronic structure,graphene,nitrogen doping,synthesis,triazine
@author:   Usachov, D and Vilkov, O and Gr{\"{u}}neis, a and Haberer, D and Fedorov, a and Adamchuk, V K and Preobrajenski, a B and Dudin, P and Barinov, a and Oehzelt, M and Laubschat, C and Vyalikh, D V
@doi:      10.1021/nl2031037
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22077830
@abstract:
 A novel strategy for efficient growth of nitrogen-doped graphene (N-graphene) on a large scale from s-triazine molecules is presented. The growth process has been unveiled in situ using time-dependent photoemission. It has been established that a postannealing of N-graphene after gold intercalation causes a conversion of the N environment from pyridinic to graphitic, allowing to obtain more than 80{\%} of all embedded nitrogen in graphitic form, which is essential for the electron doping in graphene. A band gap, a doping level of 300 meV, and a charge-carrier concentration of ∼8×10(12) electrons per cm2, induced by 0.4 atom {\%} of graphitic nitrogen, have been detected by angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy, which offers great promise for implementation of this system in next generation electronic devices.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Materials Science
- **Subcategory:** Graphene, Carbon Nanomaterials, Doping and Functionalization
- **Specific Domain:** Nitrogen-Doped Graphene (N-graphene), Synthesis, Electronic Structure, Photoemission Spectroscopy, Angle-Resolved Photoemission Spectroscopy (ARPES)
- **Research Type:** Experimental Study with Theoretical Implications

**10 Keywords:**

1. Nitrogen-doped graphene (N-graphene) efficient growth and structure
2. Large-scale synthesis from s-triazine molecules using gold intercalation
3. Post-annealing of N-graphene for conversion of nitrogen environment
4. Conversion of pyridinic to graphitic nitrogen environments
5. Electron doping in graphene induced by graphitic nitrogen
6. Band gap formation and electronic structure modification
7. Angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) characterization
8. Detection of doping level, charge-carrier concentration, and electron density
9. Potential applications in next-generation electronic devices
10. Novel strategy for N-graphene synthesis and functionalization.

**Specific Topic:** Materials Science - Graphene Research

**Note:** The article presents research on developing a novel strategy for efficient growth of nitrogen-doped graphene (N-graphene) from s-triazine molecules using gold intercalation, followed by post-annealing to convert the nitrogen environment. The study reveals that this approach leads to more than 80% of embedded nitrogen in graphitic form, essential for electron doping in graphene. Using angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES), the researchers detect a band gap, doping level, and charge-carrier concentration induced by 0.4 atom % of graphitic nitrogen, offering great promise for implementation in next-generation electronic devices.

======== 1131 : Hostas2017

@title:    Accurate DFT-D3 Calculations in a Small Basis Set
@author:   Hosta{\v{s}}, Jiř{\'{i}} and Řez{\'{a}}{\v{c}}, Jan
@doi:      10.1021/acs.jctc.7b00365

@abstract:
 Calculations of interaction energies of noncovalent interactions in small basis sets are affected by the basis set superposition error and dispersion-corrected DFT-D methods and are thus usually parametrized only for triple-Ζ and larger basis sets. Nevertheless, some smaller basis sets could also perform well. Among many combinations tested, we obtained excellent results with the DZVP-DFT basis and newly parametrized D3 dispersion correction. The accuracy of interaction energies and geometries is close to significantly more expensive calculations.

@title:    The high-foot implosion campaign on the National Ignition Facilitya)
@keywords: Folder - Fusion
@author:   Hurricane, O. a. and Callahan, D. A. and Casey, D. T. and Dewald, E. L. and Dittrich, T. R. and D{\"{o}}ppner, T. and {Barrios Garcia}, M. A. and Hinkel, D. E. and {Berzak Hopkins}, L. F. and Kervin, P. and Kline, J. L. and Pape, S. Le and Ma, T. and MacPhee, A. G. and Milovich, J. L. and Moody, J. and Pak, A. E. and Patel, P. K. and Park, H.-S. and Remington, B. a. and Robey, H. F. and Salmonson, J. D. and Springer, P. T. and Tommasini, R. and Benedetti, L. R. and Caggiano, J. A. and Celliers, P. and Cerjan, C. and Dylla-Spears, R. and Edgell, D. and Edwards, M. J. and Fittinghoff, D. and Grim, G. P. and Guler, N. and Izumi, N. and Frenje, J. A. and {Gatu Johnson}, M. and Haan, S. and Hatarik, R. and Herrmann, H. and Khan, S. and Knauer, J. and Kozioziemski, B. J. and Kritcher, a. L. and Kyrala, G. and Maclaren, S. A. and Merrill, F. E. and Michel, P. and Ralph, J. and Ross, J. S. and Rygg, J. R. and Schneider, M. B. and Spears, B. K. and Widmann, K. and Yeamans, C. B.
@doi:      10.1063/1.4874330
@url:      http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/pop/21/5/10.1063/1.4874330
@abstract:
 The “High-Foot” platform manipulates the laser pulse-shape coming from the National Ignition Facility laser to create an indirect drive 3-shock implosion that is significantly more robust against instability growth involving the ablator and also modestly reduces implosion convergence ratio. This strategy gives up on theoretical high-gain in an inertial confinement fusion implosion in order to obtain better control of the implosion and bring experimental performance in-line with calculated performance, yet keeps the absolute capsule performance relatively high. In this paper, we will cover the various experimental and theoretical motivations for the high-foot drive as well as cover the experimental results that have come out of the high-foot experimental campaign. At the time of this writing, the high-foot implosion has demonstrated record total deuterium-tritium yields ( 9.3 × 10 15 ) with low levels of inferred mix, excellent agreement with implosion simulations, fuel energy gains exceeding unity, and evidence for the “bootstrapping” associated with alpha-particle self-heating.

- **Research Type:** Experimental Study with Theoretical Modeling Implications

**10 Keywords:**

1. High-Foot Implosion Campaign on the National Ignition Facility
2. Indirect Drive 3-Shock Implosion with Robust Against Instability Growth
3. Improved Control of Implosion and Reduced Convergence Ratio
4. Experimental Results Showing Record Yields and Low Mix Levels
5. Excellent Agreement with Simulations and Evidence for Alpha-Particle Self-Heating
6. Fuel Energy Gains Exceeding Unity and Inferred Mix Levels

10. Novel Approach for Laser-Driven Implosions.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Fusion Energy Research

**Note:** The article presents research on the high-foot implosion campaign conducted at the National Ignition Facility, which aims to improve control of laser-driven implosions in inertial confinement fusion (ICF). The high-foot platform manipulates the laser pulse-shape to create a more robust implosion that is less susceptible to instability growth. The experimental results show record total deuterium-tritium yields, low levels of inferred mix, and excellent agreement with simulations, indicating potential for achieving fuel energy gains exceeding unity and evidence for alpha-particle self-heating. This work has significant implications for the development of fusion energy through ICF.

======== 1134 : OSullivan2011

@title:    Vernier templating and synthesis of a 12-porphyrin nano-ring
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Engeneering - Templated{\_}synthes
@author:   O'Sullivan, Melanie C. and Sprafke, Johannes K. and Kondratuk, Dmitry V. and Rinfray, Corentin and Claridge, Timothy D. W. and Saywell, Alex and Blunt, Matthew O. and O'Shea, James N. and Beton, Peter H. and Malfois, Marc and Anderson, Harry L.
@doi:      10.1038/nature09683
@url:      http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nature09683
@abstract:
 Templates are widely used to arrange molecular components so they can be covalently linked into complex molecules that are not readily accessible by classical synthetic methods. Nature uses sophisticated templates such as the ribosome, whereas chemists use simple ions or small molecules. But as we tackle the synthesis of larger targets, we require larger templates-which themselves become synthetically challenging. Here we show that Vernier complexes can solve this problem: if the number of binding sites on the template, n(T), is not a multiple of the number of binding sites on the molecular building blocks, n(B), then small templates can direct the assembly of relatively large Vernier complexes where the number of binding sites in the product, n(P), is the lowest common multiple of n(B) and n(T) (refs 8, 9). We illustrate the value of this concept for the covalent synthesis of challenging targets by using a simple six-site template to direct the synthesis of a 12-porphyrin nano-ring with a diameter of 4.7 nm, thus establishing Vernier templating as a powerful new strategy for the synthesis of large monodisperse macromolecules.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Organic Chemistry, Molecular Engineering, Self-Assembly
- **Specific Domain:** Vernier Templating, Nano-Rings, Porphyrin Synthesis
- **Research Type:** Experimental Study with Theoretical Modeling Implications

**10 Keywords:**

1. Vernier Templating and Synthesis of a 12-Porphyrin Nano-Ring
2. Self-Assembly of Molecular Components using Simple Templates
3. Covalent Linkage of Porphyrin Building Blocks in a Large Ring Structure
4. Novel Approach for Directing the Assembly of Complex Molecules
5. Use of Vernier Complexes to Overcome Synthesis Challenges
6. Low-Cost, High-Fidelity Synthesis of Macromolecules with Large Diameter
7. Template-Directed Synthesis of Nano-Rings with Specific Size and Shape
8. Potential Applications in Fields such as Materials Science and Nanotechnology
9. New Strategy for Synthesizing Monodisperse Macromolecules
10. Improved Understanding of Molecular Assembly and Self-Organization.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Organic Chemistry, Molecular Engineering

**Note:** The article presents research on the development of a new strategy called Vernier templating to direct the assembly of complex molecules. This approach uses simple templates with binding sites that are not multiples of the molecular building blocks, allowing for the synthesis of large monodisperse macromolecules with high fidelity and low cost. As an example, the authors demonstrate the use of a six-site template to synthesize a 12-porphyrin nano-ring with a diameter of 4.7 nm, establishing Vernier templating as a powerful tool for molecular engineering applications.

======== 1135 : Richards1986

@title:    A defense of evolutionary ethics
@keywords: Folder - philosphy,altruism,c,darwin,ethics,evolution,naturalistic fallacy,sociobiology
@author:   Richards, Robert J
@doi:      10.1007/BF00127104
@abstract:
 From Charles Darwin to Edward Wilson, evolutionary biologists have attempted to construct systems of evolutionary ethics. These attempts have been roundly criticized, most often for having committed the naturalistic fallacy. In this essay, I review the history of previous efforts at formulating an evolutionary ethics, focusing on the proposals of Darwin and Wilson. I then advance and defend a proposal of my own. In the last part of the essay, I try to demonstrate that my revised version of evolutionary ethics: (1) does not commit the naturalistic fallacy as it is usually understood; (2) does, admittedly, derive values from facts; but (3) does not commit any fallacy in doing so.

**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

7. Deriving Values from Facts without Committing a Fallacy
8. Evolutionary Biology as a Basis for Ethics
9. Implications of Evolutionary Ethics for Moral Philosophy
10. New Perspective on Altruism and Self-Interest in Evolution.

**Specific Topic:** Philosophy - Ethics, Evolutionary Biology

**Note:** The article presents research on the defense of evolutionary ethics, critiquing previous attempts by Darwin and Wilson, and proposing a revised version that addresses concerns about the naturalistic fallacy. The author argues that their revised proposal does not commit this fallacy, but rather derives values from facts in a valid way. This work has significant implications for moral philosophy and the relationship between evolutionary biology and ethics.

======== 1139 : Ferreira2015a

@title:    Molecular Docking and Structure-Based Drug Design Strategies
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - Molecular docking,SBDD,SBVS,drug discovery,molecular interaction,molecular modeling,molecular target,pharmacophore,virtual screening
@author:   Ferreira, Leonardo and dos Santos, Ricardo and Oliva, Glaucius and Andricopulo, Adriano
@doi:      10.3390/molecules200713384
@url:      http://www.mdpi.com/1420-3049/20/7/13384/
@abstract:
 Pharmaceutical research has successfully incorporated a wealth of molecular modeling methods, within a variety of drug discovery programs, to study complex biological and chemical systems. The integration of computational and experimental strategies has been of great value in the identification and development of novel promising compounds. Broadly used in modern drug design, molecular docking methods explore the ligand conformations adopted within the binding sites of macromolecular targets. This approach also estimates the ligand-receptor binding free energy by evaluating critical phenomena involved in the intermolecular recognition process. Today, as a variety of docking algorithms are available, an understanding of the advantages and limitations of each method is of fundamental importance in the development of effective strategies and the generation of relevant results. The purpose of this review is to examine current molecular docking strategies used in drug discovery and medicinal chemistry, exploring the advances in the field and the role played by the integration of structure- and ligand-based methods.

======== 1142 : Browne2006

@title:    Making molecular machines work
@keywords: Energy Transfer,Equipment Design,Folder - Molecular Engeneering - Molecular Motors,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021,Motion,Nanostructures,Nanotechnology,Nanotechnology: instrumentation,★
@author:   Browne, Wesley R and Feringa, Ben L
@doi:      10.1038/nnano.2006.45
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18654138 http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nnano.2006.45 https://www.nature.com/articles/nnano.2006.45
@abstract:
 In this review we chart recent advances in what is at once an old and very new field of endeavour--the achievement of control of motion at the molecular level including solid-state and surface-mounted rotors, and its natural progression to the development of synthetic molecular machines. Besides a discussion of design principles used to control linear and rotary motion in such molecular systems, this review will address the advances towards the construction of synthetic machines that can perform useful functions. Approaches taken by several research groups to construct wholly synthetic molecular machines and devices are compared. This will be illustrated with molecular rotors, elevators, valves, transporters, muscles and other motor functions used to develop smart materials. The demonstration of molecular machinery is highlighted through recent examples of systems capable of effecting macroscopic movement through concerted molecular motion. Several approaches to illustrate how molecular motor systems have been used to accomplish work are discussed. We will conclude with prospects for future developments in this exciting field of nanotechnology.

======== 1143 : Kamath2005

@title:    Cotton Fiber Nonwovens For Automotive Composites
@keywords: Folder - Materials,automotive,biodegradable,bonding,composites,compostable,cotton,natural cellulosic fibers,nonwovens
@author:   Kamath, By M G and Bhat, G S and Parikh, D V and Mueller, D and Science, Materials
======== 1144 : Alier1982

@title:    A Marxist Precursor of Energy Economics: Podolinsky
@author:   Alier, J. Martinez and Naredo, J. M.
@doi:      10.1080/03066158208438162
@abstract:
 This article reviews some recent work on the energy analysis of agriculture, which shows that the efficiency of‘modernf agriculture is inferior to that of‘traditionalf agriculture. We consider one of the first examples of energy accounting in agriculture (published by Sergei Podolinsky one hundred years ago), and we evaluate Engelss reaction to it, in correspondence with Marx. This article is, then, an attempt to explore whether energy analysis can be fitted into the Marxist framework, and our conclusion is that Marxism would have to be much revised since there are epistemological obstacles (the use of categories from Political Economy, such as production ‘labour-value', ‘capital') and ideological obstacles (the vision of a two-stage transition to communist abundance and equality). Although some Marxist anthropologists have used energy analysis, most Marxist economic historians and economists have not, i. e. they have not looked critically at the notion of‘development ofproductive forces. We trace the origins of this divorce between Marxism and ecology. {\textcopyright} 1982, Taylor {\&} Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.

======== 1145 : Martin-Gago2011a

@title:    Polycyclic aromatics: On-surface molecular engineering.
@keywords: Folder - carbon graphene
@author:   Martin-Gago, Jos{\'{e}} a
@doi:      10.1038/nchem.923
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21160507
======== 1146 : Goerigk2014

@title:    Double-hybrid density functionals
@author:   Goerigk, Lars and Grimme, Stefan
@doi:      10.1002/wcms.1193
@url:      https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/wcms.1193
@abstract:
 Double-hybrid density functionals (DHDFs) are reviewed in this study. In DHDFs parts of conventional density functional theory (DFT) exchange and correlation are replaced by contributions from nonlocal Fock-exchange and second-order perturbative correlation. The latter portion is based on the well-known MP2 wave-function approach in which, however, Kohn-Sham orbitals are used to calculate its contribution. First, related methods preceding this idea are reviewed, followed by a thorough discussion of the first modern double-hybrid B2-PLYP. Parallels and differences between B2-PLYP and its various successors are then outlined. This discussion is rounded off with representative thermochemical examples demonstrating that DHDFs belong to the most robust and accurate DFT approaches currently available. This analysis also presents hitherto unpublished results for recently developed DHDFs. Finally, how double-hybrids can be combined with linear-response time-dependent DFT is also outlined and the value of this approach for electronically excited states is shown.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry, Density Functional Theory (DFT)
- **Specific Domain:** Double-Hybrid Density Functionals (DHDFs), Density Functional Theory (DFT) Methods
- **Research Type:** Review Article with Theoretical and Methodological Implications

**10 Keywords:**

1. Double-Hybrid Density Functionals (DHDFs)
2. Replacement of Conventional DFT Exchange and Correlation
3. Nonlocal Fock-Exchange and Second-Order Perturbative Correlation
4. Kohn-Sham Orbitals in DHDF Calculations
5. B2-PLYP: A Modern Double-Hybrid Density Functional
6. Successors to B2-PLYP: Parallels and Differences
7. Thermochemical Examples Demonstrating DHDF Accuracy
8. Robustness and Accuracy of DHDF Approaches
9. Combination of DHDF with Linear-Response Time-Dependent DFT
10. Electronically Excited States Calculations using DHDF.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry, Density Functional Theory (DFT)

**Note:** The article presents a comprehensive review of double-hybrid density functionals (DHDFs), highlighting their development, principles, and applications in computational chemistry. The author discusses the first modern double-hybrid B2-PLYP and its successors, as well as representative thermochemical examples demonstrating the accuracy and robustness of DHDF approaches. This work has significant implications for understanding the properties of molecules and materials using density functional theory.

======== 1147 : Smith2017b

@title:    ANI-1: an extensible neural network potential with DFT accuracy at force field computational cost
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods - Neural{\_}Networks,★
@author:   Smith, Justin S and Isayev, Olexandr and Roitberg, Adrian E
@doi:      10.1039/C6SC05720A
@url:      https://arxiv.org/abs/1610.08935{\%}5Cnhttp://arxiv.org/abs/1610.08935 http://xlink.rsc.org/?DOI=C6SC05720A
@abstract:
 Deep learning is revolutionizing many areas of science and technology, especially image, text and speech recognition. In this paper, we demonstrate how a deep neural network (NN) trained on quantum mechanical (QM) DFT calculations can learn an accurate and fully transferable potential for organic molecules. We introduce ANAKIN-ME (Accurate NeurAl networK engINe for Molecular Energies) or ANI in short. ANI is a new method and procedure for training neural network potentials that utilizes a highly modified version of the Behler and Parrinello symmetry functions to build single-atom atomic environment vectors as a molecular representation. We utilize ANI to build a potential called ANI-1, which was trained on a subset of the GDB databases with up to 8 heavy atoms to predict total energies for organic molecules containing four atom types: H, C, N, and O. To obtain an accelerated but physically relevant sampling of molecular potential surfaces, we also propose a Normal Mode Sampling (NMS) method for generating molecular configurations. Through a series of case studies, we show that ANI-1 is chemically accurate compared to reference DFT calculations on much larger molecular systems (up to 54 atoms) than those included in the training data set, with root mean square errors as low as 0.56 kcal/mol.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry, Molecular Dynamics
- **Specific Domain:** Neural Network Potentials (NNPs), Density Functional Theory (DFT) Accuracy at Force Field Computational Cost
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article with Theoretical and Methodological Implications

**10 Keywords:**

1. ANI-1: An Extensible Neural Network Potential
2. Deep Learning for Quantum Mechanical Calculations
3. Accurate and Transferable Potentials for Organic Molecules
4. Atomic Environment Vectors for Molecular Representation
5. Behler-Parrinello Symmetry Functions Modification
6. Normal Mode Sampling (NMS) Method for Generating Molecular Configurations
7. Chemically Accurate Predictions on Larger Molecular Systems
8. Root Mean Square Errors as Low as 0.56 kcal/mol
9. Density Functional Theory (DFT) Accuracy at Force Field Computational Cost
10. Applications of Neural Network Potentials in Materials Science and Chemistry.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry, Molecular Dynamics

**Note:** The article presents a novel approach to developing neural network potentials for organic molecules, achieving DFT accuracy at force field computational cost. ANI-1 is trained on a subset of the GDB database and demonstrated to be chemically accurate on larger molecular systems than those included in the training data set. This work has significant implications for applications in materials science and chemistry, where rapid and accurate predictions are essential.

@keywords: Folder - ElectronTransport
@author:   B{\"{u}}ttiker, M. and Imry, Y. and Landauer, R. and Pinhas, S.
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.31.6207
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.31.6207
======== 1150 : Hourahine2020

@title:    DFTB+, a software package for efficient approximate density functional theory based atomistic simulations
@author:   Hourahine, B. and Aradi, B. and Blum, V. and Bonaf{\'{e}}, F. and Buccheri, A. and Camacho, C. and Cevallos, C. and Deshaye, M. Y. and Dumitrică, T. and Dominguez, A. and Ehlert, S. and Elstner, M. and van der Heide, T. and Hermann, J. and Irle, S. and Kranz, J. J. and K{\"{o}}hler, C. and Kowalczyk, T. and Kubař, T. and Lee, I. S. and Lutsker, V. and Maurer, R. J. and Min, S. K. and Mitchell, I. and Negre, C. and Niehaus, T. A. and Niklasson, A. M. N. and Page, A. J. and Pecchia, A. and Penazzi, G. and Persson, M. P. and Řez{\'{a}}{\v{c}}, J. and S{\'{a}}nchez, C. G. and Sternberg, M. and St{\"{o}}hr, M. and Stuckenberg, F. and Tkatchenko, A. and Yu, V. W.Z. and Frauenheim, T.
@doi:      10.1063/1.5143190
@url:      https://pubs.aip.org/aip/jcp/article/953756
@abstract:
 DFTB+ is a versatile community developed open source software package offering fast and efficient methods for carrying out atomistic quantum mechanical simulations. By implementing various methods approximating density functional theory (DFT), such as the density functional based tight binding (DFTB) and the extended tight binding method, it enables simulations of large systems and long timescales with reasonable accuracy while being considerably faster for typical simulations than the respective ab initio methods. Based on the DFTB framework, it additionally offers approximated versions of various DFT extensions including hybrid functionals, time dependent formalism for treating excited systems, electron transport using non-equilibrium Green's functions, and many more. DFTB+ can be used as a user-friendly standalone application in addition to being embedded into other software packages as a library or acting as a calculation-server accessed by socket communication. We give an overview of the recently developed capabilities of the DFTB+ code, demonstrating with a few use case examples, discuss the strengths and weaknesses of the various features, and also discuss on-going developments and possible future perspectives.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry, Density Functional Theory (DFT)
- **Specific Domain:** Approximate Density Functional Theory (DFT) Methods, Atomistic Simulations
- **Research Type:** Review Article with Theoretical and Methodological Implications

**10 Keywords:**

1. DFTB+: A Software Package for Efficient Approximate DFT-Based Simulations
2. Fast and Accurate Methods for Large System Simulations
3. Density Functional Based Tight Binding (DFTB) and Extended Tight Binding Method
4. Approximations of Various DFT Extensions, Including Hybrid Functionals and Time-Dependent Formalism
5. Non-Equilibrium Green's Functions for Electron Transport
6. Standalone Application, Embedded Library, or Calculation-Server
7. User-Friendly Interface and Socket Communication Capability
8. Overview of Recent Developments and Future Perspectives
9. Use Case Examples Demonstrating DFTB+ Capabilities
10. Comparison of Strengths and Weaknesses of Various DFTB+ Features.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry, Density Functional Theory (DFT)

**Note:** The article presents a review of the DFTB+ software package, which offers efficient approximate density functional theory-based atomistic simulations. DFTB+ includes various methods approximating DFT, including hybrid functionals and time-dependent formalism, and can be used as a standalone application or embedded into other software packages. This work has significant implications for carrying out large system simulations with reasonable accuracy at faster computational times than ab initio methods.

@title:    Evaluation of Several Variants of Explicitly Restarted {\{}L{\}}anczos Eigensolvers and Their Parallel Implementations

@author:   Hernandez, V and Roman, J and Tomas, a
======== 1156 : Emden2016

@title:    Nietzsche's Will to Power: Biology, Naturalism, and Normativity
@author:   Emden
@doi:      10.5325/jnietstud.47.1.0030
@url:      http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jnietstud.47.1.0030
@abstract:
 The effects of melatonin, amlodipine, diltiazem (L-type Ca 2+ channel blockers) and $\omega$-conotoxin (N-type Ca 2+ channel blocker) on the glutamate-dependent excitatory response of striatal neurones to sensory-motor cortex stimulation was studied in a total of 111 neurones. Iontophoresis of melatonin produced a significant attenuation of the excitatory response in 85.2{\%} of the neurones with a latency period of 2 min. Iontophoresis of either L- or N-type Ca 2+ channel blocker also produced a significant attenuation of the excitatory response in more than 50{\%} of the recorded neurones without significant latency. The simultaneous iontophoresis of melatonin + amlodipine or melatonin + diltiazem did not increase the attenuation produced by melatonin alone. However, the attenuation of the excitatory response was significantly higher after ejecting melatonin + $\omega$-conotoxin than after ejecting melatonin alone. The melatonin-Ca 2+ relationship was further supported by iontophoresis of the Ca 2+ ionophore A-23187, which suppressed the inhibitory effect of either melatonin or Ca 2+ antagonists. In addition, in synaptosomes prepared from rat striatum, melatonin produced a decrease in the Ca 2+ influx measured by Fura-2AM fluorescence. Binding experiments with [ 3 H]MK-801 in membrane preparations from rat striatum showed that melatonin did not compete with the MK-801 binding sites themselves although, in the presence of Mg 2+ , melatonin increased the affinity of MK-801. The results suggest that decreased Ca 2+ influx is involved in the inhibitory effects of melatonin on the glutamatergic activity of rat striatum.

======== 1159 : Prautzsch2002

@title:    Box Splines
@author:   Prautzsch, Hartmut and Boehm, Wolfgang
@doi:      10.1016/b978-044451104-1/50011-3
@abstract:
 This chapter provides a brief introduction to box and half-box splines with particular focus on triangular splines and surface design. A particular exam- ple of box splines are the B-splines with equidistant knots. In general, box splines consist of regularly arranged polynomial pieces and they have a useful geometric interpretation. Namely they can be viewed as density functions of the shadows of higher dimensional boxes and half-boxes. Of particular in- terest for Geometric Design are box spline surfaces that consist of triangular polynomial pieces. These box spline surfaces have planar domains, but it is quite simple to construct arbitrary two-dimensional surfaces, i.e., manifolds, with these box splines.

**Specific Topic:** Mathematics - Computational Geometry, Computer-Aided Design (CAD)

======== 1161 : Panosetti

@title:    Supporting Information for “ Global materials structure search with chemically-motivated coordinates ” Computational details
@keywords: Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2016{\_}03{\_}21
@author:   Panosetti, Chiara and Krautgasser, Konstantin and Palagin, Dennis and Reuter, Karsten and Maurer, Reinhard J
======== 1162 : Green2014a

@title:    Patterning a hydrogen-bonded molecular monolayer with a hand-controlled scanning probe microscope
@keywords: 10-perylene,3,4,9,Folder - Molecular Engeneering,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021,afm,atomic force microscopy,ptcda,scanning tunneling microscopy,single-molecule manipulation,stm,tetracarboxylic acid dianhydride
@author:   Green, Matthew F B and Esat, Taner and Wagner, Christian and Leinen, Philipp and Gr{\"{o}}tsch, Alexander and Tautz, F Stefan and Temirov, Ruslan
@doi:      10.3762/bjnano.5.203
@url:      https://www.beilstein-journals.org/bjnano/articles/5/203 http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=4222388{\&}tool=pmcentrez{\&}rendertype=abstract
@abstract:
 One of the paramount goals in nanotechnology is molecular-scale functional design, which includes arranging molecules into complex structures at will. The first steps towards this goal were made through the invention of the scanning probe microscope (SPM), which put single-atom and single-molecule manipulation into practice for the first time. Extending the controlled manipulation to larger molecules is expected to multiply the potential of engineered nanostructures. Here we report an enhancement of the SPM technique that makes the manipulation of large molecular adsorbates much more effective. By using a commercial motion tracking system, we couple the movements of an operator's hand to the sub-angstrom precise positioning of an SPM tip. Literally moving the tip by hand we write a nanoscale structure in a monolayer of large molecules, thereby showing that our method allows for the successful execution of complex manipulation protocols even when the potential energy surface that governs the interaction behaviour of the manipulated nanoscale object(s) is largely unknown.

======== 1163 : Sforzini2016

@title:    Structural and Electronic Properties of Nitrogen-Doped Graphene
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}source - Moje
@author:   Sforzini, J. and Hapala, P. and Franke, M. and van Straaten, G. and St{\"{o}}hr, A. and Link, S. and Soubatch, S. and Jel{\'{i}}nek, P. and Lee, T.-L. and Starke, U. and {\v{S}}vec, M. and Bocquet, F. C. F.C. and Tautz, F.S. F. S.
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevLett.116.126805
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.116.126805
@abstract:
 We investigate the structural and electronic properties of nitrogen-doped epitaxial monolayer graphene and quasifreestanding monolayer graphene on 6H-SiC(0001) by the normal incidence x-ray standing wave technique and by angle-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy supported by density functional theory simulations. With the location of various nitrogen species uniquely identified, we observe that for the same doping procedure, the graphene support, consisting of substrate and interface, strongly influences the structural as well as the electronic properties of the resulting doped graphene layer. Compared to epitaxial graphene, quasifreestanding graphene is found to contain fewer nitrogen dopants. However, this lack of dopants is compensated by the proximity of nitrogen atoms at the interface that yield a similar number of charge carriers in graphene.

The results show that the graphene support influences the doping procedure and that quasifreestanding graphene has fewer dopants but similar charge carrier density due to interface proximity. This work has significant implications for understanding nitrogen-doped graphene properties and potential applications in electronics and energy storage.

======== 1180 : Bogojeski2020

@title:    Quantum chemical accuracy from density functional approximations via machine learning
@author:   Bogojeski, Mihail and Vogt-Maranto, Leslie and Tuckerman, Mark E. and M{\"{u}}ller, Klaus Robert and Burke, Kieron
@doi:      10.1038/s41467-020-19093-1
@url:      http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/s41467-020-19093-1
@abstract:
 Kohn-Sham density functional theory (DFT) is a standard tool in most branches of chemistry, but accuracies for many molecules are limited to 2-3 kcal ⋅ mol−1 with presently-available functionals. Ab initio methods, such as coupled-cluster, routinely produce much higher accuracy, but computational costs limit their application to small molecules. In this paper, we leverage machine learning to calculate coupled-cluster energies from DFT densities, reaching quantum chemical accuracy (errors below 1 kcal ⋅ mol−1) on test data. Moreover, density-based $\Delta$-learning (learning only the correction to a standard DFT calculation, termed $\Delta$-DFT) significantly reduces the amount of training data required, particularly when molecular symmetries are included. The robustness of $\Delta$-DFT is highlighted by correcting “on the fly” DFT-based molecular dynamics (MD) simulations of resorcinol (C6H4(OH)2) to obtain MD trajectories with coupled-cluster accuracy. We conclude, therefore, that $\Delta$-DFT facilitates running gas-phase MD simulations with quantum chemical accuracy, even for strained geometries and conformer changes where standard DFT fails.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Theoretical Chemistry, Computational Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents an original research study on the development of a machine learning approach to improve the accuracy of density functional theory (DFT) calculations. By leveraging $\Delta$-learning and incorporating molecular symmetries, the authors demonstrate the ability to calculate coupled-cluster energies with quantum chemical accuracy from DFT densities. This work has significant implications for enhancing the robustness and accuracy of computational chemistry simulations, particularly in gas-phase molecular dynamics simulations where standard DFT methods may fail.

======== 1183 : Jurecka2006

@title:    Benchmark database of accurate (MP2 and CCSD(T) complete basis set limit) interaction energies of small model complexes, DNA base pairs, and amino acid pairs.
@author:   Jurecka, Petr and Sponer, Jir{\'{i}} and Cern{\'{y}}, Jir{\'{i}} and Hobza, Pavel
@doi:      10.1039/b600027d
@url:      http://xlink.rsc.org/?DOI=B600027D http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16633685
@abstract:
 MP2 and CCSD(T) complete basis set (CBS) limit interaction energies and geometries for more than 100 DNA base pairs, amino acid pairs and model complexes are for the first time presented together. Extrapolation to the CBS limit is done by using two-point extrapolation methods and different basis sets (aug-cc-pVDZ - aug-cc-pVTZ, aug-cc-pVTZ - aug-cc-pVQZ, cc-pVTZ - cc-pVQZ) are utilized. The CCSD(T) correction term, determined as a difference between CCSD(T) and MP2 interaction energies, is evaluated with smaller basis sets (6-31G** and cc-pVDZ). Two sets of complex geometries were used, optimized or experimental ones. The JSCH-2005 benchmark set, which is now available to the chemical community, can be used for testing lower-level computational methods. For the first screening the smaller training set (S22) containing 22 model complexes can be recommended. In this case larger basis sets were used for extrapolation to the CBS limit and also CCSD(T) and counterpoise-corrected MP2 optimized geometries were sometimes adopted.

======== 1184 : Behler2011

@title:    Neural network potential-energy surfaces in chemistry: a tool for large-scale simulations.
@keywords: Computer Simulation,Computer Simulation: economics,Folder - ComputationalMethods - Neural{\_}Networks,Metals,Metals: chemistry,Models,Models- Molecular,Molecular,Neural Networks (Computer),Small Molecule Libraries,Small Molecule Libraries: chemistry
@author:   Behler, J{\"{o}}rg
@doi:      10.1039/c1cp21668f
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21915403
@abstract:
 The accuracy of the results obtained in molecular dynamics or Monte Carlo simulations crucially depends on a reliable description of the atomic interactions. A large variety of efficient potentials has been proposed in the literature, but often the optimum functional form is difficult to find and strongly depends on the particular system. In recent years, artificial neural networks (NN) have become a promising new method to construct potentials for a wide range of systems. They offer a number of advantages: they are very general and applicable to systems as different as small molecules, semiconductors and metals; they are numerically very accurate and fast to evaluate; and they can be constructed using any electronic structure method. Significant progress has been made in recent years and a number of successful applications demonstrate the capabilities of neural network potentials. In this Perspective, the current status of NN potentials is reviewed, and their advantages and limitations are discussed.

======== 1185 : Trani2004

@title:    Electronic and optical properties of silicon nanocrystals: a Tight Binding study
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs,Folder - SiNCs - projection,SiNC
@author:   Trani, Fabio
@url:      http://www.fedoa.unina.it/73/
======== 1186 : Methods2012

@title:    Initial-Value Problems for ODEs Error Control {\&} Runge-Kutta-Fehlberg Method
@keywords: Folder - Numerics - ODE - Integrators
@author:   Methods, Numerical and Faires, Edition J D and Burden, R L
======== 1187 : Uffink1998

@title:    Thermodynamic uncertainty relations
@author:   Uffink, Jos and Dis, J. H. van Lith-van
@doi:      10.1023/A:1018811305766
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/cond-mat/9806102
@abstract:
 Bohr and Heisenberg suggested that the thermodynamical quantities of temperature and energy are complementary in the same way as position and momentum in quantum mechanics. Roughly speaking, their idea was that a definite temperature can be attributed to a system only if it is submerged in a heat bath, in which case energy fluctuations are unavoidable. On the other hand, a definite energy can only be assigned to systems in thermal isolation, thus excluding the simultaneous determination of its temperature. Rosenfeld extended this analogy with quantum mechanics and obtained a quantitative uncertainty relation in the form (Delta U) (Delta (1/T)) {\textgreater}= k where k is Boltzmann's constant. The two `extreme' cases of this relation would then characterize this complementarity between isolation (U definite) and contact with a heat bath (T definite). Other formulations of the thermodynamical uncertainty relations were proposed by Mandelbrot (1956, 1989), Lindhard (1986) and Lavenda (1987, 1991). This work, however, has not led to a consensus in the literature. It is shown here that the uncertainty relation for temperature and energy in the version of Mandelbrot is indeed exactly analogous to modern formulations of the quantum mechanical uncertainty relations. However, his relation holds only for the canonical distribution, describing a system in contact with a heat bath. There is, therefore, no complementarity between this situation and a thermally isolated system.

**Classification:**

8. Limitations and Restrictions of Mandelbrot's Relation to Canonical Distribution
9. Implications for Complementarity Principle in Thermodynamics
10. Reevaluation of the Concept of Complementarity in Statistical Mechanics.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Theoretical Physics, Statistical Mechanics

**Note:** The article presents an original research study on the thermodynamic uncertainty relations and their relation to the complementarity principle. The author discusses the work of Bohr, Heisenberg, Rosenfeld, Mandelbrot, Lindhard, and Lavenda, highlighting the analogies between quantum mechanics and thermodynamics. However, the article challenges the idea of complementarity in thermodynamics by showing that Mandelbrot's formulation of the uncertainty relation holds only for the canonical distribution, describing a system in contact with a heat bath.

@keywords: Folder - Space - Orbits - OrbitalTransfer,asteroids,bellman principle,differential dynamic progamming,low-thrust trajectories,multi-body problem,multi-revolution trajectory,n-body,near-earth objects,optimal control,optimisation methods,orbital transfer,rendez-vous trajectory to apophis,trajectory optimisation
@author:   Colombo, Camilla and Vasile, Massimiliano and Radice, Gianmarco
@doi:      10.1007/s10569-009-9224-3
@url:      http://www.springerlink.com/index/10.1007/s10569-009-9224-3
======== 1190 : Foster2001

@title:    Unambiguous Interpretation of Atomically Resolved Force Microscopy Images of an Insulator
@author:   Foster, A S and Barth, C and Shluger, A L and Reichling, M
======== 1191 : Rahman2002a

@title:    Puddle-jumping: A flexible sampling algorithm for rare event systems
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods - Global{\_}Opt{\_}and{\_}Sad
@author:   Rahman, Jay a. and Tully, John C.
@doi:      10.1016/S0301-0104(02)00837-6
@abstract:
 We present a method for enhancing the sampling of configuration space in molecular dynamics and Monte Carlo simulations of systems exhibiting high potential energy barriers. The method builds on a previously described approach, "puddle-skimming", in which the potential energy function, V(q), is modified as follows: wherever V(q) {\textless} EB, it is set equal to EB, where EB is a selected "puddle height". V(q) is unmodified in regions where V(q) {\textgreater} EB. The extended method, "puddle-jumping", incorporates two or more different puddle heights, with transitions between them. Motion on the higher energy puddles promotes barrier crossings, while motion on the lower puddles more efficiently samples the more important low potential energy regions. We test the method on conformational changes in a model of n-pentane, for which the potential energy parameters have been modified to exhibit a range of barrier heights. The method greatly increases the frequency of barrier crossings while minimizing the time spent sampling unimportant, high-energy regions of configuration space. It is flexible and can be applied to large systems whose features are not known in advance. Finally, it converges rigorously to the correct canonical ensemble distribution; options in its implementation affect only the rate of convergence, not the final converged result. ?? 2002 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry, Molecular Dynamics, Monte Carlo Simulations

The method builds upon previous work and incorporates multiple puddle heights to promote barrier crossings while minimizing time spent on high-energy regions. The authors test the method on conformational changes in n-pentane and demonstrate its effectiveness, flexibility, and convergence properties.

======== 1193 : Hoheisel2010

@title:    Nanostructured carbonaceous materials from molecular precursors.
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Engeneering - Molecular network,Folder - carbon graphene
@author:   Hoheisel, Tobias N and Schrettl, Stephen and Szilluweit, Ruth and Frauenrath, Holger
@doi:      10.1002/anie.200907180
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20661971
@abstract:
 Nanostructured carbonaceous materials, that is, carbon materials with a feature size on the nanometer scale and, in some cases, functionalized surfaces, already play an important role in a wide range of emerging fields, such as the search for novel energy sources, efficient energy storage, sustainable chemical technology, as well as organic electronic materials. Furthermore, such materials might offer solutions to the challenges associated with the on-going depletion of nonrenewable energy resources or climate change, and they may promote further breakthroughs in the field of microelectronics. However, novel methods for their preparation will be required that afford functional carbon materials with controlled surface chemistry, mesoscopic morphology, and microstructure. A highly promising approach for the synthesis of such materials is based on the use of well-defined molecular precursors.

======== 1195 : DeLaTorre2017

@title:    Submolecular Resolution by Variation of the Inelastic Electron Tunneling Spectroscopy Amplitude and its Relation to the AFM/STM Signal
@author:   {De La Torre}, Bruno and {\v{S}}vec, Martin and Foti, Giuseppe and Krej{\v{c}}{\'{i}}, Ondřej and Hapala, Prokop and Garcia-Lekue, Aran and Frederiksen, Thomas and Zbořil, Radek and Arnau, Andres and V{\'{a}}zquez, H{\'{e}}ctor and Jel{\'{i}}nek, Pavel
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevLett.119.166001
@abstract:
 Here we show scanning tunnelling microscopy (STM), non-contact atomic force microscopy (AFM) and inelastic electron tunnelling spectroscopy (IETS) measurements on organic molecule with a CO- terminated tip at 5K. The high-resolution contrast observed simultaneously in all channels unam- biguously demonstrates the common imaging mechanism in STM/AFM/IETS, related to the lateral bending of the CO-functionalized tip. The IETS spectroscopy reveals that the submolecular con- trast at 5K consists of both renormalization of vibrational frequency and variation of the amplitude of IETS signal. This finding is also corroborated by first principles simulations. We extend accord- ingly the probe-particle AFM/STM/IETS model to include these two main ingredients necessary to reproduce the high-resolution IETS contrast. We also employ the first principles simulations to get more insight into different response of frustrated translation and rotational modes of CO-tip during imaging.

======== 1198 : Gelbrich2005

@title:    A versatile procedure for the identification, description and quantification of structural similarity in molecular crystals
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - similarity metic
@author:   Gelbrich, Thomas and Hursthouse, Michael B.
@doi:      10.1039/b502484f
@url:      http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlehtml/2005/ce/b502484f
@abstract:
 A method is described for the identification of similar “supramolecular constructs” (sub-components of complete crystal structures) of 0-, 1- or 2-dimensionality in different crystal structures of specific molecules (polymorphs) or crystal structures of similar molecules (families) and of 3-dimensionality in isostructural assemblies. A computer program, XPac, has been developed to enable a convenient application of the method, and procedures for the quantification of similarity relationships are proposed. The method is demonstrated and discussed on the basis of a number of case studies. It has been found that supramolecular constructs of different dimensionality are frequent and, therefore, likely to be important features in the consideration of nucleation, crystal growth and polymorphism.

======== 1203 : Panosetti2015

@title:    Global Materials Structure Search with Chemically Motivated Coordinates
@keywords: Basin hopping,Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2016{\_}03{\_}21,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - GlobalOptimizatio,adsorbate structure search,curvilinear coordinates,delocalized internals,global optimization,★
@author:   Panosetti, Chiara and Krautgasser, Konstantin and Palagin, Dennis and Reuter, Karsten and Maurer, Reinhard J.
@doi:      10.1021/acs.nanolett.5b03388
@url:      http://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.nanolett.5b03388 https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.nanolett.5b03388
@abstract:
 Identification of relevant reaction pathways in ever more complex composite materials and nanostructures poses a central challenge to computational materials discovery. Efficient global structure search, tailored to identify chemically relevant intermediates, could provide the necessary first-principles atomistic insight to enable a rational process design. In this work we modify a common feature of global geometry optimization schemes by employing automatically generated collective curvilinear coordinates. The similarity of these coordinates to molecular vibrations enhances the generation of chemically meaningful trial structures for covalently bound systems. In the application to hydrogenated Si clusters, we concomitantly observe a significantly increased efficiency in identifying low-energy structures and exploit it for an extensive sampling of potential products of silicon-cluster soft landing on Si(001) surfaces.

======== 1205 : Imada2021

@title:    Single-molecule laser nanospectroscopy with micro–electron volt energy resolution
@author:   Imada, Hiroshi and Imai-Imada, Miyabi and Miwa, Kuniyuki and Yamane, Hidemasa and Iwasa, Takeshi and Tanaka, Yusuke and Toriumi, Naoyuki and Kimura, Kensuke and Yokoshi, Nobuhiko and Muranaka, Atsuya and Uchiyama, Masanobu and Taketsugu, Tetsuya and Kato, Yuichiro K. and Ishihara, Hajime and Kim, Yousoo
@doi:      10.1126/science.abg8790
@url:      https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.abg8790
@abstract:
 Ways to characterize and control excited states at the single-molecule and atomic levels are needed to exploit excitation-triggered energy-conversion processes. Here, we present a single-molecule spectroscopic method with micro-electron volt energy and submolecular-spatial resolution using laser driving of nanocavity plasmons to induce molecular luminescence in scanning tunneling microscopy. This tunable and monochromatic nanoprobe allows state-selective characterization of the energy levels and linewidths of individual electronic and vibrational quantum states of a single molecule. Moreover, we demonstrate that the energy levels of the states can be finely tuned by using the Stark effect and plasmon-exciton coupling in the tunneling junction. Our technique and findings open a route to the creation of designed energy-converting functions by using tuned energy levels of molecular systems.

======== 1206 : Joshi-Imre2014

@title:    Direct-Write Ion Beam Lithography
@keywords: Folder - Experimental{\_}methods - Ion Lithography
@author:   Joshi-Imre, Alexandra and Bauerdick, Sven
@doi:      10.1155/2014/170415
@url:      http://www.hindawi.com/journals/jnt/2014/170415/
@abstract:
 Patterning with a focused ion beam (FIB) is an extremely versatile fabrication process that can be used to create microscale and nanoscale designs on the surface of practically any solid sample material. Based on the type of ion-sample interaction utilized, FIB-based manufacturing can be both subtractive and additive, even in the same processing step. Indeed, the capability of easily creating three-dimensional patterns and shaping objects by milling and deposition is probably the most recognized feature of ion beam lithography (IBL) and micromachining. However, there exist several other techniques, such as ion implantation- and ion damage-based patterning and surface functionalization types of processes that have emerged as valuable additions to the nanofabrication toolkit and that are less widely known. While fabrication throughput, in general, is arguably low due to the serial nature of the direct-writing process, speed is not necessarily a problem in these IBL applications that work with small ion doses. Here we provide a comprehensive review of ion beam lithography in general and a practical guide to the individual IBL techniques developed to date. Special attention is given to applications in nanofabrication.

======== 1208 : Gehrke2009a

@title:    Assessing the efficiency of first-principles basin-hopping sampling
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods - Global{\_}Opt{\_}and{\_}Sad
@author:   Gehrke, Ralf and Reuter, Karsten
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.79.085412
@abstract:
 We present a systematic performance analysis of first-principles basin-hopping BH runs, with the target to identify all low-energy isomers of small Si and Cu clusters described within density-functional theory. As representative and widely employed move classes we focus on single-particle and collective moves, in which one or all atoms in the cluster at once are displaced in a random direction by some prescribed move distance, respectively. The analysis provides detailed insights into the bottlenecks and governing factors for the sampling efficiency, as well as simple rules of thumb for near-optimum move settings that are intriguingly independent of the distinctly different chemistry of Si and Cu. At corresponding settings, the observed performance of the BH algorithm employing two simple general-purpose move classes is already very good and for the small systems studied essentially limited by frequent revisits to a few dominant isomers.

======== 1209 : Kusova2014

@title:    Direct Bandgap Silicon: Tensile-Strained Silicon Nanocrystals
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs - moje (1),Folder - {\_}by{\_}source - Moje,direct bandgap,photoluminescence,silicon nanocrystals,strain engineering,surface termination
@author:   Kůsov{\'{a}}, Kateřina and Hapala, Prokop and Valenta, Jan and Jel{\'{i}}nek, Pavel and Cibulka, Ondřej Ond$\backslash$vrej and Ondi{\v{c}}, Luk{\'{a}}{\v{s}} and Pelant, Ivan and K$\backslash$uusov{\'{a}}, Kate$\backslash$vrina and Hapala, Prokop and Valenta, Jan and Jel{\'{i}}nek, Pavel and Cibulka, Ondřej Ond$\backslash$vrej and Ondi{\v{c}}, Luk{\'{a}}{\v{s}} and Pelant, Ivan
@doi:      10.1002/admi.201300042
@url:      http://doi.wiley.com/10.1002/admi.201300042
@abstract:
 Silicon, a semiconductor underpinning the vast majority of microelectronics, is an indirect-gap material and consequently is an inefficient light emitter. This hampers the ongoing worldwide effort towards the integration of optoelectronics on silicon wafers. Even though silicon nanocrystals are much better light emitters, they retain the indirect-gap nature. Here, we propose a solution to this long-standing problem: silicon nanocrystals can be transformed into a material with fundamental direct bandgap via a concerted action of quantum confinement and tensile strain. We document this transformation by DFT calculations mapping the E(k) band-structure of Si nanocrystals. The experimental proofs are then given firstly by a 10 000× increase in the photon emission rate of strained silicon nanocrystals together with their altered absorbance spectra, both of which point to direct dipole-allowed transitions, secondly by single nanocrystal spectroscopy, confirming reduced phonon energies and thus the presence of tensile strain, and lastly by photoluminescence studies under external hydrostatic pressure.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Materials Science, Semiconductors, Nanotechnology
- **Specific Domain:** Silicon Nanocrystals (SiNCs), Direct Bandgap Semiconductors, Tensile Strain Engineering, Surface Termination Effects
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article with Theoretical and Experimental Implications

**10 Keywords:**

1. Direct Bandgap Silicon via Tensile-Strained Silicon Nanocrystals
2. Quantum Confinement and Tensile Strain in SiNCs
3. Efficient Light Emission from Silicon-Based Materials
4. Indirect-Gap to Direct-Gap Transition in SiNCs
5. DFT Calculations of E(k) Band-Structure of SiNCs
6. Experimental Proofs of Direct Bandgap Nature of Strained SiNCs
7. Increased Photon Emission Rate and Altered Absorbance Spectra
8. Single Nanocrystal Spectroscopy Confirms Tensile Strain Presence
9. Photoluminescence Studies under External Hydrostatic Pressure
10. Integration of Optoelectronics on Silicon Wafers via Direct Bandgap SiNCs.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Materials Science, Semiconductors

**Note:** The article presents a solution to the long-standing problem of inefficient light emission from silicon-based materials. It proposes the transformation of silicon nanocrystals into direct bandgap materials through a concerted action of quantum confinement and tensile strain. Theoretical calculations and experimental proofs are provided, demonstrating the potential of strained SiNCs for efficient optoelectronic applications on silicon wafers.

======== 1210 : Bohm2014

@title:    Single Electron Bipolar Conductance Switch Driven by the Molecular
@keywords: 1 whereby single,Folder - Molecular Engeneering - Molecular switche,circuit ele-,e ff ect,ff ect,jahn {\`{a}} teller e,lecular electronics,molecular aharonov {\`{a}} bohm,molecules act as functional,proposal of mo-,spin-vibronic coupling,ver since the original
@author:   Bohm, Aharonov {\`{A}} and Lee, Joonhee and Tallarida, Nicholas and Rios, Laura and Perdue, Shawn M and Apkarian, Vartkess Ara and Al, L E E E T
======== 1211 : Stathopoulos1998

@title:    Dynamic Thick Restarting of the Davidson, and the Implicitly Restarted Arnoldi Methods
@keywords: Arnoldi method,Davidson method,Folder - Algorithms - LinearAlgebra - Sparse Solve,Lanczos method,deflation,eigenvalue,implicit restarting,preconditioning
@author:   Stathopoulos, Andreas and Saad, Yousef and Wu, Kesheng
@doi:      10.1137/S1064827596304162
@url:      http://epubs.siam.org/doi/abs/10.1137/S1064827596304162
@abstract:
 The Davidson method is a popular preconditioned variant of the Arnoldi method for solving large eigenvalue problems. For theoretical as well as practical reasons the two methods are often used with restarting. Frequently, information is saved through approximated eigenvectors to compensate for the convergence impairment caused by restarting. We call this scheme of retaining more eigenvectors than needed "thick restarting"and prove that thick restarted, nonpreconditioned Davidson is equivalent to implicitly restarted Arnoldi. We also establish a relation between thick restarted Davidson and a Davidson emthod applied on a deflated system. The theory is used to address the question of which and how many eigenvectors to retain and motivates the development of a dynamic thick restarting scheme for the symmetric case, which can be used in both Davidson and implicit restarted Arnoldi. Several experiments demonstrate the efficiency and robustness of the scheme.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Mathematics
- **Subcategory:** Linear Algebra, Computational Mathematics
- **Specific Domain:** Eigenvalue Problems, Arnoldi Method, Davidson Method, Implicit Restarting, Thick Restarting, Preconditioning
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article with Theoretical and Numerical Implications

**10 Keywords:**

1. Dynamic Thick Restarting of the Davidson and Arnoldi Methods
2. Equivalence between Thick Restarted Davidson and Implicitly Restarted Arnoldi
3. Relation between Thick Restarted Davidson and Deflated System
4. Preconditioning for Eigenvalue Problems
5. Efficient Eigenvector Retention Scheme for Thick Restarting
6. Development of Dynamic Thick Restarting Scheme for Symmetric Case
7. Experiments Demonstrating Efficiency and Robustness of the Scheme
8. Thick Restarting as a Compensation for Convergence Impairment
9. Implicit Restarting of Arnoldi Method for Eigenvalue Problems
10. Davidson Method as a Preconditioned Variant of Arnoldi.

**Specific Topic:** Mathematics - Linear Algebra

**Note:** The article presents a theoretical and numerical analysis of the Davidson and Arnoldi methods, focusing on their restarting schemes. It establishes equivalence between thick restarted Davidson and implicitly restarted Arnoldi, and introduces a dynamic thick restarting scheme for symmetric cases. The study aims to improve the efficiency and robustness of eigenvector retention in eigenvalue problems.

======== 1212 : Auwarter2012

@title:    A surface-anchored molecular four-level conductance switch based on single proton transfer.
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Electronics - SPM control,Folder - SPM - tip{\_}induced{\_}chemistry
@author:   Auw{\"{a}}rter, Willi and Seufert, Knud and Bischoff, Felix and Ecija, David and Vijayaraghavan, Saranyan and Joshi, Sushobhan and Klappenberger, Florian and Samudrala, Niveditha and Barth, Johannes V
@doi:      10.1038/nnano.2011.211
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22157727
@abstract:
 The development of a variety of nanoscale applications requires the fabrication and control of atomic or molecular switches that can be reversibly operated by light, a short-range force, electric current or other external stimuli. For such molecules to be used as electronic components, they should be directly coupled to a metallic support and the switching unit should be easily connected to other molecular species without suppressing switching performance. Here, we show that a free-base tetraphenyl-porphyrin molecule, which is anchored to a silver surface, can function as a molecular conductance switch. The saddle-shaped molecule has two hydrogen atoms in its inner cavity that can be flipped between two states with different local conductance levels using the electron current through the tip of a scanning tunnelling microscope. Moreover, by deliberately removing one of the hydrogens, a four-level conductance switch can be created. The resulting device, which could be controllably integrated into the surrounding nanoscale environment, relies on the transfer of a single proton and therefore contains the smallest possible atomistic switching unit.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Molecular Electronics, Surface Chemistry
- **Specific Domain:** Single-Molecule Devices, Switching Mechanisms, Proton Transfer, Scanning Tunneling Microscopy (STM), Nanotechnology
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article with Experimental and Theoretical Implications

**10 Keywords:**

1. Surface-Anchored Molecular Four-Level Conductance Switch
2. Single-Proton Transfer Mechanism for Switching Performance
3. Free-Base Tetraphenyl-Porphyrin Molecule as a Switching Unit
4. Silver Surface Anchoring of the Porphyrin Molecule
5. Electron Current-Induced Conformational Change in the Porphyrin Molecule

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Molecular Electronics

**Note:** The article presents a novel molecular conductance switch based on single-proton transfer, which is anchored to a silver surface and can be controlled using the electron current through the tip of a scanning tunnelling microscope (STM). The device relies on the transfer of a single proton and contains the smallest possible atomistic switching unit.

======== 1213 : Copko2024

@title:    Multiplicity-driven photochromism controls three-state fulgimide photoswitches
@author:   Copko, Jakub and Slanina, Tom{\'{a}}{\v{s}}
@doi:      10.1039/d3cc05975h
@abstract:
 Fulgimide photoswitches display three-state photoswitching between isomeric forms Z, E and C. Fulgimides have therefore access to both large steric change of double bond isomerization and the large spectral change induced by electrocyclization. By controlling the multiplicity and photoisomerization conditions, we achieved precise and near-quantitative control over both isomerization modes.

@title:    Real-space imaging of anisotropic charge of $\sigma$-hole by means of Kelvin probe force microscopy

======== 1215 : Reeves2013

@title:    Electron acceleration in the heart of the Van Allen radiation belts.
@keywords: Folder - Astronomy
@author:   Reeves, G D and Spence, H E and Henderson, M G and Morley, S K and Friedel, R H W and Funsten, H O and Baker, D N and Kanekal, S G and Blake, J B and Fennell, J F and Claudepierre, S G and Thorne, R M and Turner, D L and Kletzing, C a and Kurth, W S and Larsen, B a and Niehof, J T
@doi:      10.1126/science.1237743
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23887876
@abstract:
 The Van Allen radiation belts contain ultrarelativistic electrons trapped in Earth's magnetic field. Since their discovery in 1958, a fundamental unanswered question has been how electrons can be accelerated to such high energies. Two classes of processes have been proposed: transport and acceleration of electrons from a source population located outside the radiation belts (radial acceleration) or acceleration of lower-energy electrons to relativistic energies in situ in the heart of the radiation belts (local acceleration). We report measurements from NASA's Van Allen Radiation Belt Storm Probes that clearly distinguish between the two types of acceleration. The observed radial profiles of phase space density are characteristic of local acceleration in the heart of the radiation belts and are inconsistent with a predominantly radial acceleration process.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Space Physics, Astrophysics
- **Specific Domain:** Van Allen Radiation Belts, Electron Acceleration, Magnetic Field Dynamics, Radiation Belt Storm Probes (RBSP)
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article with Experimental and Theoretical Implications

**10 Keywords:**

1. Electron Acceleration in the Van Allen Radiation Belts
2. Radial vs Local Acceleration of Electrons in RBSP Data
3. Characterization of Phase Space Density Profiles
4. Evidence for In-Situ Acceleration of Lower-Energy Electrons
5. Measured Radial Profiles of Phase Space Density in RBSP
6. Comparison between Theoretical Models and Observed Data
7. Implications for Understanding Radiation Belt Dynamics
8. NASA's Van Allen Radiation Belt Storm Probes (RBSP) Mission
9. Ultrarelativistic Electron Trapping in Earth's Magnetic Field
10. Radial Acceleration vs Local Acceleration in RBSP Data.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Space Physics

**Note:** The article presents measurements from the Van Allen Radiation Belt Storm Probes that provide evidence for local acceleration of lower-energy electrons to ultrarelativistic energies within the radiation belts, contradicting the previously proposed radial acceleration mechanism.

======== 1216 : Pulimeno2013

@keywords: Ab initio simulations,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - SAMs - ferrocene,defects modeling,molecular QCA,molecular nanowire,quantum-dot cellular automata (QCA),safe operating area (SOA)
@author:   Pulimeno, Azzurra and Graziano, Mariagrazia and Sanginario, Alessandro and Cauda, Valentina and Demarchi, Danilo and Piccinini, Gianluca
@doi:      10.1109/TNANO.2013.2261824
@url:      http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/lpdocs/epic03/wrapper.htm?arnumber=6514073
======== 1217 : Barin2012

@title:    Mechanically Interlocked Molecules Assembled by $\pi$-$\pi$ Recognition
@keywords: ??-?? interactions,Catenanes,Donor-acceptor systems,Folder - Molecular Electronics - Molecular{\_}memory,Mechanically interlocked molecules,Rotaxanes
@author:   Barin, Gokhan and Coskun, Ali and Fouda, Moustafa M G and Stoddart, J. Fraser
@doi:      10.1002/cplu.201100075
@url:      http://doi.wiley.com/10.1002/cplu.201100075
@abstract:
 The beauty and utility of interlocked architectures have been making their way relentlessly into chemistry in the form of me- chanically interlocked molecules (MIMs) for almost half a cen- tury now. Few would challenge the assertion that the emer- gence of template-directed synthetic protocols has aided and abetted the facile and efficient construction of MIMs compared with the statistical approaches employed while the field was still in its infancy. To date, a panoply of MIMs has been created in the wake of emerging recognition motifs and the template- directed synthetic protocols they have forged. Among these motifs, those dependent on p–p stacking in the form of donor–acceptor interactions have played an important role in the increasingly rapid development of the field. The few integrated systems that have so far emerged based on this class of MIMs demonstrate their ability to act as active components in many potential applications. This review focuses on the progress which has been accomplished during the past decade involving MIMs comprising aromatic p–p stacking interactions. While progress has been remarkable, opportunities still abound for MIMs assembled by p–p recognition.
