======== 1218 : Kusova-singleNcSi-ACSNano2010

@title:    Brightly luminescent organically capped silicon nanocrystals fabricated at room temperature and atmospheric pressure.
@keywords: Atmospheric Pressure,Colloids,Electron,Folder - SiNCs,Folder - SiNCs - znami,Fourier Transform Infrared,Light,Luminescent Measurements,Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy,Microscopy,NMR,Nanoparticles,Nanoparticles: chemistry,Nanotechnology,Nanotechnology: methods,Organic capping,Photoluminescence,Radiation,Scattering,SiNC,Silicon,Silicon nanocrystals,Silicon: chemistry,Single-nanocrystal spectroscopy,Spectroscopy,Surface Properties,Temperature,Transmission
@author:   Kůsov{\'{a}}, Kateřina Katerina and Cibulka, Ondrej Ondřej and Dohnalov{\'{a}}, Katerina Kateřina and Pelant, Ivan and Valenta, Jan and Fuc{\'{i}}kov{\'{a}}, Anna and Z{\'{i}}dek, Karel and Lang, Jan and Englich, Jir{\'{i}} Jiř{\'{i}} and Matejka, Pavel and Step{\'{a}}nek, Petr and Bakardjieva, Snejana and Fǔc{\'{i}}kov{\'{a}}, Anna and {\v{Z}}{\'{i}}dek, Karel and Lang, Jan and Englich, Jir{\'{i}} Jiř{\'{i}} and Mat{\v{e}}jka, Pavel and {\v{S}}t{\v{e}}p{\'{a}}nek, Petr and Bakardjieva, Snejana
@doi:      10.1021/nn1005182
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20690596
@abstract:
 Silicon nanocrystals are an extensively studied light-emitting material due to their inherent biocompatibility and compatibility with silicon-based technology. Although they might seem to fall behind their rival, namely, direct band gap based semiconductor nanocrystals, when it comes to the emission of light, room for improvement still lies in the exploitation of various surface passivations. In this paper, we report on an original way, taking place at room temperature and ambient pressure, to replace the silicon oxide shell of luminescent Si nanocrystals with capping involving organic residues. The modification of surface passivation is evidenced by both Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and nuclear magnetic resonance measurements. In addition, single-nanocrystal spectroscopy reveals the occurrence of a systematic fine structure in the emission single spectra, which is connected with an intrinsic property of small nanocrystals since a very similar structure has recently been observed in specially passivated semiconductor CdZnSe nanoparticles. The organic capping also dramatically changes optical properties of Si nanocrystals (resulting ensemble photoluminescence quantum efficiency 20{\%}, does not deteriorate, radiative lifetime 10 ns at 550 nm at room temperature). Optically clear colloidal dispersion of these nanocrystals thus exhibits properties fully comparable with direct band gap semiconductor nanoparticles.

- **Specific Domain:** Silicon Nanocrystals (SiNCs), Surface Passivation, Organic Capping, Colloidal Dispersion, Photoluminescence

**Specific Topic:** Materials Science - Nanotechnology

**Note:** The article presents an original method for fabricating brightly luminescent organically capped silicon nanocrystals at room temperature and atmospheric pressure, which involves replacing the silicon oxide shell with organic residues. The modification is evidenced by FTIR and NMR measurements, and single-nanocrystal spectroscopy reveals a systematic fine structure in the emission spectrum. The optical properties of the resulting SiNCs are dramatically improved, with an ensemble photoluminescence quantum efficiency of 20% and a radiative lifetime of 10 ns at room temperature.

======== 1219 : Jelinek2005

@title:    Multicenter approach to the exchange-correlation interactions in ab initio tight-binding methods
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods - Fireball,Folder - SiNCs,SiNC,fireball
@author:   Jel{\'{i}}nek, Pavel and Wang, Hao and Lewis, James and Sankey, Otto and Ortega, Jos{\'{e}}
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.71.235101
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.71.235101
======== 1220 : Keten2010

@title:    Nanoconfinement controls stiffness, strength and mechanical toughness of beta-sheet crystals in silk.
@keywords: Folder - sctructural{\_}tech - MaterialScience - Biom,Mechanics,Models,Models- Molecular,Molecular,Nanotechnology,Protein Structure,Protein Structure- Secondary,Secondary,Silk,Silk: chemistry
@author:   Keten, Sinan and Xu, Zhiping and Ihle, Britni and Buehler, Markus J
@doi:      10.1038/nmat2704
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20228820
@abstract:
 Silk features exceptional mechanical properties such as high tensile strength and great extensibility, making it one of the toughest materials known. The exceptional strength of silkworm and spider silks, exceeding that of steel, arises from beta-sheet nanocrystals that universally consist of highly conserved poly-(Gly-Ala) and poly-Ala domains. This is counterintuitive because the key molecular interactions in beta-sheet nanocrystals are hydrogen bonds, one of the weakest chemical bonds known. Here we report a series of large-scale molecular dynamics simulations, revealing that beta-sheet nanocrystals confined to a few nanometres achieve higher stiffness, strength and mechanical toughness than larger nanocrystals. We illustrate that through nanoconfinement, a combination of uniform shear deformation that makes most efficient use of hydrogen bonds and the emergence of dissipative molecular stick-slip deformation leads to significantly enhanced mechanical properties. Our findings explain how size effects can be exploited to create bioinspired materials with superior mechanical properties in spite of relying on mechanically inferior, weak hydrogen bonds.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Materials Science
- **Subcategory:** Nanotechnology, Biomaterials, Protein Structure
- **Specific Domain:** Silk Mechanics, Beta-Sheet Crystals, Nanoconfinement Effects, Molecular Dynamics Simulations
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Nanoconfinement Controls Stiffness and Strength of Beta-Sheet Crystals in Silk
2. Exceptional Mechanical Properties of Silk due to Beta-Sheet Nanocrystals
3. Molecular Dynamics Simulations reveal Size Effects on Silk Mechanics
4. Uniform Shear Deformation enhances Hydrogen Bond Efficiency in Silk
5. Dissipative Molecular Stick-Slip Deformation increases Mechanical Toughness
6. Nanoconfinement leads to superior mechanical properties in spite of weak hydrogen bonds
7. Bioinspired Materials with enhanced mechanical properties through size effects
8. Large-scale molecular dynamics simulations reveal mechanisms behind silk mechanics
9. Poly-(Gly-Ala) and poly-Ala domains contribute to beta-sheet nanocrystal strength
10. Nanoconfinement-induced stiffening, strengthening, and toughening of beta-sheet crystals.

**Specific Topic:** Materials Science - Nanotechnology

**Note:** The article presents a series of large-scale molecular dynamics simulations that reveal how nanoconfinement affects the mechanical properties of beta-sheet crystals in silk. The findings explain why silkworm and spider silks exhibit exceptional strength and toughness, despite relying on weak hydrogen bonds. The research shows that nanoconfinement leads to uniform shear deformation and dissipative stick-slip deformation, resulting in superior mechanical properties.

======== 1221 : Jiang2012

@title:    Submolecular control, spectroscopy and imaging of bond-selective chemistry in single functionalized molecules
@keywords: Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2015{\_}11{\_}09
@author:   Jiang, Ying and Huan, Qing and Fabris, Laura and Bazan, Guillermo C. and Ho, Wilson
@doi:      10.1038/nchem.1488
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23247175 http://www.nature.com.globalproxy.cvt.dk/nchem/journal/v5/n1/full/nchem.1488.html{\%}5Cnhttp://www.nature.com.globalproxy.cvt.dk/nchem/journal/v5/n1/pdf/nchem.1488.pdf http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nchem.
@abstract:
 One of the key challenges in chemistry is to break and form bonds selectively in complex organic molecules that possess a range of different functional groups. To do this at the single-molecule level not only provides an opportunity to create custom nanoscale devices, but offers opportunities for the in-depth study of how the molecular electronic structure changes in individual reactions. Here we use a scanning tunnelling microscope (STM) to induce a sequence of targeted bond dissociation and formation steps in single thiol-based $\pi$-conjugated molecules adsorbed on a NiAl(110) surface. Furthermore, the electronic resonances of the resulting species were measured by spatially resolved electronic spectroscopy at each reaction step. Specifically, the STM was used to cleave individual acetyl groups and to form Au-S bonds by manipulating single Au atoms. A detailed understanding of the Au-S bond and its non-local influence is fundamentally important for determining the electron transport in thiol-based molecular junction.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Physical Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents a study on the submolecular control of bond-specific chemistry in single functionalized molecules using scanning tunnelling microscopy (STM) and spatially resolved electronic spectroscopy. The research demonstrates how to induce targeted bond dissociation and formation steps in thiol-based π-conjugated molecules adsorbed on a NiAl(110) surface, providing insights into the molecular electronic structure and electron transport in thiol-based molecular junctions.

======== 1230 : El-Kaderi2007

@title:    Designed synthesis of 3D covalent organic frameworks.
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Engeneering,Folder - Molecular Engeneering - Molecular network
@author:   El-Kaderi, Hani M and Hunt, Joseph R and Mendoza-Cort{\'{e}}s, Jos{\'{e}} L and C{\^{o}}t{\'{e}}, Adrien P and Taylor, Robert E and O'Keeffe, Michael and Yaghi, Omar M
@doi:      10.1126/science.1139915
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17431178
@abstract:
 Three-dimensional covalent organic frameworks (3D COFs) were synthesized by targeting two nets based on triangular and tetrahedral nodes: ctn and bor. The respective 3D COFs were synthesized as crystalline solids by condensation reactions of tetrahedral tetra(4-dihydroxyborylphenyl) methane or tetra(4-dihydroxyborylphenyl)silane and by co-condensation of triangular 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexahydroxytriphenylene. Because these materials are entirely constructed from strong covalent bonds (C-C, C-O, C-B, and B-O), they have high thermal stabilities (400 degrees to 500 degrees C), and they also have high surface areas (3472 and 4210 square meters per gram for COF-102 and COF-103, respectively) and extremely low densities (0.17 grams per cubic centimeter).

@title:    The force needed to move an atom on a surface.
@author:   Ternes, Markus and Lutz, Christopher P and Hirjibehedin, Cyrus F and Giessibl, Franz J and Heinrich, Andreas J
@doi:      10.1126/science.1150288
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18292336
@abstract:
 Manipulation of individual atoms and molecules by scanning probe microscopy offers the ability of controlled assembly at the single-atom scale. However, the driving forces behind atomic manipulation have not yet been measured. We used an atomic force microscope to measure the vertical and lateral forces exerted on individual adsorbed atoms or molecules by the probe tip. We found that the force that it takes to move an atom depends strongly on the adsorbate and the surface. Our results indicate that for moving metal atoms on metal surfaces, the lateral force component plays the dominant role. Furthermore, measuring spatial maps of the forces during manipulation yielded the full potential energy landscape of the tip-sample interaction.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Condensed Matter Physics, Nanotechnology
- **Specific Domain:** Scanning Probe Microscopy (SPM), Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM), Single-Atom Manipulation, Surface Science
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Measuring Forces for Moving Individual Atoms on a Surface
2. Atomic Force Microscopy for Tip-Sample Interaction Studies
3. Lateral and Vertical Forces in Atomic Manipulation
4. Adsorbate-Surface Dependence of Atomic Movement Forces
5. Metal Atom Movement on Metal Surfaces
6. Dominant Role of Lateral Forces in Atomic Manipulation
7. Spatial Maps of Forces during Single-Atom Manipulation
8. Full Potential Energy Landscape of Tip-Sample Interaction
9. Scanning Probe Microscopy for Controlled Atomic Assembly
10. Understanding the Driving Forces behind Atomic Manipulation.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Condensed Matter Physics

**Note:** The article presents a study on measuring the forces required to move individual atoms on a surface using atomic force microscopy. The research reveals that the lateral force component plays a dominant role in moving metal atoms on metal surfaces and provides insights into the tip-sample interaction potential energy landscape, advancing our understanding of single-atom manipulation.

@title:    Toward nanocomputers
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Electronics - Molecular{\_}memory

======== 1237 : Schiros2012

@title:    Connecting dopant bond type with electronic structure in N-doped graphene.
@keywords: 2d,Folder - carbon graphene - Defects,bonding,electronic structure,he two dimensional,including high con-,it,it a,nature of graphene endows,nitrogen-doped graphene,promising electronic contact material,unique properties that make,with a number of,workfunction,x-ray spectroscopy
@author:   Schiros, Theanne and Nordlund, Dennis and P{\'{a}}lov{\'{a}}, Lucia and Prezzi, Deborah and Zhao, Liuyan and Kim, Keun Soo and Wurstbauer, Ulrich and Guti{\'{e}}rrez, Christopher and Delongchamp, Dean and Jaye, Cherno and Fischer, Daniel and Ogasawara, Hirohito and Pettersson, Lars G M and Reichman, David R and Kim, Philip and Hybertsen, Mark S and Pasupathy, Abhay N
@doi:      10.1021/nl301409h
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22746249
@abstract:
 Robust methods to tune the unique electronic properties of graphene by chemical modification are in great demand due to the potential of the two dimensional material to impact a range of device applications. Here we show that carbon and nitrogen core-level resonant X-ray spectroscopy is a sensitive probe of chemical bonding and electronic structure of chemical dopants introduced in single-sheet graphene films. In conjunction with density functional theory based calculations, we are able to obtain a detailed picture of bond types and electronic structure in graphene doped with nitrogen at the sub-percent level. We show that different N-bond types, including graphitic, pyridinic, and nitrilic, can exist in a single, dilutely N-doped graphene sheet. We show that these various bond types have profoundly different effects on the carrier concentration, indicating that control over the dopant bond type is a crucial requirement in advancing graphene electronics.

@title:    A close look at Saturn's rings with Cassini VIMS
@keywords: Folder - Space{\_}Tech - SaturnRings,infrared observations,planetary rings,rings,saturn
@author:   Nicholson, Philip D. and Hedman, Matthew M. and Clark, Roger N. and Showalter, Mark R. and Cruikshank, Dale P. and Cuzzi, Jeffrey N. and Filacchione, Gianrico and Capaccioni, Fabrizio and Cerroni, Priscilla and Hansen, Gary B. and Sicardy, Bruno and Drossart, Pierre and Brown, Robert H. and Buratti, Bonnie J. and Baines, Kevin H. and Coradini, Angioletta
@doi:      10.1016/j.icarus.2007.08.036

======== 1239 : Duan2015

@title:    Theoretical modeling of plasmon-enhanced raman images of a single molecule with subnanometer resolution
@author:   Duan, Sai and Tian, Guangjun and Ji, Yongfei and Shao, Jiushu and Dong, Zhenchao and Luo, Yi
@doi:      10.1021/jacs.5b03741
@abstract:
 Under local plasmonic excitation, Raman images of single molecules can now surprisingly reach subnanometer resolution. However, its physical origin has not been fully understood. Here we report a quantum-mechanical description of the interaction between a molecule and a highly confined plasmonic field. We show that when the spatial distribution of the plasmonic field is comparable to the size of the molecule, the optical transition matrix of the molecule becomes dependent on the position and distribution of the plasmonic field, resulting in a spatially resolved high-resolution Raman image of the molecule. The resonant Raman image reflects the electronic transition density of the molecule. In combination with first-principles calculations, the simulated Raman image of a porphyrin derivative adsorbed on a silver surface nicely reproduces its experimental counterpart. The present theory provides the basic framework for describing linear and nonlinear responses of molecules under highly confined plasmonic fields.

**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

1. Theoretical Modeling of Plasmon-Enhanced Raman Images of a Single Molecule
2. Subnanometer Resolution in Raman Imaging of Single Molecules
3. Interaction between Molecule and Highly Confined Plasmonic Field
4. Quantum-Mechanical Description of Plasmon-Molecule Interaction
5. Spatially Resolved High-Resolution Raman Image of a Molecule
6. Electronic Transition Density of a Molecule Reflected in Resonant Raman Image
7. First-Principles Calculations and Simulated Raman Images of Porphyrin Derivative
8. Experimental Validation of Theoretical Model using Porphyrin Derivative Adsorbed on Silver Surface
9. Basic Framework for Describing Linear and Nonlinear Responses of Molecules under Plasmonic Fields

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Condensed Matter Physics, Nanotechnology

**Note:** The article presents a theoretical model to explain the subnanometer resolution achieved in Raman imaging of single molecules using plasmon-enhanced Raman scattering. The research combines quantum-mechanical and first-principles calculations to describe the interaction between a molecule and a highly confined plasmonic field, providing insights into the physical origin of this phenomenon.

======== 1240 : Kleinman1982a

@title:    Efficacious Form for Model Pseudopotentials
@keywords: Folder - {\_}Thesis - Grid

@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevLett.48.1425

======== 1241 : Liu-directGeTheory-OE2007

@title:    Tensile-strained, n-type Ge as a gain medium for monolithic laser integration on Si.
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs,SiNC
@author:   Liu, Jifeng and Sun, Xiaochen and Pan, Dong and Wang, Xiaoxin and Kimerling, Lionel C and Koch, Thomas L and Michel, Jurgen
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19547484
@abstract:
 We analyze the optical gain of tensile-strained, n-type Ge material for Si-compatible laser applications. The band structure of unstrained Ge exhibits indirect conduction band valleys (L) lower than the direct valley (Gamma) by 136 meV. Adequate strain and n-type doping engineering can effectively provide population inversion in the direct bandgap of Ge. The tensile strain decreases the difference between the L valleys and the Gamma valley, while the extrinsic electrons from n-type doping fill the L valleys to the level of the Gamma valley to compensate for the remaining energy difference. Our modeling shows that with a combination of 0.25{\%} tensile strain and an extrinsic electron density of 7.6x10(19)/cm(3) by n-type doping, a net material gain of {\~{}}400 cm(-1) can be obtained from the direct gap transition of Ge despite of the free carrier absorption loss. The threshold current density for lasing is estimated to be {\~{}}6kA cm(-2) for a typical edgeemitting double heterojunction structure. These results indicate that tensile strained n-type Ge is a good candidate for Si integrated lasers.

1. Tensile-Strained n-Type Ge as a Gain Medium for Monolithic Laser Integration on Si
2. Optical Gain Analysis of Tensile-Strained Ge for Si-Compatible Laser Applications

**Specific Topic:** Engineering - Electrical Engineering, Materials Science

**Note:** The article presents an analysis of the optical gain of tensile-strained, n-type Ge material for Si-compatible laser applications. The research shows that a combination of strain and n-type doping engineering can provide population inversion in the direct bandgap of Ge, making it a good candidate for Si integrated lasers.

======== 1242 : Dikin2007

@title:    Preparation and characterization of graphene oxide paper.
@keywords: Folder - carbon graphene
@author:   Dikin, Dmitriy a and Stankovich, Sasha and Zimney, Eric J and Piner, Richard D and Dommett, Geoffrey H B and Evmenenko, Guennadi and Nguyen, SonBinh T and Ruoff, Rodney S
@doi:      10.1038/nature06016
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17653188
@abstract:
 Free-standing paper-like or foil-like materials are an integral part of our technological society. Their uses include protective layers, chemical filters, components of electrical batteries or supercapacitors, adhesive layers, electronic or optoelectronic components, and molecular storage. Inorganic 'paper-like' materials based on nanoscale components such as exfoliated vermiculite or mica platelets have been intensively studied and commercialized as protective coatings, high-temperature binders, dielectric barriers and gas-impermeable membranes. Carbon-based flexible graphite foils composed of stacked platelets of expanded graphite have long been used in packing and gasketing applications because of their chemical resistivity against most media, superior sealability over a wide temperature range, and impermeability to fluids. The discovery of carbon nanotubes brought about bucky paper, which displays excellent mechanical and electrical properties that make it potentially suitable for fuel cell and structural composite applications. Here we report the preparation and characterization of graphene oxide paper, a free-standing carbon-based membrane material made by flow-directed assembly of individual graphene oxide sheets. This new material outperforms many other paper-like materials in stiffness and strength. Its combination of macroscopic flexibility and stiffness is a result of a unique interlocking-tile arrangement of the nanoscale graphene oxide sheets.

**Specific Topic:** Materials Science - Nanotechnology

**Note:** The article presents a study on the preparation and characterization of graphene oxide paper, a free-standing carbon-based membrane material made by flow-directed assembly of individual graphene oxide sheets. The research highlights the unique interlocking-tile arrangement in graphene oxide sheets, which leads to exceptional stiffness and strength properties.

======== 1243 : Hill2007

@title:    Spin-component scaling methods for weak and stacking interactions
@author:   Hill, J. Grant and Platts, James A.
@doi:      10.1021/ct6002737
@abstract:
 New scaling parameters are presented for use in the spin-component scaled (SCS) variant of density fitted local second-order Moller-Plesset perturbation theory (DF-LMP2) that have been optimized for use in evaluating the interaction energy between nucleic acid base pairs. The optimal set of parameters completely neglects the contribution from antiparallel-spin electron pairs to the MP2 energy while scaling the parallel contribution by 1.76. These spin-component scaled for nucleobases (SCSN) parameters are obtained by minimizing, with respect to SCS parameters, the rms interaction energy error relative to the best available literature values, over a set of ten stacked nucleic acid base pairs. The applicability of this scaling to a wide variety of noncovalent interactions is verified through evaluation of a larger set of model complexes, including those dominated by dispersion and electrostatics. {\textcopyright} 2007 American Chemical Society.

======== 1245 : Cote2005a

@title:    Porous, crystalline, covalent organic frameworks.
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Engeneering,Folder - Molecular Engeneering - Molecular network
@author:   C{\^{o}}t{\'{e}}, Adrien P and Benin, Annabelle I and Ockwig, Nathan W and O'Keeffe, Michael and Matzger, Adam J and Yaghi, Omar M
@doi:      10.1126/science.1120411
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16293756
@abstract:
 Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) have been designed and successfully synthesized by condensation reactions of phenyl diboronic acid {\{}C6H4[B(OH)2]2{\}} and hexahydroxytriphenylene [C18H6(OH)6]. Powder x-ray diffraction studies of the highly crystalline products (C3H2BO)6.(C9H12)1 (COF-1) and C9H4BO2 (COF-5) revealed expanded porous graphitic layers that are either staggered (COF-1, P6(3)/mmc) or eclipsed (COF-5, P6/mmm). Their crystal structures are entirely held by strong bonds between B, C, and O atoms to form rigid porous architectures with pore sizes ranging from 7 to 27 angstroms. COF-1 and COF-5 exhibit high thermal stability (to temperatures up to 500 degrees to 600 degrees C), permanent porosity, and high surface areas (711 and 1590 square meters per gram, respectively).

======== 1246 : Sweetman2014b

@title:    Unique determination of "subatomic" contrast by imaging covalent backbonding.
@keywords: 1 scanning tunneling microscopy,111,afm,and atomic force microscopy,dfm,fi rst obtained by,have become,ince atomic resolution was,microscopy,nc-afm,qplus,scanning probe,si,spm,stm,subatomic,uhv
@author:   Sweetman, Adam and Rahe, Philipp and Moriarty, Philip
@doi:      10.1021/nl4041803
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24628698
@abstract:
 The origin of so-called "subatomic" resolution in dynamic force microscopy has remained controversial since its first observation in 2000. A number of detailed experimental and theoretical studies have identified different possible physicochemical mechanisms potentially giving rise to subatomic contrast. In this study, for the first time we are able to assign the origin of a specific instance of subatomic contrast as being due to the back bonding of a surface atom in the tip-sample junction.

======== 1247 : Whiting2004a

@title:    Orbital Transfer Trajectory Optimization
@keywords: Folder - Space - Orbits - OrbitalTransfer,long,orbital transfer
@author:   Whiting, James K
======== 1248 : Tayi2012

@title:    Room-temperature ferroelectricity in supramolecular networks of charge-transfer complexes
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Electronics - Molecular{\_}memory
@author:   Tayi, Alok S. and Shveyd, Alexander K. and Sue, Andrew C.-H. and Szarko, Jodi M. and Rolczynski, Brian S. and Cao, Dennis and Kennedy, T. Jackson and Sarjeant, Amy a. and Stern, Charlotte L. and Paxton, Walter F. and Wu, Wei and Dey, Sanjeev K. and Fahrenbach, Albert C. and Guest, Jeffrey R. and Mohseni, Hooman and Chen, Lin X. and Wang, Kang L. and Stoddart, J. Fraser and Stupp, Samuel I.
@doi:      10.1038/nature11395
@url:      http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature11395
@abstract:
 Materials exhibiting a spontaneous electrical polarization that can be switched easily between antiparallel orientations are of potential value for sensors, photonics and energy-efficient memories. In this context, organic ferroelectrics are of particular interest because they promise to be lightweight, inexpensive and easily processed into devices. A recently identified family of organic ferroelectric structures is based on intermolecular charge transfer, where donor and acceptor molecules co-crystallize in an alternating fashion known as a mixed stack: in the crystalline lattice, a collective transfer of electrons from donor to acceptor molecules results in the formation of dipoles that can be realigned by an external field as molecules switch partners in the mixed stack. Although mixed stacks have been investigated extensively, only three systems are known to show ferroelectric switching, all below 71 kelvin. Here we describe supramolecular charge-transfer networks that undergo ferroelectric polarization switching with a ferroelectric Curie temperature above room temperature. These polar and switchable systems utilize a structural synergy between a hydrogen-bonded network and charge-transfer complexation of donor and acceptor molecules in a mixed stack. This supramolecular motif could help guide the development of other functional organic systems that can switch polarization under the influence of electric fields at ambient temperatures.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Organic Chemistry, Materials Science, Molecular Electronics
- **Specific Domain:** Supramolecular Chemistry, Charge-Transfer Complexes, Ferroelectricity in Organic Systems
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Room-Temperature Ferroelectricity in Supramolecular Networks of Charge-Transfer Complexes
2. Ferroelectric Switching with Curie Temperature above 300K (Room Temperature)
3. Structural Synergy between Hydrogen-Bonded Network and Charge-Transfer Complexation
4. Mixed Stacks: Co-Crystallization of Donor and Acceptor Molecules for Ferroelectricity
5. Supramolecular Motif for Polar and Switchable Organic Systems at Ambient Temperatures
6. Potential Applications in Sensors, Photonics, and Energy-Efficient Memories
7. Lightweight, Inexpensive, and Easily Processed into Devices: Advantages of Organic Ferroelectrics
8. Collective Transfer of Electrons from Donor to Acceptor Molecules for Dipole Formation
9. Realignment of Dipoles by External Electric Field through Molecular Switching in Mixed Stacks
10. Development of Functional Organic Systems with Improved Polarization Switching Properties.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Materials Science

**Note:** The article presents a study on the discovery of supramolecular charge-transfer networks that exhibit ferroelectric polarization switching at room temperature, which is above the previously known limit of 71K. The research focuses on the structural synergy between hydrogen-bonded networks and charge-transfer complexation in mixed stacks, providing insights into the design of functional organic systems with improved properties.

@title:    Beyond the random phase approximation: Improved description of short-range correlation by a renormalized adiabatic local density approximation

@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.88.115131

======== 1252 : Telychko2014

@title:    Achieving High-Quality Single-Atom Nitrogen Doping of Graphene/SiC(0001) by Ion Implantation and Subsequent Thermal Stabilization
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}source - Moje,STM,SiC,doping,graphene,implantation,nitrogen,photoemission
@author:   Telychko, Mykola and Mutombo, Pingo and Ondr{\'{a}}{\v{c}}ek, Martin and Hapala, Prokop and Bocquet, Fran{\c{c}}ois C F.C. and Koloren{\v{c}}, Jindřich and Vondr{\'{a}}{\v{c}}ek, Martin and Jel{\'{i}}nek, Pavel and {\v{S}}vec, Martin
@doi:      10.1021/nn502438k
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24884035 http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/nn502438k https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/nn502438k
@abstract:
 We report a straightforward method to produce high-quality nitrogen-doped graphene on SiC(0001) using direct nitrogen ion implantation and subsequent stabilization at temperatures above 1300 K. We demonstrate that double defects, which comprise two nitrogen defects in a second-nearest-neighbor (meta) configuration, can be formed in a controlled way by adjusting the duration of bombardment. Two types of atomic contrast of single N defects are identified in scanning tunneling microscopy. We attribute the origin of these two contrasts to different tip structures by means of STM simulations. The characteristic dip observed over N defects is explained in terms of the destructive quantum interference.

======== 1253 : Janis1897

@title:    Statistick{\'{a}} n{\'{a}}hodnost v kovov{\'{y}}ch materi{\'{a}}lech : elektrick{\'{y}} odpor , difuse a lokalizace elektronů
@keywords: Folder - Theory
@author:   Jani{\v{s}}, V{\'{a}}clav
======== 1254 : Summa2007

@title:    Near-native structure refinement using in vacuo energy minimization.
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - GlobalOptimizatio
@author:   Summa, Christopher M and Levitt, Michael
@doi:      10.1073/pnas.0611593104
@abstract:
 One of the greatest shortcomings of macromolecular energy minimization and molecular dynamics techniques is that they generally do not preserve the native structure of proteins as observed by x-ray crystallography. This deformation of the native structure means that these methods are not generally used to refine structures produced by homology-modeling techniques. Here, we use a database of 75 proteins to test the ability of a variety of popular molecular mechanics force fields to maintain the native structure. Minimization from the native structure is a weak test of potential energy functions: It is complemented by a much stronger test in which the same methods are compared for their ability to attract a near-native decoy protein structure toward the native structure. We use a powerfully convergent energy-minimization method and show that, of the traditional molecular mechanics potentials tested, only one showed a modest net improvement over a large data set of structurally diverse proteins. A smooth, differentiable knowledge-based pairwise atomic potential performs better on this test than traditional potential functions. This work is expected to have important implications for protein structure refinement, homology modeling, and structure prediction.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Biochemistry
- **Subcategory:** Computational Biology, Structural Biology, Protein Chemistry
- **Specific Domain:** Molecular Mechanics, Energy Minimization, Protein Structure Refinement
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Near-Native Structure Refinement using In Vacuo Energy Minimization
2. Preserving Native Protein Structures through Energy Minimization Techniques
3. Comparison of Popular Molecular Mechanics Force Fields for Native Structure Preservation
4. Database of 75 Proteins used to Test Energy Minimization Methods
5. Traditional Molecular Mechanics Potentials vs. Smooth, Differentiable Pairwise Atomic Potential
6. Powerfully Convergent Energy-Minimization Method Developed for Protein Structure Refinement
7. Implications for Protein Structure Prediction, Homology Modeling, and Structure Refinement
8. Importance of Native Structure Preservation in Computational Biology and Structural Biology
9. Evaluating the Performance of Molecular Mechanics Force Fields on a Large Dataset of Proteins
10. Advancements in Energy Minimization Techniques for Improving Protein Structure Predictions.

**Specific Topic:** Biochemistry - Computational Biology

**Note:** The article presents a study on refining near-native protein structures using in vacuo energy minimization techniques. The research compares the performance of popular molecular mechanics force fields and identifies a smooth, differentiable pairwise atomic potential as more effective for preserving native protein structures. This work has important implications for protein structure prediction, homology modeling, and structure refinement in computational biology and structural biology.

======== 1255 : Teschner2003

@author:   Teschner, Matthias and Matthias, M and Gross, Markus
======== 1256 : Duwez2006

@title:    Mechanochemistry: targeted delivery of single molecules.
@keywords: Atomic Force,Atomic Force: methods,Chemical,Computer Simulation,Drug Delivery Systems,Drug Delivery Systems: methods,Folder - Molecular Electronics - SPM control,Mechanical,Microchemistry,Microchemistry: methods,Micromanipulation,Micromanipulation: methods,Microscopy,Microscopy- Atomic Force,Microscopy- Atomic Force: methods,Models,Models- Chemical,Organic Chemicals,Organic Chemicals: chemistry,Stress,Stress- Mechanical
@author:   Duwez, Anne-Sophie and Cuenot, St{\'{e}}phane and J{\'{e}}r{\^{o}}me, Christine and Gabriel, Sabine and J{\'{e}}r{\^{o}}me, Robert and Rapino, Stefania and Zerbetto, Francesco
@doi:      10.1038/nnano.2006.92
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18654163
@abstract:
 The use of scanning probe microscopy-based techniques to manipulate single molecules and deliver them in a precisely controlled manner to a specific target represents a significant nanotechnological challenge. The ultimate physical limit in the design and fabrication of organic surfaces can be reached using this approach. Here we show that the atomic force microscope (AFM), which has been used extensively to investigate the stretching of individual molecules, can deliver and immobilize single molecules, one at a time, on a surface. Reactive polymer molecules, attached at one end to an AFM tip, are brought into contact with a modified silicon substrate to which they become linked by a chemical reaction. When the AFM tip is pulled away from the surface, the resulting mechanical force causes the weakest bond - the one between the tip and polymer - to break. This process transfers the polymer molecule to the substrate where it can be modified by further chemical reactions.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Materials Science
- **Subcategory:** Nanotechnology, Organic Chemistry, Surface Science
- **Specific Domain:** Scanning Probe Microscopy (SPM), Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM), Mechanochemistry, Single Molecule Manipulation
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Mechanochemistry: Targeted Delivery of Single Molecules using AFM
2. Scanning Probe Microscopy-based Techniques for Nanotechnological Challenges
3. Atomic Force Microscope (AFM) used to Deliver and Immobilize Single Molecules
4. Reactive Polymer Molecules Attached to AFM Tip for Single-Molecule Manipulation
5. Chemical Reaction between AFM-Tip-Bound Polymer and Modified Silicon Substrate
6. Mechanical Force-induced Breakage of Weakest Bond: Transferring Polymer to Substrate
7. Further Chemical Reactions modify Polymer on Substrate after Transfer
8. Ultimate Physical Limit in Design and Fabrication of Organic Surfaces Achieved using AFM
9. Implications for Nanotechnology, Organic Chemistry, and Surface Science Research
10. Single-Molecule Delivery and Manipulation: A New Paradigm for Mechanochemistry.

**Specific Topic:** Materials Science - Nanotechnology

**Note:** The article presents a study on the use of atomic force microscopy (AFM) to deliver and immobilize single molecules on a surface through mechanochemical means. The research demonstrates the ability to transfer reactive polymer molecules from an AFM tip to a modified silicon substrate using mechanical force, with potential implications for nanotechnology, organic chemistry, and surface science research.

======== 1257 : Lin2017

@title:    Why Does Deep and Cheap Learning Work So Well?
@keywords: Artificial neural networks,Deep learning,Statistical physics
@author:   Lin, Henry W. and Tegmark, Max and Rolnick, David
@doi:      10.1007/s10955-017-1836-5
@url:      http://link.springer.com/10.1007/s10955-017-1836-5
@abstract:
 We show how the success of deep learning could depend not only on mathematics but also on physics: although well-known mathematical theorems guarantee that neural networks can approximate arbitrary functions well, the class of functions of practical interest can frequently be approximated through "cheap learning" with exponentially fewer parameters than generic ones. We explore how properties frequently encountered in physics such as symmetry, locality, compositionality, and polynomial log-probability translate into exceptionally simple neural networks. We further argue that when the statistical process generating the data is of a certain hierarchical form prevalent in physics and machine-learning, a deep neural network can be more efficient than a shallow one. We formalize these claims using information theory and discuss the relation to the renormalization group. We prove various "no-flattening theorems" showing when efficient linear deep networks cannot be accurately approximated by shallow ones without efficiency loss, for example, we show that {\$}n{\$} variables cannot be multiplied using fewer than 2{\^{}}n neurons in a single hidden layer.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Computer Science
- **Subcategory:** Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, Data Science
- **Specific Domain:** Deep Learning, Neural Networks, Statistical Physics
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Why Does Deep and Cheap Learning Work So Well?
2. Success of Deep Learning Depends on both Mathematics and Physics
3. Properties in Physics like Symmetry, Locality, Compositionality Simplify Neural Networks
4. Hierarchical Form of Statistical Process Generating Data Facilitates Deep Networks
5. Information Theory Used to Formalize Claims about Efficient Deep Networks
6. Relation between Deep Learning and Renormalization Group Discussed
7. "No-Flattening Theorems" Proven for Efficient Linear Deep Networks vs. Shallow Ones
8. Implications of No-Flattening Theorems for Neural Network Design and Optimization
9. Potential Applications in Image Recognition, Natural Language Processing, and Robotics
10. New Perspective on the Role of Physics in Machine Learning and AI Research.

**Specific Topic:** Computer Science - Artificial Intelligence

**Note:** The article presents a study on the success of deep learning and argues that it depends not only on mathematics but also on physics. The research explores how properties frequently encountered in physics, such as symmetry, locality, compositionality, and polynomial log-probability, translate into exceptionally simple neural networks. The authors formalize these claims using information theory and discuss the relation to the renormalization group.

======== 1258 : Berger2020a

@title:    Quantum dissipation driven by electron transfer within a single molecule investigated with atomic force microscopy
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021
@author:   Berger, Jan and Ondr{\'{a}}{\v{c}}ek, Martin and Stetsovych, Oleksandr and Mal{\'{y}}, Pavel and Hol{\'{y}}, Petr and Ryb{\'{a}}{\v{c}}ek, Jiř{\'{i}} and {\v{S}}vec, Martin and Star{\'{a}}, Irena G. and Man{\v{c}}al, Tom{\'{a}}{\v{s}} and Star{\'{y}}, Ivo and Jel{\'{i}}nek, Pavel
@doi:      10.1038/s41467-020-15054-w
@url:      http://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-020-15054-w https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-020-15054-w
@abstract:
 Intramolecular charge transfer processes play an important role in many biological, chemical and physical processes including photosynthesis, redox chemical reactions and electron transfer in molecular electronics. These charge transfer processes are frequently influenced by the dynamics of their molecular or atomic environments, and they are accompanied with energy dissipation into this environment. The detailed understanding of such processes is fundamental for their control and possible exploitation in future technological applications. Most of the experimental studies of the intramolecular charge transfer processes so far have been carried out using time-resolved optical spectroscopies on large molecular ensembles. This hampers detailed understanding of the charge transfer on the single molecular level. Here we build upon the recent progress in scanning probe microscopy, and demonstrate the control of mixed valence state. We report observation of single electron transfer between two ferrocene redox centers within a single molecule and the detection of energy dissipation associated with the single electron transfer.

- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

The research uses atomic force microscopy (AFM) to control mixed valence state and observe single electron transfer between ferrocene redox centers within a single molecule. The authors detect energy dissipation associated with single electron transfer, providing new insights into the underlying mechanisms of charge transfer processes.

Consequently, we are witnessing extensive activity in search for a reliable and robust protocol to image the charge distribution. In this chapter, we will discuss different methods which provide information about charge distribution at atomic or submolecular scale, including Kelvin probe force microscopy, scanning quantum dot microscopy or high-resolution imaging with functionalized tips. We will briefly discuss the mechanism of each of the different methods as well as their advantages and drawbacks. ======== 1263 : Krautgasser2016

@title:    Global structure search for molecules on surfaces: Efficient sampling with curvilinear coordinates
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - GlobalOptimizatio,★
@author:   Krautgasser, Konstantin and Panosetti, Chiara and Palagin, Dennis and Reuter, Karsten and Maurer, Reinhard J.
@doi:      10.1063/1.4961259
@url:      http://dx.doi.org/10.1063/1.4961259 http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/jcp/145/8/10.1063/1.4961259 http://arxiv.org/abs/1606.06614 http://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.4961259
@abstract:
 Efficient structure search is a major challenge in computational materials science. We present a modification of the basin hopping global geometry optimization approach that uses a curvilinear coordinate system to describe global trial moves. This approach has recently been shown to be efficient in structure determination of clusters [Nano Letters 15, 8044-8048 (2015)] and is here extended for its application to covalent, complex molecules and large adsorbates on surfaces. The employed, automatically constructed delocalized internal coordinates are similar to molecular vibrations, which enhances the generation of chemically meaningful trial structures. By introducing flexible constraints and local translation and rotation of independent geometrical subunits we enable the use of this method for molecules adsorbed on surfaces and interfaces. For two test systems, trans-{\$}\backslashbeta{\$}-ionylideneacetic acid adsorbed on a Au(111) surface and methane adsorbed on a Ag(111) surface, we obtain superior performance of the method compared to standard optimization moves based on Cartesian coordinates.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry, Materials Science, Surface Science
- **Specific Domain:** Global Structure Search, Basin Hopping Algorithm, Curvilinear Coordinates
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Efficient Structure Search for Molecules on Surfaces using Curvilinear Coordinates
2. Modification of the Basin Hopping Global Geometry Optimization Approach
3. Application to Covalent, Complex Molecules and Large Adsorbates on Surfaces
4. Use of Automatically Constructed Delocalized Internal Coordinates
5. Enhanced Generation of Chemically Meaningful Trial Structures
6. Introduction of Flexible Constraints for Surface Adsorption
7. Local Translation and Rotation of Independent Geometrical Subunits
8. Superior Performance compared to Standard Optimization Moves based on Cartesian Coordinates
9. Test Systems: trans-{\$}\backslashbeta{\$}-ionylideneacetic acid on Au(111) and Methane on Ag(111)

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents a modification of the basin hopping global geometry optimization approach that uses curvilinear coordinates to efficiently search for molecular structures on surfaces. The authors demonstrate its application to complex molecules and large adsorbates on surfaces, achieving superior performance compared to standard optimization methods based on Cartesian coordinates.

======== 1265 : Chen1999

@title:    Large On-Off Ratios and Negative Differential Resistance in a Molecular Electronic Device
@keywords: Folder - ElectronTransport
@author:   Chen, J
@doi:      10.1126/science.286.5444.1550
@url:      http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/doi/10.1126/science.286.5444.1550
======== 1266 : Lin2016a

@title:    Why does deep and cheap learning work so well?
@keywords: Folder - Artificial{\_}Inteligence{\_}Robotocs - Deep le,Folder - Artificial{\_}Inteligence{\_}Robotocs - Theory{\_},Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2016{\_}09{\_}26,Folder - {\_}ToRead,★
@author:   Lin, Henry W. and Tegmark, Max
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1608.08225
@abstract:
 We show how the success of deep learning depends not only on mathematics but also on physics: although well-known mathematical theorems guarantee that neural networks can approximate arbitrary functions well, the class of functions of practical interest can be approximated through "cheap learning" with exponentially fewer parameters than generic ones, because they have simplifying properties tracing back to the laws of physics. The exceptional simplicity of physics-based functions hinges on properties such as symmetry, locality, compositionality and polynomial log-probability, and we explore how these properties translate into exceptionally simple neural networks approximating both natural phenomena such as images and abstract representations thereof such as drawings. We further argue that when the statistical process generating the data is of a certain hierarchical form prevalent in physics and machine-learning, a deep neural network can be more efficient than a shallow one. We formalize these claims using information theory and discuss the relation to renormalization group procedures. Various "no-flattening theorems" show when these efficient deep networks cannot be accurately approximated by shallow ones without efficiency loss - even for linear networks.

8. Efficient Deep Neural Networks for Approximating Natural Phenomena and Abstract Representations
9. "No-Flattening Theorems" Showing when Shallow Networks Cannot Accurately Approximate Deep Ones
10. Relation to Renormalization Group Procedures and Information Theory.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Theoretical Physics

**Note:** The article presents a study on the success of deep learning, arguing that it depends not only on mathematics but also on physics. The authors show how the class of functions of practical interest can be approximated through "cheap learning" with exponentially fewer parameters than generic ones, due to simplifying properties tracing back to the laws of physics. They explore the relation between these properties and exceptionally simple neural networks, and formalize their claims using information theory and renormalization group procedures.

@title:    Wafer-scale synthesis of monolayer two-dimensional porphyrin polymers for hybrid superlattices
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021
@author:   Zhong, Yu and Cheng, Baorui and Park, Chibeom and Ray, Ariana and Brown, Sarah and Mujid, Fauzia and Lee, Jae-Ung and Zhou, Hua and Suh, Joonki and Lee, Kan-heng and Mannix, Andrew J and Kang, Kibum and Sibener, S J and Muller, David A and Park, Jiwoong
@doi:      10.1126/science.aax9385
@url:      http://www.sciencemag.org/lookup/doi/10.1126/science.aax9385 https://www.sciencemag.org/lookup/doi/10.1126/science.aax9385
@abstract:
 The large-scale synthesis of high-quality thin films with extensive tunability derived from molecular building blocks will advance the development of artificial solids with designed functionalities. We report the synthesis of two-dimensional (2D) porphyrin polymer films with wafer-scale homogeneity in the ultimate limit of monolayer thickness by growing films at a sharp pentane/water interface, which allows the fabrication of their hybrid superlattices. Laminar assembly polymerization of porphyrin monomers could form monolayers of metal-organic frameworks with Cu 2+ linkers or covalent organic frameworks with terephthalaldehyde linkers. Both the lattice structures and optical properties of these 2D films were directly controlled by the molecular monomers and polymerization chemistries. The 2D polymers were used to fabricate arrays of hybrid superlattices with molybdenum disulfide that could be used in electrical capacitors.

The authors report the use of laminar assembly polymerization to form monolayers of metal-organic frameworks or covalent organic frameworks with controlled lattice structures and optical properties. They also demonstrate the application of these 2D polymers in hybrid superlattices for electrical capacitors.

======== 1269 : LeBris2000

@title:    Control theory applied to quantum chemistry: some tracks
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Electronics - Optimal control a
@author:   {Le Bris}, Claude
@doi:      10.1051/proc:2000006
@url:      http://www.edpsciences.org/10.1051/proc:2000006
======== 1270 : Lewis2009a

@title:    Mining the Sky
@keywords: Folder - Space
@author:   Lewis, John S.
======== 1271 : Cash1990a

@title:    A variable order Runge-Kutta method for initial value problems with rapidly varying right-hand sides
@keywords: Folder - Numerics - ODE - Integrators,and phrases,differential,equations,methods,runge-kutta,singularities
@author:   Cash, J. R. and Karp, Alan H.
@doi:      10.1145/79505.79507
@abstract:
 High-order Runge-Kutta methods require more function evaluations per integration step than, for example, Adams methods used in PECE mode, and so, with RKMs, it is especially important to avoid rejected steps. Steps are often rejected when certain derivatives of the solution are very large for part of the region of integration. This corresponds, for example, to regions where the solution has a sharp front or, in the limit, some derivative of the solution is discontinuous. In these circumstances the assumption that the local truncation error is changing slowly is invalid, and so any step-choosing algorithm is likely to produce an unacceptable step. In this paper we derive a family of explicit Runge-Kutta formulas. Each formula is very efficient for problems with smooth solutions as well as problems having rapidly varying solutions. Each member of this family consists of a fifth-order formula that contains imbedded formulas of all orders 1 through 4. By computing solutions at several different orders, it is possible to detect sharp fronts or discontinuities before all the function evaluations defining the full Runge-Kutta step have been computed. We can then either accept a lower order solution or abort the step, depending on which course of action seems appropriate. The efficiency of the new algorithm is demonstrated on the DETEST test set as well as on some difficult test problems with sharp fronts or discontinuities.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Mathematics
- **Subcategory:** Numerical Analysis, Ordinary Differential Equations (ODEs)
- **Specific Domain:** Runge-Kutta Methods, Initial Value Problems (IVPs), Adaptive Step-Sizing Techniques
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Variable Order Runge-Kutta Method for IVPs with Rapidly Varying Right-Hand Sides
2. Efficient Runge-Kutta Formulas for Smooth and Non-Smooth Solutions
3. Adaptive Step-Sizing Technique to Detect Sharp Fronts or Discontinuities
4. Imbedded Formulas of Orders 1 through 5 in a Single Fifth-Order Formula
5. Detection of Sharp Fronts or Discontinuities before Completing Full Runge-Kutta Step
6. Accepting Lower Order Solution or Aborting Step based on Situation
7. Efficiency Demonstrated on DETEST Test Set and Difficult Test Problems
8. High-Order Runge-Kutta Methods with Reduced Function Evaluations per Integration Step
9. Avoidance of Rejected Steps in PECE Mode using RKMs with Adaptive Step-Sizing
10. Improved Performance for IVPs with Sharp Fronts or Discontinuities.

**Specific Topic:** Mathematics - Numerical Analysis

**Note:** The article presents a study on the development of a variable order Runge-Kutta method (VORKM) that can efficiently handle initial value problems (IVPs) with rapidly varying right-hand sides. The authors propose an adaptive step-sizing technique to detect sharp fronts or discontinuities in the solution, allowing for either accepting a lower-order solution or aborting the step. They demonstrate the efficiency of this new method on several test sets and difficult problem examples.

======== 1272 : Stipe1998

@title:    Single-Molecule Vibrational Spectroscopy and Microscopy
@author:   Stipe, B. C.
@doi:      10.1126/science.280.5370.1732
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9624046{\%}5Cnhttp://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/doi/10.1126/science.280.5370.1732 http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/doi/10.1126/science.280.5370.1732
@abstract:
 Vibrational spectra for a single molecule adsorbed on a solid surface have been obtained with a scanning tunneling microscope (STM). Inelastic electron tunneling spectra for an isolated acetylene (C2H2) molecule adsorbed on the copper (100) surface showed an increase in the tunneling conductance at 358 millivolts, resulting from excitation of the C-H stretch mode. An isotopic shift to 266 millivolts was observed for deuterated acetylene (C2D2). Vibrational microscopy from spatial imaging of the inelastic tunneling channels yielded additional data to further distinguish and characterize the two isotopes. Single-molecule vibrational analysis should lead to better understanding and control of surface chemistry at the atomic level.

======== 1273 : Lyakhov2013

@title:    New developments in evolutionary structure prediction algorithm USPEX
@keywords: Cluster structure prediction,Crystal structure prediction,Evolutionary algorithms,Fingerprint function,Folder - ComputationalMethods - Global{\_}Opt{\_}and{\_}Sad,Genetic algorithms,Global optimization,Particle swarm optimization
@author:   Lyakhov, Andriy O. and Oganov, Artem R. and Stokes, Harold T. and Zhu, Qiang
@doi:      10.1016/j.cpc.2012.12.009
@url:      http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cpc.2012.12.009
@abstract:
 We present new developments of the evolutionary algorithm USPEX for crystal structure prediction and its adaptation to cluster structure prediction. We show how to generate randomly symmetric structures, and how to introduce 'smart' variation operators, learning about preferable local environments. These and other developments substantially improve the efficiency of the algorithm and allow reliable prediction of structures with up to ???200 atoms in the unit cell. We show that an advanced version of the Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) can be created on the basis of our method, but PSO is strongly outperformed by USPEX. We also show how ideas from metadynamics can be used in the context of evolutionary structure prediction for escaping from local minima. Our cluster structure prediction algorithm, using the ideas initially developed for crystals, also shows excellent performance and outperforms other state-of-the-art algorithms. ?? 2012 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

======== 1282 : Shi2011

@title:    Scanning tunneling microscope study of polyacrylonitrile-based carbon fibers
@keywords: Folder - carbon graphene - Carbon Fiebers
@author:   Shi, Dongxia and Liu, Ning and Yang, Haiqiang and Gao, Juning and Jiang, Yueshan and Pang, Shijin and Wu, Xubiao and Ji, Zhen
@doi:      10.1557/JMR.1997.0337
@url:      http://www.journals.cambridge.org/abstract{\_}S0884291400041327
======== 1283 : Panosetti2020

@title:    Learning to Use the Force: Fitting Repulsive Potentials in Density-Functional Tight-Binding with Gaussian Process Regression
@author:   Panosetti, Chiara and Engelmann, Artur and Nemec, Lydia and Reuter, Karsten and Margraf, Johannes T.
@doi:      10.1021/acs.jctc.9b00975
@url:      https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.jctc.9b00975
@abstract:
 The Density-Functional Tight Binding (DFTB) method is a popular semiempirical approximation to Density Functional Theory (DFT). In many cases, DFTB can provide comparable accuracy to DFT at a fraction of the cost, enabling simulations on length and time scales that are unfeasible with first-principles DFT. At the same time (and in contrast to empirical interatomic potentials and force fields), DFTB still offers direct access to electronic properties such as the band structure. These advantages come at the cost of introducing empirical parameters to the method, leading to a reduced transferability compared to true first-principle approaches. Consequently, it would be very useful if the parameter sets could be routinely adjusted for a given project. While fairly robust and transferable parametrization workflows exist for the electronic structure part of DFTB, the so-called repulsive potential Vrep poses a major challenge. In this paper, we propose a machine-learning (ML) approach to fitting Vrep, using Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) to reconstruct Vrep with DFT-DFTB force residues as training data. The use of GPR circumvents the need for nonlinear or global parameter optimization, while at the same time offering arbitrary flexibility in terms of the functional form. We also show that the proposed method can be applied to multiple elements at once, by fitting repulsive potentials for organic molecules containing carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen. Overall, the new approach removes focus from the choice of functional form and parametrization procedure, in favor of a data-driven philosophy.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

- **Specific Domain:** Density Functional Theory (DFT), Density Functional Tight-Binding (DFTB) Method, Gaussian Process Regression (GPR)
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

1. Fitting Repulsive Potentials in DFTB using Gaussian Process Regression
2. Machine-Learning Approach for Parametrizing DFTB Electronic Structure
3. Density Functional Tight-Binding (DFTB) Method for Simulating Materials
4. Semiempirical Approximation to Density Functional Theory (DFT)
5. Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) for Nonlinear Parameter Optimization
6. Flexible Functional Form and Data-Driven Philosophy in Parametrization
7. Repulsive Potentials (Vrep) Fitting for DFT-DFTB Force Residues
8. Transferability of Parametrized DFTB Models with GPR Approach
9. Application to Organic Molecules Containing Multiple Elements
10. Data-Driven Method for Routine Adjustment of Parameter Sets in DFTB.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Computational Physics

**Note:** The article presents a study on the development and application of a machine-learning approach, specifically Gaussian Process Regression (GPR), for fitting repulsive potentials (Vrep) in the Density Functional Tight-Binding (DFTB) method. This new method circumvents the need for nonlinear or global parameter optimization, enabling the creation of transferable parametrized DFTB models with high accuracy and flexibility. The authors demonstrate the success of their approach on organic molecules containing multiple elements, showcasing its potential for routine adjustment of parameter sets in DFTB simulations.

======== 1284 : Watanabe2009a

@title:    Formation of Nuclear “Pasta” in Supernovae
@keywords: Folder - Nuclear - Nuclear pasta
@author:   Watanabe, Gentaro and Sonoda, Hidetaka and Maruyama, Toshiki and Sato, Katsuhiko and Yasuoka, Kenji and Ebisuzaki, Toshikazu
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevLett.103.121101
@url:      https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.103.121101
@abstract:
 In supernova cores, nuclear “pasta” phases such as a triangular lattice of rodlike nuclei and layered structure of slablike nuclei are considered to exist. However, it is still unclear whether or not they are actually formed in collapsing supernova cores. Using ab initio simulations called quantum molecular dynamics, here we solve this problem by demonstrating that a lattice of rodlike nuclei is formed from a bcc lattice by compression. We also find that, in the transition process, the system undergoes a zigzag configuration of elongated nuclei, which are formed by a fusion of two original spherical nuclei.

**Note:** The article presents a study on the formation of nuclear "pasta" phases in supernovae cores using ab initio quantum molecular dynamics (QMD) simulations. The authors demonstrate the formation of a lattice of rodlike nuclei from a body-centered cubic (BCC) lattice by compression and identify a zigzag configuration of elongated nuclei formed through the fusion of two original spherical nuclei.

======== 1286 : Otero2008

@title:    Fullerenes from aromatic precursors by surface-catalysed cyclodehydrogenation.
@keywords: Folder - carbon graphene
@author:   Otero, Gonzalo and Biddau, Giulio and S{\'{a}}nchez-S{\'{a}}nchez, Carlos and Caillard, Renaud and L{\'{o}}pez, Mar{\'{i}}a F and Rogero, Celia and Palomares, F Javier and Cabello, Noem{\'{i}} and Basanta, Miguel a and Ortega, Jos{\'{e}} and M{\'{e}}ndez, Javier and Echavarren, Antonio M and P{\'{e}}rez, Rub{\'{e}}n and G{\'{o}}mez-Lor, Berta and Mart{\'{i}}n-Gago, Jos{\'{e}} a
@doi:      10.1038/nature07193
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18704082
@abstract:
 Graphite vaporization provides an uncontrolled yet efficient means of producing fullerene molecules. However, some fullerene derivatives or unusual fullerene species might only be accessible through rational and controlled synthesis methods. Recently, such an approach has been used to produce isolable amounts of the fullerene C(60) from commercially available starting materials. But the overall process required 11 steps to generate a suitable polycyclic aromatic precursor molecule, which was then dehydrogenated in the gas phase with a yield of only about one per cent. Here we report the formation of C(60) and the triazafullerene C(57)N(3) from aromatic precursors using a highly efficient surface-catalysed cyclodehydrogenation process. We find that after deposition onto a platinum (111) surface and heating to 750 K, the precursors are transformed into the corresponding fullerene and triazafullerene molecules with about 100 per cent yield. We expect that this approach will allow the production of a range of other fullerenes and heterofullerenes, once suitable precursors are available. Also, if the process is carried out in an atmosphere containing guest species, it might even allow the encapsulation of atoms or small molecules to form endohedral fullerenes.

The authors demonstrate that this method can achieve high yields (>100%) with the use of a platinum (111) surface as catalyst. They also discuss the potential applications and future directions for this approach, including the production of endohedral fullerenes by encapsulating atoms or molecules within the fullerene framework.

======== 1287 : Guo2014

@title:    SI-Real-space imaging of interfacial water with submolecular resolution.
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM - H2O,Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2015{\_}06{\_}29 - Choosen,Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2015{\_}06{\_}29 - ambient{\_}AFM,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - NNFF{\_}H2O{\_}NaCl - Exp,★
@author:   Guo, Jing and Meng, Xiangzhi and Chen, Ji and Peng, Jinbo and Sheng, Jiming and Li, Xin-zheng and Xu, Limei and Shi, Jun-ren and Wang, Enge and Jiang, Ying
@doi:      10.1038/nmat3848
@url:      http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nmat3848{\%}5Cnhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24390380 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24390380
@abstract:
 Water/solid interfaces are vital to our daily lives and are also a central theme across an incredibly wide range of scientific disciplines. Resolving the internal structure, that is, the O-H directionality, of water molecules adsorbed on solid surfaces has been one of the key issues of water science yet it remains challenging. Using a low-temperature scanning tunnelling microscope, we report submolecular-resolution imaging of individual water monomers and tetramers on NaCl(001) films supported by a Au(111) substrate at 5 K. The frontier molecular orbitals of adsorbed water were directly visualized, which allowed discrimination of the orientation of the monomers and the hydrogen-bond directionality of the tetramers in real space. Comparison with ab initio density functional theory calculations reveals that the ability to access the orbital structures of water stems from the electronic decoupling effect provided by the NaCl films and the precisely tunable tip-water coupling.

The authors report submolecular-resolution imaging and direct visualization of the frontier molecular orbitals of adsorbed water, allowing discrimination of the orientation of monomers and hydrogen-bond directionality of tetramers. This work highlights the importance of precise control over tip-water coupling in low-temperature experiments and provides new insights into the structure and dynamics of interfacial water.

======== 1288 : Suleji2011a

@title:    B-spline and NURBS Curves
@keywords: Folder - Numerics - Splines
@author:   {\v{S}}uleji, Marko
======== 1289 : Schaedler2011a

@title:    Ultralight metallic microlattices.
@keywords: Folder - sctructural{\_}tech - MaterialScience,Folder - sctructural{\_}tech - MaterialScience - Hier
@author:   Schaedler, T a and Jacobsen, a J and Torrents, a and Sorensen, a E and Lian, J and Greer, J R and Valdevit, L and Carter, W B
@doi:      10.1126/science.1211649
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22096194
@abstract:
 Ultralight ({\textless}10 milligrams per cubic centimeter) cellular materials are desirable for thermal insulation; battery electrodes; catalyst supports; and acoustic, vibration, or shock energy damping. We present ultralight materials based on periodic hollow-tube microlattices. These materials are fabricated by starting with a template formed by self-propagating photopolymer waveguide prototyping, coating the template by electroless nickel plating, and subsequently etching away the template. The resulting metallic microlattices exhibit densities $\rho$ ≥ 0.9 milligram per cubic centimeter, complete recovery after compression exceeding 50{\%} strain, and energy absorption similar to elastomers. Young's modulus E scales with density as E {\~{}} $\rho$(2), in contrast to the E {\~{}} $\rho$(3) scaling observed for ultralight aerogels and carbon nanotube foams with stochastic architecture. We attribute these properties to structural hierarchy at the nanometer, micrometer, and millimeter scales.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Engineering
- **Subcategory:** Materials Science, Mechanical Engineering
- **Specific Domain:** Ultralight Cellular Materials, Metallic Microlattices, Hierarchical Structures
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

**Specific Topic:** Engineering - Materials Science

**Note:** The article presents a study on the fabrication and properties of ultralight metallic microlattices with periodic hollow-tube structure. The authors demonstrate the formation of these materials using self-propagating photopolymer waveguide prototyping, electroless nickel plating, and template etching. They report unique properties including densities < 10 milligrams per cubic centimeter, complete recovery after compression exceeding 50% strain, and energy absorption similar to elastomers. The authors attribute these properties to hierarchical structures at multiple scales and highlight the potential applications of ultralight metallic microlattices in various fields.

@title:    Ballistic fibers: A review of the thermal, ultraviolet and hydrolytic stability of the benzoxazole ring structure
@keywords: Folder - Materials,Folder - Materials - Fiebers,PBO,armour,review,★
@author:   Holmes, G. a. and Rice, K. and Snyder, C. R.
@doi:      10.1007/s10853-005-5597-1
@url:      http://www.springerlink.com/index/10.1007/s10853-005-5597-1
======== 1293 : Thalheim2015

@title:    A Branch-and-Bound Approach for Tautomer Enumeration
@keywords: Branch-and-Bound,Chemoinformatics,Combinatorial chemistry,Combinatorial optimization,Computational chemistry,Double bond,Exact algorithm,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - GlobalOptimizatio,Hydrogen atom shift,Moving hydrogen atom,Optimization problem,Proton-shift tautomerism,Tautomerism
@author:   Thalheim, Torsten and Wagner, Barbara and K{\"{u}}hne, Ralph and Middendorf, Martin and Sch{\"{u}}{\"{u}}rmann, Gerrit
@doi:      10.1002/minf.201400128
@url:      http://doi.wiley.com/10.1002/minf.201400128 https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/minf.201400128
@abstract:
 Knowledge about tautomer forms of a structure is important since, e.g., a property prediction for a molecule can yield to different results which depend on the individual tautomer. Tautomers are isomers that can be transformed to each other through chemical equilibrium reactions. In this paper the first exact Branch-and-Bound (B{\&}B) algorithm to calculate tautomer structures is proposed. The algorithm is complete in the sense of tautomerism and generates all possible tautomers of a structure according to the tautomer definition, it is initialized with. To be efficient, the algorithm takes advantage of symmetric and formation properties. Some restrictions are used to enable an early pruning of some branches of the B{\&}B tree. This is important, since a simple enumeration strategy would lead to number of candidate tautomers that is exponentially increasing with the number of hydrogen atoms and their attachment sites. The proposed implementation of the B{\&}B algorithm covers the majority of the prototropic tautomer cases, but can be adapted to other kinds of tautomerism too. Furthermore, a computer processable definition of tautomerism is given in the form of the moving hydrogen atom problem.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Computer Science
- **Subcategory:** Artificial Intelligence, Combinatorial Optimization, Computational Chemistry
- **Specific Domain:** Chemoinformatics, Tautomer Enumeration, Branch-and-Bound Algorithm
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Tautomer Enumeration using Branch-and-Bound Algorithm
2. Exact Algorithm for Computing All Possible Tautomers
3. Combinatorial Optimization in Computational Chemistry
4. Knowledge Representation of Molecules and Their Tautomers
5. Efficient Generation of Tautomers with Symmetric and Formation Properties
6. Early Pruning of Infeasible Branches using Restrictions
7. Exponential Increase in Candidate Tautomers for Simple Enumeration Strategies
8. Computer-Processable Definition of Tautomerism as Moving Hydrogen Atom Problem
9. Implementation of Branch-and-Bound Algorithm for Prototropic Tautomer Cases
10. Adaptable Framework for Other Kinds of Tautomerism and Tautomer Definitions.

**Specific Topic:** Computer Science - Artificial Intelligence

**Note:** The article presents a study on the development of an exact Branch-and-Bound algorithm for calculating tautomer structures in computational chemistry. The authors propose a complete and efficient algorithm that generates all possible tautomers according to a given definition, taking advantage of symmetric and formation properties. They also provide a computer-processable definition of tautomerism as the moving hydrogen atom problem and discuss the potential applications of their implementation for various kinds of tautomerism.

======== 1301 : Yuan2016a

@title:    Quantitative Understanding of van der Waals Interactions by Analyzing the Adsorption Structure and Low-Frequency Vibrational Modes of Single Benzene Molecules on Silver
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM - inelastic
@author:   Yuan, Dingwang and Han, Zhumin and Czap, Gregory and Chiang, Chi-Lun and Xu, Chen and Ho, Wilson and Wu, Ruqian
@doi:      10.1021/acs.jpclett.6b00894
@url:      http://dx.doi.org/10.1021/acs.jpclett.6b00894 http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acs.jpclett.6b00894
@abstract:
 The combination of a sub-Kelvin scanning tunneling microscope (STM) and density functional calculations incorporating van der Waals (vdW) corrections has been used successfully to probe the adsorption structure and low frequency vibrational modes of single benzene molecules on Ag(110). The inclusion of optimized vdW functionals and improved C6-based vdW dispersion schemes in density functional theory is crucial for obtaining the correct adsorption structure and low-energy vibrational modes. These results demonstrate the emerging capability to quantitatively probe the weak bond between a physisorbed molecule and an inert substrate.

@keywords: Folder - Nuclear - Fussion
@author:   Stroth, U and Murakami, M and Dory, R.A and Yamada, H and Okamura, S and Sano, F and Obiki, T
@doi:      10.1088/0029-5515/36/8/I11
@url:      http://stacks.iop.org/0029-5515/36/i=8/a=I11?key=crossref.635c1f078eda4fbceca3df9207a457bd https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/0029-5515/36/8/I11
======== 1303 : Zhang2013

@title:    Self-assembly of binary molecular nanostructure arrays on graphite
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - SAMs
@author:   Zhang, Jia Lin and Niu, Tian Chao and Wee, Andrew T. S. and Chen, Wei
@doi:      10.1039/c3cp00023k
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23588216{\%}5Cnhttp://xlink.rsc.org/?DOI=c3cp00023k http://xlink.rsc.org/?DOI=c3cp00023k
@abstract:
 The controlled positioning and assembly of functional molecules into ordered nanostructures on surfaces depends on the interplay of multiple interactions on different strength and length scales. On metal surfaces, the relatively strong molecule-substrate interactions can constrain the molecules to adsorb in registry with the surface periodicity and lock them into specific adsorption sites. This can significantly reduce the structural tunability of the molecular nanostructure arrays formed. Inert graphite has a smooth potential-energy surface as well as relatively weak interfacial interactions with adsorbed molecules, and is therefore chosen as a supporting substrate for constructing molecular nanostructures with a high degree of controllability and tunability. The aim of this article is to highlight recent progress in the fabrication of self-assembled molecular nanostructures on inert graphite surfaces in ultra-high vacuum, with particular emphasis on the role of intermolecular interactions in the self-assembly process. We describe the formation of tunable two-dimensional (2D) binary molecular networks by directional and selective hydrogen bonding, as well as the templating effect of these 2D molecular networks, demonstrating the rational design and construction of long-range ordered 2D molecular nanostructures with desired functionality.
