======== 1400 : Gross2012

@title:    Bond-order discrimination by atomic force microscopy.
@keywords: Aromatic,Aromatic: chemistry,Atomic Force,Carbon Monoxide,Carbon Monoxide: chemistry,Copper,Copper: chemistry,Electrons,Folder - HR-SPM,Microscopy,Molecular Structure,Polycyclic Compounds,Polycyclic Compounds: chemistry,Polycyclic Hydrocarbons,SPM,Sodium Chloride,Sodium Chloride: chemistry,★
@author:   Gross, Leo and Mohn, Fabian and Moll, Nikolaj and Schuler, Bruno and Criado, Alejandro and Guiti{\'{a}}n, Enrique and Pe{\~{n}}a, Diego and Gourdon, Andr{\'{e}} and Meyer, Gerhard
@doi:      10.1126/science.1225621
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22984067
@abstract:
 We show that the different bond orders of individual carbon-carbon bonds in polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and fullerenes can be distinguished by noncontact atomic force microscopy (AFM) with a carbon monoxide (CO)-functionalized tip. We found two different contrast mechanisms, which were corroborated by density functional theory calculations: The greater electron density in bonds of higher bond order led to a stronger Pauli repulsion, which enhanced the brightness of these bonds in high-resolution AFM images. The apparent bond length in the AFM images decreased with increasing bond order because of tilting of the CO molecule at the tip apex.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Physical Chemistry, Surface Science
- **Specific Domain:** Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM), Bond Order Discrimination, Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (PAHs), Fullerenes
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Bond Order Discrimination by Noncontact Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM)
2. Carbon Monoxide (CO)-Functionalized AFM Tips for Bond Order Imaging
3. Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (PAHs) and Fullerenes as Model Systems
4. Density Functional Theory Calculations to Understand Contrast Mechanisms
5. Electron Density and Pauli Repulsion Effects on Bond Order Imaging
6. Apparent Bond Length Variation with Increasing Bond Order in AFM Images
7. Tilting of CO Molecules at the Tip Apex Explains Bond Length Effects
8. High-Resolution AFM Imaging of Individual Carbon-Carbon Bonds
9. Potential Applications in Materials Science and Chemistry Education
10. Understanding Molecular Structure and Bonding through Advanced Imaging Techniques.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Physical Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents a novel approach to bond order discrimination using noncontact atomic force microscopy (AFM) with CO-functionalized tips, demonstrating the ability to distinguish between different carbon-carbon bonds in PAHs and fullerenes.

======== 1404 : Lee2018

@title:    Microscopy with a single-molecule scanning electrometer
@author:   Lee, Joonhee and Tallarida, Nicholas and Chen, Xing and Jensen, Lasse and Apkarian, V. Ara
@doi:      10.1126/sciadv.aat5472
@url:      https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/sciadv.aat5472
@abstract:
 The vibrational spectrum of a single carbon monoxide molecule, adsorbed on the tip apex of a scanning tunneling microscope, is used to image electrostatic fields with submolecular spatial resolution. The method takes advantage of the vibrational Stark effect to image local electrostatic fields and the single-molecule sensitivity of tip-enhanced Raman scattering (TERS) to optically relay the signal. We apply the method to single metalloporphyrins adsorbed on Au(111) to image molecular charges, intramolecular polarization, local photoconductivity, atomically resolved hydrogen bonds, and surface electron density waves.

======== 1405 : Schuler2017

@title:    Characterizing aliphatic moieties in hydrocarbons with atomic force microscopy
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM
@author:   Schuler, Bruno and Zhang, Yunlong and Collazos, Sara and Fatayer, Shadi and Meyer, Gerhard and P{\'{e}}rez, Dolores and Guiti{\'{a}}n, Enrique and Harper, Michael R. and Kushnerick, J. Douglas and Pe{\~{n}}a, Diego and Gross, Leo
@doi:      10.1039/C6SC04698C
@url:      http://xlink.rsc.org/?DOI=C6SC04698C
======== 1406 : Bellman2006a

@title:    Molecular hydrogen adsorption at surface adatoms.
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM - TLS{\_}H2
@author:   Bellman, J and Svensson, K and Andersson, S
@doi:      10.1063/1.2220560
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16942302
@abstract:
 Using electron-energy-loss spectroscopy, we have measured preferential adsorption of molecular hydrogen at Cu and Au adatoms deposited on a cold Cu(100) surface. We show, with particular attention to the D(2)-Au system, that the molecules adsorb at the adatoms, with an enhanced binding energy. The adsorption state is not of chemisorption character, the D(2) rotational and internal vibrational transition energies are close to the corresponding gas phase values, a characteristic property of a physisorbed state. A revealing signature of the D(2)-Au interaction is an induced dipole activity of the rotational transition, which discriminates molecules adsorbed at the adatoms from those adsorbed on the bare substrate surface. The average number of molecules per Au atom depends on the Au coverage and increases at lower coverages, for example, at 4{\%} of an adatom monolayer, there are approximately six D(2) molecules per Au adatom. In this limit, Au monomers prevail, and a cluster of six D(2) around a single Au adatom appears to be an optimal dense two-dimensional configuration.

- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Molecular Hydrogen Adsorption at Cu and Au Adatoms on a Cold Cu(100) Surface
2. Preferential Adsorption of D(2) Molecules at Adatoms using EELS Spectroscopy
3. Enhanced Binding Energy of D(2) Molecules Adsorbed at Adatoms
4. Physisorbed State Characterized by Rotational and Vibration Transition Energies Close to Gas Phase Values
5. Induced Dipole Activity in Rotational Transitions Discriminating Adsorption at Adatoms versus Bare Substrate Surface
6. Dependence of Average Number of D(2) Molecules per Au Atom on Au Coverage and Adatom Density
7. Optimal Dense 2D Configuration with Six D(2) Molecules per Single Au Monomer

9. Importance of Understanding H(2) Adsorption at Metal Surfaces for Various Applications
10. Novel Insights into the Physics of Molecular Hydrogen Adsorption and Physisorption.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Condensed Matter Physics

**Note:** The article presents a detailed study of molecular hydrogen adsorption at surface adatoms using electron-energy-loss spectroscopy, revealing preferential adsorption and enhanced binding energy at Cu and Au adatoms.

======== 1407 : Schutt2017

@title:    SchNet: A continuous-filter convolutional neural network for modeling quantum interactions
@author:   Sch{\"{u}}tt, Kristof T. and Kindermans, Pieter-Jan and Sauceda, Huziel E. and Chmiela, Stefan and Tkatchenko, Alexandre and M{\"{u}}ller, Klaus-Robert
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1706.08566
@abstract:
 Deep learning has the potential to revolutionize quantum chemistry as it is ideally suited to learn representations for structured data and speed up the exploration of chemical space. While convolutional neural networks have proven to be the first choice for images, audio and video data, the atoms in molecules are not restricted to a grid. Instead, their precise locations contain essential physical information, that would get lost if discretized. Thus, we propose to use continuous-filter convolutional layers to be able to model local correlations without requiring the data to lie on a grid. We apply those layers in SchNet: a novel deep learning architecture modeling quantum interactions in molecules. We obtain a joint model for the total energy and interatomic forces that follows fundamental quantum-chemical principles. This includes rotationally invariant energy predictions and a smooth, differentiable potential energy surface. Our architecture achieves state-of-the-art performance for benchmarks of equilibrium molecules and molecular dynamics trajectories. Finally, we introduce a more challenging benchmark with chemical and structural variations that suggests the path for further work.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Quantum Chemistry, Computational Chemistry
- **Specific Domain:** Deep Learning, Artificial Neural Networks, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), Continuous-Filter CNNs, Quantum Interactions in Molecules
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. SchNet: A Novel Deep Learning Architecture for Modeling Quantum Interactions in Molecules
2. Continuous-Filter Convolutional Layers for Local Correlations without Grid Discretization
3. Rotationally Invariant Energy Predictions and Smooth, Differentiable Potential Energy Surface
4. Joint Model for Total Energy and Interatomic Forces following Fundamental Quantum-Chemical Principles
5. State-of-the-Art Performance on Benchmarks of Equilibrium Molecules and Molecular Dynamics Trajectories
6. Deep Learning for Speeding up Exploration of Chemical Space in Quantum Chemistry
7. Advantages of Continuous-Filter CNNs over Discrete Grid-Based Approaches in Modeling Atoms in Molecules
8. Potential Energy Surface with Smooth and Differentiable Features using SchNet Architecture
9. Challenging Benchmark with Chemical and Structural Variations for Further Work on SchNet Model
10. Novel Applications of Deep Learning in Quantum Chemistry and Materials Science.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry

**Note:** The article proposes a novel deep learning architecture, SchNet, that uses continuous-filter convolutional layers to model local correlations in molecules without discretizing the data. It achieves state-of-the-art performance on benchmarks of equilibrium molecules and molecular dynamics trajectories, suggesting its potential for speeding up exploration of chemical space in quantum chemistry.

======== 1408 : Franco2009a

@title:    Single-molecule pulling and the folding of donor-acceptor oligorotaxanes: Phenomenology and interpretation
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Electronics - applications
@author:   Franco, Ignacio and Schatz, George C. and Ratner, Mark a.
@doi:      10.1063/1.3223729
@url:      http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/jcp/131/12/10.1063/1.3223729
@abstract:
 The thermodynamic driving force in the folding of a class of oligorotaxanes is elucidated by means of molecular dynamics simulations of equilibrium isometric single-molecule force spectroscopy by atomic force microscopy experiments. The oligorotaxanes consist of cyclobis(paraquat-p-phenylene) rings threaded onto an oligomer of 1,5-dioxynaphthalenes linked by polyethers. The simulations are performed in a high dielectric medium using MM3 as the force field. The resulting force versus extension isotherms show a mechanically unstable region in which the molecule unfolds and, for selected extensions, blinks in the force measurements between a high-force and a low-force regime. From the force versus extension data the molecular potential of mean force is reconstructed using the weighted histogram analysis method and decomposed into energetic and entropic contributions. The simulations indicate that the folding of the oligorotaxanes is energetically favored but entropically penalized, with the energetic contributions overcoming the entropy penalty and effectively driving the folding. In addition, an analogy between the single-molecule folding/unfolding events driven by the atomic force microscope (AFM) tip and the thermodynamic theory of first-order phase transitions is discussed. General conditions (on the molecule and the AFM cantilever) for the emergence of mechanical instabilities and blinks in the force measurements in equilibrium isometric pulling experiments are also presented. In particular, it is shown that the mechanical stability properties observed during the extension are intimately related to the fluctuations in the force measurements.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Physical Chemistry, Molecular Dynamics Simulations
- **Specific Domain:** Single-Molecule Force Spectroscopy, Oligorotaxanes, Cyclobis(paraquat-p-phenylene) Rings, Polyethers, MM3 Force Field, Weighted Histogram Analysis Method
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Single-Molecule Pulling and Folding of Donor-Acceptor Oligorotaxanes
2. Molecular Dynamics Simulations of Equilibrium Isometric Single-Molecule Force Spectroscopy
3. Atomic Force Microscopy Experiments for Measuring Force versus Extension Isotherms
4. Mechanically Unstable Region in Oligorotaxane Folding Induced by AFM Tip Pulling
5. Weighted Histogram Analysis Method for Reconstructing Molecular Potential of Mean Force
6. Energetic and Entropic Contributions to Oligorotaxane Folding from Simulations
7. Analogy between Single-Molecule Folding/Unfolding Events and Thermodynamic Theory of First-Order Phase Transitions
8. Mechanical Instabilities and Blinks in Force Measurements related to Fluctuations in AFM Cantilever Forces
9. General Conditions for Emergence of Mechanical Instabilities in Equilibrium Isometric Pulling Experiments
10. Oligorotaxane Folding as an Example of Energetically Favored but Entropically Penalized Process.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Physical Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents molecular dynamics simulations and atomic force microscopy experiments to study the folding of oligorotaxanes, a class of molecules consisting of cyclobis(paraquat-p-phenylene) rings threaded onto an oligomer of 1,5-dioxynaphthalenes linked by polyethers. It elucidates the thermodynamic driving forces behind oligorotaxane folding and discusses analogies between single-molecule folding/unfolding events and first-order phase transitions in thermodynamics theory.

======== 1410 : Tan2019

@title:    Utilizing Hirshfeld surface calculations, non-covalent interaction (NCI) plots and the calculation of interaction energies in the analysis of molecular packing
@keywords: Hirshfeld surface calculations,Interaction energies,Molecular packing,Non-covalent interaction plots
@author:   Tan, Sang Loon and Jotani, Mukesh M. and Tiekink, Edward R. T.
@doi:      10.1107/S2056989019001129
@url:      https://scripts.iucr.org/cgi-bin/paper?S2056989019001129
@abstract:
 The analysis of atom-to-atom and/or residue-to-residue contacts remains a favoured mode of analysing the molecular packing in crystals. In this contribution, additional tools are highlighted as methods for analysis in order to complement the `crystallographer's tool', PLATON [Spek (2009). Acta Cryst . D 65 , 148–155]. Thus, a brief outline of the procedures and what can be learned by using Crystal Explorer [Spackman {\&} Jayatilaka (2009). CrystEngComm 11 , 19–23] is presented. Attention is then directed towards evaluating the nature, i.e . attractive/weakly attractive/repulsive, of specific contacts employing NCIPLOT [Johnson et al. (2010). J. Am. Chem. Soc . 132 , 6498–6506]. This is complemented by a discussion of the calculation of energy frameworks utilizing the latest version of Crystal Explorer . All the mentioned programs are free of charge and straightforward to use. More importantly, they complement each other to give a more complete picture of how molecules assemble in molecular crystals.

======== 1412 : GarijodelRio2019

@title:    Local Bayesian optimizer for atomic structures
@author:   {Garijo del R{\'{i}}o}, Estefan{\'{i}}a and Mortensen, Jens J{\o}rgen and Jacobsen, Karsten Wedel
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.100.104103
@url:      https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.100.104103
@abstract:
 A local optimization method based on Bayesian Gaussian processes is developed and applied to atomic structures. The method is applied to a variety of systems including molecules, clusters, bulk materials, and molecules at surfaces. The approach is seen to compare favorably to standard optimization algorithms like the conjugate gradient or Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno in all cases. The method relies on prediction of surrogate potential energy surfaces, which are fast to optimize, and which are gradually improved as the calculation proceeds. The method includes a few hyperparameters, the optimization of which may lead to further improvements of the computational speed.

======== 1413 : GarciaYarnoz2013

@title:    Easily retrievable objects among the NEO population
@keywords: Folder - Space{\_}Tech - asteroides,asteroid capture,asteroids dynamics,libration,near-earth objects
@author:   {Garc{\'{i}}a Y{\'{a}}rnoz}, D. and Sanchez, J. P. and McInnes, C. R.
@doi:      10.1007/s10569-013-9495-6
@url:      http://link.springer.com/10.1007/s10569-013-9495-6
======== 1414 : Kastner2008

@title:    Superlinearly converging dimer method for transition state search
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods - Global{\_}Opt{\_}and{\_}Sad,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - GlobalOptimizatio
@author:   K{\"{a}}stner, Johannes and Sherwood, Paul
@doi:      10.1063/1.2815812
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18190184 http://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.2815812
@abstract:
 Algorithmic improvements of the dimer method [G. Henkelman and H. Jonsson, J. Chem. Phys. 111, 7010 (1999)] are described in this paper. Using the limited memory Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (L-BFGS) optimizer for the dimer translation greatly improves the convergence compared to the previously used conjugate gradient algorithm. It also saves one energy and gradient calculation per dimer iteration. Extrapolation of the gradient during repeated dimer rotations reduces the computational cost to one gradient calculation per dimer rotation. The L-BFGS algorithm also improves convergence of the rotation. Thus, three to four energy and gradient evaluations are needed per iteration at the beginning of a transition state search, while only two are required close to convergence. Moreover, we apply the dimer method in internal coordinates to reduce coupling between the degrees of freedom. Weighting the coordinates can be used to apply chemical knowledge about the system and restrict the transition state search to only part of the system while minimizing the remainder. These improvements led to an efficient method for the location of transition states without the need to calculate the Hessian. Thus, it is especially useful in large systems with expensive gradient evaluations.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry, Quantum Mechanics, Transition State Search
- **Specific Domain:** Dimer Method, Limited Memory Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (L-BFGS) Optimizer, Conjugate Gradient Algorithm, Internal Coordinates, Weighted Coordinates
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Superlinearly Converging Dimer Method for Transition State Search
2. Algorithmic Improvements of the Dimer Method using L-BFGS Optimizer
3. Reduced Computational Cost with Extrapolation of Gradient during Dimer Rotation
4. Efficient Location of Transition States without Calculating Hessian
5. Application to Large Systems with Expensive Gradient Evaluations

7. Weighting of Coordinates for Restricting Transition State Search
8. Improved Convergence using L-BFGS Algorithm for Dimer Rotation
9. Comparison with Conjugate Gradient Algorithm for Dimer Translation
10. Development of Advanced Methods for Efficient Transition State Search.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents algorithmic improvements to the dimer method, a widely used technique for transition state search in chemistry. The authors introduce the use of the limited memory Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (L-BFGS) optimizer and extrapolation of the gradient during repeated dimer rotations to improve convergence and reduce computational cost. They also apply the dimer method in internal coordinates and weighting of coordinates to restrict the transition state search. These improvements lead to an efficient method for locating transition states without calculating the Hessian, especially useful in large systems with expensive gradient evaluations.

======== 1415 : Zhao2022

@title:    A Density Functional Theory and Information-Theoretic Approach Study of Interaction Energy and Polarizability for Base Pairs and Peptides
@keywords: base pairs,density functional theory (DFT),information-theoretic approach (ITA),molecular polarizability,peptides
@author:   Zhao, Dongbo and Liu, Shubin and Chen, Dahua
@doi:      10.3390/ph15080938
@abstract:
 Using density functional theory (DFT) and the information-theoretic approach (ITA) quantities to appreciate the energetics and properties of biopolymers is still an unaccomplished and ongoing task. To this end, we studied the building blocks of nucleic acid base pairs and small peptides. For base pairs, we have dissected the relative importance of energetic components by using two energy partition schemes in DFT. Our results convincingly show that the exchange-correlation effect predominantly governs the molecular stability of base pairs while the electrostatic potential plays a minor but indispensable role, and the steric effect is trivial. Furthermore, we have revealed that simple density-based ITA functions are in good relationships with molecular polarizabilities for a series of 30 hydrogen-bonded base pairs and all 20 natural $\alpha$-amino acids, 400 dipeptides, and 8000 tripeptides. Based on these lines, one can easily predict the molecular polarizabilities of larger peptides, even proteins as long as the total molecular wavefunction is available, rather than solving the computationally demanding coupled-perturbed Hartree–Fock (CPHF) equation or its DFT counterpart coupled-perturbed Kohn–Sham (CPKS) equation.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry, Quantum Mechanics, Biophysics
- **Specific Domain:** Density Functional Theory (DFT), Information-Theoretic Approach (ITA), Molecular Polarizability, Base Pairs, Peptides
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

1. Density Functional Theory (DFT) Study of Interaction Energy for Base Pairs and Peptides

4. Role of Exchange-Correlation Effect, Electrostatic Potential, and Steric Effect on Molecular Stability

8. Application of DFT and ITA to Study 30 Hydrogen-Bonded Base Pairs, 20 Amino Acids, and Thousands of Peptides
9. Development of Novel Methodologies for Understanding Biopolymer Properties
10. Use of DFT and ITA in Predicting Molecular Polarizabilities for Complex Systems.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents a study using density functional theory (DFT) and the information-theoretic approach (ITA) to understand the interaction energy and polarizability of base pairs and peptides. The authors analyze the relative importance of energetic components in DFT and reveal that simple density-based ITA functions are well-related to molecular polarizabilities for a series of biopolymers. They propose a novel method for predicting molecular polarizabilities of larger peptides and proteins, which can be applied without solving computationally demanding coupled-perturbed equations.

@author:   DRELA, MARK
@doi:      10.2514/3.45650
@url:      http://arc.aiaa.org/doi/abs/10.2514/3.45650
======== 1418 : VonArnim1999a

@title:    Geometry optimization in generalized natural internal coordinates
@keywords: Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2016{\_}03{\_}21 - references{\_}Glob
@author:   von Arnim, Malte and Ahlrichs, Reinhart
@doi:      10.1063/1.479510
@url:      http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/jcp/111/20/10.1063/1.479510
@abstract:
 The automatic generation of natural internal coordinates is extended to all cases except multiply fused ring systems, i.e., ''cages.'' This is achieved by a relatively simple code; most of the geometrical cases can now be treated by a single subroutine. To handle molecules containing cages we combine the natural internal coordinates with the delocalized coordinates of Baker, Kessi, and Delley. We have also modified the delocalized coordinates to separate modes with strongly different force constants. The new methods show very good convergence properties in geometry optimizations. Our test set of molecules covers a wide range of atoms and of different bonding situations. For such molecules good internal coordinates are particularly important because no reliable initial force constant matrix can be obtained to accelerate convergence.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry, Quantum Mechanics, Molecular Modeling
- **Specific Domain:** Geometry Optimization, Natural Internal Coordinates, Delocalized Coordinates, Force Constants, Convergence Properties
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

1. Extension of Automatic Generation of Natural Internal Coordinates to All Cases
2. Treatment of Multiply Fused Ring Systems using Delocalized Coordinates
3. Combination of Natural and Delocalized Coordinates for Efficient Geometry Optimization
4. Modification of Delocalized Coordinates to Separate Modes with Different Force Constants
5. Good Convergence Properties in Geometry Optimizations using New Methods
6. Importance of Reliable Initial Force Constant Matrix in Accelerating Convergence
7. Development of Novel Methods for Handling Molecules with Complex Bonding Situations
8. Application of New Methods to a Wide Range of Atoms and Molecules
9. Comparison of Performance between Natural Internal Coordinates and Delocalized Coordinates
10. Advantages of Using Combined Natural-Delocalized Coordinate Approach in Geometry Optimization.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents an extension of the automatic generation of natural internal coordinates to all cases, except multiply fused ring systems (cages). The authors also develop a novel method for combining natural and delocalized coordinates to handle molecules containing cages. This approach shows very good convergence properties in geometry optimizations and is particularly useful for molecules with complex bonding situations where reliable initial force constant matrices are difficult to obtain.

@title:    AERODYNAMICS AND DESIGN FOR ULTRA-LOW REYNOLDS NUMBER FLIGHT {\textcopyright} Copyright 2003 by Peter J . Kunz All Rights Reserved

@author:   Dissertation, A
======== 1421 : Lin2005

@title:    Computer-aided molecular design using Tabu search
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - GlobalOptimizatio,computation time,computer-aided molecular design,tabu search,transition metal catalysts,★
@author:   Lin, B. and Chavali, S. and Camarda, K. and Miller, D.C.
@doi:      10.1016/j.compchemeng.2004.10.008
@url:      http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0098135404003199 https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0098135404003199
@abstract:
 A detailed implementation of the Tabu search (TS) algorithm for computer-aided molecular design (CAMD) of transition metal catalysts is presented in this paper. Previous CAMD research has applied deterministic methods or genetic algorithms to the solution of the optimization problems which arise from the search for a molecule satisfying a set of property targets. In this work, properties are estimated using correlations based on connectivity indices, which allows the TS algorithm to use several novel operators to generate neighbors, such as swap and move, which would have no effect with a traditional group contribution-based approach. In addition, the formulation of the neighbor generation process guarantees that molecular valency and connectivity constraints are met, resulting in a complete molecular structure. Results on two case studies using TS are compared with a deterministic approach and show that TS is able to provide a list of good candidate molecules while using a much smaller amount of computation time.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry, Molecular Design, Optimization Methods
- **Specific Domain:** Tabu Search Algorithm, Computer-Aided Molecular Design (CAMD), Transition Metal Catalysts, Connectivity Indices, Group Contribution-Based Approach
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Implementation of Tabu Search Algorithm for Computer-Aided Molecular Design
2. Application to Transition Metal Catalysts with Property Targets
3. Use of Correlations Based on Connectivity Indices for Property Estimation
4. Novel Operators for Generating Neighbors in TS Algorithm (Swap and Move)
5. Guaranteed Satisfaction of Molecular Valency and Connectivity Constraints
6. Complete Molecular Structure Generation using TS Algorithm
7. Comparison with Deterministic Approach and Genetic Algorithms
8. Reduced Computation Time for TS Algorithm Compared to Traditional Methods
9. Development of Novel Optimization Method for CAMD Applications
10. Potential for Improved Molecular Design using Tabu Search Algorithm.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents a detailed implementation of the Tabu search (TS) algorithm for computer-aided molecular design (CAMD) of transition metal catalysts. The authors use correlations based on connectivity indices to estimate properties and develop novel operators for generating neighbors in the TS algorithm. The results show that TS is able to provide good candidate molecules while using a much smaller amount of computation time compared to traditional methods.

======== 1422 : Clayson2017

@title:    Counter-propagating radiative shock experiments on the Orion laser and the formation of radiative precursors
@keywords: Counter propagating shocks,Radiative precursor,Radiative shock
@author:   Clayson, T. and Suzuki-Vidal, F. and Lebedev, S.V. and Swadling, G.F. and Stehl{\'{e}}, C. and Burdiak, G.C. and Foster, J.M. and Skidmore, J. and Graham, P. and Gumbrell, E. and Patankar, S. and Spindloe, C. and Chaulagain, U. and Kozlov{\'{a}}, M. and Larour, J. and Singh, R.L. and Rodriguez, R. and Gil, J.M. and Espinosa, G. and Velarde, P. and Danson, C.
@doi:      10.1016/j.hedp.2017.03.002
@url:      https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0360544218305395 http://arxiv.org/abs/1703.01205 http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.hedp.2017.03.002 https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1574181817300198
@abstract:
 We present results from new experiments to study the dynamics of radiative shocks, reverse shocks and radiative precursors. Laser ablation of a solid piston by the Orion high-power laser at AWE Aldermaston UK was used to drive radiative shocks into a gas cell initially pressurised between {\$}0.1{\$} and {\$}1.0 \backslash bar{\$} with different noble gases. Shocks propagated at {\{}{\$}80 \backslashpm 10 \backslash km/s{\$}{\}} and experienced strong radiative cooling resulting in post-shock compressions of {\{} {\$}\backslashtimes 25 \backslashpm 2{\$}{\}}. A combination of X-ray backlighting, optical self-emission streak imaging and interferometry (multi-frame and streak imaging) were used to simultaneously study both the shock front and the radiative precursor. These experiments present a new configuration to produce counter-propagating radiative shocks, allowing for the study of reverse shocks and providing a unique platform for numerical validation. In addition, the radiative shocks were able to expand freely into a large gas volume without being confined by the walls of the gas cell. This allows for 3-D effects of the shocks to be studied which, in principle, could lead to a more direct comparison to astrophysical phenomena. By maintaining a constant mass density between different gas fills the shocks evolved with similar hydrodynamics but the radiative precursor was found to extend significantly further in higher atomic number gases ({\$}\backslashsim{\$}{\$}4{\$} times further in xenon than neon). Finally, 1-D and 2-D radiative-hydrodynamic simulations are presented showing good agreement with the experimental data.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Plasma Physics, High-Energy Density Physics, Astrophysics
- **Specific Domain:** Radiative Shocks, Counter-Propagating Shocks, Radiative Precursors, Laser-Matter Interactions, High-Power Lasers
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Study of Radiative Shocks and Reverse Shocks using Counter-Propagating Configuration
2. Experiment on the Orion Laser to Drive Radiative Shocks into a Gas Cell
3. Investigation of Radiative Cooling and Post-Shock Compressions in Different Gases
4. Use of X-Ray Backlighting, Optical Self-Emission Streak Imaging, and Interferometry for Simultaneous Study of Shock Front and Radiative Precursor
5. Numerical Validation through 1-D and 2-D Radiative-Hydrodynamic Simulations
6. Comparison of Shocks in Different Noble Gases (Neon, Argon, Xenon)
7. Effects of Atomic Number on the Radiative Precursor and Shock Evolution
8. Study of 3-D Effects of Radiative Shocks and Potential for Direct Comparison to Astrophysical Phenomena
9. Development of New Configuration for Counter-Propagating Radiative Shock Experiments
10. Advantages of Using High-Power Lasers for Studying Radiative Shocks and Reverse Shocks.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Plasma Physics

**Note:** The article presents results from new experiments on the dynamics of radiative shocks, reverse shocks, and radiative precursors using a counter-propagating configuration driven by the Orion high-power laser. The authors use X-ray backlighting, optical self-emission streak imaging, and interferometry to study both the shock front and the radiative precursor. The results show significant effects of atomic number on the radiative precursor and shock evolution, and good agreement with 1-D and 2-D radiative-hydrodynamic simulations. This work presents a new configuration for studying radiative shocks and reverse shocks, and has potential implications for understanding astrophysical phenomena.

======== 1423 : Yushmanov1990a

@title:    Scalings for tokamak energy confinement
@keywords: Folder - Nuclear - Fussion
@author:   Yushmanov, PN and Takizuka, T
@url:      http://iopscience.iop.org/0029-5515/30/10/001
======== 1424 : Macher2014

@title:    The random phase approximation applied to ice
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - NNFF{\_}H2O{\_}NaCl - ab{\_}inito
@author:   Macher, M. and Klime{\v{s}}, J. and Franchini, C. and Kresse, G.
@doi:      10.1063/1.4865748
@url:      http://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.4865748
@abstract:
 Standard density functionals without van der Waals interactions yield an unsatisfactory description of ice phases, specifically, high density phases occurring under pressure are too unstable compared to the common low density phase Ih observed at ambient conditions. Although the description is improved by using functionals that include van der Waals interactions, the errors in relative volumes remain sizable. Here we assess the random phase approximation (RPA) for the correlation energy and compare our results to experimental data as well as diffusion Monte Carlo data for ice. The RPA yields a very balanced description for all considered phases, approaching the accuracy of diffusion Monte Carlo in relative energies and volumes. This opens a route towards a concise description of molecular water phases on surfaces and in cavities.

6. Development of a Balanced Description of Molecular Water Phases using RPA
7. Potential Applications of RPA to Describe Molecular Water Phases on Surfaces and in Cavities
8. Comparison with Standard Density Functionals without Van der Waals Interactions

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents an assessment of the random phase approximation (RPA) for correlation energy calculations in ice phases, comparing its results with experimental data and diffusion Monte Carlo simulations. The RPA yields a balanced description of all considered phases, approaching the accuracy of diffusion Monte Carlo in relative energies and volumes. This opens a route towards a concise description of molecular water phases on surfaces and in cavities, which may have implications for various fields such as materials science and biological physics.

======== 1430 : Weiss2010a

@title:    Imaging Pauli repulsion in scanning tunneling microscopy
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM,SPM,inelastic,★
@author:   Weiss, C. and Wagner, C. and Kleimann, C. and Rohlfing, M. and Tautz, F. S. and Temirov, R.
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevLett.105.086103
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1006.0835 http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.105.086103
@abstract:
 A scanning tunneling microscope (STM) has been equipped with a nanoscale force sensor and signal transducer composed of a single D2 molecule that is confined in the STM junction. The uncalibrated sensor is used to obtain ultra-high geometric image resolution of a complex organic molecule adsorbed on a noble metal surface. By means of conductance-distance spectroscopy and corresponding density functional calculations the mechanism of the sensor/transducer is identified. It probes the short-range Pauli repulsion and converts this signal into variations of the junction conductance.

======== 1431 : Chenoweth2008c

@title:    ReaxFF reactive force field for molecular dynamics simulations of hydrocarbon oxidation
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods - Force Fields,Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2016{\_}09{\_}26,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021
@author:   Chenoweth, Kimberly and van Duin, Adri C. T. and Goddard, William A. and {Goddard III}, William A. and Goddard, William A.
@doi:      10.1021/jp709896w
@url:      https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/jp709896w http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18197648
@abstract:
 To investigate the initial chemical events associated with high-temperature gas-phase oxidation of hydrocarbons, we have expanded the ReaxFF reactive force field training set to include additional transition states and chemical reactivity of systems relevant to these reactions and optimized the force field parameters against a quantum mechanics (QM)-based training set. To validate the ReaxFF potential obtained after parameter optimization, we performed a range of NVT-MD simulations on various hydrocarbon/O2 systems. From simulations on methane/O2, o-xylene/O2, propene/O2, and benzene/O2 mixtures, we found that ReaxFF obtains the correct reactivity trend (propene {\textgreater} o-xylene {\textgreater} methane {\textgreater} benzene), following the trend in the C-H bond strength in these hydrocarbons. We also tracked in detail the reactions during a complete oxidation of isolated methane, propene, and o-xylene to a CO/CO2/H2O mixture and found that the pathways predicted by ReaxFF are in agreement with chemical intuition and our QM results. We observed that the predominant initiation reaction for oxidation of methane, propene, and o-xylene under fuel lean conditions involved hydrogen abstraction of the methyl hydrogen by molecular oxygen forming hydroperoxyl and hydrocarbon radical species. While under fuel rich conditions with a mixture of these hydrocarbons, we observed different chemistry compared with the oxidation of isolated hydrocarbons including a change in the type of initiation reactions, which involved both decomposition of the hydrocarbon or attack by other radicals in the system. Since ReaxFF is capable of simulating complicated reaction pathways without any preconditioning, we believe that atomistic modeling with ReaxFF provides a useful method for determining the initial events of oxidation of hydrocarbons under extreme conditions and can enhance existing combustion models.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry, Theoretical Chemistry, Molecular Dynamics Simulations
- **Specific Domain:** ReaxFF Reactive Force Field, Hydrocarbon Oxidation, High-Temperature Gas-Phase Oxidation, Quantum Mechanics (QM) Calculations, Atomistic Modeling
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Development of the ReaxFF Reactive Force Field for Molecular Dynamics Simulations
2. Investigation of Initial Chemical Events in Hydrocarbon Oxidation using ReaxFF
3. Expansion and Optimization of the ReaxFF Training Set against Quantum Mechanics (QM) Calculations

5. Prediction of Correct Reactivity Trend for Different Hydrocarbons using ReaxFF
6. Tracking of Complete Oxidation Pathways for Isolated Methane, Propene, and o-Xylene
7. Initiation Reactions in Fuel Lean and Fuel Rich Conditions Predicted by ReaxFF
8. Comparison with Chemical Intuition and QM Results for Oxidation Pathways
9. Use of Atomistic Modeling with ReaxFF to Enhance Existing Combustion Models
10. Potential Applications of ReaxFF in Determining Initial Events of Hydrocarbon Oxidation.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents the development and validation of the ReaxFF reactive force field for molecular dynamics simulations of hydrocarbon oxidation. The authors expand the ReaxFF training set, optimize the force field parameters against QM calculations, and perform NVT-MD simulations to predict the correct reactivity trend and complete oxidation pathways for different hydrocarbons. The results show that ReaxFF is capable of simulating complicated reaction pathways without preconditioning and can enhance existing combustion models by providing insights into the initial events of hydrocarbon oxidation under extreme conditions.

======== 1432 : Pinheiro2011a

@title:    Challenges and opportunities for structural DNA nanotechnology
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Engeneering - DNA{\_}origami,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021

@abstract:
 DNA molecules have been used to build a variety of nanoscale structures and devices over the past 30 years, and potential applications have begun to emerge. But the development of more advanced structures and applications will require a number of issues to be addressed, the most significant of which are the high cost of DNA and the high error rate of self-assembly. Here we examine the technical challenges in the field of structural DNA nanotechnology and outline some of the promising applications that could be developed if these hurdles can be overcome. In particular, we highlight the potential use of DNA nanostructures in molecular and cellular biophysics, as biomimetic systems, in energy transfer and photonics, and in diagnostics and therapeutics for human health.

======== 1438 : Boneschanscher2012

@title:    Quantitative Atomic Resolution Force Imaging on Epitaxial Graphene with Reactive and Nonreactive AFM Probes
@author:   Boneschanscher, Mark P and van der Lit, Joost and Sun, Zhixiang and Swart, Ingmar and Liljeroth, Peter and Vanmaekelbergh, Dani{\"{e}}l
======== 1439 : Ondracek2016

@title:    Charge-state dynamics in electrostatic force spectroscopy
@keywords: Atomic force microscopy,Electron tunneling,Electrostatic force spectroscopy,Folder - {\_}by{\_}source - Moje,Redox nanoswitches,atomic force microscopy,electron tunneling,electrostatic force,redox nanoswitches
@author:   Ondr{\'{a}}{\v{c}}ek, Martin and Hapala, Prokop and Jel{\'{i}}nek, Pavel
@doi:      10.1088/0957-4484/27/27/274005
@url:      http://stacks.iop.org/0957-4484/27/i=27/a=274005?key=crossref.39144f72bce01400f1caa0d3db83c44c
@abstract:
 We present a numerical model that allows us to study the response of an oscillating probe in electrostatic force spectroscopy to charge switching in quantum dots at various time scales. The model provides more insight into the behavior of frequency shift and dissipated energy under different scanning conditions when measuring a temporarily charged quantum dot on a surface. Namely, we analyze the dependence of the frequency shift, the dissipated energy, and their fluctuations on the resonance frequency of the tip and on the electron tunneling rates across the tip-quantum dot and quantum dot-sample junctions. We discuss two complementary approaches to simulating the charge dynamics, a stochastic and a deterministic one. In addition, we derive analytic formulas valid for small amplitudes, describing relations between the frequency shift, dissipated energy, and the characteristic rates driving the charging and discharging processes.

======== 1440 : Simpson2014a

@title:    New class of metal bound molecular switches involving H-tautomerism.
@keywords: 1 recti fi ers,2,3 and switches 4,6,Folder - Molecular Engeneering - Molecular switche,devices such as transistors,eld of molecular,forms the basis of,he use of molecules,inelastic tunneling,molecular switches,of electronic,stm,tautomerization,the rapidly expanding fi,to perform the function
@author:   Simpson, Grant J and Hogan, Simon W L and Caffio, Marco and Adams, Christopher J and Fr{\"{u}}chtl, Herbert and van Mourik, Tanja and Schaub, Renald
@doi:      10.1021/nl4038517
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24471795
@abstract:
 A potential end-point in the miniaturization of electronic devices lies in the field of molecular electronics, where molecules perform the function of single components. To date, hydrogen tautomerism in unimolecular switches has been restricted to the central macrocycle of porphyrin-type molecules. The present work reveals how H-tautomerism is the mechanism for switching in substituted quinone derivatives, a novel class of molecules with a different chemical structure. We hence reveal that the previous restrictions applying to tautomeric molecular switches bound to a surface are not valid in general. The activation energy of switching in a prototypical quinone derivative is determined using inelastic electron tunneling. Through computational modeling, we show that the mechanism underlying this process is tautomerization of protons belonging to two amino groups. This switching property is retained upon functionalization by the addition of side groups, meaning that the switch can be chemically modified to fit specific applications.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Molecular Chemistry, Organic Chemistry, Molecular Electronics
- **Specific Domain:** Hydrogen Tautomerism, Unimolecular Switches, Porphyrin-Type Molecules, Quinone Derivatives, Inelastic Electron Tunneling Spectroscopy (IETS)
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. New Class of Metal-Bound Molecular Switches through H-Tautomerism
2. Mechanism of Switching in Substituted Quinone Derivatives Revealed
3. Activation Energy of Switching Determined using IETS
4. Computational Modeling of Tautomerization Process in Amino-Functionalized Quinones
5. Potential Applications of Chemically Modified Molecular Switches
6. Retention of Switching Property upon Functionalization with Side Groups
7. Novel Mechanism for H-Tautomerism in Molecules Bound to a Surface

9. Development of New Classes of Unimolecular Switches for Electronic Devices
10. Integration of Molecular Switches into Nanoscale Electronic Circuits.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Organic Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents a new class of metal-bound molecular switches involving H-tautomerism, where the mechanism is tautomerization of protons belonging to amino groups in substituted quinone derivatives. This novel switching property is retained upon functionalization with side groups, enabling chemical modification for specific applications.

======== 1444 : Requardt2015a

@title:    The Structurally Dynamic Cellular Network and Quantum Graphity Approaches to Quantum Gravity and Quantum Geometry - A Review and Comparison
@keywords: (),Folder - fundamental{\_}physics - discrete network sp
@author:   Requardt, Manfred and Rastgoo, Saeed
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1501.0391 http://arxiv.org/abs/1501.00391
@abstract:
 Starting from the working hypothesis that both physics and the corresponding mathematics and in particular geometry have to be described by means of discrete concepts on the Planck-scale, one of the many problems one has to face in this enterprise is to find the discrete protoforms of the building blocks of our ordinary continuum physics and mathematics living on a smooth background, and perhaps more importantly find a way how this continuum limit emerges from the mentioned discrete structure. We model this underlying substratum as a structurally dynamic cellular network (basically a generalisation of a cellular automaton). We regard these continuum concepts and continuum spacetime in particular as being emergent, coarse-grained and derived relative to this underlying erratic and disordered microscopic substratum, which we would like to call quantum geometry and which is expected to play by quite different rules, namely generalized cellular automaton rules. A central role in our analysis is played by a geometric renormalization group which creates (among other things) a kind of sparse translocal network of correlations between the points in classical continuous space-time and underlies, in our view, such mysterious phenomena as holography and the black hole entropy-area law. The same point of view holds for quantum theory which we also regard as a low-energy, coarse-grained continuum theory, being emergent from something more fundamental. In this paper we review our approach and compare it to the quantum graphity framework.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Theoretical Physics, Quantum Gravity, Quantum Geometry, Discrete Mathematics
- **Specific Domain:** Structurally Dynamic Cellular Network, Quantum Graphity Approach, Geometric Renormalization Group, Emergent Continuum Theory
- **Research Type:** Review Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Structurally Dynamic Cellular Network as a Model for Quantum Geometry
2. Emergent Continuum Theory and the Discrete Substratum of Classical Physics
3. Geometric Renormalization Group and Sparse Translocal Network of Correlations
4. Comparison with Quantum Graphity Framework for Understanding Quantum Gravity
5. Discrete Protoforms of Building Blocks of Ordinary Continuum Physics and Mathematics
6. Planck-Scale Discreteness in Physics and Geometry
7. Generalized Cellular Automaton Rules Governing Quantum Geometry
8. Holography and Black Hole Entropy-Area Law as Emergent Phenomena
9. Quantum Theory as a Low-Energy, Coarse-Grained Continuum Theory
10. Fundamentals of Quantum Gravity and the Emergence of Classical Space-Time.

**Specific Topic:** Physics - Theoretical Physics

**Note:** The article reviews and compares two approaches to understanding quantum gravity: structurally dynamic cellular networks (SDCNs) and quantum graphity. Both models attempt to describe physics in terms of discrete concepts on the Planck scale, with SDCNs focusing on a geometric renormalization group and sparse translocal network of correlations. The authors argue that classical space-time is an emergent phenomenon arising from this underlying substratum, which they call quantum geometry.

======== 1445 : Mendieta-Moreno2014a

@title:    Fireball / amber: An efficient local-orbital DFT QM/MM method for biomolecular systems
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021
@author:   Mendieta-Moreno, Jes{\'{u}}s I. and Walker, Ross C. and Lewis, James P. and G{\'{o}}mez-Puertas, Paulino and Mendieta, Jes{\'{u}}s and Ortega, Jos{\'{e}}
@doi:      10.1021/ct500033w
@url:      https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/ct500033w
@abstract:
 In recent years, quantum mechanics/molecular mechanics (QM/MM) methods have become an important computational tool for the study of chemical reactions and other processes in biomolecular systems. In the QM/MM technique, the active region is described by means of QM calculations, while the remainder of the system is described using a MM approach. Because of the complexity of biomolecules and the desire to achieve converged sampling, it is important that the QM method presents a good balance between accuracy and computational efficiency. Here, we report on the implementation of a QM/MM technique that combines a DFT approach specially designed for the study of complex systems using first-principles molecular dynamics simulations (fireball) with the amber force fields and simulation programs. We also present examples of the application of this QM/MM approach to three representative biomolecular systems: the analysis of the effect of electrostatic embedding in the behavior of a salt bridge between an aspartic acid and a lysine residue, a study of the intermediate states for the triosephosphate isomerase catalyzed conversion of dihydroxyacetone phosphate into glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate, and the detailed description, using DFT QM/MM molecular dynamics, of the cleavage of a phosphodiester bond in RNA catalyzed by the enzyme RNase A. {\textcopyright} 2014 American Chemical Society.

**Note:** The article presents a novel implementation of the fireball / amber QM/MM method, which combines first-principles molecular dynamics simulations with MM simulation programs. This approach is applied to three representative biomolecular systems: electrostatic embedding in salt bridges, intermediate states for triosephosphate isomerase catalyzed conversion, and phosphodiester bond cleavage in RNA catalyzed by RNase A enzyme.

@title:    Low Reynolds Number flow over Airfoils

======== 1450 : Lu2011a

@title:    Self-doping of molecular quantum-dot cellular automata: mixed valence zwitterions.
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Electronics - mQCA
@author:   Lu, Yuhui and Lent, Craig
@doi:      10.1039/c1cp21332f
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21755091
@abstract:
 Molecular quantum-dot cellular automata (QCA) is a promising paradigm for realizing molecular electronics. In molecular QCA, binary information is encoded in the distribution of intramolecular charge, and Coulomb interactions between neighboring molecules combine to create long-range correlations in charge distribution that can be exploited for signal transfer and computation. Appropriate mixed-valence species are promising candidates for single-molecule device operation. A complication arises because many mixed-valence compounds are ions and the associated counterions can potentially disrupt the correct flow of information through the circuit. We suggest a self-doping mechanism which incorporates the counterion covalently into the structure of a neutral molecular cell, thus producing a zwitterionic mixed-valence complex. The counterion is located at the geometrical center of the QCA molecule and bound to the working dots via covalent bonds, thus avoiding counterion effects that bias the system toward one binary information state or the other. We investigate the feasibility of using multiply charged anion (MCA) boron clusters, specifically closo-borate dianion, as building blocks. A first principle calculation shows that neutral, bistable, and switchable QCA molecules are possible. The self-doping mechanism is confirmed by molecular orbital analysis, which shows that MCA counterions can be stabilized by the electrostatic interaction between negatively charged counterions and positively charged working dots.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Molecular Electronics, Quantum-Dot Cellular Automata (QCA), Molecular Design and Synthesis

- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Molecular Quantum-Dot Cellular Automata (mQCA) for Molecular Electronics
2. Mixed Valence Species as Building Blocks for Single-Molecule Devices
3. Self-Doping Mechanism to Avoid Disruptive Counterion Effects
4. Zwitterionic Complexes with Covalently Bound Counterions
5. Feasibility of Multiply Charged Anion (MCA) Boron Clusters in mQCA
6. First Principle Calculations for Neutral, Bistable, and Switchable QCA Molecules
7. Molecular Orbital Analysis to Confirm Self-Doping Mechanism
8. Stabilization of Covalently Bound Counterions by Electrostatic Interaction
9. Potential Applications of mQCA in Nanoscale Electronic Devices
10. Advances in Molecular Design and Synthesis for Quantum Computing.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Molecular Electronics

**Note:** The article presents a novel self-doping mechanism to create zwitterionic mixed-valence complexes for molecular quantum-dot cellular automata (mQCA). This approach aims to avoid the disruptive effects of counterions on signal transfer and computation in mQCA devices. The authors investigate the feasibility of using multiply charged anion (MCA) boron clusters as building blocks and provide a first principle calculation to demonstrate the potential for neutral, bistable, and switchable QCA molecules.

======== 1451 : VanderLubbe2017

@title:    Hydrogen‐Bond Strength of CC and GG Pairs Determined by Steric Repulsion: Electrostatics and Charge Transfer Overruled
@keywords: DNA base pairs,bonding analysis,density functional calculations,hydrogen bonds,steric repulsion
@author:   van der Lubbe, Stephanie C. C. and {Fonseca Guerra}, C{\'{e}}lia
@doi:      10.1002/chem.201701821
@url:      http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28485530 http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=PMC6563699 https://chemistry-europe.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/chem.201701821
@abstract:
 Theoretical and experimental studies have elucidated the bonding mechanism in hydrogen bonds as an electrostatic interaction, which also exhibits considerable stabilization by charge transfer, polarization, and dispersion interactions. Therefore, these components have been used to rationalize the differences in strength of hydrogen‐bonded systems. A completely new viewpoint is presented, in which the Pauli (steric) repulsion controls the mechanism of hydrogen bonding. Quantum chemical computations on the mismatched DNA base pairs CC and GG (C=cytosine, G=guanine) show that the enhanced stabilization and shorter distance of GG is determined entirely by the difference in the Pauli repulsion, which is significantly less repulsive for GG than for CC. This is the first time that evidence is presented for the Pauli repulsion as decisive factor in relative hydrogen‐bond strengths and lengths.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Theoretical Chemistry, Computational Chemistry, Quantum Mechanics
- **Specific Domain:** Hydrogen Bonding, DNA Base Pairs, Steric Repulsion, Electrostatics, Charge Transfer
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Reevaluation of Hydrogen Bonding Mechanism in DNA Base Pairs
2. Role of Steric Repulsion in Controlling Hydrogen Bond Strength and Length
3. Pauli (Steric) Repulsion as Decisive Factor in Relative Hydrogen-Bond Strengths
4. Quantum Chemical Computations on Mismatched DNA Base Pairs CC and GG
5. Enhanced Stabilization and Shorter Distance of GG Pair Determined by Steric Repulsion
6. Overriding Effects of Electrostatics, Charge Transfer, Polarization, and Dispersion Interactions
7. New Understanding of Hydrogen Bonding Mechanism in Biological Systems
8. Implications for Theoretical Models of DNA Structure and Function
9. Computational Methods for Analyzing Hydrogen Bonding in Biomolecules
10. Insights into the Fundamental Nature of Hydrogen Bonding.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Theoretical Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents a novel perspective on the mechanism of hydrogen bonding, arguing that steric repulsion (Pauli repulsion) plays a crucial role in controlling the strength and length of hydrogen bonds between DNA base pairs. Using quantum chemical computations, the authors demonstrate that the difference in Pauli repulsion is responsible for the enhanced stabilization and shorter distance of the GG pair compared to the CC pair. This finding challenges the conventional view that electrostatics, charge transfer, polarization, and dispersion interactions are the primary factors governing hydrogen bond strengths and lengths.

======== 1452 : Franc2011

@title:    Covalent networks through on-surface chemistry in ultra-high vacuum: state-of-the-art and recent developments.
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Engeneering - Molecular network,Folder - SPM - tip{\_}induced{\_}chemistry,Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2014{\_}07{\_}28

======== 1453 : Botti2000

@title:    Photoluminescence from silicon nano-particles synthesized by laser-induced decomposition of silane
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs

======== 1454 : Tomfohr2002

@title:    Complex band structure, decay lengths, and Fermi level alignment in simple molecular electronic systems
@author:   Tomfohr, John K. and Sankey, Otto F.
@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevB.65.245105
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.65.245105
@abstract:
 The complex band structure of a periodic system is the conventional band structure extended to complex Bloch k vectors. The k vectors with an imaginary part describe spatially decaying wave functions and arise in, for example, the analysis of impurity and surface states. They also represent the quantum tunneling states which are vehicles of electron transport through a barrier such as a thin oxide layer or a molecule. We present a method for obtaining the complex band structure of a molecule which is composed of repeating units. The complex band structures of some simple organic molecules (n-alkanes, alkenes, and linked benzene rings) will be determined and used to analyze electron conduction through molecules (e.g., octanedithiol) connected between gold electrodes. The form of the complex band structure clearly elucidates the molecule length dependence of the tunneling current and also suggests the energy for alignment of the Fermi level.

**Note:** The article presents a novel approach to analyze the complex band structure of simple molecular electronic systems using quantum mechanics and density functional theory (DFT) simulations. It demonstrates how the complex band structure can be used to understand electron transport through molecules, including the influence of molecule length on tunneling current and the energy alignment of the Fermi level. The results have implications for various fields, including molecular electronics, optoelectronics, and energy harvesting.

======== 1455 : Momany1978

@title:    Determination of partial atomic charges from ab initio molecular electrostatic potentials. Application to formamide, methanol, and formic acid
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods - Charge Projection,Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - Humbolt - Energy{\_}function
@author:   Momany, Frank A.
@doi:      10.1021/j100494a019
@url:      http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/j100494a019
@abstract:
 The title procedure involved the calcn. of an ab initio mol. electrostatic potential, at the minimal STO-3G and 4-31G basis set levels, between a neutral mol. and a pos. charge located at various points beyond the van der Waals contact region surrounding the mol. Partial at. C charges located on the atoms were detd. by fitting the classical electrostatic Coulomb potential to the potential obtained from MO calcns. Electroneutrality was preserved, and the magnitude and direction of the exptl. dipole moments of the mol. were used in the fitting procedures. The differences between classical Coulombic potentials and ab initio electrostatic potentials were discussed for at. charges obtained from other procedures using MO methods. The extension of the procedure described here to other methods for defining the charge distribution was discussed. [on SciFinder(R)]

======== 1456 : Kolorenc2011

@title:    Applications of quantum Monte Carlo methods in condensed systems
@author:   Koloren{\v{c}}, Jindřich and Mitas, Lubos
@doi:      10.1088/0034-4885/74/2/026502
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1010.4992 http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0034-4885/74/2/026502 http://stacks.iop.org/0034-4885/74/i=2/a=026502?key=crossref.21e9807c5ff743d063c521e4366c5294
@abstract:
 The quantum Monte Carlo methods represent a powerful and broadly applicable computational tool for finding very accurate solutions of the stationary Schroedinger equation for atoms, molecules, solids and a variety of model systems. The algorithms are intrinsically parallel and are able to take full advantage of the present-day high-performance computing systems. This review article concentrates on the fixed-node/fixed-phase diffusion Monte Carlo method with emphasis on its applications to electronic structure of solids and other extended many-particle systems.

======== 1457 : Zhang2016

@title:    Visualizing coherent intermolecular dipole–dipole coupling in real space
@keywords: Folder - {\_}by{\_}project - ERC2021
@author:   Zhang, Yang Yao and Luo, Yang Yi and Zhang, Yang Yao and Yu, Yun-Jie and Kuang, Yan-Min and Zhang, Li and Meng, Qiu-Shi and Luo, Yang Yi and Yang, Jin-Long and Dong, Zhen-Chao and Hou, J. G.
@doi:      10.1038/nature17428
@url:      http://www.nature.com/articles/nature17428
======== 1458 : Fogolari2018

@title:    Free Energy, Enthalpy and Entropy from Implicit Solvent End-Point Simulations
@keywords: Continuum solvent,Enthalpy,Entropy,Free energy,Implicit solvent,MM/GBSA,Molecular dynamics simulations
@author:   Fogolari, Federico and Corazza, Alessandra and Esposito, Gennaro
@doi:      10.3389/fmolb.2018.00011
@url:      http://journal.frontiersin.org/article/10.3389/fmolb.2018.00011/full
@abstract:
 Free energy is the key quantity to describe the thermodynamics of biological systems. In this perspective we consider the calculation of free energy, enthalpy and entropy from end-point molecular dynamics simulations. Since the enthalpy may be calculated as the ensemble average over equilibrated simulation snapshots the difficulties related to free energy calculation are ultimately related to the calculation of the entropy of the system and in particular of the solvent entropy. In the last two decades implicit solvent models have been used to circumvent the problem and to take into account solvent entropy implicitly in the solvation terms. More recently outstanding advancement in both implicit solvent models and in entropy calculations are making the goal of free energy estimation from end-point simulations more feasible than ever before. We review briefly the basic theory and discuss the advancements in light of practical applications.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Chemistry
- **Subcategory:** Computational Chemistry, Molecular Dynamics Simulations, Biophysics
- **Specific Domain:** Implicit Solvent Models, Free Energy Calculations, Enthalpy and Entropy Estimation
- **Research Type:** Review Article

**10 Keywords:**

1. Calculation of Free Energy from End-Point Molecular Dynamics Simulations
2. Implicit Solvent Models for Solvation and Entropy Calculation
3. MM/GBSA (Molecular Mechanics-Generalized Born Surface Area) Methodology
4. Enthalpy Estimation from Equilibrated Simulation Snapshots
5. Entropy Calculation Challenges in Biological Systems
6. Advances in Implicit Solvent Models for Improved Accuracy
7. Free Energy, Enthalpy, and Entropy Estimation Methods
8. Applications of Implicit Solvent Models in Biophysics and Computational Chemistry
9. Practical Considerations and Limitations of End-Point Simulations
10. Recent Developments and Future Directions in Free Energy Calculations.

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry

**Note:** The article reviews the current state-of-the-art in calculating free energy, enthalpy, and entropy from end-point molecular dynamics simulations using implicit solvent models. It discusses the challenges associated with estimating solvent entropy and highlights recent advancements in both implicit solvent models and entropy calculations that make free energy estimation more feasible.

======== 1461 : Dookhitram2009a

@title:    A new method for accelerating Arnoldi algorithms for large scale eigenproblems
@keywords: Dynamic switching,Folder - Algorithms - LinearAlgebra - Sparse Solve,Implicitly restarted Arnoldi,Matrix computations,Nonsymmetric eigenvalue problems,Refined Arnoldi
@author:   Dookhitram, K. and Boojhawon, R. and Bhuruth, M.
@doi:      10.1016/j.matcom.2009.07.009
@abstract:
 We propose a new method for accelerating the convergence of the implicitly restarted Arnoldi (IRA) algorithm for the solution of large sparse nonsymmetric eigenvalue problems. A new relationship between the residual of the current step and the residual in the previous step is derived and we use this relationship to develop a technique for dynamically switching the Krylov subspace dimension at successive cycles. We give numerical results for various difficult nonsymmetric eigenvalue problems that demonstrate the capability of the dynamic switching strategy for significantly accelerating the convergence of Arnoldi algorithms. For some large scale difficult eigenvalue problems that arise in the fields of computational fluid dynamics, electrical engineering and materials science, our strategy leads to significant reductions in the number of matrix-vector products, orthogonalization costs and computational time. ?? 2009 IMACS.

======== 1462 : Richmond1984

@title:    Solvent accessible surface area and excluded volume in proteins
@keywords: Folder - HR-SPM - forcefield
@author:   Richmond, Timothy J.
@doi:      10.1016/0022-2836(84)90231-6
@url:      http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/0022283684902316
@abstract:
 An analytical formula has been derived for the calculation of the solvent accessible surface area of a protein molecule or equivalently the surface area exterior to an arbitrary number of overlapping spheres. The directional derivative of this function with respect to atomic co-ordinates is provided to facilitate minimization procedures used with molecular docking algorithms and energy calculations. An analytical formula for the calculation of the volume enclosed within the accessible surface, the excluded volume, is also derived. Although the area function is not specific to the structures of proteins, the derivation was motivated by the need for a computationally feasible simulation of the hydrophobic effect in proteins. A computer program using the equations for area has been tested and has had limited application to the docking of protein ??-helices. Possible relationships of the solvent excluded volume to hydrophobic interaction free energy and transfer free energy of solute molecules are derived from the statistical mechanics of solution. ?? 1984.

@title:    Density-functional exchange-energy approximation with correct asymptotic behavior
@keywords: Folder - ComputationalMethods - DFT
@author:   Becke, a. D.

@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevA.38.3098
@abstract:
 Current gradient-corrected density-functional approximations for the exchange energies of atom- ic and molecular systems fail to reproduce the correct 1/r asymptotic behavior of the exchange- energy density. Here we report a gradient-corrected exchange-energy functional with the proper asymptotic limit. Our functional, containing only one parameter, fits the exact Hartree-Fock ex- change energies of a wide variety of atomic systems with remarkable accuracy, surpassing the per- formance of previous functionals containing two parameters or more.

@title:    Non-Precious Metal Fuel Cell Cathodes : Catalyst Development and Electrode Structure Design
@keywords: Folder - carbon graphene - Catalyst
@author:   Zelenay, Piotr
======== 1470 : Benson2015a

@title:    DNA rendering of polyhedral meshes at the nanoscale
@keywords: Folder - Molecular Engeneering - DNA{\_}origami,★
@author:   Benson, Erik and Mohammed, Abdulmelik and Gardell, Johan and Masich, Sergej and Czeizler, Eugen and Orponen, Pekka and H{\"{o}}gberg, Bj{\"{o}}rn
@doi:      10.1038/nature14586
@url:      http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nature14586 https://www.nature.com/articles/nature14586
@abstract:
 It was suggested more than thirty years ago that Watson-Crick base pairing might be used for the rational design of nanometre-scale structures from nucleic acids. Since then, and especially since the introduction of the origami technique, DNA nanotechnology has enabled increasingly more complex structures. But although general approaches for creating DNA origami polygonal meshes and design software are available, there are still important constraints arising from DNA geometry and sense/antisense pairing, necessitating some manual adjustment during the design process. Here we present a general method of folding arbitrary polygonal digital meshes in DNA that readily produces structures that would be very difficult to realize using previous approaches. The design process is highly automated, using a routeing algorithm based on graph theory and a relaxation simulation that traces scaffold strands through the target structures. Moreover, unlike conventional origami designs built from close-packed helices, our structures have a more open conformation with one helix per edge and are therefore stable under the ionic conditions usually used in biological assays.

@doi:      10.1103/PhysRevLett.111.146102
@url:      http://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.111.146102
======== 1479 : Niesse1996

@title:    Global geometry optimization of atomic clusters using a modified genetic algorithm in space‐fixed coordinates
@keywords: Folder - {\_}NaPondeli - 2016{\_}03{\_}21 - references{\_}Glob
@author:   Niesse, J. a and Mayne, Howard R
@doi:      doi:10.1063/1.472311
@url:      http://jcp.aip.org/resource/1/jcpsa6/v105/i11/p4700{\_}s1{\%}5Cnhttp://link.aip.org/link/?JCPSA6/105/4700/1/pdf
@abstract:
 In a recent paper, Gregurick, Alexander, and Hartke [S. K. Gregurick, M. H. Alexander, and B. Hartke, J. Chem. Phys. 104, 2684 (1996)] proposed a global geometry optimization technique using a modified Genetic Algorithm approach for clusters. They refer to their technique as a deterministic/stochastic genetic algorithm (DS‐GA). In this technique, the stochastic part is a traditional GA, with the manipulations being carried out on binary‐coded internal coordinates (atom–atom distances). The deterministic aspect of their method is the inclusion of a coarse gradient descent calculation on each geometry. This step avoids spending a large amount of computer time searching parts of the configuration space which correspond to high‐energy geometries. Their tests of the technique show it is vastly more efficient than searches without this local minimization. They report geometries for clusters of up to n=29 Ar atoms, and find that their computer time scales as O(n4.5). In this work, we have recast the genetic algorithm optimization in space‐fixed Cartesian coordinates, which scale much more favorably than internal coordinates for large clusters. We introduce genetic operators suited for real (base‐10) variables. We find convergence for clusters up to n=55. Furthermore, our algorithm scales as O(n3.3). It is concluded that genetic algorithm optimization in nonseparable real variables is not only viable, but numerically superior to that in internal candidates for atomic cluster calculations. Furthermore, no special choice of variable need be made for different cluster types; real Cartesian variables are readily portable, and can be used for atomic and molecular clusters with no extra effort. {\textcopyright} 1996 American Institute of Physics.

9. Advantages of Using Real Cartesian Variables over Internal Coordinates

**Specific Topic:** Chemistry - Computational Chemistry

**Note:** The article presents a modified genetic algorithm approach for global geometry optimization of atomic clusters in space-fixed Cartesian coordinates, which scales more favorably than internal coordinates for large clusters. The authors introduce genetic operators suited for real variables and find convergence for clusters up to n=55, with a computational scaling of O(n3.3). They conclude that genetic algorithm optimization in non-separable real variables is numerically superior to that in internal candidates for atomic cluster calculations.

@title:    Size independent blue luminescence in nitrogen passivated silicon nanocrystals
@keywords: Folder - SiNCs
@author:   Dasog, Mita and Veinot, Jonathan G. C.
@doi:      10.1002/pssa.201200273
@url:      http://doi.wiley.com/10.1002/pssa.201200273
======== 1482 : Dabrowski

@title:    Doping of graphene by a Au(111) substrate: Calculation strategy within the local density approximation and a semiempirical van der Waals approach
@keywords: Folder - carbon graphene,SPM
@author:   Slawinska, J. and Dabrowski, P and Zasada, I
@url:      http://arxiv.org/abs/1102.4543
@abstract:
 We have performed a density functional study of graphene adsorbed on Au(111) surface using both a local density approximation and a semiempirical van der Waals approach proposed by Grimme, known as the DFT-D2 method. Graphene physisorbed on metal has the linear dispersion preserved in the band-structure, but the Fermi level of the system is shifted with respect to the conical points which results in a doping effect. We show that the type and amount of doping depends not only on the choice of the exchange-correlation functional used in the calculations, but also on the supercell geometry that models the physical system. We analyzed how the factors such as the in-plane cell parameter and interlayer spacing in gold influence the Fermi level shift and we found that even a small variation in these parameters may cause a transition from p-type to n-type doping. We have selected a reasonable set of model parameters and obtained that graphene is either undoped or at most slightly p-type doped on the clean Au(111) surface, which seems to be in line with experimental findings. On the other hand, modifications of the substrate lattice may induce larger doping up to 0.30-0.40 eV depending on the graphene-metal adsorption distance. The sensitivity of the graphene-gold interface to the structural parameters may allow to tune doping across the samples which could lead to possible applications in graphene-based electronic devices. We believe that the present remarks can be also useful for other studies based on the periodic DFT.

### LLM: 
**Classification:**

Based on the title and abstract, I would classify this research article as:

- **Category:** Physics
- **Subcategory:** Materials Science, Condensed Matter Physics, Computational Physics
- **Specific Domain:** Density Functional Theory (DFT) Study of Graphene-Au(111) Interface
- **Research Type:** Original Research Article
